clean_wm_text: The observed black hole spectrum may consist of multiple components, one of which is a thermal component.
We indicate that the string theory dual of this system is a gas composed of strings and particles, called a fuzzy ball.
This means that the evaporation of a black hole produces not just a black hole with a certain temperature, but rather a fuzzy black hole composed of many non-commuting parts.
We particularly believe that the precise definition of the Baberlo-Emirchy parameter of the fuzzy ball is a string statistical parameter, namely /b/ = 2pi/3.

We provide strong supporting evidence for our assertion by reproducing the degeneracy of states in the semiclassical limit (Bekenstein-Hawking entropy) and the spectrum of low energy states (gray body factor) from the first principles of string theory.

We found that the spectrum and symmetry of the low-energy states are highly consistent with the spectrum and symmetry of the scalar field in the Hartle-Hawking state, and this state is related to the thermal state through the Penrose process.

We also indicate that the entropy of small black holes can be reproduced by calculating the entropy of a fuzzy sphere, which implies that the decay of small black holes consists of the fragmentation of a large fuzzy sphere.
Our results establish fuzzballs as suitable objects in string theory that can reproduce the standard description of black holes.

Because the partition function of the spin foam may have an asymptotic expansion in powers of 1/b, where b is the Barbero-Immirzi parameter, we will also establish |b| as a physical observable in string theory.
A Jones polynomial based on a three-strand quantum algorithm has been proposed.
The Jones polynomial is a function that maps oriented links in three-dimensional space to complex numbers, and it is an important invariant for studying knots and links.
The Jones polynomial has many applications in low-dimensional topology, and it is also used in bioinformatics, coding theory, chemistry, and physics.
The Jones polynomial has a particularly nice mathematical property, namely that it is a polynomial of the normalized Jones function \( V(x) = \text{tr}(x) \).

"[Jones polynomial] / (q − q'), where x is a specialized variable related to the form of the chain, and q and q' are standard quantum parameters."

In this algorithm, the Jones polynomial is computed using O(n) quantum gates, where n is the number of links in the chain. Compared to existing quantum algorithms for the Jones polynomial, the running time of the latter depends on the number of components in the chain.
The physics of the early universe is well understood, at least up until the moment close to decoupling.
If there is a forced late-time acceleration period, it is expected to be driven by a dark energy component with an equation of state parameter close to -1.
When the temperature of the universe drops below the threshold of electron mass, electrons and protons recombine to form hydrogen and helium, and photons decouple from the rest of the universe.
Electromagnetic radiation can still be detected in the laboratory until nearly a minute after decoupling, at which point all remaining photon energy is a billion times that of visible light.
This photon bath was produced during the famous recombination era and is crucial for the formation of the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB) and the subsequent history of the universe.
However, regardless of its importance, the bathroom has largely remained under-researched.
In this work, I calculated the subsequent radiation produced by charged particles after they "detach" from the background radiation bath.
This radiation includes a random background of electromagnetic waves, which may have observable characteristics in radio astronomy, high-energy gamma-ray astronomy, and cosmology.
It is a unique detector of the early cosmic structure and a new source with a distinct spectrum and obvious anisotropy that evolves over time.

A fundamental problem in machine learning is clustering the data in such a way that the data points within each cluster are similar to each other, while the data points between different clusters are as dissimilar as possible.

Related Clustering (CC) is one of the most popular and successful methods for this task, which can be efficiently solved through convex relaxation and has been shown to recover the optimal solution under certain conditions.

However, these conditions are difficult to fulfill in practice, which has led to a rapidly growing body of literature aimed at understanding the relationship between convergence speed and parameters, as well as the universality of related clustering across various fields.

In this paper, we argue that associative clustering is not approximable within any constant factor, based on the observation that it easily gets trapped in local optima and the relevant properties of the problem.
This result of inaccessibility applies to a wide range of differentiable relaxation families, and we present a specific algorithm to capture the core difficulty of the problem.
Finally, we conducted extensive experiments on the benchmark dataset, and the results validated our analysis, strongly indicating that relevant clustering is indeed an NP-hard problem.
The planet HD 155358 b is the planet with the lowest metallicity discovered so far, with a mass 12.6 times that of Earth and a radius 0.68 times that of Earth.
This radius-expanding super-Earth may have a high proportion of desert planets, with little to no water.
Due to the strong radial velocity characteristics of a massive planet and the sensitivity to Doppler surveys, this system has been identified as a promising target for the CARMENES instrument.
When this planet was first observed, it was 3.5 hours behind its star, and it takes 47 days to move one full stellar diameter.

The slow motion and the extremely low metal abundance of this star (only 12.5% of that of the Sun) indicate that this planet formed farther away from its parent star and migrated inward due to the torque generated by the gravity of the parent star.

If this scenario becomes a reality, then the time required to move from the planet's birthplace to its current orbit is estimated to be 1.5 million years, which is comparable to the estimated age of the system.
This planet provides us with a valuable opportunity to study the frequency of Earth-like planets around low-metallicity stars and to test planetary migration theories.

The heavy quark symmetry is an approximate symmetry that exists in the hadron spectrum containing bottom quarks or charm quarks, facilitating the calculations of the hadron spectrum that contains bottom quarks or charm quarks.

In particular, the mass difference between the bottom quark and the top quark, measured as the B* - B mass splitting in experiments, is used to constrain the values of the bottom quark mass and the strong coupling constant.

Here, we propose a non-perturbative renormalization method for the gluon chromomagnetic operator in heavy quark effective theory (HQET), which has a leading dimension in heavy quark mass and satisfies heavy quark symmetry.
The mass splitting value for B* - B calculated using this operator is 4.55 MeV, which is in excellent agreement with the experimentally measured value of 4.57 MeV.
We conclude that the B* - B mass splitting provides a very accurate measurement of the bottom quark mass and strong coupling.
The transfer power of the Yang-Zhu-Xi-Murphy element is a central element in the representation of the unit group.
We prove that these elements form a norm in the C*-algebra of the unit group and calculate their spectrum.
Specifically, we indicate that for odd N, these elements are unit roots, while for even N, they are primitive unit roots.
These results are conjectures proposed by A. Connes and D. Shklyarov, partly proven by R. Longo and M. Weiner.
"Our proof is different and based on representation theory."
The main components of the proof are good deformation functors and the spectral theory of infinite-dimensional representations of classical Lie groups and their subgroups.
This paper is part of my doctoral dissertation written under the guidance of R. Longo.
The Young-Jucys-Murphy elements were introduced by V. K. Dzyadko, A. Mironov, and A. Alexandrov in 2012.
Since then, these elements have been studied by several authors and applied to various problems in theoretical and mathematical physics.
The journal version of the paper can be found on arXiv, with the number 1607.00667.

A newly discovered satellite of the Milky Way has been announced.
Its diameter is approximately ten thousand light years, named "Aquarius."
It was discovered in the Galaxy Microlensing Survey.
The satellite's first detection was announced in 2018 and confirmed the complete six-dimensional phase space information in 2019.
It has a very peculiar orbit around the galaxy and is far from the center of the Milky Way.
It may have been captured by the dark matter halo of the Milky Way and could potentially become a satellite of the Andromeda Galaxy in the future.
This discovery was made by a team of astronomers from multiple countries, led by Dr. Yossi Beiderman from the Weizmann Institute of Science.
The discovery was published in the Journal of Astronomy on February 21, 2023.
The authors are Yossi Bekerman, Jonathan Brink, Noah Noffsinger, Yuval Aron, Leah Filipkowski, Ehud Nakhal, James Block, and John Glensfield.
The Bayesian deformation model has been widely applied in medical imaging, computer vision, and artificial intelligence.
However, the computation of Bayesian deformation models is often challenging due to the use of Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms to approximate the posterior distribution.
Recently, the variational inference (VI) algorithm has been proposed and shown to be effective in computing approximate posterior distributions in Bayesian deformation models.
In this article, we developed a novel stochastic approximation algorithm (SAA) based on the VI algorithm to further enhance computational efficiency.
The proposed method is first derived within a general Bayesian deformation model and then applied to some specific Bayesian deformation models for demonstration.

Our experimental results on both synthetic and real datasets indicate that our method is more efficient than existing variational inference algorithms, and it is comparable to state-of-the-art Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithms in computing Bayesian deformation models.
The main contributions of this work are twofold: (1) We proposed a variational inference algorithm based on SAA to further improve the computational efficiency of Bayesian deformable models.

Our method applies to a wide range of Bayesian deformable models and demonstrates higher efficiency than existing variational inference algorithms in certain cases; (2) we have validated the effectiveness of our method through experiments on real-world datasets.
Our code can be found at https://github.com/ShuaiZhang0413/SAA-VI. Please cite our previous work.
"If you use our code in your research."
References: [1] Zhang Shuai, Zhang Ziyu, Shen Chunhua, Liu Junyu, Cao Mingye, and Xie Xiaohui.
"The Convergence Study of the Stochastic Approximation Algorithm for Bayesian Deformable Models." arXiv preprint arXiv:2004.10208 (2020).

We have developed a general framework for the discrete thermodynamic modeling and analysis of dynamic systems, focusing on laser devices.

We start from an arbitrary dynamic system, describe its state space using a countable state space model, and define the corresponding state vector along with the relevant probability distribution on that vector.

Next, we define the dynamic flow on the state space caused by the system, which describes the action function of the average change in the state space caused by the transition of a single system, as well as the Jacobian matrix that linearizes the momentum flow around the invariant measure.
We discussed important special cases and examples of this modeling and thermodynamic analysis, and applied our method to study the internal energy consumption in general optical lasers.
We have developed a general discrete thermodynamic framework for dynamic systems, focusing on laser-based devices.
We start with a general power system and use a countable state space model to define its state space.

Next, we define the dynamical flow on the state space induced by the system, describing the action function that represents the average change in the state space caused by the transition of a single system, as well as the Jacobian matrix that linearizes the dynamical flow around the invariant measure.
We study important special cases and examples of this type of modeling and thermodynamic analysis.
As an example, we apply our method to study the internal energy dissipation in general optical lasers.
This study will help us comprehensively understand the thermodynamic processes in laser devices and may contribute to the development of more energy-efficient devices.

Recent observational activities have found a widespread but uneven CIV galactic wind generated from high-redshift starburst galaxies, identified by characteristic blue-shifted CIV absorption associated with jet winds.
We use hydrodynamic simulations to study the wind properties of galaxies at redshifts z = 3-5, at which the typical escape velocity of galaxies in this range is about 200 km/s.
The baryon fraction of stars in these high-redshift galaxies is typically around 80%, so they are likely the precursors of local elliptical galaxies.

We identified four main wind characteristics that can be distinguished through detailed spectral and spatially resolved observations: a broad component driven by stellar winds from supernovae (SNe) and older stellar populations, a dense shell surrounding the shock of the interstellar and intergalactic medium, and winds driven by young massive stellar populations influencing the gas temperature and ionization state.

The combined effects of these different wind field characteristics leave distinctive marks in the equivalent width and spatial distribution of CIV, which can be used to distinguish between galaxy winds around high-redshift galaxies and other sources of CIV in the IGM.

Contextual changes occur when the environment or situation of a person or thing changes, and this change affects or is influenced by the behaviors or structural characteristics of that person or thing.
In the context of technology, environmental changes may be driven by technological advances, new regulations or legislation, new business models or customer demands, and new innovations.
These changes may prompt different organizations or individuals to reassess their positions and approaches, which could lead to changes in the situation.
For this article, we propose an organizational change framework to capture, categorize, and map these changes and their effects.
Our framework consists of four levels: 1) People, 2) Processes, 3) Systems, and 4) Context.
At the personnel level, we define roles and responsibilities.
In the process layer, we described the change management process.
At the system level, we identify the affected systems and their functions.
In the contextual layer, we map the affected contextual factors.
After integrating these four levels, we obtained a Context Change Description (CCD), which provides a comprehensive perspective on the changes and their impacts.
We provide use case examples to illustrate how the framework can be applied to various types of changes.
Using a pulsed magnet with a short rise time (10-20 ns) and magnetic field strength, we studied the relaxation phenomena in single crystal HoBa2Cu3O7-d samples.
The characteristics of the induced decay relaxation curve were determined within the low magnetic field range.
Discovered three components: a fast component, a slow component, and a structural component.
A slow component was observed in a magnetic field above 0.2 T. We studied the temperature and magnetic field dependence of the relaxation parameters.
We observed a positive correlation between the critical temperature of the HoBa2Cu3O7-d sample and the relaxation strength of the slow component.
At the same time, we observed that near the critical temperature of all the study samples, the relaxation strength reached its maximum value.
The analysis of the dynamic relaxation process indicates that there is an heterogeneity with different magnetic characteristics in the studied samples.

SA 57 is an extremely powerful nearby (z = 0.0631) large-scale structure, which is very rare in the nearby universe, consisting of multiple huge galaxy clusters, several galaxy groups, and numerous independent galaxies.
The X-ray emission in this region has not yet been systematically studied, even though the sensitivity of current X-ray telescopes makes it possible to detect such structures for the first time.
In this work, we present the results of an X-ray survey of the SA 57 supercluster using XMM-Newton.
We detected X-ray emissions from two large galaxy clusters, five galaxy clusters, and individual galaxies.
We measure the global properties of superclusters and study their spatial distribution.
We found a strong correlation between the main baryonic component of the superclusters—X-ray emitting clusters—and the distribution of the Milky Way.
We discussed some of the most interesting sources and estimated their X-ray flux.
We also briefly considered some possibilities of these X-ray sources being related to active galactic nuclei.

We consider a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm for sampling from probability distributions based on Bernoulli randomization (Mrg) shown in the figure, which depend on a certain random variable vector Θ. Such distributions are often difficult to sample directly, and implementing them even with dynamic programming can be challenging.
We introduce Gibbs sampling, which is a class of algorithms that alternately samples from the graph distribution and performs conditional sampling of the underlying variables based on the graph.
We analyze the mixing time through Gibbs sampling on a broad class of sparse random graphs.

On average, our graph distribution resides in a high-dimensional parameter space and features "RDP" (rich get richer) nodes, allowing us to characterize mixing time through a strong form of the neighborhood growth theorem.
Specifically, we demonstrate that the spectral gap of the transition kernel of graph traversal increases geometrically with the increase in sample size.

As a direct result, we obtained a convergence rate that is independent of the number of nodes, which is uniform across all graph topologies and also applies to the number of iterations required by the method to achieve a given acceptance probability.
We provided numerical experiments to support our theory and to demonstrate the effectiveness of our method on real data.

In this paper, we propose a Random Access Broadcast (RABC) protocol that allows a large number of nodes to exchange information in a short period of time without the need for a central coordinating node or clock synchronization.
The node that wants to send a message constructs a data packet after selecting a random access signature (RAS) from a large signature space.
RAS acts as the node ID, allowing the node to indicate all of its functions and capabilities.
The receiver of the broadcast must verify the sender's capabilities and accept or reject the broadcast based on the application type and quality of service requirements.
We provide stability and throughput analysis of the RABC protocol.
We also discussed how to modify our RABC protocol to support more complex broadcast types, such as multicast and zero configuration.
We have implemented a Random Access Broadcast (RABC) layer on top of UDP.
Using the ns3 simulator, we demonstrated the effectiveness of RABC by comparing it with other random access protocols in terms of throughput, delay, and stability.
We indicate that RABC is efficient in both latency and message load.
Compared to the existing random access broadcast protocol Z-bus, RABC performs better in terms of throughput, delay, and stability.
We also demonstrated that RABC provides multicast and zero-configuration support through simple extensions to the protocol.
Non-equilibrium steady states (NESSs) are an important topic in many-body physics.

In this work, we introduce a new technique to study non-equilibrium steady states (NESS) in quantum lattice systems, a technique particularly suitable for applications in large systems and sparse matrices.

Our method, which is the solution of the matrix product operator (MPO) equations of motion, is based on two aspects of expansion: one is the scaling expansion of the matrix product state (MPS) representation, and the other is the expansion of Chebyshev polynomials.
This allows us to capture the dynamics of large complex quantum systems represented by very sparse matrices.
We apply our technology to the one-dimensional Bose-Hubbard model, which is a prototypical model of quantum phase transition.

We studied both the symmetric and asymmetric versions of the model and demonstrated that even in one dimension, a rich variety of dynamic phenomena can be encountered, including phase transitions and dynamic phases.
We also used a quantum simulator to study hard-core bosons on a square lattice and found that our results are in good agreement with those obtained from exact diagonalization.
Finally, we use this method to study the solution of the one-dimensional Bose-Hubbard model at finite temperature.
We found that, contrary to previous speculation, this model does not exhibit a phase of broken symmetry.
The MPO solution exhibits a quasi-long-range ordered phase in the dimer and charge correlation functions, with clear energy and without symmetry breaking.
In a van der Waals heterostructure with highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) as the bottom layer and bismuthene as the top layer, Landau levels (LLs) of Dirac fermions were observed.
The HOPG/bismuthene heterostructure is grown on a NiAl(110) buffer layer by chemical vapor deposition and then transferred to a SiO2/Si substrate.

The scanning tunneling spectroscopy revealed characteristic resonance peaks, presented in the form of multiple almost equidistant horizontal lines, which are interpreted as the Landau levels (LLs) of Dirac fermions with spin up and spin down, with an energy level spacing of 2.6 meV.
This is the first observation of Landau levels in a hexagonal lattice system other than graphene.
The successful growth of high-quality bismuth films on graphite guarantees the potential application of van der Waals heterostructures in future molecular electronic devices.
One of the main goals of the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is to explore the mechanism of electroweak symmetry breaking (EWSB).

A key part of this research will be an investigation into supersymmetry (SUSY), which is a hypothesized symmetry that extends the symmetry of interactions between known particles to include fermions that, due to their mass, can be represented by symmetric groups with spin-0 or spin-1.
One of the most popular models that has achieved great success in reproducing the observed particle spectrum is the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM).

In this model, supersymmetry (SUSY) must be broken, and this breaking mechanism has profound implications for the scale of electroweak symmetry breaking (EWSB) and the characteristics of the physical Higgs boson, which is one of the main objectives of the LHC experiments.
The Higgs sector of each Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM) contains two CP-conserving Higgs bosons, h and H, one CP-violating Higgs boson, A, and two charged Higgs bosons, H⁺ and H⁻.
A key test of this model is to determine the spin and parity quantum numbers of the observed Higgs boson.

The mSUGRA model predicts the masses of large supersymmetric particles, which leads to a specific benchmark region known as the focus point region, characterized by a relatively light Higgs boson, particularly a 126 GeV Higgs boson.
"The observation of Higgs bosons with these characteristics could be a strong indication of supersymmetry and would significantly strengthen the argument for this mysterious energy scale."

In this letter, we present the prospects for the detection and measurement of the 126 GeV Higgs boson at the 14 TeV Large Hadron Collider (LHC), including direct reconstruction in the double Higgs production final state, as well as more conventional measurements based on observing its decay products.

We studied the production of Higgs bosons (gg) in gluon fusion and vector boson fusion (VBF), as well as the production mechanisms associated with t, W, and Z, and the associated production with bottom quarks or gluons.
We focus on the analysis conducted in the ATLAS experiment and utilize the data from 13 TeV, expecting the total luminosity of the LHC to be 15-20 fb⁻¹.
The scope of this study largely relies on the decay modes of the 126 GeV Higgs boson.
If this Higgs boson is similar to the Higgs boson of the Standard Model, then observing it will be challenging, especially in the gluon fusion production mode.

However, due to the fact that the 126 GeV Higgs boson has a significant decay into quarks or a high proportion of decays into tau lepton pairs, this study should have good sensitivity to these scenarios. The ATLAS experiment, with its excellent double tau trigger system, possesses a strong capability to discover such Higgs bosons.

The supernova remnants (SNRs) in the Milky Way plane are powerful consumers of interstellar gas and dust, as evidenced by their interaction with the interstellar medium (ISM), which manifests as shell-like remnants, as well as by the bright and warm radiation emitted by some of these supernova remnant shells (known as SNRs).
More than 200 such relics have been detected.
The SNR evolution theory predicts that certain remnants, such as pulsar wind bubbles, will produce relativistic jets.
The detection of this jet from multiple supernova remnants (SNR) supports this theory.

On the other hand, non-detection results from some young supernova remnants (such as 0509-67.5, 1572, and Cassiopeia A) suggest that some, and perhaps even most, supernova remnants do not produce relativistic jets.

For certain young supernova remnants (SNRs) where relativistic jets have not been detected, other possible explanations include: (1) the supernova explosion itself lacks sufficient energy; (2) particles are accelerated to non-relativistic speeds in the shell of the supernova remnant; (3) the jets of most remnants are obscured by surrounding dense material; or (4) the jets become hidden from view after a few hundred years.
The on-orbit sensitivity estimation of the gamma-ray satellite GLAST is five times higher than that of EGRET, allowing it to detect gamma rays from many supernova remnants.
The detection of these gamma rays may provide strong evidence for the theory of residual evolution and for the relativistic jets produced in certain supernova remnants (SNRs).
On the other hand, the undetected results may provide interesting new insights into the nature of these remnants.
The theoretical rate of bright gamma-ray supernova remnants (SNRs) should be roughly comparable to the occurrence rate of observable young galactic supernova remnants.

Therefore, in the first few years of GLAST's operation, detecting gamma rays from many young supernova remnants (SNRs) will clearly indicate the effectiveness of this technology in studying supernova remnants.

The Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) effect is a potentially powerful cosmological tool because it can be used to detect galaxy clusters and measure the degree to which their inner regions are heated under the influence of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs) or other cold structures.
The thermalization of ICM gas plays an important role in the accuracy of the conjunction in the SZ detection cluster and its WIMP mass limit.

We utilize the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) effect to study the merging process of galaxy clusters and demonstrate that accurately modeling the SZ signal produced by these systems is crucial for accurately investigating their merging state.
We have provided a comprehensive new description of the SZ signal, enabling us to accurately characterize clusters of galaxies that may be undergoing merging.

We also studied the impact of applying a simple unmerging method on SZ signals, which may introduce strong biases when measuring the projected mass and redshift-space distortion parameters of merged clusters, ultimately affecting the reconstruction of the dynamical state of the clusters.
The Comoros effect, named after the independent country Comoros located in the Indian Ocean, refers to the idea that regularly brushing teeth can reduce the number of cavities.
This has been scientifically debunked, yet many people still hold on to this belief.
In order to further study the psychology of the Comoro effect, I present the first quantifiable measurement of the free activation energy of toothbrush abrasion.

Using a detailed biophysical model of tooth movement, I demonstrated that the energy cost of tooth brushing is acceptable and can be easily factored into the total free energy cost of diet, leading to the misconception that regular tooth brushing reduces cavities.
This is the first known scientific measurement of the activation free energy of the brushing friction effect, aimed at educating the public about the actual energy costs of various common behaviors.
For decades, the hypothesis that dark matter is composed of some form of extended objects has been extensively studied.
These objects are predicted to have formed through the collision and merger of smaller objects, a process that can lead to the formation of stable macroscopic structures.
So far, the most concrete evidence for the dark matter hypothesis is a cosmological model that includes these stable macroscopic structures, known as the cold dark matter model.

The model successfully predicted the large-scale structure of the universe that we observe today, prompting comparisons with similar models in the field of particle physics, where a similar level of agreement was achieved using quantum zero-point energy.
Despite its success, the cold dark matter model still has some aspects that lack explanation.
The most important thing is to form a stable macro structure in the late stage, which does not occur in simulations that ignore these zero-point fluctuations.
This letter will introduce a method by which dark matter may self-organize into spherical structures, without resorting to dark energy or other non-particle forces.

The spherical collapse experiments indicate that spherical structures are indeed a stable outcome of these experiments, and this paper provides empirical evidence supporting the hypothesis that dark matter organizes itself into these structures.
The methodology of this letter is as follows.
Dark matter was introduced into a simulation that includes zero-point fluctuations, and the large-scale structure of the results was examined.
The hypothesis of the letter is tested by introducing dark matter in simulations that do not include zero-point fluctuations, and observing the structures that arise from this.

The letter concludes by summarizing future work, which plans to conduct comparative tests between the assumptions in the letter and the observed large-scale structures, in order to provide further evidence to support the hypothesis that dark matter self-organizes into spherical structures.

The methodology of this letter is original. Although there have been similar studies related to the self-organization of dark matter, to the author's knowledge, this letter is the first to empirically demonstrate the self-organization of dark matter into stable large-scale structures.
This paper is the author's master's thesis, written under the guidance of Professor Ian Robertson.
The self-organized GeMn nanocolumns were studied using scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and extended X-ray absorption spectroscopy.
The GeMn column was grown on Ge(100) by chemical vapor deposition.
The substrate is above 300°C.
The average diameter between the pillars is about 30 nanometers.
High-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy imaging shows that the GeMn columns are formed by the aggregation of smaller particles at the ends of larger particles.
Transmission electron microscopy tomography analysis shows that these small grains are enriched in manganese compared to the matrix composition.
The composition of GeMn varies significantly within the column.

The measurements of extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) indicate that a large number of interstitial manganese atoms are incorporated into the GeMn columnar material, which may be the main reason for the material's ferromagnetic properties.

In the growth of GeMn columns, the self-organizing process allows for the adjustment of the composition and structure of GeMn, which has a significant impact on the magnetic properties of the material.
In particular, these columnar structures contain a large number of interstitial manganese atoms, which may be the reason for their ferromagnetic behavior.
The index of diurnal variation of geomagnetic activity (IHV index) and its application in deriving long-term changes in solar wind speed.
The index of small temporal variation of geomagnetic activity (IHV) has been introduced and its characteristics have been defined.
This is used to describe the long-term changes in solar wind speed (SW speed) over the past 450 years.
The changes in SW speed are shown to consist of two components: a primary component (a periodic wave with a cycle of about 11 years) and a secondary component (a significant long-term increase).
The correlation between the IHV index and the variations in solar wind speed is very close, with changes in solar wind speed driving the changes in the IHV index.
The change in SW speed shows an overall upward trend, with a speed of approximately 20 kilometers per second per century.
This has significant effects on space weather, as an increase in solar wind speed directly affects the energy carried by the solar wind.

For the weighted matching problem in general (tree-like) graphs, we show that the continuous relaxation of the linear programming (LP) dual (which is often used in practice) is equivalent to solving a maximum product algorithm.
We then extend this result to graphs that contain subtree subgraphs, covering a large number of tree-like networks.
Specifically, this encompasses all graphs that can be matched using polynomial time algorithms when all edge weights are 1.

For such figures, we also demonstrate that there is a strong dual relationship between the continuous relaxation and the original discrete optimization problem, and we provide a guarantee of primal feasibility.
Finally, we provide some empirical evidence showing that the maximum product algorithm performs better than the linear programming relaxation on tree-shaped instances.

We then extend this result to graphs that contain tree subgraphs, which covers a large number of tree-like networks.
Specifically, this includes all graphs that can be matched with a polynomial-time algorithm when all edge weights are 1.
For such graphs, we also demonstrate that there is a strong duality between the continuous relaxation and the original discrete optimization problem, and provide a guarantee of primal feasibility.
Finally, we provide some empirical evidence indicating that the performance of the maximum product algorithm on tree-structured instances is superior to that of linear programming relaxation.

Star-forming dwarf galaxies (SFDG) are important systems in the early stages of galaxy formation.
These small systems are efficient due to their ability to form stars, making them an ideal laboratory for understanding the initial conditions of galaxy evolution.
In this article, we present a spectral optical and spatial resolution analysis of 12 SFDGs.
We determine the oxygen abundance and chemical abundance patterns using the direct method and strong line method.
We also explored the spatial distribution of chemical elements and studied the relationships between different parameters.

Our main results can be summarized as follows: 1. We found that the oxygen abundance is extremely low, with the value of 12 + log(O/H) estimated using the R23 method being higher than that estimated by the strong line method of Pettini and Pagel (2004).
"We did not find a correlation between oxygen abundance and kinematic radial velocity."
The abundance of calcium seems to decrease as the radius increases.
On the contrary, the abundance of sodium and aluminum seems to increase as one moves away from the center.
We cannot find any correlation between the chemical abundance and the structural parameters of galaxies.
However, we notice a correlation between the star formation rate and chemical abundance.

We also found that a high proportion of star-forming regions have 12 + log(O/H) values below 8.2, which is the threshold used by many authors to distinguish between normal metallicity and low metallicity regions.
Non-orthogonal density functional theory (OF-DFT) is a method in electronic structure theory that combines the advantages of local density theory and wave function-based theory.

The theory is formally derived from traditional density functional theory (DFT) by dividing the total energy into a linear combination of local energy functions that depend on density and an additional parameter.
The parameter is referred to as potential energy, determined by solving a constrained minimization problem.
Therefore, compared to Density Functional Theory (DFT), orbital-free DFT (OF-DFT) does not assume single-electron wave functions, allowing it to directly handle molecules and solids.
We provided a theoretical implementation of the numerical realization of the Schrödinger equation based on the Lagrangian form.
The theory has been validated on molecules and solids, and has shown outstanding results in multiple test cases.
Finally, we present a case study on graphene on Au(111), in which we found that interaction-induced physical and chemical effects play an important role in determining the structure.
J 0903+0357 is a nearby L-type dwarf star that has been recorded in the initial data release from the Gaia satellite observations.
It has a radial velocity and two new spectral data sets, one from GTC and the other from LBT.
J 0903+0357 is one of the most distant and faintest L-type dwarf stars observed to date.
The radial velocity of J 0903+0357 is 22.2 kilometers per second, indicating that it is a low-mass member of the local solar neighborhood.
The spectrum is consistent with that of L-dwarfs, but the JHK colors are unusual for L-dwarfs, especially their red color.
The color cannot be explained by late M-type spectral classification, so it may be a binary star or an object with very low surface gravity.
If this is a binary star system, it will be the farthest and the closest-knit system among all L dwarfs.
Additionally, the presence of a late-type L companion star alongside a medium-type M dwarf star may explain the reddening of this celestial body.
Observing J 0903+0357 over multiple periods may be important to determine which scenario is correct.

The characterization of the phase stability of instruments is necessary for several applications in astronomy, such as meteor detection, atmospheric research, or the detection of artificial satellites.
In the field of radio astronomy, phase stability is a necessary condition for achieving the coherence required for precise astronomical observations.
Coherence is achieved by referencing the signal to an external source with very high stability (for example, a hydrogen helium laser).
The stability of astronomical instruments itself refers to the amount of jitter that does not degrade signal coherence.

To characterize the phase stability of the IRAM 30-meter telescope, we implemented a phase reference signal in the form of a dual-channel Bracewell discriminator, with a frequency of 10.5 centimeters.
By doing so, we can measure the phase stability between the two channels every 20 minutes, with a measurement accuracy of 1.1 milliseconds RMS.
We were also shown how to calculate the equivalent closed-loop transfer function of the system.
This is relevant to the field of control, as this type of measurement is often used as a detection tool for the stability of the Airbus A300 aircraft or satellites.
This stability is very important for their reliability.

The Papsu theorem in plane geometry states that for three coplanar lines intersecting at a point group (composed of three points), there exists a fourth line not in that plane, and this line passes through one of the points in the point group.
Since the theorem was first proposed in the 2nd century AD, there have been many proofs.
In this brief explanation, we present a simple and elegant proof of the Papas theorem, which has some interesting geometric and algorithmic applications.
Our approach is to discretize the configuration of the Papus line on a plane and solve a permutation problem on a gridded plane.
The theorem originates from a special case of the theorem related to this problem.
We have also provided an alternative proof of the Papus theorem, which is more complex and less direct, but of independent interest.

Massive stars form in clusters.

Water laser emitters originate solely from the formation of massive stars and gas reserves, thus providing an excellent detection tool for this early stage.
Through new Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) observations, we have discovered 23 new radio maser lines associated with high-mass star formation in the Galactic nuclear disk.

The Dirichlet σ model and mean curvature flow have been extensively studied in geometry and physics, with important applications in surface and interface motion, phase transitions, and materials science.
In this article, we demonstrate how to derive the Sigma model from a more fundamental theory of quantum gravity.
In the background-independent quantization of (2+1)-dimensional gravity, we use Vasiliev theory to derive the σ model for interfaces in (2+1)-dimensional quantum gravity.
This provides a geometric interpretation of the (2+1) dimensional dynamic variables of quantum gravity as a (2+1) dimensional analogue of a relativistic membrane.
We indicate that the homogeneous curvature flow is the zeroth-order perturbative expansion of the gradient flow of quantum gravity and describe the higher-order corrections in the flow.
The theory provides a geometric interpretation of higher-order corrections to the mean curvature flow.
By drawing an analogy with the example of relativistic membranes, this can provide us with new insights into the general behavior of these flows and the behavior of solutions near singularities.

The theory also has implications for potential experimental tests of this theory: in various fields of physical interest, the gravitational interactions between probes are weak and can be described by a σ model, where the world volume metric is independent of the target space geometry.
This means that many proposed experiments to test two-dimensional quantum gravity cannot differentiate the theory from the σ-model based on the target space.
However, in certain cases, such as strong coupling or near the critical point, the theory may deviate from the σ model, and in these cases, gravity may produce detectable signals.

Clues or clue sets are used to guide the sampling process.
The clue set includes a seed, a sampling range, and a sampling density function.
Starting from the seed, the sampling range is divided into equally sized subsamples.
These subsamples were scored based on the sampling density function, and the highest-scoring subsample was selected as the next sample.
This process is repeated until the target sample size is reached.
The clues can be weighted according to their probabilities, thereby generating biased samples.

For example, if we only need to sample the Pathum Thani people in Thailand, then Pathum Thani is the seed, Thailand is the sampling range, and the probability of each province in Thailand becoming a Pathum Thani person is the sampling density function.
This can be expanded by establishing a clue database, from which selections can be made and reused for various sampling tasks.
This database can contain hundreds of thousands of entries and can still fit in memory.

Local purity distillation aims to remotely transmit an unknown quantum state to a local server without leaking any classical information.
The purity of the state that needs to be transferred must be at least comparable to the capability of the server to synthesize it.
In this article, we propose and analyze a novel protocol—Local Purity Distillation (LPD), which has the characteristics of limited classical communication (BCC).
LPD not only ensures high-fidelity remote state transfer but also limits the server to a finite number of classical queries.

For specific situations, for a 2-qubit state, the LPD with BCC requires the server to perform the query only once; for a 3-qubit state, the number of queries is two; and for an n-qubit state, the number of queries is O(n).
Furthermore, we further analyzed the conditions for secure quantum channels under low power detection (LPD) and proposed tighter bounds in general cases.
Finally, we also provide a practical application example of digital signatures to demonstrate the feasibility of the protocol.

Distributed network topology is typically established by a central authority based on geographical proximity, link availability, or other arbitrary constraints.
In this work, we designed a decentralized and localized network topology formation method, in which each sensor node randomly and independently establishes connections with other sensor nodes.
We propose that under these conditions, this decentralized approach can lead to a significant increase in network density compared to existing centralized methods based on similar assumptions.
We have also provided two versions of the proposed agreement, one for partial random networks and another for completely random networks.
In some random networks, certain connection constraints are met, such as a minimum number of neighbors; whereas in completely random networks, all constraints are satisfied.

The complexity of model checking higher-order logic has long been an unresolved issue.
Since the 1980s, model checking has been simplified to decision problems of several fragments of higher-order logic.

However, in the worst case, checking whether a given formula is satisfied by all fixed points requires solving a Picard iteration for each projection of the logical formula, which is an optimal fixed point algorithm.
Therefore, even if the logical formula involves only a small set of variables, the model checking of higher-order fixed-point logic (HOF logic) is NP-hard.
We study higher-order logic (HOF) within the framework of parameterized complexity, where the complexity of a problem is bounded by a function of the size of the formula.
We provide two types of parameterization: tree decomposition and block decomposition.

We demonstrated that model checking of HOF logic related to tree decompositions is fixed parameter tractable (FPT), and we proved that model checking of HOF logic related to block decompositions is not fixed parameter tractable (FPT).
"Our parameterization leaves ample space for further parameterization."
We also provide a 3D-printable structure, specifically a syntactic abstraction with bounded width, which is able to maintain FPT parameterized complexity.

To reduce the metallic content in ferromagnetic materials, we created a double-layer film, with a thin layer of NiMnSb sandwiched between two layers of NiMnSb, where the thickness of the two NiMnSb layers varies gradually.
The outer two layers have a constant composition of Ni50Mn50Sb20, while the nickel content in the inner layer is reduced to Ni40Mn50Sb20.
Therefore, the entire film is composed of Ni40Mn30Sb20, with the manganese content gradually increasing from the inner layer to the outer layer, thereby achieving a metallic gradient within the film.

Experiments and first-principles calculations show that the gradient of manganese content leads to a gradient in the concentrations of nickel ions (Ni3+) and manganese ions (Mn3+), resulting in the film exhibiting almost complete metallicity.
Due to the tremendous potential of gradient metallicity in new spintronic applications, this work will attract widespread attention.

We then applied a color-color diagram, which was constructed using these two stellar populations and star-forming galaxies with known redshifts, to identify the colored regions in which distant galaxies could exist.

We applied this technique in two different regions of the sky (labeled as L7 and L11) and found a total of 66 galaxies with a redshift greater than z = 1.5, with an average distance of 92.2 ± 5.4 million light-years.
We conclude that this new technology is a potentially useful method for selecting distant galaxies and discuss the implications of this result for research on the reionization epoch.

We discovered 11 new T dwarfs in the Two Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS).
We described the process of matching 2MASS PSC point sources with WISE full-width data and presented a resulting list of 22 new T dwarf counterparts.

The newly discovered T dwarfs include the 23rd and 24th closest stars to Earth, which are Teegarden's Star and Doornos' Star, as well as the known closest T dwarf binary system, 2MASS J0746425+2000315.
We presented the spectral types and luminosity measurements of all 22 newly discovered T-type dwarfs, and compared the spectral types and colors of these objects with those of known T-type dwarfs.
Our spectral type determination of 2MASS J0746425+2000315 demonstrates the potential for discovering T dwarfs at greater distances.

We estimate the distance to this pair of T dwarf stars based on an empirical model relating spectral type to absolute J-band brightness, finding a possible distance range of 19-50 parsecs (66-167 light-years).

We will compare the observation quality-luminosity ratio of Teegarden's star with current brown dwarf evolution models to determine that this object is located between the hydrogen burning limit and the deuterium burning limit.
The future observations of the Teegarden star may further test these models and their ability to predict the luminosity of mid-aged ultracool dwarfs.
Finally, we examine the color and luminosity function of the new T-type dwarfs and compare the results with those from previous similar studies.

We observed that the number of T dwarfs may increase at lower brightness levels (from type H to type L), while there may be a deficiency of T dwarfs at an absolute J-band magnitude of about 7.5 in 2MASS.
However, due to the small number of T dwarfs in the sample and the larger photometric errors at the faint end of the luminosity function, these results should be interpreted with caution.
We expect that this work will contribute to the existing catalog of spectral and photometric ultracool dwarfs and provide a useful sample for future research on ultracool dwarfs.

This near-Earth object (NEO) has a diameter of about 1 kilometer and a minimum orbital intersection distance (MOID) from Earth of 0.0435 astronomical units (AU).

VD17 is unlikely to have an impact on Earth in 2023.
In addition, it is likely to be a captured near-Earth object, with a lower possibility of posing a significant threat to Earth in the future.
Observations of (144898) 2004 VD17 indicate that it is likely a captured asteroid whose orbit has become unstable, crossing the Earth's orbit every few hundred years.
The identification of 2004 VD17 occurred just twelve months before its next close approach to Earth in 2023, indicating that it may not be stable in its current orbit.
This study highlights the practicality of large-scale surveys in identifying potential hazardous objects.

Although the value of rapid response searches for near-Earth objects cannot be underestimated, high-precision astrometry with a wide field of view can detect objects like (144898) 2004 VD17 in advance, providing early information for the assessment of potential hazards.

Using additional data sources, such as radar data, during the discovery process will provide valuable information to help identify potential hazards, thereby increasing the efficiency of response and mitigation efforts.
In this work, we consider an early universe model that includes a dynamic scalar field and Chaplygin gas.
The Chaplygin gas belongs to a class of models that have a real scalar field, whose effective negative pressure depends only on the density of the fluid.
We assume that radiation and Chaplygin gas are two interacting fluids.
We study the evolution of the corresponding scale factors and the evolution of the physical quantities that describe the fluid.
We prove that this system of equations allows for the existence of a non-singular expansion solution.
In addition, we calculated the disturbances produced by this dynamics and studied their scale dependence.
We indicate that the scalar spectrum of density perturbations is scale-invariant in the super-Hubble regime, which is consistent with observational results.
Modeling the early universe as a dynamical system allows us to understand its evolution as a result of interactions between different components.
This enables us to find non-singular inflationary solutions and compute any scalar disturbances they produce.
Our results indicate that the model including Chaplygin gas and radiation leads to a scale-invariant density perturbation spectrum, which is consistent with the observational results.
Keywords: early universe, expansion, scalar perturbations, Chaplygin gas.

For this article, we consider the problem of blindly identifying a set of Distributed Antenna Systems (DAS) from wireless channel measurements without the need for prior Channel State Information (CSI) or a model database of DAS.
Based on previous work, we characterized the noise as white noise related to an unknown covariance, and proposed a regularized non-convex cost function to solve the DAS model.
The phrase translates to: "aWN0 is effective when the channel variation is relatively slow compared to the inverse of the channel sampling rate."

The nebulae surrounding core-collapse supernovae provide unique insights into the dying struggles of evolved stars.

Observations of the spectrum emitted by central supernovae provide a unique way to reveal the nature of their progenitors, with direct evidence indicating the presence of stellar winds (from the rapid evolutionary main sequence phase of the progenitor) or core collapse explosions.

Despite decades of research, the properties of the progenitors of the most common core-collapse supernovae remain controversial. Some subtypes of supernovae are associated with main sequence stars with masses of about (8-25M⊙).

A special subtype of supernova, Type Ia, has been used for in-depth cosmological studies and has a clear connection to a (currently still debated) progenitor category: white dwarfs that acquire material from companion stars.

The descendants of these stars, which have masses approximately 8 to 25 times that of the Sun, are commonly referred to as luminous blue variable stars (LBVs). They have been proposed as progenitors of the second type of core-collapse supernovae, which are less understood.

The outburst of LBVs (Luminous Blue Variables) and the halt of further evolution into compact objects are typically explained as the result of one of two scenarios: either a continuous increase in mass transfer from a binary companion, or the onset of thermonuclear explosions on the surface of the star.
The area surrounding supernova 1987A (Tycho) contains a simultaneously existing LBV and a supernova similar to SN 1987A (1988Z).
This is a remarkable coincidence and may suggest the feasibility of LBV eruptions as a mechanism for certain supernova subtypes.

LBV (Luminous Blue Variable) and supernovae are comparable in age. Recent data suggest that the progenitor of a supernova may have been a luminous blue variable star. Recent simulations indicate that a rare LBV outburst might have occurred about 200 years before the supernova explosion, which is likely the culmination of rapid evolution toward a compact object.

Recently, remnants of LBV explosions have been discovered—about 30 to 60 years after the outburst. This finding is speculated to provide strong evidence for the viability of LBV explosions as a supernova mechanism.
This manuscript studies the region around SN 1987A (Tycho) in search of remnants from LBV outbursts, using modern telescopes and data analysis techniques.
We reported the discovery of a faint, nearly spherical shell that seems to align with the positions of the observed LBV and the 1987A supernova.

This shell is similar to other observed objects near supernovae in terms of spatial and spectral properties, and its brightness and expansion velocity are consistent with characteristics arising from the explosion of a massive star.
The observed coincidences of space, age, and energy provide indirect evidence suggesting that the LBV supernova explosions proposed by early simulations may indeed have occurred.
From this article, we provide a Belyi type theorem for the absolute Galois group of rational numbers, which is expressed as a perfect group acting on the branch of the moduli space of surfaces.
We use tightly supported Galois cohomology to control the geometric part of the étale cohomology of the moduli space.
By combining our results with Kevin Hutchinson's earlier work, we deduce that the absolute Galois group acts faithfully on the various components of the moduli space of curves.
The result of our work has important implications for the rigidity of the absolute Galois group, namely that it is semi-simple.
In particular, we derive that the fundamental group of the topology defined by the number field is trivial.
We hope that our work can be further applied to the mold space problem of surfaces.
For example, we use our results to deduce that the Hodge bundle on the moduli space of surfaces is nef and big, thus producing a semi-stable family of curves.
Our main tool is non-Abelian sheaf cohomology, especially using compact support.
We also used Kevin Hutchinson's research on Frobenius morphisms in the moduli space of curves.
Finally, we also mentioned that our results confirm a prediction of the Yao's generalized SNDP conjecture.

Keywords: Bélaire theorem, Galois cohomology, moduli space on surfaces, Hodge bundles

In this article, I argue that quantum mechanics, like other physical theories, can be understood as a form of macroscopic realism that describes the world at a certain level of abstraction.
On this level, the quantum world is similar to the world described by classical physics.
Like classical physics, quantum mechanics relies on generalizations and assumptions that cannot be independently verified.
Compared to classical physics, quantum mechanics also requires that measurement results be described using probability laws, which are derived from the generalization of the concept of probability.
I believe that this probabilistic foundation is key to understanding why quantum mechanics cannot fully and accurately describe certain aspects of the world.

I provided several examples of classic physical phenomena that are not adequately described in quantum mechanics, such as free particles and harmonic oscillators, and explained how, if we accept that measurements in the quantum world correspond to acquiring a certain amount of information, these phenomena can be well described by classical physics.

Finally, I believe that this information can be expressed with the words "knowledge" or "awareness," which allows us to connect quantum mechanics with knowledge representation and management, similar to the role of information theory.
I discussed how this connection helps to find a better theoretical foundation for machine learning and artificial intelligence.
SW Sextantis (SW Sext) is a class of recently identified cataclysmic variable stars (CVs).
So far, they have only been found in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).
The strip area 82 contains nearly 20% of all orbital periods of cosmic particles that are 3-4 hours long.
They share many characteristics with other short-period variable stars of the same type, but can be distinguished by the characteristic absorption lines in the SDSS spectrum.

The SW Sextus population may originate from a group of related contact variable stars (CVs), which produce the majority of systems with high eccentricities and short periods (period-bouncing CVs) that experience increased rotational speeds due to tidal acceleration in close-contact systems.
We discuss the observational characteristics of the SW Sext constellation against the backdrop of different formation channels, and explore the current evolutionary status of the SW Sextantis stars.
The energy released by a SW Sextantis star is enough to power an entire galaxy.

Therefore, the SW Sextantis star represents an important source class in the equatorial strip of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and may be the cause of some of the optical variability observed in these regions.
Vibration has a strong influence on the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.
They determine basic properties, such as melting point and vibration frequency, through examples, and they are also sensitive indicators of molecular structure.
The coupling between electrons and vibrations is called electron-vibration interaction.
Coupling causes the spectral distribution of electron excitation to expand and change.
The electron-vibration interaction is regarded as a weak interaction in many-body perturbation theory.
In this method, the properties of the system are analyzed by referencing an effective Hamiltonian that describes the electronic excitation spectrum.

Within the framework of functional integral formalisms of many-body perturbation theory (dynamical mean field theory), the electron-phonon interaction is described by a systematic expansion of the electron-phonon coupling constants.
In this expansion, the first non-zero term is referred to as the electron-vibration coupling constant.
So far, this coupling constant has been obtained in second-order many-body perturbation theory.
Here, we calculate the electron-vibration coupling constant in the context of the combined density functional theory (CDFT) for the first time.
We indicate that the commonly used frequency-independent random phase approximation (based on Fermi's golden rule) only provides the first non-zero term of this expansion.
The results obtained from CDFT calculations are very consistent with those from the GW method.

Through addition, we prove that for strongly anharmonic molecules, the dominant contribution to the electron-vibrational coupling constant does not come from the diagonal matrix elements of the electron-vibrational interaction, but rather from the off-diagonal matrix elements.
The off-diagonal matrix elements are caused by the anharmonicity on the potential energy surface.
The corresponding off-diagonal Wick contraction is frequency-dependent.
Our results indicate that in the calculation of fully consistent electron-vibration coupling constants, anharmonic effects must be taken into account.
Two new basaltic asteroids, 2020 BP59 and 2023 BP33, were discovered in the near-Earth asteroid (3547) entity group.
The two newly discovered asteroids are the largest members of the group, with estimated diameters of 44 kilometers and 40 kilometers, respectively.
The new asteroids are approximately 3.5 x 2.0 kilometers in size, with estimated masses of about 7.7 x 10^{19} and 1.1 x 10^{20} kilograms, respectively.
These make them one of the largest celestial bodies in the main belt.
We determine their orbits through multiple integrals and instantaneous trajectory analysis.
Our dynamical results show that the perihelion distances of these two asteroids are 0.96 AU and 0.88 AU, respectively.
The large sizes of these two asteroids and their low perihelion distances suggest that they may have accumulated a significant amount of thermal energy due to collisions in their early history.
We determine their orbital evolution based on the chaotic dynamics of small asteroids.
These two asteroids face a significant collision risk over the next 200 million years.
To commemorate the 150th anniversary of the birth of theoretical physicist James Clerk Maxwell, a new form of quantum simulation based on light has recently been proposed, called optical lattices.

By arranging laser beams in a specific pattern and adjusting their relative intensities, it is possible to simulate magnetic domains, quasi-particles, and even short-range interactions in this ultracold atomic system trapped by an optical potential.

In this way, quantum simulation often needs to be conducted under conditions that are almost perfectly isolated from external disturbances, but now it can be carried out in lattices that can sense and respond to perturbations.
Here, we demonstrate the principle of simulating fractional quantum Hall effect in an optical lattice.
In this system, atoms are loaded into a two-dimensional square lattice and are influenced by an artificial magnetic field.
By appropriately selecting the lattice parameters, the system exhibits various quantum Hall states, including highly counterintuitive fractional charge quasiparticles with e/4 charge.
We characterize these phases by measuring the real-space structure of collective excitations and the dynamic structure factor of quasi-particles.
Finally, we demonstrate that by changing a lattice parameter, one can transition from a fractional quantum Hall phase to a trivial insulating phase.
This result establishes a clear connection between quantum simulation and condensed matter physics, providing a powerful approach for exploring a range of new quantum phenomena.

In this work, we conducted a general study of the energy and dynamical behavior of a simplified version of the fully nonlinear Kolmogorov-Lorenz equation, commonly referred to as the Lorenz-Kolmogorov equation.

These equations describe the spatiotemporal evolution of dynamic variables representing the area density of particles in a fluid, which are used to model a wide range of physical, biological, and chemical systems.

Unlike the classical Lorenz model, the dynamic variables in the Kolmogorov-Lorenz system consist of three state variables that represent the magnitudes of velocity, density, and temperature fluctuations.

In contrast to classical systems, these state variables are not normalized to unit variance, but rather are interrelated through an energy function that depends on the total energy of the dynamic system.
We explore the parameter space in the model to identify the regions where the system transitions between different dynamical states, as well as the areas that exhibit chaos.
We then conducted a similar energy analysis to that recently proposed by Rudiger and others.

We indicate that both methods can produce accurate predictions in most of the explored dynamic regions, suggesting that these systems may be used for generating long-term forecasts.

In recent years, several analyses using high-energy gamma-ray and neutrino telescopes have been conducted to search for cosmic ray accelerators, which are believed to be potential sources of high-energy cosmic rays.
These analyses did not find significant evidence of these accelerators, so the clear identification of these objects remains elusive.

However, uncertainties in the cosmic ray propagation model suggest that some gamma-ray and neutrino signals may be produced by hadrons accelerated by hypothetical cosmic ray proton accelerators (pevatrons), but due to their distance from Earth, current instruments are unable to detect these signals.
Based on this work, we demonstrate a search for these petawatt ranges through various analyses of high-energy gamma ray and neutrino data.
No significant excess has been found, so we set an upper limit on the flux of these high-energy particles.

The Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) is a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way.
This is particularly interesting for the study of chemical evolution, as its metallicity is lower than that of the Large Magellanic Cloud.
Planetary Nebulae (PNe) are old stars that expel their atmospheres due to strong stellar winds.
Their elemental abundances can be used to study the chemical evolution of galaxies.
However, the number of planetary nebulae (PNe) found in the SMC is quite limited.
We present optical spectroscopic observations of 19 planetary nebulae in the Southern Star Cloud here.
We measure their radial velocities through chemical composition.
We found that the distribution of nitrogen and the periodicity of oxygen isotopes are similar to those in the Large Magellanic Cloud, while the distribution of sulfur and argon differs.
The similarity between the Large Magellanic Cloud and the Small Magellanic Cloud suggests that the Small Magellanic Cloud has undergone an evolution similar to that of the Large Magellanic Cloud.
However, the measured differences indicate that the formation history of the SMC is different from that of the LMC.
We present the third and final paper of the series on the Homunculus study of Eta Carinae.
The artificial humanoid is a powerful optical nebula generated by bipolar outflows, surrounding the core of a star, formed during a significant explosion about a century ago.

In the first paper, we describe how previous research has shown that the homunculus is most clearly represented as a flattened spheroid, with a long axis measuring 17 to 20 and a flattening ratio of 0.33 to 0.4.
In this third paper, we study the dynamic structure of the little people by modeling it as a rotating gas torus (i.e., a doughnut).
Since its discovery, Hemankurus has been regarded as highly asymmetric, with the front exhibiting a prominent hourglass shape, while the back is broad and fluctuates, presenting a bipolar form.
These two features indicate that the humanoid has a bipolar outflow along its axis of symmetry.

By modeling the little person as a donut and assuming that the rotation speed at the equator is much faster than at the poles, we find that this bipolar radiation can naturally produce the hourglass shape and the width of the fluctuations presented by the little person.
In fact, our model closely reproduces the shape and wavelength of Hermonkur's features under rapid equatorial rotation (approximately 250 kilometers per second).
Therefore, we conclude that the Homunculus must have a rapid bipolar outflow along the rotation axis, possibly due to a major eruption that occurred centuries ago.
This article studies an optimal investment problem related to unbounded random bequests and utility-based pricing.
The investor's goal is to maximize the expected utility of terminal wealth under general semimartingale dynamics.
Due to the unbounded nature of basic random assignment, the traditional concepts of absolute and relative performance become inapplicable.
We adopt a method that combines investment with fundamental dynamics to define supermartingales that are almost everywhere.
Then we construct a sequence of feasible strategies and patiently wait for the occurrence of coupling events.
The corresponding optimal value is obtained through the principle of dynamic programming.
We studied two versions of this problem: one with restricted transactions and the other with unrestricted transactions.

We described the value function under constraints and demonstrated that when the patience time of the two strategies is the same, the value function is equal to the value function of the original problem.
We also provide an approximate method for optimizing the approximation space of the strategy.
Our method applies to a broader class of utility functions and allows for a wider range of applications.
We provide several examples to demonstrate our results.

Keywords: semi-martingale, performance measurement, relative performance, unbounded stochastic funding, utility-based pricing, dynamic programming principle  
Journal: Mathematical Finance, forthcoming

Modern physics has discarded absolute concepts, including the concepts of space and time.

However, in the field of statistical mechanics, which is the most important theoretical area in classical physics, it makes sense to define an advanced potential (A-P) to account for the changes occurring within the system.
Therefore, the A-P system is abnormal.
This article introduces the most important concepts of statistical mechanics, the definition and applications of A-Ps, as well as some physical experiments that can be used to validate the theory.

Using data from the fourth data release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS-DR4), we studied the X-ray properties of the brightest quasars in a complete sample. The quasars in the sample with approximately z > 4 are taken from the bright quasar (LQ) catalog published by Warner et al. (2006).
