clean_wm_text: Compared to local active galactic nuclei, these highest redshift objects have an extremely high spatial density, making them excellent tools for studying supermassive black holes and the growth of their host bulges and galaxies.

We found that the quasars with the highest redshifts have similar X-ray characteristics to those with low redshifts, but their broad equivalent width (EW) and X-ray luminosity are approximately 10 times higher.
The most plausible explanation for this launch is the hot coronal gas in the main galaxy, which has broad emission lines.

Compared to a radio-bright sample matched in X-ray luminosity, these quasars show significantly enhanced radio emission, although it does not reach the predictions of models that suggest the strong radiation emitted by quasars would drive gas into a hot, kiloparsec-scale halo.
The weak differences in radio radiation may indicate that in high redshift cases, the nuclei of quasars are less obscured than those in the local universe.
We believe this may be due to the brighter cosmic background at high redshift being able to penetrate the hypothetical ring structure more easily.

In addition to its inherent interest, this article also provides a cautionary example illustrating that applying single flux limit sample analysis to high-redshift populations may lead to erroneous conclusions.

The analysis of the Dalitz plot for the decay D+ to K-π+π+ in the FOCUS experiment, which is a charm meson spectroscopy experiment at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory B factory, was conducted by the Europpia collaboration, paper 519, (2002); Ivashin Yu. A. et al., paper 589, (2002).
The decay of the D+ to K-π+π+ is a Cabibbo-suppressed weak decay, which plays a key role in understanding quark dynamics.
It has not yet been observed, but according to current theories, Dalitz plot analysis may allow for the distinction between different models of D decays.
The FOCUS detector is a small cylindrical component within the equipment, located in the reserve cyclotron accelerator chain at Fermilab, used for Dalitz plot analysis of the decay from D+ to K-π+π+.
The results in this article were obtained during the data collection period in 2002.

We proposed an analytical model that describes the self-similar scaling relationship between the Shnieriev-Zeldovich (SZ) effect signal and the physical properties of the astrophysical systems from which it originates.
The model takes into account the projection effects in the spatial structure of the system and considers the hydrostatic bias caused by the distribution of luminous or total mass.

We applied our model to interpret the SZ profiles obtained using the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) and showed that if certain scaling relations are imposed, the SZ surface brightness profiles derived from ACT can be well fitted by a self-similar form.

We also indicated that there are systematic errors in the SZ measurements due to limited signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and beam smoothing effects, and we proposed an empirical method to reduce these systematic errors.
We tested our method through numerical simulations and demonstrated that self-similar scaling relationships may be violated if hydrostatic bias is not properly considered.
We applied our model to the Horizon-AGN simulation and demonstrated that the typical magnitude of the violation of the scaling relation is about 40%.

We also indicate that the amplitude of the scaling relation can be used to measure the deviation factor between the total mass and the gas mass, which can be used to calibrate the flux deviation correction of the SZ effect.
The scaling relations obtained from our model are independent of cosmological models and can be used to impose robust cosmological constraints using SZ effect data.
The Milky Way (MW) has accreted dozens of satellite galaxies during its life cycle, some of which may still exist today.
The mass of these satellites may vary from tens to thousands of times that of the Milky Way (MW), and they can leave a coherent signal in the form of stellar halos.
So far, no such signals have been detected.
Here, I present a series of N-body simulations that demonstrate that satellite galaxies with appropriate characteristics can still leave such signals even after being completely destroyed.
These simulations include the comprehensive response of the host halo and its satellites to interactions, which have been shown to match the characteristics of the stellar halo observed today.
The growth of such galaxies can thus explain the stellar halo of the Milky Way, a constraint that was previously thought to be difficult to satisfy.
This may be due to the disturbances caused by satellite galaxies, which leave behind dark matter halos and stellar halos in the Milky Way, and this stellar halo can be detected in the existing data.

This work highlights the practicality of galaxy halos in exoplanet detection, as many of the recently bright stars are surrounded by faint stellar halos that should be detectable with current instruments.
A damped Lyman-alpha (DLA) absorber observed in the direction of a bright quasar at redshift z = 2.2625 was reported, using near-infrared spectral techniques.
The galaxy that causes the DLA coincides with a massive, rapidly rotating galaxy at z = 3.
Its half-light radius is \( r_h = 6.3 \) kpc, and its stellar mass is \( M* = 7.2 \times 10^{11} M_{\odot} \), making it one of the largest galaxies at high redshift.
The total dynamical mass at an effective radius is Mdyn = 1.8 x 10^11 M⊙, which is 9.5 times higher than the dark matter halo mass Mhalo = 9.4 x 10^11 M⊙ derived from galaxy formation simulations.
This indicates the need to use the HOD model to explain the gravity in this galaxy.
This is the most massive galaxy with z = 3, providing direct evidence from the "dark ages" of the universe to the "galaxy era."
By measuring the systematic redshift of galaxies, we limit the shift from quasars to galaxies to 300 km/s, which corresponds to a projected distance of 100 kpc at z = 3.

In the framework of overlapping galaxies, the absorption is a single Gaussian distribution with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 280 km/s, blue-shifted by 120 km/s relative to the velocity of the galaxy.

This large-scale kinematics suggests that the absorbed galaxy is likely a primordial galaxy that is in the process of forming a massive, high-rotational-velocity galaxy, coinciding with a peak period of starburst and black hole growth.
This work was conducted at the 6.5-meter Baade telescope of the Magellan Clay Observatory in Las Campanas, Chile, as part of the Magellan DLA pipeline execution team.
In this article, we use the ADM decomposition method to construct the Hamiltonian dynamics in the Friedman universe.
Since the total Hamiltonian is a constraint, we use the discarded Dirac procedure to introduce the time evolution of phase space variables.
The complete dynamics includes two secondary constraints, which can be used to eliminate two pairs of standard variables.
After this process, the resulting system is described by a pair of canonical variables, and the symplectic form is completely defined.
The quantization of the system is straightforward by using the correspondence between classical variables and quantum variables.
The physical inner product can be defined in two ways: one is using the traditional Schrödinger representation, and the other is using the Berezin integral.
In the former case, the Wheeler-DeWitt equation is an equation similar to the Schrödinger equation.
In the latter case, the Wheeler-DeWitt equation can be obtained through the normalization factor of the Berezin integral.
Many quasars have broad absorption line (BAL) troughs in their spectra, which are produced by gas flowing out along the line of sight to the quasar.
BAL quasars (BALQSOs) are excellent tools for studying the large-scale structure of the universe, as they have high spatial density and narrow absorption lines.
The 2MASS recently revealed a previously unknown group of very red (J-K) BALQSOs.
Through optical spectral analysis of 30 extremely red BALQSO samples from the 2MASS catalog, we present evidence for a unique category of 2MASS extremely red BALQSOs (2MASSVRBALQSOs).
The near-infrared colors of these sources are J-K > 4.8, which are heavily obscured optically (A_V > 10), but show extremely red 2MASS JHK colors, similar to those of normal quasars.
The proportion of 2MASS VR BAL QSOs among all BAL QSOs ranges between 57% and 67%, depending on how 2MASS VR BAL QSOs are defined.

The unprecedented availability of extremely red BALQSOs in the 2MASS database will make it possible to test models of BALQSO evolution and provide new insights into the physical mechanisms driving the large-scale structure of the universe.
Recent experimental advances in the field of Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) have made it possible to observe new types of quantum many-body phenomena.
It is worth noting that the engineering of driving dissipative quantum systems allows for the observation of quantum phase transitions through light, particularly in the Bose-Hubbard model.
The integration of BECs in cavity quantum electrodynamics, as another milestone in coherent light research, provides the possibility for the effective gauge potential of quantum particles.
Here, we have realized both effects in a single-chip device and observed the formation of chiral superfluid and chiral spin liquid.

We have demonstrated that cavity ultracold atom gas platforms have many potential applications, ranging from the discovery of new quantum phases to the realization of quantum simulators and quantum information processing.
The article summarizes recent experimental results in the field of cavity Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC).
The author demonstrated the implementation of effective potential and the Bose-Hubbard model in a single-chip device.
Such integrated systems can be applied in quantum simulators and quantum information processing.
In the past thirty years, quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) have been discovered in the X-ray flux of some compact celestial objects.
Two different types of quasi-periodic oscillations (QPO) have been identified: low-frequency (LF) QPO (0.001–30 Hz) and high-frequency (HF) QPO (0.03–300 Hz).
HF QPOs are particularly remarkable because several sources exhibit multiple distinct HF QPO peaks, indicating that the rotation of these objects is close to a certain stable self-frequency.

The different frequencies of HF QPO peaks, as well as the phenomenon of their clustering around certain values and occasional stability over longer periods, can be best explained by the idea that these peaks are produced by fluid movement along circular geodesic orbits in compact objects such as neutron stars or black holes.
The gravitational magnetic effects generated by fluids may lead to modulation of the orbital period, resulting in noticeable high-frequency quasi-periodic oscillation peaks.
In this way, the gravitational magnetic effect can serve as a unified mechanism for several existing compact stellar models.
Around the center of the galaxy IC342, a surprising variety of celestial objects have been discovered.
This includes at least 15 dark galaxies, up to 750 globular clusters, and numerous very unusual X-ray sources.
An X-ray survey of the center of this galaxy was conducted using the Chandra X-ray Observatory, with a resolution of 20 arcseconds.
Through the Chandra telescope, 22 point-like X-ray sources were resolved, the majority of which are likely low-mass X-ray binary systems (LMXRBS).

A globular cluster appears to be driven by a bright ultraluminous X-ray source, while several other globular clusters seem to have faint X-ray sources. Additionally, two newly discovered dwarf galaxies seem to be entirely powered by X-ray radiation from stellar black holes.
The presence of a large number of highly abnormal X-ray sources is quite significant, as no other galactic center has shown such a diverse group of anomalous objects.
These objects, having existed for more than 10 billion years, suggest that some dark galaxies may be viable candidates for forming new galaxies.
The mass loss events in the late stages of stellar evolution are crucial for understanding the final fate of stars.
The radial velocity curves of typical stars can be accurately modeled using the theory of mass loss processes, which have radiative outer layers.
However, the processes driving the dramatic mass loss events observed in some supergiants are still not well understood.

It's particularly worth noting the events that drive the rapid material loss exhibited by many Luminous Blue Variables (LBVs), as well as the quasi-periodic modulations (QPMs) of the radio features of several supernova explosions.
Recent research on massive loss of mass stars (LBVs) has significantly increased the number of known instances and provided a framework for explaining some of the more extreme events observed.
In some cases, the observed mass loss can be well described by relatively simple magnetohydrodynamic-driven stellar winds.
In other cases, mass loss is more consistent with radiation-driven winds.
This may indicate that there are multiple mass loss mechanisms among these celestial bodies, or it involves more complex processes such as aggregation or significant rotation.
The quantum phase patterns (QPMs) observed in the radio signals from several supernova explosions continue to persist for many years after the explosion.
These modulations can usually be well described by simple harmonic functions, with frequencies close to 0.25, 0.6, 1.0, 2.0, and 4.5 cycles per year.
The frequency of 0.6 times per year has also been found to decrease with the evolution of supernovae.
This seems to indicate that the process of modulation has a memory characteristic.
In most models, this requires a binary companion or another form of internal resonance.
Various observational and theoretical methods have been used to study these severe mass loss events.
Recent modeling has greatly benefited from theoretical advancements in fields such as fluid dynamics, magnetohydrodynamics, and nuclear reaction networks.
Future work may benefit from continuing to study individual subjects, as well as from coordinating monitoring programs designed to detect the onset of such rapid quality decline.
The study of the molecular emission origins around the Re 4 IRS - HH 188 region in the Southern Hemisphere utilized data from ATCA and SEST.
The emissions from molecular lines such as CS, HCN, HCO+, H21, and CH3OH are associated with shocks caused by IRS 4B (and possibly IRS 4A), which interact with an inclined gas and dust disk.
The observed HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 spectra exhibit characteristics of thermochemical processes, while the weaker CH3OH line indicates that the effects of thermal treatment are minimal.

The observed spatial distribution and velocity structure indicate that the observed emission originates from an hourglass-shaped shock envelope, oriented toward the center of mass, featuring a bow-shaped shock cavity wall, and possibly includes a broad redshift component that may originate from an externally triggered jet.
The study on the origin of molecular emissions in the southern hemisphere Re 4 IRS - HH 188 region utilized data from ATCA and SEST.

The emission of molecular lines, such as CS, HCN, HCO+, H21, and CH3OH, has been found to be associated with the shocks excited by IRS 4B and possibly related to IRS 4A, with these shocks interacting with the tilted gas and dust disk.

The observed HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 spectral lines exhibit typical characteristics of thermal n-Chemistry, while the weaker CH3OH spectral line suggests that the influence of thermal processing is relatively minor.

The observed spatial distribution and velocity structure indicate that the observed radiation originates from a shell-like shock envelope that is hourglass-shaped, has a near-central orientation, bow shock cavity walls, and possibly a broad redshift component from externally triggered outflows.

Feynman-Wilson Quantum Gravity (FW QG) is a hybrid quantum-classical theory of gravity based on a renormalizable effective field theory (EFT), which originates from the forefront of research in quantum gravity.
It offers a candidate theory of everything (TOE) to unify all known interactions, including gravity.

FW QG is an effective field theory (EFT) with an effective range up to the Planck scale. FW QG extends the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics, including not only the currently observed fields but also the fields at higher energies according to the principles of effective field theory.
FW QG is the first theory to incorporate quantum gravity into relativistic quantum field theory.

As of now, it has passed all known empirical tests: gravitational physics, weak interactions, as well as strong interactions and electromagnetic interactions, with the remaining parameters calculated using the EFT method.
Expanding it to include the complete standard model and additional terms to fill in the missing equations (Planck scale detection/interactions) remains a priority for future research.
Therefore, FW QG is a fully renormalized, empirically self-consistent, and internally coherent theory of everything (TOE).
The gamma-ray binary LS I +61 303 consists of a compact object, most likely a black hole, that is accreting gas from its companion star.
The companion star is a main-sequence star of spectral type O9.5V, located 2.4 kiloparsecs away.

The orbit of this binary star has a high eccentricity, with a period of 12.8 years and a distance of 5.5 astronomical units. Detection of solar eclipses, luminosity dips, highly polarized gamma-ray emissions, and directional jets indicate that this compact object is mostly hidden, occasionally making brief appearances when it approaches the star in a spiral manner.
The dynamic characteristics of the system have always been a topic of debate; some studies support the scenario of a third body, while others advocate for the collision wind model.
In this case, the interstellar wind generated by the companion star sweeps up and compresses a dense ring around the black hole.
The surface generated most of the observed gamma-ray radiation.
In this article, we evaluate the two models through a combination of numerical simulation and analytical demonstration.
The main result of this assessment is that, although the aggregation model is less elegant and more complex, it is more successful in reproducing multi-wavelength data.
The accumulation model of LS I +61 303 relies on the existence of an accretion disk, which is supplied by material captured from the companion star.
This substance is likely guided into the black hole through a hot, relatively weakly ionized outflow of the magnetosphere.
The capture rate is very eccentric in the orbital plane of the black hole, which allows matter to be supplied to the disk continuously but irregularly.

The magnetic field of the black hole and the thermal coupling of the disk prevent the formation of an external thin disk, while allowing for efficient high-energy radiation through synchrotron radiation or magnetically constrained jet models.
In contrast, the collision wind model assumes that the compact object is a Wolf-Rayet star, composed of high-velocity WR winds interacting with the dense, slow-moving winds from O-type stars.
This system is very biased, although the perihelion is the place where collision winds occur.
The two flows weaken and collide, forming a complex region of partially ionized shock gas and radiation.

Although the existence of collisional winds has been demonstrated in the case of massive stars, we have shown that collisional winds can also apply to relatively low-mass companion stars and produce observable radiation.
In addition, the launch area of the collision wind is small and localized, while the large orbit of LS I +61 303 requires a dispersed launch area.

Through the combination of 1D and 3D simulations, we demonstrate that the collisional wind scenario cannot reproduce the multi-band spectral energy distribution of LS I +61 303, and predict that this system should have relatively quiet radio waves.
The recent experimental search for the small mismatch between the masses of neutrinos and antineutrinos has surpassed the world's leading sensitivity.

The new results from the Muon g-2 experiment at Brookhaven National Laboratory yield a total discrepancy of over 2.6 standard deviations between observed and predicted values, providing strong support for the existence of a small, potentially sterile neutrino mass.
The new results are in complete agreement with the predictions of the standard model, providing further evidence for the so-called "normal" neutrino mass hierarchy.

If the central value of the soon-to-be-released new results is lower than the current best fit value, it will be a clear indication of new physics and will necessitate updates to the current model construction.

However, considering the current statistical and systematic uncertainties, even an order of magnitude improvement in sensitivity would not significantly change the current best-fit three neutrino models.

Manganate R$_{1-x}$A$_x$MnO$_3$ (R: rare earth elements, A: alkaline earth metals) is regarded as a typical example for observing the non-continuous metal-insulator transition (MIT) with orbital ordering.
MIT is caused by the competition between the JT interactions and the coupling of electrons (Hand).
So far, there is still a lack of microscopic explanations for the observed orbital order.
Here, we present the first microscopic theory regarding the correlated orbital dynamics in ferromagnetic manganites.
We use the multi-orbital Hubbard model to describe the Mn $3d$ electrons with a significant separation between the Mn $3d$ and O $2p$ orbitals.
The model describes the competitive interactions in the system, specifically considering the local spins of Mn$^{3+}$ and Mn$^{4+}$, which are regarded as pseudo-spins.
The key input of the model is the derivation of the effective Hamiltonian for the Mn $e_g$ electrons, which is carried out within the framework of the Hubbard lattice method.
We discovered a ferromagnetic orbital liquid phase, in which the order parameters of both the conventional (inclined) orbital order and the ferromagnetic order vanish.

The nesting of the Fermi surface leads to a strong renormalization of bare interactions and induces orbital polarization within a small Jett coupling and a tiny range of Hund coupling. Our estimates are based on actual band structure calculations.
We believe that if the valence state of manganese fluctuates slightly, then the observed metal-insulator transition in these compounds can be explained without the need for orbital ordering.
We formalized the equivalence of Nash equilibrium and subgame perfect equilibrium in game theory.
This equivalence relation is strong enough to infer various properties of Nash equilibria, such as their existence or uniqueness.
Unfortunately, generally speaking, these properties do not hold for subgame perfect equilibrium. We provide clear game examples to refute these properties regarding subgame perfect equilibrium.
This negates a conjecture of H. Brézis, which states that subgame perfect equilibria, and thus also Nash equilibria, must be acyclic.

We have provided a constructive version of the above equivalence relation and used it to demonstrate that in any game, subgame perfect equilibria always contain all the information about that game, which implies that any path in the subgame perfect equilibrium graph will yield a Nash equilibrium.

We also provided a combination proof showing that in two-player zero-sum games, any subgame perfect equilibrium is also a Nash equilibrium, thereby offering a simpler and more direct proof than the earlier construction using fixed-point theorems, confirming this well-known result.
The Coma Cluster is the first singular instance of an X-ray cluster discovered by the Rosat satellite.

Its impressive morphology has been confirmed by all high-resolution X-ray instruments, except for the Chandra and XMM-Newton telescopes, whose observations revealed the presence of large-scale peripheral components associated with the cluster.
This component is aligned with the coma center and connects it to the Abel 1367 galaxy cluster located in the southwest direction.
We reported the southwest extension of the Pleiades cluster discovered in Chandra observations.
Its size is approximately 2 Mpc, with a velocity of 7500 km/s, a position angle of 90 degrees, and it covers the front part of the main cluster component.
The positions in this sub-group coincide with the emission peaks of the hot gas and the brightest galaxy members.
The existence of the galaxy group supports a scenario in which the large coma is the result of a merger with another galaxy cluster, leading to the observed cD galaxy being left behind.

The burning bridge model (BBMs) is a simple artificial network model that exhibits a clear transition between unburned and burned states. It is widely used to study a variety of systems, ranging from biologically inspired computations to chemical systems and soft condensed matter systems.

The field of biomimetic molecular motors has recently begun to utilize BBMs as a means to explore the relationship between structure and function, where the dynamics of molecular motors interacting with BBMs are considered a potential design variable.
From this work, we introduce a simple bistable BBM that demonstrates a locking state which depends on the dynamics of molecular motors.
Using a simplified two-state BBM, we are able to qualitatively reproduce the locking phenomenon observed in more complex BBMs.
In addition, by adding discrete rotational dynamics to the motor, we are able to reproduce the observed locking behavior using one-dimensional BBM.

Our research results indicate that the locking phenomenon observed in more detailed biomembrane models is a result of the coupling between the continuous rotational dynamics of molecular motors and the dynamic structure of the biomembrane.
The internal state of isotropic particle packing in the model.
I. Assembling process and the geometric shape of the contact network.
The assembly process of granular materials is of considerable interest both scientifically and technologically.

In contrast to atomic and molecular systems, the assembly of granular particles is an open system: the rearrangement of particles alters the geometric arrangement, thereby changing the internal state of the packing.
From this work, we study how this rearrangement affects the geometric and topological properties of the contact network, which is a unique way to describe the connectivity within the packing.
We conducted a numerical simulation of a crowded process based on the Omodei law, which successfully captures the structure of the contact network during the evolution of packing towards stability.

In order to analyze the rearrangement mechanism, we represent the internal state within the package using a small number of global variables.
We will focus our analysis on two packing characteristics: the average angle between neighbors and the radial distribution function.
Finally, we introduced a metric to quantify the topological changes caused by the rearrangement, and we provided a characterization of different rearrangement mechanisms.
The KATRIN experiment at FZK has completed the collection of beta decay spectrum data at |$q$| = 0.75 eV/c, and aims to determine the mass hierarchy of neutrinos.
KATRIN measures the beta spectrum in a completely dark room using a background radiation level of sub-parts-per-million (sub-ppm).

The experiment is expected to have a sensitivity to neutrino mass at the 1 σ level of 0.35-0.9 eV, depending on the neutrino mass hierarchy, and a sensitivity to right-handed currents in the neutrino sector of 10-35%.

The experiment used an array composed of 18 metal wires (cathodes) with an inner diameter of 3 millimeters, which are relatively movable to reduce the motion noise of the micro-manipulators located on top of these wires.
The axial movement of the wire is read through a reflection mixer, and the phase of the reflection signal is used to determine the flight time.
In order to accurately determine the endpoint, a high-speed digitizer with a timing precision of 0.5 nanoseconds was used to record the spectrum.
An emerging active region has generated a flux rope configuration in the coronal magnetic field.
If there are no other magnetic fields to stabilize it, the rope will become unstable.
In this study, we demonstrated the evolution of this unstable rope through stereoscopic observation and nonlinear force-free field (NLFFF) modeling.
The rope呈现出一个剪切拱廊的形状，具有两个在两端突出部分的特征，可以最好地描述为一个圆锥体，其轴线沿着局部背景场.
The direction of the two fields—the coronal field and the local background field—seems to influence the stability of the rope.
When they align, the ropes become unstable and explode within 24 hours.

When the angle between them exceeds 90°, the rope does not break but instead extends further into the coronal field and gradually shortens until it is eventually torn into multiple fragments approximately 48 hours after the initial shear activation.
The extension time and length of the rope vary depending on the angle between the two domains.

The angles of approximately 60° and 120° seem to be critical angles: when the angle is below 60°, the rope is erupting; when the angle exceeds 120°, the rope is not erupting, but it further extends into the coronal field.
In this paper, we investigate the geometric and topological properties of the cosmic solutions in the standard cosmological model, known as the Lambda-CDM model.
We first demonstrate that the phase space of the model has a symplectic structure, and it inherits the scalar properties of the gravitational part.
We then study the possible topology and smoothness of the universe obtained from the research, and conclude whether it is a singular spacetime with nontrivial homology groups.
The study was conducted within the framework of the School of Mathematics, Statistics and Physics at Ulster University in Ireland.
The translation of "相对论宇宙学中的几何与拓扑" into English is "Geometry and Topology in Relativistic Cosmology."
In this article, we study the geometric and topological properties of cosmological solutions in the standard cosmological model — the Lambda-CDM model.
We first demonstrate that the phase space of the model has a symplectic structure, and it inherits the scalar characteristics from the gravitational part.

We continue to study the possible topological structure and smoothness of the universe obtained from the research, and draw conclusions about whether it is a singular spacetime with non-trivial homotopy groups.
The study was conducted within the framework of the School of Mathematics, Statistics, and Physics at Ulster University in Ireland.
This result indicates that the smoothness of the universe in the standard model of cosmology differs from that in general relativity, and its homotopy group is nontrivial.
The significance of these results lies in the fact that this has not yet been achieved in a mathematically rigorous way.
According to recent observations, the universe is almost flat, and these results may have significant cosmological implications.
Finally, we note that the differentiable structure of the model still allows for the existence of a non-singular solution, namely De Sitter space.
From this article, we propose a quasi-linear time algorithm for computing modular polynomials.
Let \( f(x) \) be a polynomial that is positive definite and has a leading coefficient of 1, with its coefficients being integers.

The multivariate polynomial related to \( f \) is defined as follows, where \( \chi(n) \) is the main Thue function that obtains all the unit roots as \( n \) varies within the range of positive integers.
The computation of modular polynomials for a given modulus M is fundamental in number theory and its applications.
In computational number theory, it appears in the calculation of the Shafarevich–Tate group, for which a modular polynomial with specific properties is required.

The task of computing mod polynomials related to a given polynomial is considered difficult, and it has been proven that, for c < 1, it cannot be approximated within a factor of n^c, unless the polynomial evaluation problem is difficult when c = 1.
We propose a quasi-linear time algorithm to compute modular polynomials.
Based on a simpler algorithm for calculating the prime factors of the modulus, we have proven some difficult results concerning modular polynomials.
Our algorithm has applications in computing the Shafarevich-Tate group, and it would be very interesting to see if it can be used to improve the best known algorithms for this problem.
The equation of state for dark energy (DE) can be modeled by modifying general relativity (GR).

In order to distinguish dark energy (DE) models from standard cosmology, the parameter $w$ in the equation of state is typically assumed to be a value close to -1, which is consistent with the theory of the cosmological constant in general relativity (GR).
This kind of model may conflict with modern observational results.

The data from the following experiments, such as WMAP, BOOMERanG, or PLANCK, as well as the results from standard cosmological tests, such as large-scale structure (LSS) analysis or the Integrated Faraday Macroclimate Report (IFM) analysis, are used to constrain the parameter space of dark energy models.

Specifically, a new parameter can be introduced that modifies the gravitational constant in the universe, leading to the inability of dark energy models with constant $w$ to explain the anomalies observed in large-scale structure analysis or the results of IFM experiments.
Therefore, a model with a variable $w$ is more desirable.

In this case, the density perturbation in the model is generated, and the parameter \( w \) can evolve from -1 in the late stage to a value less than -1 during the structure formation process, which can thus be consistent with the observations mentioned above.
In this work, we consider a model of this kind.

We consider an extension of gravity given by \( R + f(R) \), which leads to a modification of gravity (MGG) with a constant \( w \) that has no divergence. We model the dynamics of matter and analyze the impact of the introduced constant \( w \) on structure formation.
We also describe a method to reconstruct MGG based on the results of future experiments.
Modern electronic devices are primarily based on silicon-based components, which have made widespread automation and significant improvements in quality of life possible.
However, silicon is a brittle indirect bandgap material, which makes its integration in high-power, high-temperature, and high-frequency circuits challenging.
Graphene is a two-dimensional hexagonal lattice of carbon, providing an ideal competitor for future electronic products.

The high mobility of charge carriers in graphene, its ability to adjust its band structure through stretching or combination, and its excellent compatibility with current lithography techniques make it a promising material for next-generation electronic devices.

One potential application of graphene is in transistors, which are the fundamental components of integrated circuits, representing the most challenging obstacle for the application of graphene in the real world.
One approach to a graphene transistor is based on ballistic transport through a one-dimensional nanoribbon, which is known as a ballistic graphene nanoribbon.
This method has potential advantages compared to existing two-dimensional devices, but to fully harness this potential, a deep understanding of device characteristics at the nanoscale is needed.
Here, we present a comprehensive quantum real-space study of spherical graphene nanoribbon metal oxide semiconductor field-effect transistors.
By simulating electron transport at the atomic level, we observed the device characteristics at room temperature and characterized the effects of various device parameters.

We have demonstrated that ballistic graphene nanoribbon devices can compete with existing silicon devices while providing significant advantages, such as a higher switch current ratio and significantly reduced parasitic capacitance.

Our work is of great significance because it bridges the understanding of device performance at the nanoscale with the physics of micron-scale semiconductor devices needed for manufacturing practical devices.

The principles developed in this study can be easily extended to other one-dimensional materials and are of great significance for the design and understanding of other one-dimensional nanoelectronic devices.

Our work is of significant importance because it bridges the gap between the nanoscale understanding of device performance and the microscopic semiconductor device physics required for the manufacturing of actual devices.

The principles proposed in this study can be easily extended to other one-dimensional materials and are significantly important for the design and understanding of other one-dimensional nanoelectronic devices.

**New Technologies for Monitoring the Performance of the LAT Instrument on the GLAST Satellite**  
J. R. Leon, V. Reglero, G. B. Hobbs, R. E. Ransome, A. A. Aguilar-Torres  
The LAT, also known as the Large Area Telescope, is a gamma-ray telescope with a large surface area (approximately 4% within a sphere) and fine angular resolution (approximately 10 degrees half-power diameter), designed to detect gamma rays from large areas of the sky and conduct studies on gamma-ray bursts or air showers.
key: for, in, on, at, with, in

clean_wm_text: In order to detect astrophysical gamma rays with energies as low as 20 MeV, the detector's response was calibrated using a radioactive source, which was inserted into a small container attached to the outside of the LAT.
However, this calibration can only be performed periodically, as repeatedly inserting the jar may alter the performance of the LAT.
We proposed a novel technology that can monitor the performance of the LAT without the need to reinsert the radioactive source container.
The technology utilizes the conventional cargo satellite Chang'e 3, which carries a tank containing a radioactive source, to regularly perform similar calibration operations.

We demonstrated that the responses measured using the radiation source of Chang'e 3 and those measured from a similar tank using LAT are consistent across all energy ranges from 20 MeV to 100 GeV, with an error margin of less than 10%.
This article is recommended reading from "Gamma Ray Physics II" (December 2017).
In this article, we investigate the critical interface dynamics in the Barkhausen noise model.
The model is an oriented seepage model with additional degrees of freedom that describe the slope of the local interface.
Under long time constraints, the model exhibits critical scale behavior and continuous phase transitions.
In particular, we are interested in the fluctuations near these transitions.
In order to study these, we use the method of wavelet transform.

The analysis indicates that the scale-dependent wavelet variance exhibits singularities at critical points, presenting a universal scaling function form consistent with a static scaling exponent of the correlation length.
In addition, we discussed how to test the scaling hypothesis using numerical methods and presented Monte Carlo data that confirms our analysis results.
References: Adib, M., Berthier, C., Moreno, A., & Gorre, N. (2015).
The wavelet transform in the critical interface model of Barkhausen noise.
"Physical Review Letters," 114(17).
Bacterial chemotaxis is a navigation system used by microorganisms to detect chemical gradients in the environment and initiate adaptive responses.
Under the same chemical environment, bacterial behavioral responses show variations, ranging from no response to drastic and sustained directional changes.

As of now, the variability in bacterial responses has been linked to mutations in individual cells or even entire bacterial populations, but it is not related to the emergent behaviors at the individual cell level.

Here, we demonstrate that the temporal dynamics of individual cells under the same chemical stimulation are sufficient to explain the differences in behavioral variability at the population level, by combining microfluidic technology with high-throughput imaging.

We have demonstrated that the dynamics of bacterial polar deployment are associated with the persistence in response to chemical gradients, and these dynamics are encoded in the timescale of polar rotation.

Our research provides a fundamental link between individual cell behavior and emergent phenomena at the population level, which is significant for understanding the complexity of bacterial physiology and infectious diseases.
Phonons are the collective motion of ions in a crystal, and they can propagate through solids via various scattering processes.
The dynamics of electrons are influenced by the crystal structure, while the dynamics of phonons are determined by the interactions between atoms.
This means that phonon transport between different crystal structures may exhibit unique characteristics.
Here, we report the measurement results of longitudinal and transverse sound propagation through the epitaxial interface.
By changing the orientation of these two crystals, we are able to isolate the interface vibrations from the bulk modes.
We identified three types of resonance interfacial modes and their corresponding phonon modes in the transmission spectrum.
The first resonant mode is the lateral surface mode, also known as Rayleigh waves.
The interaction between surface waves and longitudinal and transverse waves exhibits distinctly different behaviors, which can be attributed to the polarization changes of the propagating waves.
The second mode is the bending vibration of the reconstructed interface, which is allowed by the symmetry of the coupled crystal.
The third mode is the two-dimensional interface mode.
It has zero transmission for longitudinal sound waves and only transmits transverse sound waves.
These resonance characteristics are further analyzed through atomic displacement modes.
The diffusion radiation generated in the Langmuir turbulence caused by the jet shock was observed and measured in the experiment.
This phenomenon is the result of the wave-particle interaction mediated by the ion plasma frequency.
The resultant energy diffusion coefficient depends on the wave phase, energy flux, as well as the density and temperature of the plasma.
These effects can be explained by a simple analytical theory.
The theory describes the nonlinear stage of wave evolution and the anisotropy observed experimentally.

The above physical effects were first observed and measured in the Tokamak Testing Facility (TBF) of the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER) team. By using a rotating Langmuir probe, the energy flux carried by Langmuir waves across the entire plasma profile can be continuously measured.
The turbulence energy reaches its maximum value at the shock front.
The distance between the shock front and the maximum energy flux corresponds to the thickness of the diffusion zone, as calculated theoretically.
High-temperature superconductors exhibit a complex phase diagram with multiple competing phases.
Theoretically, it has always been difficult to reconcile various experimental observations using a single model.
Here, we propose a high-temperature superconductivity model based on SU(4) symmetry, which involves components from four critical fields.

This model allows for a qualitative interpretation of various experiments, including the suppression of magnetic order caused by momentum-dependent pairing interactions, the emergence of d-wave symmetry in the superconducting order parameter, and the appearance of neutron scattering resonances at wave vectors connecting four smooth Fermi surfaces, which themselves are composed of small distorted spheres.
Several theoretical predictions can be directly tested using current technology.

Through extensive quantum Monte Carlo simulations and a slave rotor mean-field theory, we demonstrate that the low-dimensional quantum Heisenberg model on a layered lattice structure can be accurately described by a semiclassical spin-wave analysis based on valence-bond crystal recognition.

Quantum fluctuations have been found to significantly alter the spin wave spectrum, with the most pronounced effects occurring in strong frustration models, where geometric factors favor the stabilization of valence bond crystal patterns.

In particular, our results strongly indicate that the semiclassical treatment of valence bond crystals for weak tunneling between aggregates applies to a wide range of geometric shapes, in which inhomogeneous aggregates are stabilized.

The spin wave spectrum modified by quantum fluctuations has been found to enhance the effect of frustration interactions, leading to a significant suppression of the magnetization plateau state, compared to a simple semiclassical treatment.

Notably, spin wave analysis has captured all finite size effects and characteristics of valence bond crystals, even covering the smallest linear system sizes studied, paving the way for efficient simulations of frustrated Heisenberg models with local quantum fluctuations.
The study investigated the evolution of solitary waves and wave erosion in shallow water flow on a gentle slope with bottom friction.
The behavior of these waves is significantly influenced by the properties of the bottom, especially by the intensity of the bottom friction.
In the absence of bottom friction, these waves always propagate to the right and eventually break down into wave oscillations.
When considering bottom friction, solitary waves can still propagate to the right, but they may also propagate to the left, forming spiral waves, and even transform into wave shock waves.
The behavior is explored through numerical methods and asymptotic methods, and a good consistency between the two is found.
It also indicates that the dispersion relation of fluctuating waves can be obtained as an extension of the KdV (Korteweg-de Vries) regime, and provides a truncated form of that extension.
If the average speed of the oscillating wave packet is much lower than the propagation speed of the wave front, then truncation proves to be effective.
While analyzing the spectrum of the quasar HS 2211+0958 using the Keck II telescope, a damped Lyman-alpha (DLA) system located at z=0.52 was discovered.
The DLA system has a high neutral hydrogen column density, log(N(H I+)) = 20.95 cm^(-2), as well as a high neutral gas to total mass ratio, f = 0.68.
In this DLA, a high-velocity system at z=0.52 was also identified.
Based on the optical and near-infrared spectral energy distribution, the metallicity of this system has been found to exceed solar levels.
In DLA systems with low redshift and high column density, the observed 9.7 micron silicate absorption is abnormally strong.
The presence of strong silicate absorption indicates that the system may have produced dust during a high-redshift phase prior to the observation period.

The system's exceptionally strong silicate absorption and high metal abundance are consistent with the star formation in this system at high redshifts and the inferred high initial star formation rate.
Therefore, this DLA provides an excellent opportunity to study the early stages of galaxy formation at high redshift.
Open star clusters play an important role in the study of stellar evolution because the stars within the same cluster share the same initial conditions and evolutionary stages.
One of the most thoroughly studied open star clusters is the main sequence star cluster M67, which has a brightness of 7.5 and is commonly referred to as NGC 2682.

This is an ideal place to study the effects of stellar evolution, as it is mainly composed of main sequence stars that have already left the main sequence band of the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram and are evolving towards a future white dwarf state.
To study the stellar population of NGC 2682, Strömgren uvbyHβ photometric measurements were conducted.
The observed Color-Magnitude Diagram (CMD) is used to assess the impact of light pollution and incompleteness, as well as for designing membership selection methods for the Hyades star cluster.
The CMD displayed a set of possible blue stragglers, which was also confirmed by the variable star analysis.
A simulation was conducted to analyze the impact of input parameter uncertainty on the output results.

The results of this work can be summarized as follows: (1) The contamination level in the CMD of NGC2682 among the analyzed stars is estimated to be about 6.7%, (2) blue stragglers account for at least 0.26% of the total cluster members, and (3) the simulated uncertainty of the output parameters does not exceed 14%.
The brains of primates are among the most complex in mammals and exhibit a high degree of variability among different species.

Despite the abundant evidence of structural and functional connections between cortical regions in non-human primates, little is known about the connectivity patterns within individual regions or between different functional network regions.
For this work, we use graphical analysis to predict the characteristics of cortical connectivity, which are based on the anatomical and functional properties of various brain regions.
We first created a weighted, signed, and correlated structural network using MRI data and a novel cortical surface distance measurement method.
We subsequently predicted the network connections between brain regions by training machine learning models using topology and spatial node attribute values specific to the brain regions.

The model can predict positive and negative weights in networks with relevant structural and functional connectivity data, forecasting stronger positive weights between areas with similar topology and spatial node attribute values, while exhibiting weaker positive weights or negative weights between areas with differing values.
When trained on a subset of data and tested on the reserved data, the model also predicts connectivity networks that are significantly similar to the observed structural and functional networks.

These results indicate that node-specific topological and spatial features can predict their connectivity characteristics, suggesting that these features may play a causal role in determining the observed connectivity patterns.
Helium-4 is the most abundant element in the universe, and its prevalence in galaxy clusters, as well as the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) effect, has been well established.

However, the gas fraction in galaxy clusters is insufficient to keep all helium neutral, so the recent claims about the presence of non-negligible gaseous helium in large galaxy clusters have been called into question.
Using high-quality data from the Antarctic telescope, we have clearly ruled out this possibility at the 3σ level.

In the past decade, new X-ray astronomy facilities and innovative analysis methods have allowed us to detect the SZ effect of galaxy clusters, demonstrating the presence of weak yet ubiquitous cosmic microwave background (CMB) photons being scattered by electrons in the high-temperature regions of galaxy clusters.
The hot SZ effect is specific to each galaxy cluster, and its spectral features can be used to estimate the total thermal energy of the cluster, the Hubble constant, and the gas mass fraction.

The non-thermal (or SZ Pauli) effect was discovered ten years ago. Its spatial structure depends on the distribution of particles and has been used to detect interactions between the contents of star clusters and high-energy particles in large-scale structures.
In this work, we present and analyze the X-ray and SZ observational data of the galaxy cluster ZwCl 2764.
We measured the gas fraction of the star cluster and the temperature and density of its ICM (intracluster medium).
We also used the SZ observations of the galaxy cluster to constrain the Hubble constant.
We have found the best-fit cosmological parameters: H0 = 68.2 ± 1.5 km/s/Mpc, which is consistent with the results obtained from other cosmological probes.
The study on the two-photon ionization of hydrogen-like ions was conducted using a fully relativistic description based on the Riccati-Hankel method.

The angular distribution of emitted electrons has been calculated for several fixed values of the principal quantum number N and the angular momentum quantum number J, including N = 2 and J = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4.
Research shows that relativistic corrections typically smooth the behavior of the non-relativistic model and shift it to lower values of electron emission angles.

In particular, relativistic effects significantly change the numerical values of the radiation distribution peaks of certain quantum numbers N and J. The obtained results are used to determine the impact of relativistic effects on the energy levels and electronic transition probabilities of hydrogen-like ions, as well as to examine the potential of relativity by studying the effects of these phenomena on the radiation patterns of ionized electrons.
The size of celestial bodies is one of the most fundamental attributes.
It is measured by the apparent angular diameter, which is a function of the projected physical diameter and the distance to the object.
The visible angular diameters of planets, gas giants, and other large asteroids are usually less than 1 arc second, with corresponding physical diameters being several times that of the Earth.
However, when considering small objects outside the solar system, such as comets, asteroids, and Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs), their sizes become more difficult to determine.
For example, the diameter of a typical large frozen ocean celestial system is several hundred kilometers, which corresponds to less than 1 arc second in visible light, or several tens of kilometers.
To characterize the size and structure of these objects, it is necessary to have a detailed understanding of how light interacts with them.
As the first step, this work determined the reflected light curve and size of the largest body in the Kuiper Belt — the dwarf planet (1480) Pluto.

Using visible and infrared observations from the Hubble Space Telescope and the Spitzer Space Telescope, we measured the apparent diameters of Pluto and Charon as a function of phase angle, and generated the first light curve for Pluto and Charon.

These observations indicate that the largest object in the Kuiper Belt is approximately 500 kilometers by 400 kilometers in size, consisting of 3 to 4 components, with corresponding physical diameters ranging from 300 to 400 kilometers.
This work presents the light curves of Pluto and Charon for the first time, which can be used for further analysis of the Kuiper Belt to determine its physical and chemical properties.
Generally speaking, Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs) are extremely cold, dark, and distant worlds.
The Kuiper Belt, located beyond the orbit of Neptune, is the third region of the solar system, situated outside the inner main belt and the asteroid belt, characterized by countless small icy bodies.
The Kuiper Belt contains the most primitive objects from the asteroid belt, as well as the largest and least geologically active bodies in the solar system.
Although Pluto was classified as a dwarf planet in 2006 and is the smallest and farthest known member of the Kuiper Belt, it is the only one for which no light curve is available.
Thanks to the observations made with the Hubble and Spitzer telescopes from 2014 to 2018, we were able to characterize the shape, size, and structure of Pluto.

This work adds to the long list of variability curve measurements of Kuiper Belt objects, starting with QB1 in 1994 and covering a variety of different celestial bodies, such as 2012 VP113, Haumea, Makemake, Eris, and (136108) 2004 BF3.
By determining Pluto's light curve, we have also obtained its size.
Pluto is the largest Kuiper Belt object, and its light curve enables us to constrain the sizes of Kuiper Belt objects.
The symmetry of anti-de Sitter space (AdS) and asymptotically flat spacetime implies that their conserved quantities should satisfy certain linearly independent differential equations.

Specifically, conservation quantities in three-dimensional and higher-dimensional anti-de Sitter spaces should satisfy a set of constrained first-order differential equations, while in four-dimensional and higher-dimensional asymptotically flat spacetimes, they should satisfy a set of constrained second-order differential equations.
In this brief explanation, we prove several identities related to conserved charges associated with spacetime that satisfy first or second-order differential equations and constraints.
"Our identity seems to have not been discussed in the existing literature."
This document is an extension of our earlier work.

We have addressed the case of three-dimensional anti-de Sitter space (AdS$_3$) in (3+1) dimensions and four-dimensional asymptotically flat spacetime in (4+1) dimensions. The main motivation for writing this brief note is to hope for a document that includes all these results.

G. Chakraborty and S. Deshmukh, "Conservation Charge Identity in (n + 1)-dimensional Spacetime with (n - 1)-dimensional Horizon," arXiv:1910.06501 [hep-th] *The authors completed this work at the High Energy Physics Center, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, Karnataka 560012, India.*
The explanation can be found at https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.06501.
Near-Earth Asteroids (NEAs) are the most common witnesses of upcoming asteroids and play a key role in shaping the asteroid population.
The NEA thermal inertia, or the magnitude of their Yarkovsky effect, is one of the key parameters in their dynamic modeling.
The lack of understanding of NEA thermal inertia hinders the development of these fields.
We presented a thermal inertia analysis of six types of objects with different surface characteristics.
The largest thermal inertia was measured in the inner belt (3.2 ± 1.5 °C km−1 s−1), while the smallest thermal inertia (4.8 ± 1.1 °C km−1 s−1) was measured in the outer belt.

During this period, we determined the thermal inertia of near-Earth asteroids (ranging from 0.7 °C km−1 s−1 to 46.9 °C km−1 s−1) and the thermal inertia of main belt near-Earth asteroids (ranging from 0.8 °C km−1 s−1 to 46.2 °C km−1 s−1).
This work enhances our understanding of the magnitude of the Yarkovsky effect on near-Earth asteroids (NEAs) and improves our ability to model their dynamical evolution.
The alkylthiol self-assembled monolayer (MTs) is formed by connecting a carbon-carbon framework with terminal alkylthiols to a solid substrate, resulting in a monolayer structure.
Terminal groups can be protected from air oxidation by growing them on a metal substrate (for example, Ag(111)).
The formation of this protective layer can prevent the oxidation of the underlying metal, giving it practical value in the surface modification of biological interfaces.
To study the formation of this protective layer, scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used.
The STM image shows the process of MTs growing from the substrate to the Ag(111) surface.
The XPS data indicate that terminal groups and C—C and C—H bonds are formed on the Ag(111) surface.
These keys confirm the formation of the protective layer.
This article indicates that MTs can grow on Ag(111) to form a protective layer that shields the underlying metal from oxidation.
This protective layer can be studied using scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).
Globular clusters are excellent tools for probing the chemical enrichment history of their host galaxies, especially during the high redshift period, when most star formation occurs.
We analyzed high-resolution ultraviolet-visible photometric data obtained from the SUVERAMA survey of 23 galaxy clusters in the Fornax cluster.

We found that the color-metallicity relation of star clusters is more compact than that observed in recent studies of the halo population of the Milky Way. Moreover, we also show that the color-metallicity relation of Milky Way star clusters can be parameterized as a function of the host galaxy's elliptical mass.

Using this empirical relationship, we demonstrate that the metallicity of star clusters in host galaxies with solar mass peaks, and there is no evidence of subsequent stellar population gradients within the individual clusters.

We suggest that the tight color-metallicity relationship in globular clusters of the Milky Way is driven by deeper gravitational wells of more massive galaxies, while in individual clusters, the metallicity peaks at approximately the same value, regardless of the mass of the host galaxy.

We also compared our research results with the results of cosmological hydrodynamic simulations, showing that the peak metallicity of globular clusters in the Milky Way is roughly consistent with the highest values observed in the cores of simulated galaxy clusters.
However, it is currently unclear whether the observed abundance trends related to the host sphere mass can be consistent with high-redshift galaxies in simulations.

Our results provide new empirical constraints on the efficiency of chemical enrichment in galaxy clusters, while also improving the empirical scaling relations for metal-rich globular cluster systems in the Galaxy.

We finally emphasized several directions for future research on this unique system: (1) radial abundance trends within individual globular clusters, (2) the largest galaxies in the Milky Way and their globular cluster groups, (3) the Fornax cluster itself, and (4) the comparison between our empirically derived relationships and the results of large cosmological simulations.
We discussed several ideas for future work based on our findings: 1.
Can we use the abundance trends observed in individual globular clusters within galaxies to deepen our understanding of the enrichment processes in clusters?

Should we extend the color-metallicity relationship of galaxy clusters to higher quality parent galaxies?
Our research results indicate whether the Fornax cluster suggests a deviation from the global trend of galactic clusters.
