We indicate that understanding the enrichment of globular clusters within galaxy clusters is particularly significant for our comprehension of high-redshift galaxy clusters and the metallic enrichment properties of the largest galaxies in the early universe.

Our research results further demonstrate the success of the Milky Way halo as a cosmological simulator and inspire broader considerations of how the Milky Way globular cluster system can provide insights into the chemical enrichment of galaxy clusters across different redshift ranges.
The multiferroic material BiFeO$_3$ exhibits the dual characteristics of ferromagnetism and ferroelectricity, resulting in fascinating electromagnetic properties.
In the latter, electric field control of magnetization holds great appeal for potential applications.
The early model of this magnetic ferroelectric material considered the origin of magnetoelectric behavior, combining direct coupling between the electric order and magnetic order parameters.

We demonstrated, through the combination of neutron scattering, reciprocal space mapping, and first-principles calculations, that in BiFeO$_3$, this coupling is actually much weaker than expected, and no long-range magnetic order was observed even in a magnetic field of up to 16 T. These findings suggest that the observed magnetoelectric response is more likely mediated by modifications of magnetic exchange interactions caused by polarization.
The compound BiFeO$_3$ in Chinese is written as "bismuth ferrite."
At low temperatures, it exhibits two ordered states of ferromagnetism and ferroelectricity, resulting in fascinating electromagnetic properties.
For the latter, electric field control of magnetization is very appealing for potential applications.
The early magnetic ferroelectric model considered the source of magnetoelectric behavior, which included a direct coupling between the electric ordering and magnetic ordering parameters.

Through a combination of neutron scattering, reciprocal space mapping, and first-principles calculations, we demonstrate that this coupling in BiFeO$_3$ is actually much weaker than expected, and no evidence of long-range magnetic order was found even in magnetic fields as high as 16 T. These findings suggest that the observed magnetoelectric response is more likely mediated by modifications of the magnetoexchange interaction induced by polarization.

The study investigated the two-dimensional extension of the t-J model with alternating symbols on neighboring sites, referred to as the extended t-J model, using the mean-field approximation in the large N limit.

We found that in the case of resonance filling, where one-quarter of the lattice sites are occupied and two-thirds of those sites are occupied by fermions, this model possesses not only a magnetically ordered Néel phase and a stripe phase but also an additional non-magnetic phase.
We refer to this phase as the exotic Niel phase, as it breaks lattice symmetry and spin symmetry.

We provided numerical evidence that the perturbation of the heterogeneous Nèel relative long-range density-density interaction is stable, and that at larger N, the model exhibits a non-magnetic phase that includes resonating valence bond (RVB) and Fermi liquid phases.

We provided a heuristic argument showing that under appropriate twisted boundary conditions and special double degeneracy, the external Nèel phase is likely to appear in the large N SU(2) symmetric spin models, especially on a square lattice.
We also speculated on the possible experimental features.
Driven by internal noise and external periodic forces, chemical or biological oscillator systems may synchronize.
According to the amplitude and frequency of the noise and force, the resonator may be excited to a state of desynchronization, or it may not.
In this article, we investigate the propagation of synchronized waves in the excitatory system under such incentive conditions.
This kind of wave is understood as a traveling wave solution belonging to a simplified equation that captures the dominant order dynamics.

We characterize the excitation conditions as noise intensity and distance from the excitation threshold, and indicate that when these conditions are met, the wavefront is determined by a simple phase reaction equation that involves the gradient of the phase function.
Through the application of multi-scale analysis, we have derived a waveform equation characterized by a universal amplitude and phase shift formula, which we have rigorously demonstrated.

We conduct a linear stability analysis, which shows that the waveforms determined by the amplitude formula are linearly stable, while the phase shift formula generates a critical wave number that determines the size of the unstable region.
Finally, we conducted numerical simulations to confirm the analysis results and validate the formula for the critical wave number.
For this paper, we consider single-antenna transmission over a fading channel with infinite backlogs.
We analyzed the average end-to-end distortion of a simple Proportional-Integral (PI) regulator that adjusts the transmit signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) based on a linear fading channel noise model.

Unlike traditional end-to-end distortion minimization methods, which attempt to learn the statistical channel state information (CSI) of the transmitter, we assume that the transmitter has only one channel state, meaning that the transmitter has perfect CSI.
We first derive the maximum average distortion rate function in the case of an infinite buffer.
Then, we characterized the average distortion for the case of a finite buffer and further extended our results to the general case with non-vanishing delay.

Our results indicate that although CSI helps improve performance within a high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) range, reducing buffer size is critical for minimizing average distortion across all SNR values.
In a vacuum, a decaying wave packet on an atom is delayed by the surface due to the mismatch of dispersion.
Due to the difference in propagation speed, the probability of the system entering an excited state of potential energy is non-zero.
We call this phenomenon super acceleration.
The probability of ultrahigh-speed increases numerically with the intensity of the surface potential and decreases with the increase of the wave packet momentum.
Super acceleration may provide a new way to protect quantum information from decoherence.
In a vacuum, atoms will decay to the vacuum state; however, if the atoms are influenced by a surface, this may increase the probability of the atoms transitioning to an excited state.
We demonstrated this phenomenon, called superacceleration, and showed that it is caused by the difference in propagation speed between the decaying wave packet and the induced surface potential.
We calculated the probability of super-acceleration and found that it increases with the intensity of the surface potential and decreases with the decrease of the wave packet's momentum.
"Ultra-fast enhancement may provide a novel approach to protecting quantum information from decoherence."
Synaptic transmission is affected by continuous fluctuations, which are commonly referred to as "background noise."
This background noise profoundly alters the representation of incoming synaptic currents in postsynaptic cells, which may in turn affect neural processing and behavior.
We used layer 2/3 neurons from brain slices to perform whole-cell voltage clamp recordings in order to characterize the noise present at individual excitatory and inhibitory synaptic contacts.
We found that the power spectrum of synaptic current fluctuations is typically very low-pass, with the corner frequency varying between synapses but usually around ten hertz.

Next, we constructed a computational model to simulate a layer of neurons with approximately 5000 synapses, incorporating empirical estimates of the amplitude and cutoff frequency of synaptic current fluctuations.
We then used a numerical technique known in dynamic grid simulations to predict the voltage response of neurons to arbitrary synaptic current inputs.

We found that fluctuations in synaptic current often widen and lower the amplitude of the postsynaptic voltage response to abrupt changes in current input, while also introducing significant variability that affects the time required for the voltage response to reach its peak.

The former effect may reduce the efficiency of synaptic transmission, while the latter may have broad physiological significance, potentially leading to the decoupling of noise-induced postsynaptic spike timing.
The intervening metal systems in the line of sight of gamma-ray bursts and quasars (QSOs) provide an opportunity to measure the distribution of heavy elements in the early universe.
Using observational data from the Keck I telescope and the Hubble Space Telescope, I studied the distribution of carbon, oxygen, and magnesium in the universe at z > 6.5.

Although carbon and oxygen are relatively evenly distributed, the abundance of magnesium is still depleted at a significance level of 4.2σ in the host of the highest redshift quasar with a redshift of z = 6.5.

If the abundance pattern of the interstellar medium (ISM) in the Milky Way (MW) can be applied to these distant galaxies, then most of the magnesium deficiency is formed at a redshift of z = 9.1 ± 2.3.
If we apply the abundance pattern of local galaxy cluster gas, the implied formation redshift is z = 6.5 ± 0.7.
In the hosts of gamma-ray bursts, a possible local galaxy cluster disruptor was reduced to a 2.6σ level at z = 0.48, while at z = 6.5 it is consistent with the formation at z = 9.1 ± 2.3.

The highest redshift quasars and gamma-ray burst sightlines at redshifts of z = 6.5 ± 0.7 and z = 9.1 ± 2.3 showed no evidence of element depletion, suggesting that the first galaxies may not have undergone the same chemical enrichment processes as local galaxy gas.

This study is the first measurement of the early cosmic chemical evolution, extending beyond the range of the EUCLID satellite, and it may be the most precise measurement before observing higher redshift galaxies with the James Webb Space Telescope or other future telescopes.
This article employs a multi-level statistical analysis method to study the role of behavioral factors and demographic factors in determining the size of enterprises.

We found that the differences in company size among agents are significantly related to the behaviors (i.e., strategies) they use in interactions, but are not related to demographic factors such as gender, age, or position.
We also found that the same behavioral factors are significantly related to the size of the agent population, but the degree of correlation is relatively small.
These findings are significant for understanding why the sizes of enterprises vary and provide new perspectives for discussions on strategy and organizational behavior.
This paper uses multi-level statistical analysis to study the role of behavioral and demographic factors in determining the size of enterprises.

We found that the differences in company size among different agents are significantly related to the behaviors (i.e., strategies) used by these agents in interactions, but not related to demographic factors such as gender, age, or position.
We also found that the same behavioral factors are significantly related to the size of the agent population, but the degree of correlation is relatively small.
These findings are significant for understanding why there are differences in scale among companies and provide a new perspective for discussions on strategy and organizational behavior.
We study the firm size effect (FSE), which is the observation that in economic systems, large firms are often larger than small firms of equal size.
This common variation in size within the data has sparked decades of debate about its causes.
We analyzed a large amount of data from Poland, and the results indicate that FSE is primarily explained by behavioral changes.
We use a hierarchical clustering method based on strategy similarity to divide the samples into several agent groups.
The analysis shows that similar groups of agents using comparable strategies occupy the majority of the FSE.
However, for each strategic group, the FSE disappeared.
These findings are significant for understanding FSE and provide a new perspective for discussions on strategy and organizational behavior.
Researchers around the world are creating increasingly complex large-scale cosmic simulations.
These simulations, referred to as "models," are used to make predictions about the universe and can be compared against observations of the universe for testing.
A very successful model that explains the vast amount of data from the early universe is the "Λ Cold Dark Matter" model, abbreviated as ΛCDM.
It assumes that the universe is composed of about 72% dark energy, 23% dark matter, and only 5% ordinary matter, including photons, electrons, and neutrinos, among other leptons.

Neutrinos are especially important because they are extremely difficult to observe directly, but their existence is crucial for maintaining the flatness of the universe and preventing the universe from collapsing back onto itself.
The neutrinos mentioned in the model are referred to as "neutrino mass," and the phenomenon of neutrino mass is one of the most mysterious phenomena in all of science.

In the early 2000s, the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) detected a significant reduction in the speed of neutrinos moving through spacetime, indicating that neutrinos may have a small but non-zero mass.
However, many observations since then have failed to detect a decrease in this speed, which would be expected if the neutrino mass is as small as 0.1 eV.
On the other hand, various extensions of the standard particle physics model suggest that neutrinos may have a non-zero mass.
These include the swing mechanism, which assumes the existence of right-handed neutrinos.
By introducing a certain symmetry that forces the right-handed neutrinos to have a non-zero but small mass, the standard model of particle physics can be extended to the sawtooth model.
Additional experimental evidence supporting neutrino mass includes the observation of neutrino oscillations, which indicate that at least two neutrinos have non-zero but different masses.
In addition, cosmology indicates that if neutrinos have a non-zero mass, their "normal" mass must be about 0.05 eV or lower.
If the mass of neutrinos is confirmed, they will be the first fundamental particles proven to have this property.
Although their interaction remains an unsolved mystery to this day, neutrinos are the only known particles that can interact through weak interactions, which can occur over such large distances.
The observation of neutrino mass will be a significant breakthrough in our understanding of the universe.
The energy of cosmic rays exceeds \(10^{15}\) eV, and it is believed that they interact with the atmosphere of our planet. Compared to the flux at lower energy, their flux is significantly reduced.
In the energy spectrum of these cosmic rays, the so-called "knee" is defined as the energy at which the differential flux becomes roughly constant.
There are two contradictory hypotheses regarding the nature of this "knee."

One hypothesis attributes the knee point to the suppression of the spectral index of cosmic ray energy observed in experiments flying at lower altitudes, while another hypothesis posits that the knee point is an actual change in the energy spectrum of primary cosmic rays.
To resolve this dispute, it is important to have a method to determine the energy of primary cosmic rays with sufficient precision to detect changes or determine whether there is flux suppression.

The GAMMA (Gamma-Ray Astronomy in the Era of Initiatives) experiment aims to detect gamma rays generated by the interaction of cosmic rays in the atmosphere. It may contribute to this issue because, unlike most other cosmic ray experiments, it can measure the energy of the original cosmic rays with an absolute accuracy of about 30%.
In this work, we present the primary cosmic ray spectra measured by the GAMMA experiment under four experimental setups with different stiffness.

We found that the differential flux of primary cosmic rays approximately follows a power-law relationship with an exponent of -2.59 in energy, applicable for rigidity greater than \( 10^{18.5} \, \text{eV}/(\gamma - 1) \), where \( \gamma \) is the Lorentz factor of the primary cosmic rays.
Under the rigidity between \(10^{18.5}\) and \(10^{17.5}\) eV/(γ-1), the energy spectrum of cosmic rays begins to slowly flatten, indicating that the energy spectrum may change.
However, the available statistical data does not allow us to determine whether this change is statistically significant.
The giant molecular cloud discovered by Swedish amateur astronomer George Bavek in 1703 is still known as the Shinano Mountain Molecular Cloud.

The molecular cloud is located in the southern celestial hemisphere and is approximately 5.5 thousand light-years away from Earth, making it the farthest celestial object to have its molecular gas distribution spatially mapped to date.

Using the Yebian Mountain Radio Astronomy Observatory, we conducted mapping of carbon monoxide distribution in a portion of 25 nearby spiral galaxies and found that barred spiral galaxies have a greater abundance of molecular gas compared to non-barred spiral galaxies of similar optical brightness.
We propose that the strong pillars associated with the larger uplift stabilized the potential energy, thereby promoting the formation of more molecular gas.

It is now widely known that barred spiral galaxies are more abundant in the universe than non-barred spiral galaxies, indicating that bar structures play an important role in the evolution of galaxies.
Our findings support the view that bars in galaxy structures promote the evolution of host galaxies, possibly by facilitating the transfer of gas to the central regions.
The gas there has formed a stable circumnuclear region and has generated new generations of stars through the interstellar medium, leading to the formation of increasingly larger bulges.

The atomic simulation based on density functional theory (DFT) investigates the dissociation of oxygen molecules on the Al(111) surface.

The calculation is carried out using the rapid adiabatic following method, which allows for the description of non-adiabatic dynamics by solving the time-dependent Schrödinger equation on the mixed normal-Wigner representation of the Hamiltonian.
The simulation method first verifies the association path and dissociation path through experimental reaction coordinates.
The result subsequently presented the first true non-adiabatic dynamical simulation of the dissociation of oxygen molecules on Al(111).
Research has found that non-adiabatic effects can play an important role in both the concerted pathway and the dissociative pathway, particularly by influencing the transition state ensemble.
The influence of the matrix during the dissociation process was ultimately discussed.
In particular, these simulations provide a first description of the non-adiabatic dissociation process of O2 molecules on the Al(111) surface.
The simulation results indicate that the dissociation path is non-adiabatic, while the association path is adiabatic before the transition state.
In the dissociation path, the non-adiabatic coupling is very strong at the entrance of the transition state, while it can be ignored in the association path.
Finally, the simulation results demonstrate that the substrate plays an important role in the dissociation process.
The aluminum (111) surface has two stable configurations for oxygen molecules (O2): 1x2 and 2x2.

The 1x2 structure corresponds to linear geometry, with the oxygen atom located at the top position, while the two hydrogen atoms are positioned in the bridging positions; on the other hand, the 2x2 structure corresponds to bent geometry, with the oxygen atom located in the second position.
The orientations of the molecular axes of these two structures are different.
In the content below, we can refer to the 2x2 O2 structure as "curved type" and the 1x2 O2 structure as "linear type."
Initially, the O2 molecules are located on the surface with a linear geometric configuration, either in the top position or in the bridge position.
Sufficiently high energy excitation will lead to the reorientation of the molecular axis, forming a 1x2 O2 structure, with the molecular axes pointing towards the substrate.
The nuclear wave packet corresponding to this excitation has a large amplitude at the top position of the linear structure, while it nearly disappears at the bridge position.
These simulations indicate that the molecular axis is located above the bridge site on the aluminum surface, which is consistent with experimental observations.
This excitation will also lead to the dissociation of O2 molecules into two atomic oxygen atoms.
However, initially, only a small portion of wave packets limited to the linear structure participated in the dissociation process, which is in very good agreement with the existing experimental data.
This means that the associated channel is adiabatic.
From this work, we take a step further to consider the non-adiabatic dynamics of the two paths.

The long wavelength (low frequency) dynamics of liquids (such as water) seem to be well described by the Stokes equation.
In this limit, viscosity transmits the local divergence of the velocity field.
The incompressibility of a liquid also implies the divergence of the stress tensor.
The balance of forces alternates between stress and elastic force, resulting in an inherent shear wave whose amplitude decreases inversely with the square of the distance from the forcing point.
These few simple assumptions are sufficient to explain most of the complex nonequilibrium phenomena of Newtonian fluids in low-frequency rheology.
However, in practical applications, most real-world liquids have non-Newtonian characteristics.
This is particularly evident in the limit of long wavelengths, where the elastic force becomes negligible compared to the viscous force.
In this extreme, the only enforcing mechanism is viscosity.
It remains to be seen whether this simple model can explain the low-frequency rheological properties of this fluid.

Recent cosmological simulations show that galaxy evolution has reproduced the morphology-density relation and star formation rate-density relation observed in local galaxies.
These simulations cannot reproduce the complete distribution of galactic properties at low and high redshifts.
Research has shown that the feedback from active galactic nuclei (AGN) and quasars may play a role in regulating star formation in their host galaxies.

In this article, we present a set of high-resolution cosmological hydrodynamic simulations, focusing on a small portion of galaxies within a single volume in large-scale modern simulations, which include a simple radio-mode feedback model.

The characteristic of this model is a constant Bondi-Hoyle-Lyttleton accretion rate applied to supermassive black holes, with the accretion rate adjusted so that active galactic nuclei (AGNs) contribute a specified amount of radio heating to the interstellar medium.

We chose a simulation with volume limitations that addresses all galaxies exceeding a given mass. It includes stellar feedback, active galactic nucleus (AGN) feedback, and the influence of evolving gas properties from a larger simulation.

We found that even in the absence of starbursts triggered by active galactic nuclei, the momentum input from radio-mode feedback is sufficient to significantly disturb the cold flows that form the cores of cooling galaxy clusters, thereby suppressing the formation of bright elliptical galaxies.
At the same time, this feedback is not sufficient to completely disrupt the cluster.
In low-quality galaxies, below the critical cluster mass, we did not observe a significant suppression of star formation, although we did find a decrease in stellar metallicity and stellar density.

We conclude that although radio mode feedback is an effective regulator of star formation in the early universe, it is not sufficient on its own to reproduce the complete distribution of galaxies in the Hubble sequence.
Fourier analysis in similar spaces has a long-standing tradition in the field of analysis.
The convolution of local tight groups is one of the most important and widely studied operations.

In comparison, the development of Fourier analysis on semi-simple Lie groups and their homogeneous spaces is relatively lagging, although they naturally arise in the representation theory of Lie groups.
In this paper, we establish convolution results for these groups by mimicking the case of local compactness.

In particular, we show that if \( G \) is a semisimple Lie group and \( K \) is a compact abelian subgroup, then the natural correspondence of the convolution operator on the unit dual of \( G \) is also a associative algebra multiplication on the function algebra of \( G/K \). We also discuss some related results and examples.
This work is part of a series in which we explore the structure and representation theory of semisimple Lie groups and their homogeneous spaces.

In this article, we investigate the effect of confining a hard sphere fluid between two parallel hard walls on its average properties.
First, we calculate the perturbation corrections in the equation of state for an ideal hard sphere fluid.
When the fluid density in the wall is low and the spacing between the walls is much greater than the particle diameter, this correction decreases exponentially.
Using this perturbation result, we demonstrate that the change in average fluid density due to constraints is proportional to the volume of the space enclosed by the constraint walls.
Next, we examine the impact of constraints on the structural factors and demonstrate that this is also proportional to the volume of the space.
We also calculated the effect of constraints on sound velocity and mutual diffusion coefficients, indicating that they are independent of the volume of the confined space.
Our results indicate that the restrictions have almost no effect on the average entropy, enthalpy, heat capacity, viscosity, and self-diffusion rate of hard-sphere fluids.
Large spiral galaxies have been found to have statistically significantOrdered magnetic fields.
The intensity range of these fields varies from several Gauss to tens of milliGauss, with a polar structure, and there are basically field-free regions near the edges of galaxies.

These fields consist of large-scale longitudinal components and small-scale circumferential components; in other words, these fields roughly resemble the product of a large-scale longitudinal vector and a small-scale circumferential scalar.
Magnetic energy is usually between 10^-18 to 10^-16 joules, or between 10^44 to 10^-15 erg.

The average gas pressure in galaxies is sufficiently high (ranging from several times 10−13 to several times 10−12 pascals), and the observed field strength can be produced through the equipartition of energy between gas pressure and field pressure.

In this article, we propose a linear reconstruction of the Kuramoto model for self-synchronizing oscillators.

Specifically, we consider a network where each node has a dimensional variable, and all nodes are connected by an undirected network. The coupling function is a function of the difference in dimensional variables of the connected nodes, and all nodes are identical.
We prove that this model can be expressed in a coupled form of diagonal and scalar ordinary differential equations.
We then use the Schur complement to simplify the dynamics in the original model into this diagonal plus scalar system.

We analyzed the equilibrium state of the simplified model and indicated that in certain cases, the simplified model may exhibit oscillatory and chaotic behavior that is not present in the original model.
We also indicate that when certain conditions of the coupling and dimension variables are met, the dynamics of the original system propagate into the reduced system without loss.

Massive Young Stellar Objects (MYSOs) are among the brightest and most turbulent entities in the interstellar medium, but their complex structures and transition towards rich star clusters make studying them challenging.
In this letter, we conducted a multi-time period high-frequency radio continuous wave study of a sample of 38 massive young stellar object (MYSO) formation regions.
These sources were selected as strong water megamasers, which are potential indicators of high-quality star formation.
We found a relatively high incidence of positive spectral index gradients (approximately half of the samples), and these gradients are usually large and show variability on the scale of weeks.

We interpret the variations in free-free radiation primarily as being driven by the shock waves generated by outflows and jets of the protostar, which is consistent with recent findings at lower frequencies.
We also found that there is a large number of sources with negative spectral index gradients, which may be due to free-free radiation from ionized accretion material.

The infrared photometry, inferred mass accretion rates, and spectral gradient characteristics of this sample suggest that many of these sources may be transitioning from massive young stellar objects (MYSOs) to evolved stars with ionized inner disks, or transitioning to lower-mass stars with circumstellar disks.
A droplet about to land bounces on a smooth, horizontal surface, appearing to the observer as a sphere of constant size.
The translation of "它的大小实际变化了多少？" into English is "How much has its size actually changed?"
The obvious answer is that it rebounds as a whole, distributing lift throughout the entire descent process.
This simple model is called the unit rebound, which was proposed in the 17th century and corresponded with experimental results until the end of the 19th century.
Since then, droplets have shown uneven size changes when bouncing on solid surfaces at higher relative humidity (RH): they are found to shrink in some areas while growing in others.
This phenomenon is called non-uniform rebound, first observed in 1908, and there are now many videos that have documented it in detail.
This phenomenon is counterintuitive and may not conform to the classical rebound model.
We proposed a simple model to predict the lifespan of bouncing droplets and showed that it is finite.
After briefly describing the qualitative features of the model, we will introduce a more detailed model that involves a partial differential equation and is solved using numerical methods.
The solution replicates the key features of the observed non-uniform rebound: the areas of contraction and expansion, along with their lifecycles.

Then, we discussed various physical mechanisms that can explain the observed effects, including those within the proposed model framework as well as within the more standard framework of droplet rebound.

Recent progress in viewing Dynamical Mean Field Theory (DMFT) as a constrained variational program has made its efficient numerical implementation in the Linear Muffin-Tin Approximation (LMTA) possible.
We report the first realization of this kind, which allows for the computation of fermion self-energy and related response functions.

In this implementation, by combining the direct partial derivatives of the LMTA equation with the constraints of charge density, it ensures the absence of double counting interactions and response functions similar to the Hartree-Fock conditions.

Using the LDA+DMFT approximation to test the photoluminescence spectra of a half-filled three-dimensional Bethe lattice, we demonstrate that the charge density profile results produced by the obtained scheme are in good agreement with the profiles obtained from the full solutions of the LDA+DMFT equations, while significantly reducing the computation cost.
The application of the linear muffin-tin approximation to dynamical mean-field theory (DMFT) has so far been limited to the calculation of fermion self-energies and related response functions.
We report the first implementation of this kind, which allows for the calculation of fermion self-energy and related response functions.

In this implementation, by combining the simple partial derivatives of the LMTA equations with constraints on the charge density, conditions similar to those of Hartree-Fock are ensured to avoid double counting interactions and response functions.

Using the LDA+DMFT approximation with half-filled three-dimensional Bethe lattice photoemission spectra as a test case, we demonstrate that the charge density profile obtained from this scheme is very consistent with results obtained from the complete solution of the LDA+DMFT equations, while significantly reducing the computational cost.
Theory Recently, a method has been proposed to perform dynamical mean field theory (DMFT) in the context of linear muffin-tin approximation (LMTA).
The resulting method is both efficient and accurate, and has been widely used in the study of electronic structures in metals and strongly correlated systems.

In this implementation, by combining the simple partial derivatives of the LMTA equation with the constraints of the charge density, conditions similar to those of Hartree-Fock are ensured, avoiding double counting of interaction and response functions.

From this work, we report the first calculation of dynamic response functions within the framework of local many-body time-dependent interactions (LMTA), showing that the charge density distribution produced by this method is in very good agreement with the results obtained by fully solving the LDA+DMFT equations, while the computational cost is significantly reduced.

In dissipative particle dynamics (DPD), the interactions between different particles are modeled through short-range, collision-driven forces that are approximately zero-mean and have specified autocorrelation functions.
This method treats short-range interactions as Gaussian white noise, which is accurate for cases where the particle separation is much larger than the dissipation length scale.
At smaller separation distances, the separation between force and its base velocity, influenced by correlations, causes the noise to become non-Gaussian.

We determined an effective random interaction by measuring the correlation between force and speed at several different distances and using least squares fitting to derive a two-point covariance function.

The covariance function allows for a better approximation of non-Gaussian force correlations at medium distances by enabling short-range random interactions, while still effectively coupling at long distances, as the noise approaches Gaussianity in that regime.

The obtained DPD equations of motion are integrated using a stochastic velocity-Verlet algorithm, and the accuracy of the effective interactions is tested by comparing with simulations of thermal equilibrium behavior.
We present the numerical results of the observables of three-nucleon systems in nuclear matter as a function of the π meson mass.

The predictions were obtained within the framework of coupled cluster expansion, using two types of interaction nuclei: one is the long-range interaction, corresponding to the leading order of the systematic chiral perturbation theory (ChPT), and the other is the short-range interaction, corresponding to the two-nucleon contact interaction.

We demonstrated that for observables related to nuclear matter saturation, the convergence of results towards the physical point depends on the range of interactions, with shorter-range nucleons exhibiting faster convergence.

Through the supplement, it is predicted that for a given range of interactions, the dependence of meson mass on density increases as the density of the considered system decreases, that is, with the increase of the interaction range.

Finally, we believe that in order to correctly describe the evolution of nuclear many-body systems with QCD scale, an appropriate renormalization group analysis should be conducted to study the effective field theory.
Using observations from the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope, we have detected gamma rays from 37 supernova remnants (SNRs).
Gamma rays are primarily dominated by hadrons, accompanied by a small amount of bremsstrahlung radiation components.
The observed gamma-ray spectrum can be well fitted using a single power law of energy, with the exponent ranging from 2.0 to 2.7.

The gamma-ray efficiency, which refers to the proportion of energy released in the form of gamma rays during a supernova explosion, is about 1% for young supernova remnants (SNRs), and it increases with age as the amount of gas affected by the shock wave also increases.
The production rate of strong gamma rays is only a few percent of the historical yield, which indicates that cosmic ray particles pass through a dense medium with relatively mild interactions.

We conclude that the observed gamma rays are consistent with the results of the interaction between atomic nuclei and background protons, although the uncertainties in the local cosmic ray density and composition are large enough to allow for significant contributions from electrons and dark matter particles.

The detection of gamma rays from young and middle-aged supernova remnants (SNRs), without corresponding radio synchrotron emissions, presents challenges to the existing models for gamma-ray production in supernova remnants.
Using the Mileura Widefield Array Low Frequency Demonstrator System, we report on observations of the Crab Pulsar (GCTs).
The Miller-A field is located about 1260 kilometers from the center of the Moon and exhibits strong Faraday rotation.
In 2016, we recorded 20 hours of observations, during which we detected 5 GCTs and determined the Faraday rotation measurement (RM) after each pulse.
We also triggered the 1.2 MHz recording mode at two adjacent north-south positions in the array simultaneously.
In this frequency band, we detected two GCTs, but due to the long field of view of the array, the accuracy is only at the sub-meter level.
We estimate the distance between GCTs based on dispersion measurements (DM) and rotation measurements (RM), and limit its magnitude to about 1 milliarcsecond.
The DM and RM vectors we detected are generally aligned with the center of the GCT peak, which is consistent with the extreme magneto-ionic conditions in the magnetosphere of the crab pulsar.

The results presented in this study indicate that the Mileura wide-field array has the sensitivity to detect the material density (DM) of millisecond pulsars (GCTs) up to approximately 15 pc/cm³, and it demonstrates the ability to conduct a multi-frequency search for variations in material density (DM) and rotation measures (RM) in the pulses of millisecond pulsars.
Such observations can potentially detect the rotation of the Earth relative to the magnetosphere of a rotating neutron star.

The purpose of this article is to describe a fast data acquisition method based on Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Automatic Relevance Determination (ARD), intended for use in earth science applications.

The proposed method has been applied in the field of hydrogeology, where the data obtained comes from ground penetrating radar (GPR) signals that were recorded in the same area where pressure changes need to be estimated.
The proposed methodology includes two steps.
First, several signals were recorded under different conditions, from which a set of data will be selected for the learning process.
The selection criteria are based on the prediction errors calculated from the model, assuming the use of a Kalman Filter (KF) structure, utilizing the recorded data to predict pressure changes.
Secondly, principal component analysis is applied to the selected data to reduce dimensionality and obtain a low-cost model.
The proposed methodology was tested using artificial data and compared with ARD technology, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed method.
We reported the detection of magnetic-driven explosions in six rapidly rotating white dwarfs (WDs) that occurred after accretion-induced collapse.
The survey used the ASAS-SN virtual telescope, which monitors the entire visible sky every few hours.
Such explosions have not been observed in these celestial bodies before, as all known instances come from low-mass white dwarfs.
The characteristics of these explosions are a rapid increase in brightness a few days before the explosion, followed by a stable phase, and finally a gradual decline in brightness.
This plateau is caused by the ongoing collapse of a rotating white dwarf into a neutron star or black hole.

The explosion was confirmed by the potential plateau that appeared in the subsequent light curve, a phenomenon that was not observed in the case of stable nuclear burning on the surface of a white dwarf.
The duration and brightness of the platform are consistent with the expected range of projectile mass.

We compared the observational results with one-dimensional hydrodynamic simulations of accretion-induced collapse, both with and without strong magnetic fields, and found that the simulations including magnetic fields best reproduce these emissions.

We calculated that the magnetic field required to drive the explosion is approximately 100 MG, which exceeds the capabilities of future large magnet facilities, such as the EU's Exawatt plasma research center and NASA's long-term balloon projects.
Here, we report the detection of six exploding white dwarfs, all of which have previously been observed by ASAS-SN.

Among these six, four show similar light curves of a platform, with a noticeable decrease in brightness in the days leading up to the explosion, which is consistent with previous reports on low-mass white dwarf magnetic-driven explosions.

Two additional celestial bodies, SDSS J0804+2052 and SDSS J2315+1855, have shown a significant flat decline following a previous increase in brightness, which is consistent with the scenario of magnetic explosions driven by rapidly rotating white dwarfs, marking this as the first occurrence.

We compared the observed duration of the stability and brightness with simulations that included and did not include magnetic fields, and found that the emissions from both types of simulations best matched those from the simulations that included magnetic fields.

Based on the duration and luminosity of the platform we measured, we calculated the mass of the ejecta corresponding to each event and found that these are consistent with the expected range of materials ejected in such explosions.

We also identified potential host star locations by cross-referencing our samples with Gaia Data Release 2, and found that four outbursting white dwarfs are most likely to be observed within the fields of view of their respective host galaxies.
This is consistent with the following view: explosions from rapidly rotating white dwarfs are more likely to be detected from their host galaxies than explosions from low-mass white dwarfs.

Our research results indicate that the magnetic field has a significant impact on the explosion mechanisms and outcomes in this astrophysical scenario, and such an explosion is a promising way to maintain mass in rapidly rotating white dwarfs.

WZ Sge was initially identified as a strong-interaction binary system, consisting of a K-type donor star and a white dwarf companion.
Using very recent data, WZ Sge is still a unique example of a dwarf nova with an exceptionally fast outburst rate.
The outbreak from 2017 was only recently captured by ASAS-SN.
WZ Sge is known to have the longest outburst interval among the known dwarf novae.
Here, we report the results of long-term photometric and spectroscopic monitoring of WZ Sge since 2010.
Our dataset covers 19 outbursts of WZ Sge, including one normal outburst and several normal non-outburst intervals.

Particle physics is an exciting field of science, and the discovery of the Higgs boson has completed the foundational work needed to understand the universe.
In the open access publishing model, authors pay publication fees instead of reading fees, which has led to a significant increase in the quantity of research publications.

The increase in publication volume has the potential to significantly enhance our collective understanding of the universe; however, for researchers outside the field, understanding these papers and the datasets they reference may be quite challenging.
In this article, we provide a brief introduction to the open access publishing model for non-experts, and highlight some of the more interesting articles published in this emerging research field.
We hope this will serve as an introductory resource to help those interested in this emerging field of research, and encourage in-depth studies of specific topics in particle physics.

Under the limit of zero aspect ratio, the two-dimensional Ising model with strong square coupling undergoes a continuous phase transition at temperature \( T_c \). In the low-temperature phase, the interfaces are fixed by Gaussian disorder, while in the high-temperature phase, they are not fixed.

Through Monte Carlo simulation, we estimate the critical exponent related to the order of the phase transition to be \( \nu = 1.23(2) \), which is consistent with the theoretical prediction of \( \nu = 4/11 \approx 0.3622 \).
We propose an efficient dynamic renormalization group (DRG) approximation method to address this issue.
The effective interfacial tension and Gaussian disorder strength of the DRG flow display are inconsistent with the fixed point of the two-sided free field.
This indicates whether the transition is indeed continuous.
The predicted critical exponents are \( \beta = 1.25(5) \) and \( \gamma = 0.38(1) \).
Our DRG results were compared with the strong coupling expansion of [1], and we found that there is good quantitative consistency between the two for T < Tc.
After exceeding Tc, our DRG flow cannot converge, and we must seek a new fixed point with non-trivial field content.

In quantum mechanics, the density operator is a Hermitian operator with a projection value, used to represent the state of a quantum system that has uncertainty.
The density operator is a fundamental and important mathematical object in quantum mechanics, which encapsulates the statistical information of a quantum system.
In this article, we study the geometry of the set of all density operators on the complex Hilbert space, namely the space of quantum states.
Firstly, we propose a generalized von Neumann entropy and describe the entropy landscape of the entire set of quantum states.
We will continue to study extremal points and convolution structures, and provide an alternative characterization of the set of physically allowable quantum states.
Next, we demonstrate that a quantum state is a density state if and only if it can be represented as a tomographic probability distribution.
By applying these results, we derive a unified geometric framework for constructing positive operators and use it to completely classify the positive mappings of trace-class operators.
As an example, we provide an explicit formula for the operator Jordan map, which can be regarded as a quantum analogue of the complex equator on the Riemann sphere.
For a family of operators related to the one-dimensional Schrödinger operator and its periodic potentials, the asymptotic behavior of the eigenfunctions in the semiclassical limit has been studied.

Using the classical launching argument, prove that the spectral problem is equivalent to a problem concerning a new family of operators, whose parameters depend on the derivatives of the periodic potential.
The new operator is defined in a "homogenized" domain, where the spectrum is assumed to be uniformly separated from the essential spectrum.
In the semiclassical limit, the family of operators transforms into a time-independent Schrödinger operator with constant coefficients.
The asymptotic behavior of the characteristic function is studied within the framework of Floquet theory, replacing fixed dispersion relations with a basis of uniformly separated spectra.
It has been proven that the characteristic function is real-valued and a trigonometric polynomial.
The semi-classical quantization condition for this potential cycle has been derived and shown to be equivalent to Gutzwiller's trace formula.
The feasible Hamiltonian has been proposed for universal adiabatic quantum computers.
Compared to earlier proposals, our Hamiltonian can be implemented on current quantum devices.
We consider a general setup to achieve a target unitary (unit operator) and adiabatic evolution over the time interval \( T \).

The generated Hamiltonian can include any terms that support the characteristic states of the initial Hamiltonian, and thus it generally cannot be expressed as a sum of the bilinear form {|,i}H{i,}{,}.
We propose a general framework to demonstrate whether the final Hamiltonian can achieve a given target unitary operator under certain rule conditions.

For a special case, when the final Hamiltonian is also a bilinear sum of the above form, we prove that this implementation can be achieved using a device composed of qubit converters and surface gate clusters.
For more general situations, we provide a clear construction based on the Kitaev quantum double model and its adaptation to surface codes.
We analyze the performance of the Hamiltonian through the Taylor series expansion.
Specifically, we demonstrate that the energy gap of the resultant Hamiltonian closes at the order of 1/T², which means the energy gap closes exponentially at the optimal rate of T⁻².

This observation implies that, for a universal T, the corresponding quantum computer still needs to have the capability of possessing an infinite number of quantum seed states in the initial Hamiltonian to compensate for the accumulation of errors.
We conclude by discussing potential directions for moving forward that may address the issue of error accumulation and improve the performance of the resulting adiabatic quantum computer.
Fossil galaxies are large galaxy clusters that have been captured by the gravitational pull of a larger central halo.
The galaxies in these clusters are early-type, similar to the way the central galaxy is described as sharp.
We study the dynamics of galaxy clusters and compare them with a subset of millennium simulations.
Although the average quality of the simulated clusters aligns with the observational values, the proportion of clusters with multiple bright members remains lower than that in the observed clusters.

We investigated the reasons and concluded that the phenomenon of low multiple occupancy in millennium simulations can be reproduced through standard interactions and mergers between galaxies, without the need to modify the mass or dynamics of the groups.
The Millennium Simulation is an N-body simulation of our universe, operated by the Virgo Consortium and funded by the American Astronomical Society.
The resolution of the simulation is about 108 times better than the resolution of the Las Campanas survey.
I compared the dynamics of galaxy clusters in the millennium simulation with the dynamics from the Las Campanas survey.
In the simulation, the proportion of groups with multiple bright members is lower than the proportion in the survey.

I investigated the reasons and concluded that the low multiplicity occupancy rate of the group in the simulation can be reproduced through standard galaxy-galaxy interactions and mergers, without the need to modify the mass or dynamics of the group.
I confirm this by comparing the group dynamics in the millennium simulation with the group dynamics in the Laskin-Pans survey.
During the simulation process, the average population mass is consistent with the observed values.
However, the proportion of groups with multiple bright members is lower than that in the survey.

I studied the reasons and concluded that the low multiple occupancy of the population in the simulation can be reproduced using the standard treatment of galaxy-galaxy interactions and mergers, without needing to modify the mass or dynamics of the population.
The general theory of relativity proposed by Einstein is the cornerstone of modern physics.
It describes gravity as the distortion of space and time, which is caused by the asymmetric distortion of space and time due to matter and energy.
Among all physical theories, general relativity is one of the most thoroughly verified theories; it has stood the test of time, and all experimental tests have passed with high precision.
However, some people speculate that a deeper understanding of gravity may require the introduction of new concepts and ideas.
As part of this trend, there has recently been interest in how we use Einstein's theory to describe the process of gravitational interaction; that is to say, renormalization.
Renormalization refers to the process of eliminating the inherent infinities in a theory by redefining the parameters of that theory.
In this process, a more general framework for gravitational theories was created, encompassing various alternative theories such as f(R) gravity.
For this article, we will study this renormalization framework.
We have provided detailed instructions for the process and a step-by-step guide for performing calculations within this framework.
We will illustrate this process through several examples, including the calculation of the effective action for the graviton system.
We conclude by discussing our findings and recommendations for future work.
The MINOS experiment at FNAL deployed the first long-baseline neutrino oscillation appearance experiment on the NuMI beamline and recently released the results from the first year.

The experiment used a setup consisting of three detectors, including an upstream detector located at the northern initial data collection station, and two downstream detectors located at the Soudan underground mine in Minnesota (northeast detector) and Saint-S in Louisiana (southwest detector).
The data collection period was from 2011 to 2012, and the total exposure of the remote detector was 2.2 tons per year.

During this period, MINOS measured the disappearance of muon neutrinos with a significance of 5.2σ and provided evidence for the appearance of electron neutrinos for the first time, with a significance of 3.6σ.
The first MINOS result paper presents new data and preliminary global fit results.
The purpose of the development of MINOS is to study the disappearance of muon neutrinos and the appearance of electron neutrinos produced by mesons.

The new dataset includes neutrino interactions with detectors during 2011 and 2012, while the global fit incorporates the complete dataset. The preliminary results presented in this paper have been updated to include the full dataset.
The main update to the new results is the reweighting of event rates based on cross-section calculations improved by the NNPDF collaboration.
This allows for a more precise estimation of the background and sensitivity of the experiment.
The experiment found no evidence for the disappearance of muon neutrinos and provided evidence for the appearance of electron neutrinos with a significance of 3.6σ.
The results have a certain degree of uncertainty, which arises from our knowledge of neutrino flux and cross sections. This knowledge has been enhanced with this update.
Dehumidification is an important microfabrication technology widely used in the manufacturing of nanoscale features in materials such as metals, semiconductors, and dielectrics.
The process relies on removing a thin layer of material from one substrate to generate a film of that material on another substrate.

The dewetting phenomenon is initiated by selectively lowering the temperature of one or more regions of the substrate material, which can be achieved through thermal, chemical, or mechanical patterning.
A typical dehumidification scenario involves removing a thin layer of material from a bulk semiconductor to create a film of that material on another substrate.
This usually leads to the formation of one or more holes, which may have sharp edges and exist as high-energy surfaces in the form of a free air interface.
In this case, an important question is the ability of the hole edges to relax to a balanced state, which requires sufficient edge energy to overcome the surface tension.
In this work, we conducted comprehensive hydrodynamic calculations on a damped circular hole that is initially circular, constrained at the edges, and can move freely in two dimensions.

We compared the evolution of hole shapes and energies, analyzed the equilibrium solutions of circular and elliptical shapes, and examined the importance of various physical mechanisms in the relaxation process, including volume diffusion, convection, and surface tension.
In recent years, the concept of emergency spacetime has emerged, attempting to unify gravity with other physical forces, especially quantum mechanics.

These emerging spacetimes have been shown to arise in a bottom-up manner from a consistent theory in higher-dimensional spacetimes, which includes d-dimensional general relativity plus a scalar field.

In this article, we present a specific choice of coupling between scalar fields and gravitational fields in a high-dimensional spacetime that possesses enhanced symmetry. This theory emerges in a higher dimension as a dual gravitational theory with doubled spacetime dimensions.
Specifically, we consider a scalar field theory with nonlinear self-interactions in a (d+1)-dimensional Minkowski space.
The equations related to motion have a key point when corresponding to empty spacetime.

We demonstrate that by introducing a new scalar field that couples to the first scalar field, the system exhibits a higher symmetry, and can be reduced to a theory in d dimensions, featuring a newly emerged ((d-1)+1)-dimensional Minkowski spacetime.
This theory allows for the existence of non-trivial solutions that describe black holes with multiple horizons, and the length scale is determined by the charge of the black hole.

In addition, in the classical solution, there exists a smooth lower-dimensional region behind the black hole horizon, where the original (d+1)-dimensional spacetime is smoothly extended, and this extension is encoded in the structure of the solitonic strings connecting the black hole horizon and the smooth region.

We analyzed the solutions with a single black hole and cosmological horizon, and found that for sufficiently large charge, the black hole horizon and cosmological horizon coincide, resulting in a triple horizon solution.
We calculated the entropy of black holes in dual gravitational theory and found that it matches the Bekenstein-Hawking entropy of black holes in the triple horizon solution.
Finally, we discuss whether the general solutions of the theory include high-dimensional Swiss-Nordström black holes, for which the gravitational theory simplifies to five dimensions.
We finally discuss the results and possible expansions.
Date: January 30, 2023

Author: José Antonio Broni  
Title: Dual Field Theory in the (d-1)+1 Emergency Spacetime Originating from Unified Field Theory in d+2 Spacetime.
The translation of "摘要：" into English is "Abstract:".
In recent years, the concept of spacetime has begun to emerge, with the aim of integrating gravity with other physical forces, especially quantum forces.

These emerging spacetime frameworks have been demonstrated to emerge from a bottom-up approach within a consistent theory of higher-dimensional spacetime, specifically through d-dimensional general relativity coupled with a scalar field.

From this article, we demonstrate that for specific coupling choices between scalar fields and gravitational fields, this higher-dimensional spacetime possesses enhanced symmetry, and the theory manifests as a dual gravity theory in a higher dimension, with doubled spacetime dimensions.
“Specifically,” in Chinese can be translated as “具体来说，” or “特别是，” depending on the context.
The formal definition of quantum zero-knowledge proofs (QKZP) has been provided by Watrous [19].
This definition uses two interactive probability protocols.
A preliminary witness generation simulates a specific probabilistic polynomial time (PPT) process.
Second, the simulator accepts any PPT program as an opponent.
A verifier selects a random prover, sends it to the simulator, and receives a response.
The response must include a polynomial-time verification condition for the original program.
If the simulator accepts the proof with at least a 2/3 probability, and the simulator in the witness generation phase has at least a 1/3 advantage, then the proof is valid.
In this article, we study the general properties of QKZP.
First, we indicate that this definition can be expressed in the language of complexity theory.
Using this fact, we demonstrate that the PSPACE hypothesis is necessary in the definition.
Then we prove that it is impossible to construct a valid QKZP with an advantage exceeding 2/3 when only accessing the original process through a black box.
These results suggest the triviality of QKZP.
We also proposed a variant of QKZP with enhanced robustness attributes.
The strengthening of reliability evidence is both challenging and intriguing in itself.
The title of the paper describes the main theme of the abstract.
The abstract is very long because it also includes the background of the topic and general comments on the paper.
A neutron star is a term used to describe a type of celestial body that is composed almost entirely of neutrons, which are subatomic particles found in atomic nuclei.
A neutron star is an extremely dense celestial body with a mass greater than that of the Sun, but with a volume of only about one cubic kilometer or smaller.
A neutron star is formed from a supernova explosion, which occurs when about 99% of a star's mass is compressed into its core.

The reason such an extreme density can be achieved is that the density of neutrons is far higher than that of normal atoms, and the strong nuclear force that binds the atomic nuclei together weakens as it approaches the core.
When the mass of the core reaches about 2 to 3 solar masses, it does not have enough mass to resist its own gravity.
The excess energy is released in the form of a supernova explosion, which is also referred to as neutron star formation.
Most neutron stars form tight binary systems with another neutron star or, less commonly, with a black hole.
These systems are called low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs).
LMXBs are interesting research systems because they allow us to study neutron stars from two perspectives.
The first is "quiescent" (also known as "non-active" or "non-pulsing"), in this state, the neutron star orbits a more compact companion star and does not emit X-rays.
The second situation is when a neutron star "temporarily" increases its X-ray emission, which is referred to as an "outburst."
When an X-ray binary (LMXB) transitions between two states, it is very interesting to study the differences between these two states.
For example, we recently showed that the phenomenon of instantaneously brighter bursts is related to the increase in the rotation period of neutron stars.

On the contrary, when the neutron star is in a stationary state, but its X-ray radiation is slightly brighter than normal, it is found that its rotation period is longer than when the source's brightness significantly decreases.
These behavioral differences suggest a "bimodal model of LMXB."

In this model, there are two different types of growth mechanisms for neutron stars, and the difference between them is explained by the different methods of capturing material and depositing it onto the surface of the neutron star.
The first type is referred to as "feeding type," in which the captured material mainly consists of protons that adhere to the surface of the neutron star, forming a structure shaped like a "spoon."
This transient is found to be brighter when the rotation rate of the neutron star is higher.
The second type is "indirect," in which the captured materials, mainly electrons and protons, form a "cloud" around the neutron star.
These transients appear brighter when observing the neutron star in a certain state.

In the direction of the Scorpius Nebula, which is 120-150 seconds away from Earth, the Blanco 1 star cluster was identified by Béjar et al. (2004) as a young open star cluster, with an estimated age of about 10 to 30 million years.
The quality of its low-quality members has not yet been directly measured.
In this work, we estimate the mass of 10^-3 Mjup substellar members by combining infrared adaptive optics imaging with high-precision radial velocity measurements.
We derive a lower mass function n(m) ~ m^ - 1.5, with a median of 0.088 Mjup, which corresponds to 7% of the cluster mass.
This is the most in-depth exploration of the interstellar regions around young star clusters to date.
The star cluster Blanco 1 contains low-mass members, ranging from 30 Jupiter masses (Mjup) to the substellar domain, with an average of 0.088 Jupiter masses (Mjup).
The lower mass function is n(m) ~ m^(-1.5).
The MiniBooNE experiment at Fermilab released new data in March 2017, which limited the possible number of sterile neutrinos mixing with ordinary neutrinos.
These results are based on data from 2008 to 2011.
The new data supports the hypothesis that there are at least two sterile neutrinos, with a mass-squared difference of (0.15 - 2.29) eV², and at least one of them has a non-zero mass.

Multiple neutrino mass scenarios have been tested, but no evidence has been found that flavor fields lead to large mass values, which is to be expected in some fundamental theories (such as the seesaw mechanism).
The oscillation parameters determined through this analysis are also consistent with the latest results from the Daya Bay and RENO experiments.
This paper provides a critical assessment of the latest results from MiniBooNE and other experiments, considering the possible existence of inert neutrino types.
We summarize three common hypotheses regarding the allowed masses and mixing of sterile neutrinos: the minimal scenario, the mixing scenario, and the double-zero scenario.
We have presented the form of each hypothesis and shown the range of oscillation parameters associated with the mass splitting of three representative light, medium, and heavy neutrinos.
We discussed potential models for the generation of sterile neutrinos, which predict different behaviors in three types of sterile neutrino mass schemes.
We conclude by summarizing the impact of recent results on massless neutrinos under possible scenarios.
Author: M. Maltoni et al.
