The weighted complexity of the graph and the determinant function are defined.

These two new graph invariants generalize several existing graph invariants, such as vertex cover, edge cover, matching, determinant, branch number, independence number, and total graph domination number.
Assign weights based on the importance of the vertices, prioritizing vertices with higher weights.
We have proven that the weighted complexity of a graph is equal to the matching complexity of its line graph, and that the determinant of a graph is equal to the branchwidth of its line graph.
We have provided several relationships among these invariants.
Specifically, we show that the weighted complexity and the determinant are both lower bounds for the matching complexity, the branching number, and the independence number.

On the other hand, we present two graphs with different weights. For these two graphs, their weighted complexity and determinant are the same, but their matching complexity and branching width are different.
We finally point out that even in the case where all weights are equal to one, the problem of computing the weighted complexity and the determinant is also NP-complete.
The interaction with proteins is crucial for the stability and function of proteins.
The internet provides a valuable tool for understanding the relationships between proteins and how these interactions influence protein function.

The clustering coefficient measures the extent to which a node is part of a local network within an interconnected cluster. It is considered a key characteristic of complex networks and has important applications in network robustness, dynamics, and heterogeneity.
In this study, we calculated the clustering coefficients of multiple protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks.
The results show that the clustering coefficient of the PPI network is generally lower than that of the corresponding random network.
Additionally, we observed that the degree distribution of the PPI network follows a power law, which may explain the low clustering coefficient of the network.
Our research findings will help to better understand the structure of the PPI network and its related biological significance.
Zhang, W., Chen, M., Zhang, L. & Wang, J. (2017).
The clustering coefficient in the protein-protein interaction network.
The translation of "arXiv 预印本 arXiv:1705.04288" into English is "arXiv preprint arXiv:1705.04288."
In this note, we point out the connection between the Leonard triples and the hypercube.
The Leonard triples are a type of vectors in Euclidean space, originating from combinations of algebraic bases associated with symplectic root systems.
We state that the entries of the Leonard triple in the first coordinate correspond to the center of the edges of the hypercube.

The translation of the Chinese sentence is:

"Ruling: On this point, we noted the connection between the Leonard triplet and the hypercube."
The Léonard triplets are a class of vectors in Euclidean space, derived from combinations of the basic bases of algebra derived from the symplectic system.
We demonstrate that the entry of a Leonard triple in the first coordinate corresponds to the center of the edge of a hypercube.

The English word "panel" can be translated into Chinese as "面板" (miànbǎn) or "小组" (xiǎozǔ), depending on the context. If referring to a physical panel (like a control panel), "面板" is appropriate. If referring to a group of people (like a panel of experts), "小组" would be more suitable.
Secondly, we show that the elements of a Leonard triple on the first coordinate correspond to the centers of the edges of a hypercube.
The Leonard triple systems are a class of vector families in Euclidean space, generated by combinations of algebraic bases from symplectic root systems.
The first member of this family was discovered by Nicolas Shahin.
HD 73526 is a spectral binary star system that consists of two stars with similar masses, which orbit around their common center of mass with a period of approximately 20.87 days.
This brief period allows the two stars to interact strongly through angular momentum exchange and subsequently form a common envelope.
This process is expected to significantly change the configuration of stars and their orbital parameters.

In this work, we study the system by performing comprehensive numerical integration of the corresponding equations of motion, in order to characterize the current configuration and orbital parameters, as well as their changes over time.

We found that after the initial stage in which the system loses a large amount of orbital energy and angular momentum, the system reaches a resonance locking phase, during which the periods of the inner orbit and the outer orbit are equal.
These two stars have been observed to be in a stable configuration, with constant periods, masses, and distances.
Large extra dimensions (LEDs) provide a natural mechanism through which conservation laws can be localized on a four-dimensional brane embedded in high-dimensional spacetime.
The LED must be compact to address the layering issue.

The phenomenon in our universe that seemingly violates the conservation of energy, suggested by the dilution of the observed cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB), can be explained by creating our universe within a negative cosmological constant anti-de Sitter (AdS) brane.
In this case, due to the fundamental conflict between energy conservation in our membrane universe and the continuous creation of AdSLEDs, the universe exhibits four-dimensional characteristics.

In the standard cosmological model, the observed temperature of the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB) is generated by photons produced after the decoupling of free electrons from the cosmic microwave background radiation.
The photon traveled through the observable universe before reaching us.

Therefore, the observed temperature of the cosmic microwave background radiation is the result of the total energy of all particles after they were created but before they were able to interact with each other.
If the universe is strictly four-dimensional, without any extra dimensions of space or time, then the conservation of energy would be maintained, because all energy would remain within the universe.

However, if our universe is embedded in a negatively cosmological constant AdS space (AdSLED), then this conservation is violated, as the anti-de Sitter space is generated by the dynamics of the brane world.
The tidal field reconstructed from the distribution of dark matter contains a wealth of information about the galaxy's growth and merging history, as well as its current dynamical state.

We presented the strong and weak lensing mass reconstructions of the Corullo-IATA1638+29 galaxy cluster, and pointed out that these two related structures constitute a triple merger. The tidal field associated with the central galaxy reveals the orbital plane of the cluster and its projected separation.

We also demonstrated that the direction of the projected spin of galaxies tends to cluster around the same plane, and we used a two-dimensional Kuiper test to quantify the significance of this alignment, testing the spatial correlation with the direction of the tidal field of galaxy clusters.
We also examined the assumption of a uniform distribution of the galaxy's rotation direction and found that the probability of the rotation direction being random is less than 10^-4.
We conclude that the galaxies in the structure have aligned their spin with the orbital plane of the merger.
The three-dimensional space is filled with a jungle of three-dimensional curves.
All of these can be classified according to their topological type, algebraic type, or a combination of both.
The most interesting three-dimensional curves are singular curves: they are typically n-dimensional in n-dimensional space and are transverse.
Generally speaking, the classification of singular curves is based on their genus, that is, based on their codimension in the parameter space.
In the late 1980s and early 1990s, a comprehensive theory regarding characteristic curves was developed, particularly referencing Harris's works and the viewpoints of Kopp and Garone.

These works demonstrate a deformation theoretical framework used to understand the double rational classification of such curves, specifically their ability to deform into another curve in an infinitesimal manner.

The framework also suggests that for a certain general selection of curves, there exists a plane in the quadratic hypersurface within nine-dimensional projective space that does not intersect with the curve; such a plane is referred to as an exceptional plane.
Curves with special planes are referred to as decomposable.
This article studies the case of irreducible general curves: it has a unique (up to projective equivalence) special plane.
This type of curve is called irreducible.
The most common situation is when the special plane is the linear dependent plane of the general curve; such a plane is called a special secant plane.

This article develops the theory of such curves and provides a fractional classification (the so-called Wahl map) among other results. It describes how the family of non-decomposable curves of a given genus (open infinite type) fibers over the space of curves with a given special fiber (finite type).

The atomic energy of post-CCSD(T) molecules (that is, the atomic energy after applying single and double excitations corrections but before freezing pairs) is often calculated using a smaller basis set than that used for the coupled cluster double (CCD) energy, although there is no strict theoretical basis for this.

Here, we demonstrate that the understanding of basis set convergence for atomic energy can be rationalized through Partial Natural Orbital Corrections (PNOC), a method that captures the importance of dynamic correlation in post-CCSD energy.
Using explicit correlation as a measure, we demonstrate that the convergence speed of the PNOC energy is faster than that of the CCD energy with respect to the size of the basis set.

This rationalization leads us to predict that the atomization energy calculated using the CBS-QB3 method (which combines dynamic correlation through CBS connection cost and employs a relatively accurate semi-local exchange-correlation functional) will converge more rapidly than the atomization energy obtained from CCSD(T) on a basis set that is consistent with the geometry of CBS-QB3.

We tested this hypothesis in ten systems with experimental atomization energies and CCSD(T) geometric structures, and found that the CBS-QB3 atomization energies converge to within 1 kcal/mol using the 6-31G** basis set, which is very consistent with the CBS-QB3 CBS (6-31G(d,p) + CBS-QB3) equilibrium geometric structures.
These results indicate that CBS-QB3 can serve as an effective method for predicting atomization energies, and the post-CCSD(T) energy is sufficient to account for basis set convergence.
TRUFAS (Transit Recognition using Fast Algorithms) is a wavelet-based algorithm proposed for the rapid detection of planetary transits.
TRUFAS includes a detection phase and a validation phase.
During the detection phase, TRUFAS calculates a series of detection statistics for the given light curve.
"When the detected statistical value reaches the specified threshold, declare that detection has occurred."
Each transit detection will compute a periodogram and determine the transit parameters through a parabolic fitting of the highest peak in the periodogram.
The sensitivity of TRUFAS to the depth of planetary transits can reach several percentage points of the root mean square (RMS) noise of the light curve.
TRUFAS is efficient and automates the transportation search process.
The verification phase used a simulated planetary system to validate transit detection, and false alarm probability (FAP) statistics were calculated for each validated transit.
The TRUFAS website contains example brightness curves for each detected TRAPPIST-1 tile candidate, as well as detection statistics and verified planetary system information.

A network community, also known as a node cluster, refers to a structure in which the connection density between nodes within the same community is higher than the connection density between nodes in different communities. These communities play an important role in the network.
Most current algorithms only detect large groups or clusters, while ignoring the detailed structure of communities.
Here, we introduce the resolution limit of network clustering and develop a hierarchical method that can detect both large and small communities within the network.
The proposed method first identifies super-communities at multiple resolutions, and then clusters each super-community at a given resolution.
We validated our method on random networks and real-world networks, and demonstrated that our method outperforms other state-of-the-art community detection algorithms.

The complete paper along with its technical details and data can be found here: https://arxiv.org/abs/1711.09755 Ian O. Tolstoy, Han Wang, Paul J. Mucha, and Mihaela Van Con, "High-Resolution Network Communities," arXiv:1711.09755 (December 13, 2017).

Recently, the interest in network clustering has resurged, mainly due to the development of various types of network data, as well as the widespread existence of network datasets in other fields such as social media and biology.
The research tradition of online communities has traditionally focused on detecting large groups or clusters with a high density of nodes in the network.
The community detection algorithm has been shown to be sensitive to the resolution parameter, which determines the granularity of the clusters to be detected.
Higher resolution usually leads to higher quality clustering, although the trade-off is that more computationally expensive algorithms are needed to detect communities at lower resolutions.
In this article, we propose a hierarchical community detection method that can identify both large and small communities across multiple resolution levels.
The method identifies super communities, which are large clusters of nodes that are highly dense and well-connected, while having a lower density compared to other super communities.
The method then clusters the identified supercommunities to optimize the clustering structure for each resolution.
This hierarchical method allows us to detect large communities and small communities at various resolutions.

We demonstrated the practicality of our method on both synthetic networks and real-world networks, indicating that our method is highly accurate in detecting clusters and outperforms state-of-the-art community detection algorithms.
Noether's theorem is one of the fundamental principles of physics, which states that for every symmetry in physical laws, there is a corresponding conserved quantity.
In this letter, we demonstrate that by introducing hidden symmetries, conservation laws can be obtained in modified gravitational theories.

We have proved this within the category of f(R) gravity theories, showing that the standard Einstein-Hilbert term in general relativity is replaced by a modification that does not have a traditional Newtonian description.

Considering the nonlinearity of the field equations, the curvature scalar is not a suitable variable to describe the dynamics of our universe. Therefore, a simplified description based on the development of new scalar degrees of freedom is needed.

We quantitatively explore this theory through the analysis of the solutions to the field equations, indicating that this may lead to corrections in the Poisson equation and the form of cosmic matter density, potentially resulting in new physical effects in the large-scale structure of the universe.
We have proposed a simple and general program for finding exact solutions to the field equations of these theories, and demonstrated its application through some specific examples.

We indicate that these solutions lead to an uneven distribution of stars, where stars have compact cores, and such stars were not recognized in the previously modified gravitational theory field equations.
In this article, we study the (0,2) linear sigma model (LSM) on supermanifolds.
(0,2) LSM is a useful tool for studying various aspects of string theory compactified on non-trivial Ricci-flat backgrounds, such as (p,q) 7-branes, among others.
(0,2) LSM is also expected to effectively describe the low-energy dynamics of the complete intersections in certain ultra Calabi-Yau manifolds.

We extend the (0,2) LSM to a (0,2) gauged linear sigma model (GLSM) on a supermanifold, and we prove that the GLSM on the supermanifold is renormalizable when the supermanifold is non-compact and allows (restricted) gauge symmetry.
We also demonstrated that the (0,2) superfield gauge transformation on the shell is a local symmetry of the action.
Then we discuss the vacua of (0,2) GLSMs on supermanifolds and some of their symmetries, and provide some typical application examples.
Soft constraint logic programming is used to implement unicast and multicast QoS routing.
This makes it possible to achieve the required quality of service levels without intermediate routers, thereby reducing overall network usage and the necessary infrastructure.

The numerical simulation demonstrates the effectiveness of this method in terms of service quality (QoS) for the required flow, as well as the reduction in overall network occupancy and energy consumption.
This work expands on our previous paper.
It also supports multicast sessions.
First, the background of soft constraint programming is introduced in order to help the readers understand the basic concepts on which soft constraint logic programming is based.
Next, the method used in reference [1] is extended to support unicast and multicast QoS traffic.
An illustrative numerical example is used to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method in terms of the quality of service provided, overall network usage, and reduction in energy consumption.
This work is partially supported by the Spanish project TEC2014-51847-R and the Mexican SEP project, with awards including CONACYT 248735 and SNI 74598.
The fluctuation theorem of relativity is a set of equations that involve the probability relationships of different outcomes of a system in thermal equilibrium.
They were conjectured by Robert Langlands in the late 1990s and were first proven in 2003 by Euc59lin Wang and Keiji Saitoh.
Since then, many variations and promotions have proven to be effective.
The original version is applicable only to the special case in thermodynamic processes where the dynamics is Markovian and the system has only first-order time dependence.
In this case, the corresponding theorem is referred to as the classical or non-covariant fluctuation theorem.
Recent research indicates that similar theorems hold under less stringent conditions, accompanied by a covariance factor that depends on system dynamics.
In this article, we will derive these general theorems in full, including all covariances.
As a form of verification, several previously proven special cases are presented as limit cases of this general theorem.
This article is an expanded and updated version of a review published in 2014.

The atomic data for the iron project (IP) has been made available through the internet for use in stellar and plasma physics, quantum chemistry, nuclear physics, materials science, and atomic science.

The project is the result of long-term cooperation among various institutions, aimed at collecting and organizing accurate, reliable, and rigorously reviewed atomic data for all elements from helium to copper.
The data has been organized in an easily browsable database and has custom HTTP and HTTPS endpoints.
We provide data on the radiative transition rates and collision strengths for Ca II here.
The data has undergone reliability and consistency checks against other sources and our previous similar element data.
In the absence of available data elsewhere, we have provided our own calculations and uncertainty estimates for others to use in modeling and analysis.
The detailed information of the data and its organization, including references to the original sources, can be found at https://doi.org/10.26208/data.0000002329.
The NUGA Galaxy Survey is an integral field spectroscopic survey of 32 early-type galaxies, conducted using the SSO telescope.
Here, we present the data and analysis of the unique spiral galaxy NGC 4569 from the sample.
We found that most of the molecular gas in NGC 4569 is located in a large-scale bar structure.
This has been shown to drive a slowly rotating wave with dual faces in the potential, guiding the gas inward.
The molecules of this rod-shaped structure of gas are compact, with a deconvolved size of approximately 1.1 kpc.
Using a simple rod rotation model, we demonstrate that the observed size is consistent with the expected rod strength.
We detected molecular hydrogen in two secondary resonances, further confirming evidence of a massive bar structure at the center of NGC4569.
This is the first large-scale observation of molecular hydrogen in spiral galaxies.
The discussion focuses on the presence of a bar structure at the center of NGC 4569 and its relationship with the observed molecular gas.
Quarks are assumed to be elementary particles that interact via the strong interaction.
In experiments, only two of the six types of quarks, known as the up quark and the down quark, appear in the stable particles (protons and neutrons) found in ordinary matter.
The other four types are called strange quark, up quark, down quark, and bottom quark, and they appear in the form of hadrons, which can only combine to form matter through strong interactions.
The strong interaction binds the quarks of protons and neutrons together in hadrons.
The binding energy of a hadron is referred to as its mass.
Quarks are considered to be particles akin to tiny magnets, and each type of quark comes in six different "colors" (which represents the symmetry group SU(3) in quantum chromodynamics).
The six different "colors" correspond to six parts of a mathematical object known as an octet.

Each type of eight-fold flavor has a characteristic score, along with electric charge and mass, which makes it possible to define the names of "up quark" and "down quark" (with charges of 2/3 and -1/3, respectively).
The remaining flavors include strange taste, upper taste, lower taste, and base taste, each of which corresponds to a named particle.

The basic interaction between these quarks is called "confinement."

Due to the phenomenological quark model, the most fundamental particles in the universe are the up quark, down quark, and strange quark, along with their corresponding hadrons, collectively referred to as hadrons.

Quarks also exist inside other particles, but their behavior is not yet fully understood.

In the linear analysis by Balbus and Hawley (1992) and Hameury, Menou, and Dubus (2013) of rapidly rotating neutron stars as accretion agents around black holes, a new instability mode was discovered— the R mode.
The translation of the Chinese sentence is: "These patterns have very low characteristic frequencies and can grow on the timescale of an accretion event."
We present the time-dependent numerical simulation results of the R-mode unstable growth in the atmosphere of a neutron star around a black hole.
We track the dynamic evolution of unstable patterns in their nonlinear growth stage.
We found that compared to linear expectations, nonlinear effects significantly reduced the growth rate of the R mode.
Specifically, the growth rate becomes much smaller than the back-accumulation time, which is also the characteristic timescale of the problem.

We believe that the nonlinear development of R-mode instability remains an active area of research and may have significant impacts on the spin of neutron stars and the evolution of gamma-ray burst jets.
Astronomers have long known that the universe is filled with tiny particles known as cosmic microwave background radiation.
This radiation has great scientific value because it is the last wave of light emitted during the Big Bang, and can therefore be used to detect the state of the early universe.
Recently, scientists have developed a model that explains how this background radiation may be produced by quantum mechanical effects in the universe.
This model describes a universe filled with zero-point fluctuations, where particles take on various imaginable (virtual) positions in this sea.
As the universe expands and the temperature drops, these virtual particles are more likely to be in a low-energy state, thereby forming a background of virtual radiation.
This model has a key flaw: it does not describe the universe as a collection of particles, but rather as a collection of waves.
This is similar to modeling the ocean with a set of sticks floating on a pot of boiling water.
Waves are the waves in the ocean, while branches are the particles in a boiling pot of water.
The particles of the model and the fluctuations of the universe have not yet been observed.
In this model, the particles in the boiling water pot are the photons of the cosmic microwave background radiation.
As the universe cools, photons are more inclined to move towards the lowest energy state in order to achieve balance with the cold universe.

When the temperature of the universe drops to 3000 K, photons can no longer reach equilibrium with the quantum fluctuations of radiation, and thus they begin to propagate freely towards low-density regions, away from high-density regions.
This is similar to a water bottle placed in a cold place.
As the bottle cools down, water molecules start to move towards the bottom of the bottle, leaving behind a region of lower density than the surrounding air.
In this work, we consider a modified model of this phenomenon, in which the particles (photons) do not move, while the background radiation is in motion.
In this case, the universe is like a "frozen ocean," where particles settle on the seabed, but radiation waves continue to propagate throughout the universe.
In this model, as the universe cools, radiation waves continue to fluctuate throughout the universe, but particles have settled on the seabed, leaving behind areas of high and low density.
This provides a mechanism through which the universe can undergo a phase transition from a state of thermal equilibrium to a non-equilibrium state, or a phase transition dominated by cooling.

A self-managed distributed access control scheme has been proposed for IEEE 802.11 DCF, which can intelligently allocate channel capacity to improve the utilization efficiency of the wireless medium and make full use of the available bandwidth capacity.
The admission control scheme includes a control mechanism and a controlled algorithm.
The control mechanism divides the entire network into multiple fixed-size virtual channels by allocating a series of channel access priorities.
All sites on the network sense the wireless medium and calculate the corresponding data transmission rate.

The controlled algorithm selects sites by establishing connections based on network demands within the control mechanism and moves the entire network between different virtual channels according to scheduling results.
The simulation results indicate that the channel utilization efficiency can be effectively improved.

The full text of this paper can be found at http://arxiv.org/abs/1901.02605. Secondly, the control algorithm selects the sites to establish connections based on their network requirements and moves the entire network between different virtual channels according to the scheduling results.
The simulation results indicate that channel utilization efficiency can be effectively improved.

The evolution of a random SIR epidemic on random networks with heterogeneous connectivity was studied.

Research has found that in regular networks, when the average degree of the network is below a certain threshold, the disease-free state is unstable; whereas when the average degree is above the threshold, the disease will spontaneously disappear.

When the network is heterogeneous, if the network is regular, the disease-free state is still unstable; however, if the average degree of the network is greater than a certain threshold, the disease can persist in the network with a probability of 1.
Additionally, for scale-free networks, as the edge distribution exponent γ increases, the epidemic threshold decreases.
The network structure determines the stability of the healthy state.

If the average degree of the network is less than the threshold, then the disease-free state is unstable; if the average degree is greater than the threshold, then the disease-free state is stable. However, if the network is regular, the disease can still spontaneously disappear.
In addition, scale-free networks lead to a higher epidemic threshold.

This paper demonstrates the existence of pure inductive limit states of the pair of measures consisting of the Lebesgue measure on intervals and the Dirac delta mass at endpoints, contrasting with the simpler and well-known example of the pair of measures consisting of counting measure on integers and Lebesgue measure, which, while possessing pure states, does not have inductive limit states.
The proof utilizes the unique path decomposition of generalized functions.

This indicates that the unique path decomposition of Dirac δ mass regularization is weakly isomorphic to the double limit of the unique path decomposition of the regularized distribution that appears as a simple component in the general decomposition.
This further indicates that this double sequence limit is consistent with the desired pure induction limit state.
The Kolmogorov property of this purely induced limit state is proven to be derived from its uniqueness and the general properties of the induced limit state.

Further argumentation indicates that the aforementioned pair of measures, which exist in pure states rather than inductive limit states, has multiple potential applications in mathematics and theoretical physics.
The paper presents the results of work conducted in collaboration with E. Posta and I. Damián M. Medina.
Researchers typically wish to keep their studies confidential before obtaining formal consent, so that they can share this information with the public or develop proprietary products.
Although formal ethical committees will assess the merits of proposed research, it is often difficult to obtain consent for the research before a certain date in the future.
In many cases, it is not feasible to develop proprietary products without sharing preliminary research results.
It would be advantageous if a single standard could be used to assess the strengths and weaknesses of research conducted in these two different contexts.
A common definition of "advantages" will allow for the objective comparison of research projects.
In this article, we describe a mathematical framework for comparing research projects based on defining research projects as research procedures that seek optimal solutions within a solution space.

Our framework assigns a score that balances two competing concerns: the necessity of sharing information early in order to correct failures before allocating costly resources, and the necessity of obtaining consent for more widespread information distribution.
We have demonstrated the feasibility within this framework through multiple examples.
The VLT-FLAMES Massive Star Survey (VMSS) aims to study the evolution of hot massive stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) of local group galaxies.

The wind properties and evolution of hot massive stars are crucial for understanding the feedback of massive stars on their environment, which includes everything from the morphological structure of the interstellar medium to the chemical evolution of the host galaxy.

The joint high-resolution spectroscopy of VLT-FLAMES enables the determination of mass loss rates and the temperature of the polar wind through hydrogen emission, thereby analyzing the evolutionary status of these stars.

The ion mass can be derived from the mass loss rate, which can ultimately be used to study other characteristics of the wind, such as ionization degree and acceleration regions, which may affect the simulation of environmental feedback.
In this study, we present the first results on the evolution of hot massive stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud, as well as the impact of this evolution on galaxy feedback.
We confirm the previous research conclusion that, compared to the Milky Way, the initial mass function (IMF) of the Large Magellanic Cloud is biased towards massive stars.
The most massive stars show a stronger divergence from the initial mass function (IMF) as they age, indicating that these stars are significantly affected by processes of mass loss.

We have discovered some extreme cases in which the nitrogen-to-carbon (N/C) and nitrogen-to-oxygen (N/O) abundance ratios of these stars are abnormally high. This may be the result of a process involving thermohaline mixing occurring in their stellar winds, which is a hydrodynamic process that takes place in the strong winds of massive stars.
This paper studies the performance of downlink MIMO systems with multiple co-frequency and cross-channel transmission antennas.
We consider a scenario in which the base station (BS) has perfect channel state information (CSI), while the user equipment (UE) only has statistical channel state information.
We recommend using antenna switching-based combined techniques at the user equipment (UE) to leverage the advantages of multiple antennas used in the base station (BS).
We established a simple closed-form expression for achievable rate and obtained the optimal base station beamformer to maximize the achievable rate for a given user equipment combination vector.

The numerical results indicate that compared to using only the User Equipment (UE) channel state information (CSI) or only the Base Station (BS) channel state information (CSI), the use of our proposed technology can significantly improve performance.

The classic cosmic distance scale is based on accurate distance measurements of Cepheid variables in the Milky Way and host galaxies, with these distances being derived from parallax measurements.
To calibrate this relationship, it is very helpful to use methods that can measure the distances to galaxies beyond our own.
In this letter, we propose an alternative method based on the characteristics of stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC).
The LMC is our nearest satellite galaxy and serves as a good calibration point because its distance has been well determined through measurements of its Hubble flow velocity.
We utilize the fact that most of the stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud are red globular stars.
The properties of red giants have been well understood, and their distances can be measured using multivariate polynomial fitting.
We found that the median distance of the LMC measured using this method is 18.1 kiloparsecs, with an estimated observational uncertainty of 0.4 kiloparsecs.

We measured the distances of five massive star clusters in the Large Magellanic Cloud and applied the same technique to these clusters, finding that their distances are also about 18 kiloparsecs, with a small range of 0.1 kiloparsec.
We conclude that the accuracy of measuring the distance to the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) using this method is 0.4 kiloparsecs (kpc).

clean_wm_text: Organic conductors are unique systems for studying criticality and quantum phase transitions due to the unique properties of the charge, spin, and orbital degrees of freedom involved.
Here, we report observations of critical scattering and scaling behavior in quasi-one-dimensional conductors based on Bechgaard and Fabre salts.
We found that charge degrees of freedom are critical across the entire temperature range, with a dynamic critical exponent of z=2.
We provided evidence for the logarithmic correction to the scaling and estimated the central charge as c=1.
The spin and orbital degrees of freedom were found to be consistent with the Heisenberg or Kugel-Khomskii model, with clear manifestations of spin-orbit separation in single crystal samples.

Although there is some evidence of quantum critical points in the system, our data is consistent with the view that spin and orbital degrees of freedom are coupled through uniform Heisenberg coupling in independent chains, and the effective subcritical interaction strength is relatively low.
This material can be regarded as a testbed for exploring interesting theoretical issues related to quantum many-body effects and criticality limits.
Organic conductors are a newly discovered class of materials that exhibit high-temperature superconductivity and other important physical phenomena.
These materials are composed of quasi-two-dimensional molecules with strong spin-orbit coupling, resulting in a smaller spin wavelength and significant magnetic properties.
Recent neutron scattering experiments on the two-dimensional organic superconductor α-T-NbSe2 have revealed low-energy magnetic spectra, which are best described as fluctuating antiferromagnetism.
This discovery is surprising because the observed transition temperatures between low-temperature and high-temperature superconductivity and antiferromagnetism are both quite high.

Here, we conduct a phenomenological analysis of magnetic excitations in α-T-NbSe2 based on an anisotropic square lattice quantum Heisenberg model with intrinsic dimerization and feedback from magnetic order parameters.
We found that the magnetic excitation spectrum can be consistent with the experimental results without the need for immiscible dimers and antiferromagnetic order.

The measured magnetic spectrum function is a superposition of the slight damped dynamic fluctuations of the emergent magnetic order and the relatively large, temperature-independent vector antiferromagnetic order parameter coupling.

These results elucidate the interesting relationship between the coexisting antiferromagnetism and superconductivity in these materials, and suggest that fluctuating exchange may play an important role in their properties.
Lyman Break galaxies (LBGs) are high-redshift galaxies with a high star formation rate.
They can be identified through the Lyman-alpha drop feature in the spectrum and have been observed to exist up to a redshift of about 6.7.
We used the LRIS instrument on the Keck telescope to obtain spectra of three Lyman-break galaxies with redshifts of z = 5.7–5.9.
These data are used to measure the rest-frame ultraviolet spectra of these galaxies through visible wavelengths, complementing the latest research in the near-infrared (NIR) field.

These observations are of great significance for galaxy formation and re-ionization, as the Lyman-continuum radiation from massive young stars is responsible for driving the ultraviolet radiation that recovers with redshift.

These observations indicate that the era of galaxy formation was significantly delayed compared to near-infrared spectroscopy, possibly as late as redshift z ~ 5.7–5.9, corresponding to a period of just 250–500 million years after the Big Bang.
In these early stages, the high-energy ionizing radiation emitted by young stars is also likely to limit the escape of ionizing radiation.

The absorption lines observed in the ultraviolet spectra of these galaxies provide important clues about the physical conditions of these young galaxies. Comparing them with high-redshift galaxies observed by subsequent telescopes such as the Hubble Space Telescope and the Spitzer Space Telescope will enable us to study how the escape of ionizing radiation from these sources changes during the reionization epoch.
We have proposed the first effective one-body (EOB) waveform for non-spinning, equal-mass black hole mergers, achieving high precision and high reliability, with a mass ratio as low as q = 0.2.

Such waveforms, constrained within the small mass ratio limit of general relativity, are crucial for the rigorous and accurate calculation of emitted radiation and for estimating source terms in electromagnetic and gravitational wave astronomy.

We demonstrate that by making a one-time adjustment to the mass ratio, our family of waveforms, known as DECOULper waveforms, approximates the analytical solution of the effective one-body (EOB) equation, meeting the requirements of the Grand Challenge alternative modeling approach. Although they are computed for equal mass systems, they provide an accurate source term for the radiation from black hole-black hole mergers.

Superstar Clusters (SSCs) are small (about 2 parsecs in size), dense (about 10,000 members per cubic parsec), and very young (several million years old) systems, typically observed at the centers of many galaxies.
Superstar clusters form through the direct collapse of giant molecular clouds or through the merging of smaller star clusters.
Although there are many SSCs (super star clusters), their properties have not been studied in great detail due to the limitations of spatial resolution in external galaxies.
This has changed recently with the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope (HST), which has led to the discovery of many fainter super star clusters (SSCs) in the centers of nearby galaxies.
We present the results of hydrodynamic calculations regarding the strong second collapse of superclusters in gas and stars.
The second collapse formed a second population of stars, which will significantly affect the overall characteristics of the star cluster system.

We proposed an approximate analytical method to determine the effects of secondary collapse on the properties of super star clusters (SSCs), and applied it to super star clusters with a bimodal (collapse) initial density distribution.

We have demonstrated that there is a strong correlation between the ratio of the first collapse region to the second collapse region in superconductor-superconductor junctions (SSCs) and the overall SSC characteristics.

For specific situations, galaxy clusters with strong prominent initial conditions (SSCs), such as those formed within peaky dark matter distributions, exhibit a significantly higher ratio of first collapse to second collapse compared to galaxy clusters formed in flat or core-type distributions.
This leads to star clusters (SSCs) formed in galaxies with a peak profile having a higher median age and lower median stellar mass, compared to clusters formed in a peak profile.

This provides a solution to the "core-cusp problem," which describes the apparent discrepancy between observations and numerical simulations that suggest the peak dark matter distribution implies that galaxy superclusters may not be able to form.

We demonstrate the typical self-similar cosmic structure (SSC) properties as functions of the halo model and initial conditions, and discuss the implications of these properties for the theory of hierarchical structure formation.
From this work, we use effective theoretical methods to study a non-relativistic bound state of a charm quark fragmenting into light quarks, namely mesons.
In this theory, the charm quark interacts with the quantum fluctuations of the Polyakov loop, which simulates the gluon field in fundamental gauge theories.

We found that the fragmentation function of charged pions from the transition of charm quarks can be well approximated by considering the Schrödinger equation under a simple potential model, where the coupling between quarks and diquarks is parameterized by an effective coupling constant.
We use heavy quark effective theory to calculate this constant and find that, due to our truncation, it is independent of the light quark in the initial charm quark state.
The parameters of the model effectively measure the strength of interactions, that is, the effective coupling constants, which are determined by the meson spectrum measured experimentally.
We also calculated the fragmentation function from the transition of charm quarks to mesons.
We compared it with the recent LHCb data and found that the effective coupling constant when converting to mesons is much larger than the coupling constant when converting to charged pions.
We discuss the implications of this discovery, which may explain the remarkable phenomenon of the significantly greater production of K+ than K- at the LHC.
Mechanical Home Range Analysis (MHRA) is a widely used method for estimating home range size.

The method consists of two steps: 1) modeling spatial use as a function of candidate activity range spatial variables, and 2) using fast numerical optimization to identify the activity range that best fits the observed spatial use data.

In the first step, this method is most commonly applied to summary statistics of spatial usage (i.e., point patterns), and a vast amount of continually growing knowledge about spatial usage patterns is used to guide the selection of candidate home domain spatial variables.

Many of these variables are functions of the size of the home range, and fast algorithms have been developed to test the relationship between these spatial variable combinations and the observed spatial usage patterns.
Although these algorithms can quickly screen many combinations of spatial variables, all spatial variables are tested simultaneously, and many combinations of spatial variables are never used.

The second step is a global search algorithm that uses home domain spatial variables to filter results and quickly identify the combination of home domain spatial variables that best matches the observed spatial usage data.
The MHRA is often used to estimate the size of the activity range for large sample sizes, but the slow variable selection step for the activity range may limit the applicability of this method.
For example, estimating the activity range size of 10 individuals requires 45 model runs (assuming each model run uses a different combination of spatial variables).
Therefore, MHRA requires a large amount of computing resources and extensive modeling time.
Here, we have developed an analytical model of steady-state space usage patterns that can estimate the areas utilized under steady-state conditions.
"Stable space usage refers to the area used for continuous measurement of space usage over a longer period of time."
The analysis of stable space usage pattern models is similar to mechanical motion models, but the latter does not estimate space usage.

The model analysis estimates the particle flux around a central point (habitat range), while assuming spherical symmetry, and many such models have been developed for different spatial environments (e.g., closed habitats versus open habitats).
We combine this model with a global search optimization algorithm to create an algorithm capable of quickly estimating the home range area that best fits the steady-state space use pattern.
The area estimated using steady-state space utilization is different from the area estimated using MHRA, but they are related and both are indicators of space utilization.
For small sample sizes, the MHRA requires 45 model runs, but the steady-state spatial area can be estimated with a single model run.
The estimated steady-state space usage area is more accurate than the MHRA area, and it is calculated in seconds rather than in minutes or hours.

We demonstrated the practicality of using the steady-state space usage area by comparing it with the area estimated using MHRA and utilizing it to reduce the number of model runs needed to estimate the activity range size.
The astronomy community regularly discusses proposals for new telescopes, and this cycle has continued for over a decade without funding for any new large optical telescopes.

The issue of the lack of new facilities is due to a flawed approach in evaluating proposals, which did not accurately reflect the costs of new building projects, may not have fully considered the risks of cost overruns, and ultimately did not reflect the needs of the astronomy community.

We propose a different approach that better reflects the costs of the project and places greater emphasis on the benefits of new facilities, including opportunities for international cooperation and the enhancement of technical capabilities.

We hope that the astronomical community can accept this new and more appropriate future construction project process, and we also hope that the existing telescopes can be expanded to meet the growing demands of the astronomical community.
Since 2006, new proposals for telescopes have been submitted to the astronomical community for evaluation.

These proposals cover a wide range of costs and technical specifications. The new Telescope Evaluation Board (EBT) assessed each proposal based on an evaluation template that has remained largely unchanged since 2005.
The evaluation process includes several key areas of consideration, including cost, technical design, and management.

The cost composition is divided into two main areas: 1) initial capital expenditure costs for facilities, and 2) ongoing operating expenses, including operational and maintenance costs, maintenance expenses, and personnel costs.
The technical assessment focuses on the design and capabilities of the telescope, and the submitted materials will be evaluated based on their ability to achieve scientific goals.
The management assessment focuses on the management team, including the structure of the board of directors and committees, as well as compliance with the Open Periodic Table (OPT) principles.

EBT has released assessment templates for each field, and all submitted materials are evaluated based on the availability of relevant skills and facilities, costs and the likelihood of technical success, as well as other administrative considerations.

Although certain improvements have been made to the evaluation process in the "Proposal Revision 1.0" document, some aspects of proposal evaluation still need to be reconsidered to better reflect the actual costs of new projects and take risks into account.

First of all, the cost assessment does not adequately reflect the project's costs because it does not account for inflation adjustments, does not set an appropriate contingency period, and does not reflect the changing purchase prices of capital equipment over time.

These errors may lead to an overall overestimation of costs, as projects often require additional time for review of system or equipment designs, detailed construction drawings, or other activities that could drive up costs.

In addition, inflation may have a significant impact on project costs, and similar projects completed at different times often have different costs due to factors such as updated prices and transportation delays.
Secondly, the evaluation did not adequately consider the risks and cost overruns.

Therefore, the proposal evaluation may not fully reflect the true cost of building the telescope, which is particularly relevant in the case of international projects, as local political or economic factors may influence this.
Using a multipopulation magnetohydrodynamics model, we studied the effects of kinetic electron collisions on the instability of low-frequency (ion cyclotron) beams in a multi-fluid description.
Research indicates that the anomalous (cross) current density and electric potential drop generated by beam-heated plasma waves may affect mirror instability and Benford instability.
In addition, the instability threshold of the two beam heating modes increases as the temperature anisotropy decreases.
The analysis of linearizing nonlinear phenomena has also been completed.

The results of the proposed research are used to model low-frequency instability in plasma configurations such as tokamaks and solar flares more accurately. On June 30, 2023, we studied the impact of energetic electron collisions on low-frequency (ion cyclotron) beam instability using multi-fluid magnetohydrodynamic modeling.

The merging cluster system ESO137-001 consists of two merging sub-clusters, with the larger one being Abell 3627, which has a redshift of 0.1, and the smaller one being ESO137-001, which has a redshift of 0.0174.
The former is indicated by the non-detection of X-ray luminosity, while the latter is visible as a galaxy cluster in the X-ray band.
The ESO137-001 subgroup is located at the center of the sky plane between two main star clusters.
The ESO137-001 galaxy group contains two H-II regions with sizes of 10 and 15 kpc, which are ionized by a mature low-mass star cluster.
They are also associated with extended H-alpha emissions and excessive blue light.
The star formation rate in the H-II region is 2-3 × 10^−2 M☉ per year.
The H-II region is likely to have been recently ionized by some typical star clusters that are 1-3 million years old, which are currently too small to be detected individually in observations.
In the ESO137-001 galaxy group, the total star formation rate is 1-2 M☉.
The estimated contribution of this gas mass in the star cluster is 20-30%.
The X-ray brightness of the group is mainly produced by emissions from non-thermal stars.
The subgroup is located at the predicted intersection point of the two falling areas of the main group, so the proportion of recent merger activities may be higher than that of the average group.
We conducted a comprehensive analysis of the first observational evidence for candidates of circumbinary planet (CBP) PP, which required a thorough analysis of Swift/XRT data: I. Deep decay phase.
Swift/XRT observed Swift J164449.3-311543 from February 2015 to August 2016, lasting for 170 days.
The light curve can be roughly divided into three parts: shallow decay segment (SDS), normal decay segment (NDS), and steep decay segment (SDS).
SDS can be naturally interpreted as the early super-Eddington light produced by the companion planet (CBP) during the tidal disruption event (TDE).
We carefully study the characteristics in the SDS, using a simple single-zone reprocessing model and a more complex multi-zone reprocessing model.

We found that the following physical processes are necessary to reproduce the observed behavior of the light curve: (1) energy absorption from internal impacts of stellar debris in the SDS; (2) winds from the accretion disk heating the CBP; (3) tidal disruption flares (TDF) from the CBP illuminating the CBP; (4) interactions between the debris and the CBP as well as between the debris and the disk leading to an excess of late-time light; (5) continuous energy injection from the central SMBH.

We will also compare the expected reflection features of the central black hole (CBP) with the data and impose constraints on the distance between the central black hole (CBP) and the black hole (BH).
Here, we provide a comprehensive analysis of SDS using a simple single-region processing model and a more complex multi-region processing model.

We found that the following physical processes are necessary to reproduce the observed behavior of the light curve: (1) Stellar fragments absorb energy through impacts inside the SDS; (2) The wind from the accretion disk heats the CBP; (3) TDF from the CBP illuminates the CBP; (4) The interactions between the fragments and the CBP, as well as between the fragments and the disk plane, lead to late-time light excess; (5) Continuous energy injection from the central SMBH.
We also compared the expected reflection characteristics of CBP with the data and constrained the distance between CBP and BH.
Recent observations of Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*) at the center of our galaxy reveal that it is surrounded by a huge, quasi-periodic cloud of radio radiation, known as the Sgr A West radio lobe.
This cloud exhibits dramatic changes over multiple time scales, ranging from weeks to millions of years, which may be related to the dynamic environment near Sgr A*.
Based on linear analysis, recent studies suggest that this lump may be caused by disk instabilities near a black hole, rather than being the result of a supernova explosion or any other single event.

Here, we present the results of three-dimensional general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic simulations regarding disk-generated turbulence and magnetic fields. These results suggest that the dynamical environment around the supermassive black hole Sgr A* at the center of the Milky Way is likely a long-term stable and persistent phenomenon.

In our model, the low-frequency radio variations are caused by fluctuations in the mass inflow rate from the circumnuclear disk into the supermassive black hole, with a period of tens of thousands of years.

This result is consistent with several independent observations and theoretical evidence, and may resolve the long-standing issue regarding the dynamical origin of the radio ears of Sagittarius A West.

The purpose of this work is to characterize the conformational preferences of specific side chains in model polymer systems through a combination of experimental methods and molecular mechanics and nuclear magnetic resonance calculations.
Especially, aromatic side chains provide a great example, as they are likely to adopt π-stacking interactions in ordered mesostructures.

The association formed by π-π stacking between cyclic systems is considered crucial for many practically important physical properties in polymer systems, including crystal perfection, reactivity, and mechanical behavior.
Due to the strong hydrophobic characteristics of π-stacking, these interactions are generally only observed in amorphous, fluid states of polymers, such as glassy or rubbery materials.

In this study, we provide an experimental method for measuring the distribution of side-chain rotameric isomers in model polymer systems, employing a combination of 1H NMR spectroscopy and molecular mechanics with empirical potential energy calculations.

The aromatic side chains 4-fluoronitrobenzene and 4-chloronitrobenzene were studied as model systems, with particular emphasis on the quantification of side chain rotational isomers in both the crystalline and glassy states.

In addition to describing the characteristics of side chains and their impact on the macroscopic physical properties, these results also provide useful reference data for the development and validation of more advanced physical modeling methods in polymer systems.

In quantum field theory (QFT), particles possess definite values of local symmetries based on certain conserved quantum numbers, known as isospin or conserved charge symmetries, which restrict the forms of local interactions.

Especially, various isospin, baryon number, and hypercharge symmetries require different types of interactions between particles, which have different symmetries. Therefore, quantum field theories possessing these symmetries are constrained in terms of their particle content.

Specifically, the low-energy effective field theory (EFT) of quantum gravity, known as General Covariance (GC), is expected to be described by a generally covariant (differential structure) EFT (differential structure EFT), in which all particles couple to the metric and gravity.

However, there are several known cases in which isotopes or other charge symmetries undergo spontaneous breaking, resulting in dimensional reduction (DR). In this situation, local symmetry implies lower symmetry, which in turn leads to a reduction in the constraints of local interactions.
Several types of such scenarios are based on extended gravity, including the Kaluza-Klein reduction (KKR), minimal de Sitter space (dS), and projective special relativity (PSR) scenarios.

These all share a common characteristic, namely the existence of a background field, that is, a gauge field (connection), whose field strength is non-zero. As a result, local symmetry is explicitly broken down to a global symmetry.

However, the effect of symmetry breaking is independent of the parameters of local symmetry transformations; therefore, in particular, the parameters of the symmetry transformations become a Goldstone boson.
This can be used to derive the universal characteristics of dimension-reduction schemes, regardless of the specific details of the symmetry breaking mechanism.

For example, it is expected that all spontaneously broken isotopes or other charge symmetries will lead to a reduction of local symmetry, where the parameters of the local symmetry transformation correspond to a Goldstone boson.

Specifically, for the minimal de Sitter and projected special relativity scenarios, there exists an exact symmetry between local de Sitter (dS) symmetry and global Poincaré symmetry, which leads to an exact Gorini–Morrone boson equivalence.

In addition, under certain conditions, the expected spontaneous violation of isotopes or other charge symmetries will lead to universality classes of conformal, CPT, and extended conformal symmetries.
These results suggest the universal characteristics of the DR scheme, which are independent of the specific details of the symmetry breaking mechanism.
In this work, we present a spectral and photometric survey of Jupiter's Trojan asteroids, covering visible light wavelengths.

We use this unique dataset, which comes from the Spitzer Space Telescope, combined with previously published near-infrared datasets, to provide a dynamic family classification of the Jupiter Trojan population.
This work extends our initial study of the populations with sizes H=22.5-23.0 km s^-1 and 31.5-33.5 km s^-1 to the complete size range of Trojan asteroids, from H=30.0 km s^-1 to H=37.0 km s^-1.
These dynamic families are named after their similar main asteroid orbits: including (mainly) Apollo type and (secondarily) Greek type.
(Grade 3) Aten, (Grade 3) Melita, (Grade 3) Cassini or (Grade 3) Reichhart, as well as (Subgrade) Akensun, Hestia, and Opera.

We also provide the largest classification of Trojan asteroid size ranges to date, including 15 families (with a total of 134 members) identified through their relevant orbital elements, and 33 families (with a total of 442 members) identified through their physical characteristics.

Through numerical integration, we demonstrate that many of these families are interconnected through mutually escaping asteroids, and we provide the latest orbital data for the entire population of escaping members.
Using this dataset, we also evaluated the classification characteristics of each group.
We further classify 27 families as S-type and 56 families as C-type.

The S-type asteroids are consistent with the high albedo population described in earlier studies and are likely to include the family named after the main asteroid belt S-type asteroids with velocities of H=30.0-34.0 km s^-1.
C-type asteroids are mostly incompatible with known asteroid families and may include families with darker surfaces (C-type) that have not been observed on Earth.
Based on our data and previous research, we have identified two population overlapping Trojan asteroids: S-type and H-type family members with speeds ranging from 30.0 to 34.0 km/s.

The total population of these two groups (83 members) is very dynamically similar to the H=30.0-34.0 km s^-1 family, which may be evidence of a large, previously unrecognized family that connects these two groups.
We provide these members with improved orbital elements, which we call the "H=30.0-34.0 km s^-1 family."
Using exploding neutron stars (ENTs) to test general metric theories of gravity has the potential to decisively test gravity in the most extreme environments and reveal new physics.
This is our first coordinated otolaryngology search across multiple nearby galaxies, identifying 10 potential events in 5 galaxies.
These include 4 low-spin systems consistent with general relativity (GR), 4 high-spin systems inconsistent with GR, and 2 unmodeled systems.
If explained within the framework of extended general relativity, this is the first strict constraint on this class of models.
We found no evidence of deviation from general relativity (GR) and set a new Eddington parameter limit of ζ ≤ 2.5 × 10^{-3} (90% confidence level).
This result is independent of the equation of state of neutron-rich matter and can be directly applied to any ENT candidate.
Our results provide the most stringent constraints on ζ to date in any astrophysical system, offering key tests for strong gravity and fundamental physics.
In this paper, we study the susceptible-infected-recovered (SIR) epidemic model on dynamic contact networks, where nodes join and leave the network over time.
We will first introduce an epidemic model on general time-varying graphs and describe the final size of the epidemic.

We will continue to study two specific cases of this general model: the first is an epidemic model on a static graph, where edges are randomly added at random times; the second is a fully dynamic model in which nodes can be in active or inactive states, but no existing edges are removed.

We conducted an asymptotic analysis of the final scale of these two models and showed that in both cases, the number of infected nodes is close to a constant factor of the number of node connections, at most differing by a logarithmic factor.
Finally, we conduct numerical experiments to demonstrate the validity of our theoretical analysis.
Infectious disease models have been applied to various dynamic networks, including time-varying graphs, where edges are added and removed over time.

We study general models on two types of graphs: static graphs with randomly deleted edges, and completely dynamic graphs where edges can be added or deleted.
We propose an epidemic model on general time-varying graphs that describes the final size of the epidemic, and we conduct asymptotic analysis for the cases of static graphs and fully dynamic models.

For epidemic models on static graphs with random edge deletions, we demonstrate that the final size of the epidemic is at most larger than the contact frequency of a node by a logarithmic factor, and there is a constant factor as well.
For the completely dynamic model, we indicate that the number of infected nodes is close to a constant factor of the number of node contacts, differing at most by a logarithmic factor.
Our analysis shows that in both cases, the final scale of the epidemic is a constant factor that is proportional to the number of connections to the nodes.
This constant may be large in real social networks, as most connections are informal, while a small number of close connections can lead to large-scale outbreaks.

The analysis of this pair of general time-varying graphs may have independent interest, as it provides a mechanism by which the number of connections of a node can influence the final scale of an epidemic.
We conduct numerical experiments to demonstrate the validity of our theoretical analysis.
In summary, we proposed a general model for epidemic propagation on static and fully dynamic graphs, and described the final size of the epidemic.
We conduct asymptotic analysis under static graphs and fully dynamic models, and present numerical experiments to demonstrate our effectiveness.
In 2010, the radial velocity method was introduced to search for exoplanets by measuring the wobble of host stars caused by the gravitational pull of planets.

In order to confirm that the detected oscillation is indeed caused by a planet and not by other reasons such as noise, a confirmation method was developed that measures the Doppler redshift of the emitted spectrum to detect the motion of the planet around the central star.
This method is very effective, so in the following twenty years, thousands of exoplanets were confirmed.
However, in recent years, there has been a strange trend where the number of confirmed exoplanets is declining.
Although the cause of this decline is still unclear, scientists have several theories, including the possibility of false positives.
In this article, I will explain false positives, why they are a problem, and propose a new mathematical confirmation method that can reduce the number of false positives.
I will also discuss the need for more observations to confirm whether the decrease in the number of confirmed exoplanets is real.
The widely accepted and commonly used method for cleaning dirty floors is the gravity method.
This starts with piling up the dirty stuff in the center of the floor and then letting it flow outwards.
The obvious problem is that this may not be able to clean the floor completely, and as more dirt accumulates in the middle, the floor may become even dirtier.
This article proposes an alternative method, which is to first spray some cleaning agent on the ground and allow it to spread out using gravity.
The article goes on to establish a probabilistic framework to analyze this approach.
First, it derives a probabilistic model for the quantity of ground dirt and uses this model to calculate the probability of completely cleaning the surface with this method.
Then it uses this result to answer a more important question: How much dirt can this method clean up?

The analysis shows that for a moderately dirty surface, this method will clean the surface completely with a high probability, but the amount of dirt it can clean is only about 50% of the actual amount.

The article then presents a more efficient method based on this result, which starts with using twice the amount of ordinary detergent, not by sprinkling it on the ground, but by directing it to the areas with higher dirt density.
This method will thoroughly clean the floor and remove almost all dirt.
Modern nanotechnology makes it possible to precisely manufacture various nanoscale structures, which are used to study the interaction between electromagnetic waves and subwavelength structures.
Through this article, we studied the interaction between electromagnetic waves and metallic and semiconductor nanospherical particles.

By employing precise and semiclassical descriptions, we demonstrate that metallic and semiconductor spheres can support resonances of surface plasmon polaritons (SPP) and surface phonon polaritons (SPhP), which are distinct phenomena.

SPP resonance requires both bulk and surface modifications simultaneously, and it is less sensitive to the geometric size and shape of the particles. In contrast, SPhP resonance only requires bulk modification and is more sensitive to these changes.

We further prove that the surface phonon polariton (SPhP) resonance in semiconductor spheres can have a larger q (wave vector) value than light in air, and therefore they have a longer radiation lifetime.
The collective states of the strange proton nuclei are described within the framework of the Interacting Vector Boson Model (IVBM).
Within this model framework, the core is regarded as a condensed state of interacting vector bosons.
The bosonic fields are associated with their respective quasi-particle states.
The interaction between quasi-particles is described by the Brueckner reaction matrix.
The model accurately describes the ground state band structure and the first excited band of many even-even nuclei and odd-mass nuclei.
The interaction with vector bosons gives rise to monopole and dipole phonon modes.
These phonon modes generated systematic patterns in the even-even and odd-mass nuclear spectra.
Specifically, the high-K electric transition operator excites vibrational (phonon) states in even-even nuclei and oscillatory vibrational (phonon) states in odd-mass nuclei.
In the QCD (Quantum Chromodynamics) sector, the oscillation patterns have been observed and discussed recently in several experimental papers.
The theoretical description of the oscillation patterns within the IVBM remains an unresolved issue.

According to this work, we report a theoretical analysis of the oscillation patterns based on the IVBM method and predict the excitation energies and transition probabilities of the first excited states of several odd nuclei near the closed shell N.

This article also briefly discusses monopole and dipole phonon modes.
The mass and temperature of the TWA 7 debris disk were measured through observations from Herschel and Spitzer.
This surface is unusual because it exhibits at least four distinct breaks in the spectral energy distribution (SED), indicating the presence of four spatial regions with different temperatures.

The two inner rupture points, with radii of 19 and 47 AU, can be explained by a radiation-dominated belt and a transitional Kuiper Belt, while the two outer rupture points, with radii of 180 and 500 AU, may be due to solid depletion outside the ice line located at 100-150 AU.

The temperature of the intermittent region in the middle is best explained by the composition gradient of the remaining dust particle population. At 47 AU, the temperature is 50 K, and as the distance increases to 180 AU, the temperature rises to 200 K.
This indicates the presence of a relatively warm area at the middle disk radius.

The detection of these unique regions at different temperatures can only be achieved through observations by Herschel and Spitzer, as previous infrared astronomical satellites' far-infrared observations limited the ability to distinguish the multi-temperature characteristics of the disk.
