Recent ALMA observations of the young transitional disk HD 98800 show that its near-infrared spectrum is consistent with the presence of gas and small dust within approximately 2 AU of the central star, providing strong evidence for the existence of an inner transitional disk.
These dust particles are likely optically thin, close to the Keplerian orbit, and their existence is maintained by the continuous removal of small particles through light evaporation.
The total dust mass of the inner disk is less than 1% of the minimum mass solar nebula.

The density of the gas is much thinner, with a volume fraction of about 10^-5, and there is a deficiency of elements heavier than helium, which may be attributed to the gravitational influence exerted by the inner planets.

The impact of this architecture on the evolution of medium-quality stars remains to be determined, but HD 98800 is an ideal target for future studies with higher sensitivity and higher angular resolution.
The existence of massive neutrinos is one of the most important discoveries in modern astrophysics and particle physics.

Among the three known types of neutrinos, the neutral current interaction of electron neutrinos provides a unique tool for studying the interiors of galaxies and galaxy clusters, because electron neutrinos interact very little with electrons themselves, but rather scatter off the electrons in atomic nuclei.
This forward scattering process can be observed through the Doppler-shifted emission of weak electron neutrinos, which results in an exponential decay of the spectrum at low energy.

The intensity of the so-called core-collapse supernova neutrino burst measurement can only be explained by assuming the existence of nearly massless neutral Majorana neutrinos. These neutrinos were proposed by Ettore Majorana in 1937, and forty years later, the KATRIN experiment first found evidence for them.

In 2006, the Super-Kamiokande detector obtained the first direct experimental evidence regarding the Majorana nature of neutrinos, reported in the scientific journal "Nature." It described a small but finite probability of neutrinos appearing as their own antiparticles.
Although the importance of dark matter is self-evident, its nature remains one of the biggest unsolved problems in cosmology and particle physics.

The favored dark matter model is Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs), which can interact through weak interactions, and therefore are expected to produce observable signals in traditional neutrino telescopes.

However, recent observations of galaxy clusters, such as those made by the Planck satellite or through dark energy measurements, have reduced the maximum possible cross section for weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs) to about an order of magnitude close to the weak interaction coupling constant.
Due to this being several orders of magnitude smaller than the neutrino scattering cross-section, the possibility of this type of dark matter has been excluded.
Neutrino oscillations can easily explain the measured anomalies in solar and atmospheric neutrinos, thus providing an attractive alternative for dark matter.
Because neutrinos are Majorana particles, the gravitational potential of galaxy clusters can capture a finite number of electron neutrinos, thereby resolving the dark matter issue.

This process may be similar to the way a light bulb emits light when an electric current passes through it: galaxy clusters are like a giant light bulb, and the neutrino beam produces the observed 511 keV radiation.

Considering the lack of evidence for non-baryonic dark matter and its weak interaction cross section, we suggest that the observed neutrino bursts are actually produced by the scattering of electron neutrinos with dark matter particles, which may account for about 30% of the total dark matter density in the universe.

We provided an example of how to establish or falsify the existence of heavy particle dark matter through measuring the neutrino burst spectrum of a collapsing supernova in the center of our galaxy in the future.
The complexity of many real-world networks has been shown to be well captured by graphs with random layouts.

Such random graphs are typically generated using one of two paradigms: the configuration model, which assumes a uniform probability distribution for the establishment of all edges, and the community model, which allows the generation of arbitrary networks with predefined attributes.
However, different real-world networks may exhibit very different distributions of topological features.
Therefore, it is meaningful to consider how the distribution of these features varies in different random graph models.

Here, we focus on two such characteristics: the size of the largest planar matching and the size of the largest planar subgraph, both of which have well-developed algorithmic techniques that allow for their sizes to be accurately determined in any arbitrary random graph.

By using various random graph models, we found that the size of the maximum planar matching exhibits a power-law distribution in each of the models considered, while the maximum planar subgraph demonstrates a power-law distribution in some models and exhibits different characteristics, more similar to an exponential distribution, in others.

It is worth noting that we found that the power-law exponent of the scale of maximum planar matching and maximum planar subgraphs is closely related to the exponent of the degree distribution of the graph.

This indicates that the tail behavior of the distribution of these features is most strongly influenced by the diversity of high-dimensional vertices in the random graph model and their presence or absence.
A paper introducing the feasibility, limitations, and potential sources of error in determining stellar ages using the gyrochronology method.
The feasibility of this method is demonstrated by using a sample of 48 stars with known rotation periods \( T_{c} \) and surface ages.
The limitations of this method stem from the theory behind it, which has also been validated through samples.
The limitation of this method arises from the dependence of \( T_{c} \) on composition, which leads to a degeneracy between age and metallic abundance.
The potential sources of errors have also been discussed.
The sample comes from the IAC-80 visual binary catalog (IAC-80), which includes 48 known G-type stars with rotation periods (T_{c}), effective temperatures, surface ages, and metallicities.
The expected equatorial rotation rate (VΩ/sin(i)) is obtained through T_{c}, which is calculated using the infrared flux method based on the rotation period and temperature.
Using Babel Code, the age can be estimated by the time determined by the gyroscope.
The comparison of surface age and true age is conducted to determine whether gyrochronology can be used to determine the age of G-type stars.
The reliability of this method was verified through two-sample t-tests, constant stellar ratios, the Scholz radius test, and the rotation age-chemical age diagram.

The spin age method has been proven to be a feasible approach for determining the ages of G-type stars, with an average error of -2.2%. This indicates that for most stars, the spin age is within 10% of the true age.
The limitation of this method arises from the dependence of \( T_{c} \) on composition, which leads to a degeneracy between age and metal abundance.

The gyrochronology - color chronometry diagram shows the limitations of this method, illustrating the relationship between T_{c} and surface age, with metallicity represented as a separate series overlay.

The Nova Geminorum 1912 is the first observed example of gravitational lensing, becoming the first known case of a strong gravitational lens.

Many scientists and science fiction writers have hypothesized that strong gravitational lensing can be used for technological intervention and military purposes, which has led to the development of observational projects aimed at searching for strong gravitational lenses and studying their effects.
Through this article, we explore the scientific and cultural significance of Nova Tauri 1912, as well as the development in the field of gravitational lensing.
We first provide a brief overview of gravitational lenses, including a discussion of critical curves and focal points.

Next, we will describe how the strong gravitational lensing effect was first observed, and how the observation of the Gemini Nova in 1912 led to the discovery and study of gravitational lensing as a unique phenomenon.

We also studied how the observational findings of the 1912 Gemini nova led to the development of supergravity, as well as the broader interest in strong gravitational lensing as a weapon in science fiction works.

Finally, we discussed how subsequent gravitational lensing observations have led to a new understanding of this phenomenon, including the first observation of gravitational waves and the measurement of the Hubble constant.

The "missing satellite problem" refers to the observation that although there are over 20 billion galaxies in the observable universe, only a small fraction of them (about 105) are actively forming stars.

Astronomers anticipate that clusters and groups of galaxies, as well as groups and associations within galaxies, will exist due to the abundance of dark matter in the universe, commonly referred to as galaxy groups and clusters. However, in reality, only a small portion of these groups and clusters show signs of galaxy activity.
It has been suggested that less dense environments are hindering the formation of galaxies and leading to the problem of missing satellites.
We test this statement by measuring the stellar masses of galaxy groups selected from the SDSS and GMASS cluster surveys.

We show that although the galaxy mass distribution of central and satellite galaxies in these galaxy clusters is statistically equivalent, the galaxy mass distribution of central and satellite galaxies in binary systems is statistically different, with a p-value < 10^-5.

We conclude that galaxy clusters do exist in the universe, and in sufficiently dense environments, dynamical friction is not effective enough to transition galaxies from a star-forming state to a non-star-forming state.

In the Standard Model (SM) with the minimal particle content, the Electroweak Chiral Lagrangian (EWCLL) is the appropriate low-energy effective field theory (LEFT) that describes the strong interactions of the weak bosons.
During the construction process, the precise testing by EWCLL placed strong constraints on new physics (NP) scenarios.
Here, we impose strong constraints on a general Higgs portal model using the latest precise measurements from the LHC and electroweak observables.
We found that the model is strongly constrained within a larger range of the parameter space.

Specifically, the model predicts that at a 95% confidence level, the mass of the charged scalar boson is below 530 GeV, and the invisible decay width of the Z boson is expected to be greater than 0.2 MeV at the 95% confidence level.
These boundaries can be further improved in electric-weak observable quantities by using precise current and future data.
We present observations in the near-infrared (NIR) and optical bands of the nearby quasar PKS 2155-304 conducted from May 2005 to July 2005.
The NIR data was obtained using the 10.4-meter GEMINI South Observatory, while the optical data was collected through the Nordic Optical Telescope and the William Herschel Telescope.
We also provide simultaneous data from other wavelengths (X-rays, MeV, GeV) from the Whipple, HEGRA, and CAT observatories.
Based on our observations, we suggest that in the optical band, PKS 2155-304 was in a high state in early 2005, possibly reaching a flux density of 400 mJy in April 2005.
During this period, the near-infrared flux density remained relatively stable, with no significant changes.
From May 20 to 25, 2005, we detected a sharp increase in optical and near-infrared (NIR) flux, reaching a peak in June 2005.
During this period, the optical spectral index rapidly hardened, possibly reaching α = 3.2.

We hypothesize that the sudden brightness increase in PKS 2155-304 is caused by a rapid increase in the density of the external radiation field (due to the erupting galaxy M33) interacting with the relativistic jet of PKS 2155-304.
We also observed a rapid decrease in the flux density of X-rays, MeV, and GeV during the period from May to July 2005.

We suggest that this decline is due to the jet entering a new region with a weaker magnetic field, which may be caused by the increased density of the enhanced external radiation field leading to greater jet transparency.
In a previous paper, we described the scaling relations between galaxy properties and their central supermassive black holes (SMBHs), which have been found to hold at redshifts up to z=0.89.
Here, we conducted a similar analysis on the local population (z=0.36) and demonstrated that these scaling relationships still hold true here.

Specifically, there is a correlation between the mass of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) and the properties of the host galaxies, such as velocity dispersion and luminosity. The mass of SMBHs is roughly offset by about 0.75 logarithmic units from the mass of globular clusters.
In addition, active black holes are mainly dominated by early-type galaxies, which is contrary to the situation at high redshifts.
This will have a significant impact on the growth and evolution of supermassive black holes in the universe.

In this article, we prove a general version of the Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov (KYP) inequality for discrete-time passive systems described by linear difference equations.

We provide a simple and unified classical KYP inequality method, including relevant results for discrete-time linear time-invariant (LTI) systems, discrete-time linear time-variant (LTV) systems, and continuous-time LTV systems.
We have also promoted the KYP inequality under partial measurement conditions.
Finally, we demonstrate that the classical KYP inequality for linear time-invariant systems with input constraints is a special case of our more general result.

The classic KYP (Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov) inequality is valid for Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) systems. It indicates that the difference between the observability and controllability Gramian matrices is a positive semi-definite quadratic form related to the input matrix.
This result has been extended by multiple authors to linear time-invariant (LTI) systems with input constraints (i.e., zero input).
Relatively speaking, we provide a simple and unified approach for the discrete-time passive systems described by linear difference equations here.

More specifically, we demonstrate that the observability, controllability, and total square root norm matrix of discrete-time passive systems have a symmetric positive semi-definite quadratic form with respect to the input matrix.
Therefore, we have obtained the general form of the KYP inequality for discrete-time passive systems.
We provide a simple method for the traditional KYP inequality based on the input-output mapping formula of the transfer matrix of discrete-time passive systems.
In this way, we have obtained a new proof of the results for discrete-time linear time-invariant systems, discrete-time linear time-varying systems, and continuous-time linear time-varying systems.
For example, we have also proven the classic KYP (Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov) inequality for linear time-invariant (LTI) systems with input constraints.

Finally, we apply our results to design an observer for a bounded gain linear time-invariant system based on discrete-time output errors, and establish the discrete-time analogue of the continuous-time LQR theorem for discrete-time passive systems.

The superconducting states in doped copper oxides are typically divided into two categories: high-temperature superconductivity (above approximately 100 K) and low-temperature superconductivity (critical temperature T_c < 10 K).
The former stems from a lack of in-depth understanding of Fermi theory, while the latter is more clearly established as a result of strong electron-electron interactions.

In the underdoped region of copper oxides, superconductivity is an exception, where strong antiferromagnetic fluctuations are believed to suppress the formation of the Fermi surface required for superconductivity, leading to a disordered state of competing phases.

We report here on inelastic neutron scattering measurements of magnetic fluctuations in n-type Ca(Fe(1-x)Co_x)_2As_2, a material that is an electron-doped superconductor with a critical temperature of 10 K and is believed to exhibit superconductivity driven by fermionic mechanisms.
We found that the doping evolution of the low-energy resonance peak reflects changes in superconductivity, rather than changes in antiferromagnetism.

The results indicate that the superconductivity driven by the Fermi liquid state competes with the pseudogap state, and this competitive state is preoccupied by disproportionate magnetic fluctuations. It is suggested that above the pseudogap temperature \( T^* \), the pseudogap state may represent a competitive state in the cuprates.

Quantum spin liquids (QSL) have become a subject of active research in recent years due to their potential relationship with high-temperature superconductivity and chiral central spin models.

Our results provide clear evidence for the quantum spin liquid (QSL) state in two-dimensional quantum magnets and pave the way for studying its fundamental physics and potential applications.

Using the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), we conducted a thorough search for high-excitation molecular lines near the Seyfert 2 nucleus of the nearby galaxy M51 (NGC 5194).
There is no evidence of active galactic nuclei (AGN) found in the distribution or dynamics of the observed species.

On the contrary, the spatial distribution, excitation mechanisms, and kinematics of the molecular gas are consistent with a scenario where the molecular gas is influenced by the radio jets from the active nucleus of the galaxy NGC 5195.

The molecular gas is distributed in two different cloud regions in space, which are offset from the radio source by about 15-20 arcseconds, showing similar velocities but having slightly different physical properties.
These results further support the hypothesis that radio jets are effective in transporting interstellar material from their host galaxies to distances of tens of parsecs from the nucleus.

Cobalt-doped TiO2 films with different levels of cobalt doping were deposited using the sol-gel process under different O2 partial pressures.
The structure, transmission, and magnetic measurements show that the formation of the Co1-xToxOy solid solution is affected by the Co concentration and O2 partial pressure.
With the increase of Co doping levels, ferromagnetic ordering was observed in the films prepared under low O2 partial pressure.

The increase in oxygen partial pressure leads to an increase in activation energy, and the change in magnetic behavior from superparamagnetic to ferromagnetic ordering can be associated with the change in activation energy.

The cosmological constant, also known as vacuum energy, represents the contribution of zero-point energy from quantum fields to the energy density of the universe. Since the discovery that the universe is flat, it has been assumed to be positive.
However, we demonstrate that it can actually be either positive or negative, which is contrary to the assumptions of many cosmological and particle physics theories.
If the cosmological constant is positive, then many theories that could provide a natural explanation for its small positive value are ruled out.
If the cosmological constant is negative, then some of those theories are reintroduced.
These conclusions are derived by combining observational constraints with detailed theoretical calculations in specific models.
We prove that, in the standard model of particle physics, the QCD amplitude rules provide a natural, relatively small, and positive value for the cosmological constant.
This re-examination of the cosmological constant has important implications for the anthropic solution to the problem of the universe's initial conditions and the nature of dark energy.
In this article, we propose a methodology and corresponding system for evaluating user experience in immersive virtual environments (IVE).

Specifically, we describe the development of a survey called the IVE Experience Questionnaire (IVEEQ), and we constructed a set of form-based questions designed to capture the important specific experiences identified in our usability testing.
Our system then analyzes the user's responses to IVEEQ, as well as the collected metadata, to generate numerical scores and qualitative descriptions of the survey experience.

To illustrate the practicality of this method, we present the results of our evaluation of forms in virtual environments, demonstrating that IVEEQ is capable of identifying form types as factors influencing user experience.
Finally, we discussed future research directions inspired by this work, including expanding our assessment to other aspects of user experience and applying this approach to different types of forms.

In this paper, we propose a methodology for evaluating user experience in immersive virtual environments (IVE) and its accompanying system.

First, we describe the development of a survey called the "IVE Experience Questionnaire" (IVEEQ), and we constructed a set of form-style questions designed to capture important specific experiences identified in our usability testing.
Our system then analyzes users' responses to IVEEQ and the collected metadata to generate numerical scores and qualitative descriptions of the surveyed experience.

To demonstrate the practicality of this method, we present the evaluation results of the form in a virtual environment, showcasing IVEEQ's ability to identify form types as factors that affect user experience.

Turbulence is one of the most common and important phenomena in the universe, occurring in a variety of different contexts, from the flow of water in canals to the motion of gases in the atmosphere, and to the reorganization of stars in galaxies.
Turbulence is caused by randomly occurring collisions between molecules or particles, leading to an inconsistent distribution of motion.

Turbulence theory was developed in the 1920s by Norwegian engineer Karoly (Karsten) Gustaf Aktand. He founded a university now named after him—the Karoly Football University in Hungary—and a library—the Karoly Football Public Library in Hungary.

In the early theories of turbulence, mathematical descriptions were used to characterize the properties of turbulence, employing basic concepts such as integrals and derivatives, as well as different types of differential equations.
In the 1930s, the development of experimental techniques combined with the theoretical development of evaluating turbulent characteristics, leading to the formation of modern turbulence theory.
The important成果 of modern turbulence theory were published by American mathematician Robert H. Luther in 1941 and Norwegian-American mathematician Bryce L. Dysthe in 1958.
The neutrino beam from the Italian National Center for Particle Physics (CNGS) is specifically used for the NOvA and GNO experiments.

The detector installed at LNGS consists of a 150 kiloton active detector target in the real neutrino mass scenario. This target is a large cylindrical tank that contains 250 tons of liquid argon and is covered by 2.67 kilotons of rock.

The collaborative project MODULAr, consisting of researchers from Italy, the United States, and Slovenia, proposes to build a new and very large liquid argon imaging chamber, with the primary aim of searching for very low-energy neutrinos, an area that has not been explored prior to the CNGS beam.
The detector will be composed of a two-layer chamber with an internal diameter of 4 meters and a height of 3 meters.
The internal space will be divided into 18 vertical slices (VLSI), with each slice accommodating 30.48 kilograms of liquid argon.

The expected sensitivity is for the region of interest between 1 to 10 electron volts, where the expected number of signal events depends on the simulated neutrino flux used and the position of the detector in phase space.

The unprecedented large scale and compact design of the detector, combined with its high sensitivity to very low-energy neutrino interactions, makes it an ideal candidate for studying spectral distortions and exploring new physical phenomena in the field of neutrinos.
Astronomy is a powerful tool for determining the fundamental parameters of stars, especially their temperature, mass, and age.
In recent years, significant progress has been made in the field of spectroscopy, with new theories being implemented and data analysis techniques being effectively developed.

I described a method to derive these parameters through high-resolution spectroscopy, along with the current evolutionary trajectory and the intensities of certain atomic and molecular spectral lines.
To demonstrate its effectiveness, I present the application to the open star cluster IC 4651 and field stars of similar spectral types.

The required observational data, including high-resolution spectra and relevant meteorological parameters, are obtained from the literature as well as from my observations at the Haute-Provence Observatory.
The main limitation of this method is the requirement for high-resolution spectra, which are not always available for a large sample of stars.

Despite this, this method can be applied to a wide range of fields. Here, I introduce a preliminary application concerning open clusters and isolated stars, which helps us understand the characteristics of these groups.

In particular, these results indicate that medium-resolution spectrographs on large telescopes (such as MuSiC; Probeca) provide high data return and low cost, making them a good choice for surveying a large number of stars.

Extremely High Energy (EHE) peaked BL Lacertae galaxies (HBLs), referred to as the third frequency, are essentially unobservable in the optical wavelength range due to their higher Doppler shift equivalent width.
Here, we report on the optical spectroscopy study of 32 extreme high-energy Hawking radiations (EHE HBLs) using the spectrometer at the Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory (NGSOM).
This is the largest optical spectral uniform sample of EHE HBLs to date.

We have observed a compelling connection between EHE HBLs and low Doppler redshift optical brightness, which forms a complex network of associations among equivalent width, half-max full width, continuous spectrum slope, redshift, and synchrotron radiation peak frequency.
Higher equivalent width, higher half-maximum full width, steeper spectral slope, and higher redshift are all associated with the presence of optical components with low Doppler shifts.

On the contrary, a lower equivalent width, lower half-maximum full width, flatter spectral slope, and lower redshift are associated with proximity to the redshift of the main galaxy system or a lack of optical components.
We measured the highest equivalent width and half maximum full width observed so far in the optical band from ultra-high energy state high-energy brown dwarfs (EHE HBLs).
The results of this work have far-reaching implications for the EHE HBL central engine, the triggering model, and the EBL reprocessing.
Quark-gluon plasma (QGP) is a state of matter predicted by particle physicists decades ago and is known to be the densest form of matter in existence.
It displays many remarkable characteristics, such as fluctuations in charge and net baryon number, which can, in principle, be measured in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC).
Although the LHC confirmed most of the characteristics of QGP during its first run, the novel phenomenon of photon emission from QGP reported by the ALICE collaboration remains a huge mystery.

In this work, we utilize the kinetic theory of heat and angular momentum transfer to demonstrate that the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) can emit virtual photons with an intensity that depends only on temperature and plasma characteristics, thereby eliminating the need for dynamic calculations within the standard particle physics model.

The virtuality of emitted photons is defined as the square of the momentum scale at which the induced propagator disappears, and it is determined by temperature. Therefore, the emitted photons may possess the energy and virtuality required to explain the ALICE anomaly.

The proposed mechanism is not constrained by Lorentz invariance, so it can be effective in any system that exhibits significant momentum scales and non-trivial thermodynamic characteristics, such as quark-gluon plasma (QGP) systems.

To explore this mechanism, we utilize the unique characteristics and robustness of QGP thermodynamics to predict photon emission in strongly coupled plasma, and we compare these predictions with existing lattice QCD data.
We found that the predicted photon rate is sufficient to address the ALICE anomaly if it still exists at the end of the second phase of the LHC.

We report preliminary results from the large deployable feed array of the Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT) in the 2500-2750 MHz frequency range, which was used for a sensitive search for neutral hydrogen absorption in BR I 1335-0417 (OM 1365+1549) at a redshift of $z = 4.4$.

We used a 1000-hour dataset from November 2010 to March 2011 to provide an upper limit for the neutral hydrogen fraction of $f < 0.26$ within a 21 Å region, in the range of $4.4 < z < 5.2$ (at a confidence level of 2σ).

Due to the absorption region covering background quasars, which has been proposed in some hypotheses regarding the nature of dark matter, this constraint provides the most stringent limits on the neutral fraction at high redshift to date.

Due to the distribution of neutral hydrogen being smoothly distributed in small clouds around the quasar, this limitation corresponds to an upper limit on the speed of light integral optical depth Υ < 0.027, or a lower limit on the proportion of neutral hydrogen f ≥ 0.95.

This constraint is an order of magnitude more sensitive than the best measurements at this redshift previously, and it can reduce the uncertainty region by a factor of 2, thereby providing the most precise test of dark matter properties to date.
"True cluster" is a model of genuine clustering.
It is a set of points in n-dimensional space, where each cluster is represented by a hypersphere.
The true cluster matching problem is to find a perfect matching between clusters and points, such that the distance between the points and their matched clusters is minimized as much as possible.
From this work, we propose a fast algorithm to solve the Truecluster matching problem, which matches each point to the cluster center that is closest to it in n-dimensional space.
The proposed algorithm first randomly divides multiple units in n-dimensional space.
Then, select a cell from the query cell, find all clusters with centers in the query cell, and assign each point to the cluster center that is closest to that point.
We have demonstrated through experiments that the proposed algorithm is faster than existing approximate matching algorithms and produces good matching results on high-dimensional datasets.
This work was published in the proceedings of the 34th International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval.

The COMBO-17 satellite conducted a survey of the Northern Hemisphere sky in four near-infrared wavelengths, covering an area of 1.1 x 1.2 degrees in these bands, which roughly correspond to wavelengths of 0.65, 0.85, 1.35, and 2.2 micrometers in static frame visible light.
Here, we analyze the galaxy morphology and environment in the Abell 901/902 supercluster at a redshift of z = 0.33.
The structure covers an area of approximately 20 square degrees and contains 775 galaxies with measured redshifts, making it one of the largest structures discovered to date at these redshifts.
We found that 42% of the members of Abel 901/902 are early-type galaxies, which is a phenomenon of excessive density compared to the average field.

In early-type galaxies, a particularly high proportion appears in the core regions of superclusters, approximately 10 h$^{-1}$ Mpc, and in regions with a lower average redshift, redshift 0.31, compared to the rest of the structure which is about 20 h$^{-1}$.
Mpc, suggesting recent disturbances.

We did not detect large-scale structures in the density distribution of late-type galaxies, although we note that this may be due to the spatial resolution of the COMBO-17 survey at this redshift, which is 6.2 h$^{-1}$ kpc.

Our conclusion is that some early-type galaxies in Abel 901/902 are the result of recent mergers, and the morphological transformation process of cluster galaxies may still be ongoing during this period.

This phenomenon has been well studied in terms of the trends of single technologies, such as Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) and Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access (WiMAX).
A complementary trend of this innovation is the transferability or joint applicability of inventions, meaning the ability of inventions to be applied across various technologies.
We study the trends of joint applicability by mapping patents to technology categories using a combination of descriptive and category-based hierarchical Bayesian techniques.

We found that the joint applicability has increased over time, with a peak emerging in the late 1990s and early 2000s, which may reflect the rapid development of the semiconductor industry and the proliferation of mobile communication.

We also found that common applicability demonstrates a significant regional pattern: regions with advanced corresponding technologies have higher common applicability, including the Kanto region of Japan and California in the United States.
These geographical differences may reflect variations in regulations, competition, and consumer preferences.
In the improvement of gravitational theory, the dominant order behavior of the Friedman equations is usually modified by an additional function related to curvature invariants.
For specific f(R) models, this function usually diverges at certain points in field space where the model exhibits singularities in the equation of state (EOS).
These EOS singularities correspond to infinite values of density, pressure, or both.
In this work, we explore the phenomenological significance of the singularities in these equations of state, with a particular focus on the special case of finite time singularities.

We explored the model parameter space that makes the universe non-physical due to singularities in the equation of state, and proposed to represent this problem as an exclusion plot in the model parameter plane.

We demonstrate that such exclusion plots are significantly constrained by existing data from Type Ia supernovae (SNIa), baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO), and direct detection experiments, allowing only a small region of this parameter space.
We have proposed a new EOS (equation of state) formula that performs well across all parameter spaces, and we demonstrate that this significantly expands the feasible model space.
In addition to validating existing results, this also demonstrates the ability of the current data to exclude non-physical models.
Finally, we demonstrate that the EOS singularity causes certain regions of field space to become ghosts—these unitary theories have propagating negative energy degrees of freedom.
This type of spatial area can be excluded through the local gravitational constraints in the testing of the equivalence principle.
We indicate that these constraints are sufficient to exclude all regions of the phantom parameter space, further strengthening the argument for the f(R) model as a standard theory of gravity.
The brightness function (LF) is one of the most fundamental statistics in observational cosmology.
The VVDS type-1 active galactic nucleus (AGN) sample represents the largest and most complete sample of active galactic nucleus spectra to date.
This paper presents the luminosity functions of VVDS-deep and VVDS-wide at 2.2, 3.6, 4.9, 7, and 7.7 microns, based on 97, 37, 26, 53, and 20 unique redshifts, respectively.
We found that the spatial density of optically bright active galactic nuclei (Mλ≥−23.5) at z≤2 is consistent with the local value.
The evolution of the weak end slope is more pronounced, while the bright end slope is found to be α = −1.8⪘(Mλ/−23.5)½−0.5, for Mλ3.
At all redshifts, the luminosity functions (LFs) are relatively similar, indicating that the luminosity corrections are almost constant at these redshifts.

We attempted to fit a simple phenomenological form to the weak-end slope and found that the evolution can be well described by λ* ∝ (1+z)−3.0 at z < 2, while at higher redshifts, we found λ* ∝ (1+z)−4.9.
We excluded the possibility that the faint-end slope is constant at α = -0.5 and found that α = -1.8 ⪘ (Mλ/−23.5)½ − 0.7 when Mλ < −24.

The brightness function of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) exhibits extreme evolution in its faint-end slope, driven by the presence of a relatively small number of bright quasars, whose number density (per unit volume) at z=3 is as much as eight times higher than today.

In the context of such a rapid evolution of the spatial density of optically faint active galactic nuclei (AGNs), this indicates that most actively accreting supermassive black holes are difficult to detect, and that most of their growth may occur at very high redshifts.
The author comes from the VIRGO and VVDS collaboration organizations located in France and Switzerland.
This work was partially funded by the European Union's Sixth Framework Programme, grant numbers RITA-CT-2004-505304 and 011604, awarded to G.P.
The significant difference in the lifetimes of neutral B mesons may suggest the existence of new particles that have different weak interactions.
For example, this difference may occur in scenarios of supersymmetry (SUSY), where the lightest neutralinos would form such particles.

Measuring the lifetime differences of these mesons can provide a window into supersymmetric parameters and may even constrain the supersymmetry parameter space when combined with other experimental results.
Due to the significant differences in lifespan compared to the usual two mass variations, a new type of exotic Higgs particle may also make important contributions to these masses.
This may explain the latent factors that have still not been explained in several experiments.
These scenarios can be tested in the next round of B meson experiments, both directly through improved measurements of these masses and indirectly through the new constraints on these models.
The significant difference in lifetimes of neutral B mesons may suggest the existence of new particles with different weak interactions.
For example, this difference may appear in a supersymmetric (SUSY) scenario, in which case the lightest neutral exotic boson will form such a particle.

Measuring the lifetime differences of these mesons can provide a window into supersymmetry (SUSY) parameters and may even constrain the supersymmetry parameter space when combined with results from other experiments.
Due to the significant differences in lifespan and the usual two mass differences, a new specific Higgs could also make a substantial contribution to these masses.
This may explain the still unexplained invisible phenomena shown through multiple experiments.

These scenarios can be tested in the next round of B-cant experiments, either by directly measuring the improvements in these quantities or by testing them indirectly through the new constraints on these models.
Recently, a phononic bandgap (PBG) structure for microwave solids has been proposed.
It is composed of a one-dimensional (1D) photonic crystal channel with defects and is coated with a surface plasmon layer (SPL).
The PBG structure provides the possibility of achieving a high phonon quality factor (Q) in a compact size.
We designed, manufactured, and conducted experimental research on such photonic bandgap resonators.
The resonant frequency was found to be 19.35 GHz, with a spectral width of 0.5 GHz.
The measured line width and Q factor are highly consistent with the numerical results.
It also indicates that the non-autonomous phase dynamics within the photonic bandgap resonator can be effectively modeled using the nonlinear Schrödinger equation.
The non-autonomous term in the equation is caused by SPL.
Such non-autonomous terms provide additional nonlinearity, capable of stimulating the rupture of light waves.
Indeed, experiments have shown that optical fluctuation phenomena occur at the critical power of the external pump.
The timing of the breakup is very consistent with the numerical results.
The potential mechanisms of this phenomenon have been discussed.

In quantum mechanics, it has been discovered that the act of observing the measurement results of a physical system retrospectively alters the system's wave function, leading to the so-called "which-way" (WW) interference effect.

This phenomenon is used to explain many counterintuitive quantum mechanical phenomena, such as the "Schrödinger's cat" problem and the "many-worlds" interpretation of quantum mechanics, which views the act of observation as a branching quantum event.

We present a generalization of the Bohn rule here, which we call the "Weak Generalized Bohn Rule" (WGBR). According to this rule, the WW effect is not considered to change the probability of potential outcomes, but rather provides a new causal explanation for the observation of these potential outcomes.

Unlike previous interpretations of quantum mechanics, this new interpretation does not require the exclusion of the many-worlds interpretation and does not conflict with existing interpretations, such as the Copenhagen interpretation.
We tested our theory on a single photon in a one-dimensional wave packet and observed the expected WW interference pattern according to WGBR.

We also discussed the potential applications of our theory, including understanding quantum thermodynamics, predicting when quantum systems will respond differently to positive and negative measurement outcomes, and constructing quantum algorithms without using explicit wave function evolution.
Using a relativistic heat flux reconstruction solver, we have derived a new unified description of ultra-relativistic hydrodynamics and magnetohydrodynamics in arbitrary magnetic fields.
This is the first time we are solving coupled fluid dynamics, special relativistic heat transfer, general relativistic magnetohydrodynamics, and Maxwell's equations within a single framework.

We simulated various extreme fluid configurations, such as nonlinear ultra-relativistic shocks, relativistic two-dimensional blast waves in a strong magnetic field, relativistic two-dimensional Kelvin-Helmholtz instability, and one-dimensional vortices seeded in two dimensions.
Our simulation results are in excellent agreement with special relativistic fluid dynamics, general relativistic magnetohydrodynamics, and the evolution of magnetic fields.

Researchers have long contemplated whether time travel is possible, and if so, whether paradoxes such as the grandfather paradox can be logically disproven.

In a recent article, Albin et al. proposed a test to examine the "time travel paradox" using neutral $K$ and $B$ mesons, which consistently transition from incoherent quantum states to coherent quantum states.
This transformation means removing the meson from its current disordered state and placing it in a coherent superposition of all possible momentum states.

CP symmetry is a fundamental property of the universe, ensuring that such transformations are reversible. If time travel paradoxes are logically disproven, it would trigger disturbances that violate CP symmetry.
The team at the Jefferson Laboratory completed the transformation and conducted a search for CP violation, but the result was zero.
An invalid result rules out the possibility of logically refuting the time travel paradox and further indicates that the universe has logical consistency.
During the 2005 outbreak, the high-energy radiation of GRO J1655-40 revealed through INTEGRAL spectroscopy was described.

This famous black hole X-ray binary system consists of a neutron star as the primary star, which orbits a black hole with a mass 18 times that of the Sun at a close distance (13-31 R_s), completing one orbit every 2.87 hours.

It is suspected that accretion onto the neutron star is occurring in this system, as indicated by its spectral classification as a Z source, which is characterized by a strong and sometimes periodic high-velocity wind from the neutron star.
These winds may be caused by the transfer of energy from the accretion disk to the neutron star.
In 2005, the outburst of GRO J1655-40 was detected by the INTEGRAL observatory on January 28, 2005, and reached its maximum on February 24.
The work presented in this article focuses on the high-energy spectrum of GRO J1655-40 during this time period.

The main result of this work is the discovery of a cutoff power-law component in the high-energy spectrum of GRO J1655-40, which contributes approximately 50% of the flux over nearly three decades of energy.
This component is not commonly found in X-ray binaries, so its discovery by INTEGRAL represents a new paradigm for high-energy production in these systems.

The cutoff power law component is considered an extension of the blackbody component from the accretion disk. This component typically appears in black hole X-ray binaries and is generally thought to be a characteristic of the network gamma rays emitted from the inner regions of the accretion disk surrounding the black hole.

The discovery of the cutoff power law in this system, with neutron stars at its core, represents a new paradigm for high-energy production in black hole X-ray binaries, and indicates that disk accretion is not the only form of high-energy production in these binaries.
It is possible that this component is the result of a unique new type of high-energy production within the system, which may be influenced by the strong neutron star wind.
This could be a promising area for exploration through further and more detailed analysis of these data.

In a wireless broadcasting channel with multiple transmitting antennas and one receiving antenna, it is feasible and beneficial to allow certain transmitting antennas to be turned off, as long as the signal energy is reasonably distributed among the antennas.

This article studies the system design problem of how many transmitters should be turned on and what amount of transmission power should be used in order to maximize the number of receivers that can recover the transmitted information at an arbitrarily low cost.
We consider the case where the transmitter has complete knowledge of the channel state information (CSI), as well as the case where the transmitter has only statistical channel state information.

Under the condition that perfect channel state information (CSI) can be obtained at the transmitter, we determine the optimal number of active transmitters and the corresponding transmission power to maximize the number of receivers that can recover information at arbitrarily low cost.

We proceed to describe the scaling characteristics of the number of active transmitters and their corresponding transmission power in relation to the block length of channel coding, up to the logarithmic factor. In the symmetric case, the channel remains unchanged under the arrangement of antennas.

When the transmitter only obtains statistical Channel State Information (CSI), we provide sufficient conditions for low-complexity effective coding and interference management to achieve near-optimal performance. Furthermore, we describe a specific coding and interference management scheme that can achieve the effect of up to 2/3 of the maximum possible number of receivers.
The astrophysical supplementary information for the ASCC-2.5 catalog of radial velocities of stars in the Milky Way has been proposed.

The directory includes the radial velocities of about 55,000 stars obtained through spectral analysis, as well as the average radial velocities of 516 Galactic open star clusters and their associations.
The catalog can be used for the kinematic study of the galactic disk and can be applied to the dynamic evolution studies of open star clusters and their associated objects.
The English word "zephyr" can be translated into Chinese as "微风" (wēi fēng), which means a gentle breeze.

Title: Astrophysical Supplement to the ASCC-2.5 Catalogue of Radial Velocities of Stars in the Milky Way

Abstract: This paper presents an astrophysical supplement to the ASCC-2.5 catalogue of radial velocities of stars in the Milky Way.

The directory includes the radial velocities of approximately 55,000 stars derived from spectral analysis, as well as the average radial velocities of 516 open star clusters and stellar associations in the Milky Way.
The catalog can be used to study the kinematics of the Galactic disk and can be applied to the dynamic evolution of open star clusters and their associated entities.
The existing research on extragalactic background light (EBL) has utilized measurement data from the optical and far-infrared wavelength regions.
These measurements are affected by various systematic uncertainties, and the cosmic background light (EBL) in the ultraviolet (UV) and soft X-ray wavelength regions remains largely unconstrained.

In this paper, we use gamma-ray data from the Fermi Large Area Telescope to constrain the extragalactic background light (EBL) in the extreme ultraviolet (EUV) wavelength range, covering a few electron volts, specifically electromagnetic radiation with effective photon energies from 10 to 511 keV.

Given the significant uncertainties in stellar formation modeling and gamma-ray opacity, the limits on the extragalactic background light (EBL) proposed in this letter should be interpreted as a range of possible star formation rates and total extreme ultraviolet (EUV) luminosity densities.
However, measuring the photon density of extreme ultraviolet light (EUV) is an important step in understanding the energy dynamics of galaxy formation in cosmic time.
In this article, we consider the problem of identifying laggards in data streams.
The identification of laggards is an important issue in the design and analysis of distributed systems, and it has received widespread attention in the literature.
The classic solution to this problem builds a logical clock with timestamps, which often requires a large number of timestamps to converge.
Recently, variants of Bloom filters have started to be used for identifying lagging data, enabling data stream applications to operate with lower memory consumption and faster detection capabilities.

However, Bloom filters are irreversible, so existing lagging process identification schemes based on Bloom filters (whether in the literature or in commercial systems) are essentially blind: they cannot accurately identify which processes are the laggards.
We overcame this limitation by leveraging the power of Newton's identities, which are a set of three reversible deterministic matrix equations.
Unlike Bloom filters, our solution will accurately identify laggards.

We described an algorithm that can identify lagging processes with high probability using only two timestamps from each stream element, particularly being able to accurately identify lagging processes among any specified n processes. We validated our approach through extensive experiments on various benchmark data streams, including real data from large production systems, and demonstrated that our method outperforms existing techniques by several orders of magnitude in terms of performance.
Flory's model for polymerization in dilute solutions assumes that the radius of new monomer shells does not depend on the number of constituent units in the cluster.
This contradicts the original models of Smoluchowski and Marcus-Lushnikov, which account for this effect.
In this work, we derived the Smoluchowski and Marcus-Lushnikov models starting from the Flory model, both of which take into account excluded volume and density-dependent interactions.
The translation of the Chinese sentence "考虑了精确处理和均场理论" into English is: "Considered precise handling and mean field theory."
In the theory of uniform fields, the correlation function is expressed through the dual correlation function, which is obtained through simulation.

The Flory model that accounts for excluded volume interactions but lacks density-dependent terms can be used to describe the Smoluchowski model, while the Flory model that incorporates both excluded volume and density-dependent interactions can be used to describe the Marcus-Lushnikov model.
As a verification, we simulated the Marcus-Lushnikov model and found that it aligns well with the exact solution.

At a solid-solid interface, two mutually perpendicular velocity components were measured. These components change with variations in driving speed and pulse interval, as the interface propagates under the driving force that includes phonoson-assisted components.
The interface is displayed through colored scanning tunneling microscope images of tungsten films on the six vertex cylindrical defects on the tungsten telluride surface.
The auxiliary component of phonon driving force originates from the coupling between the Shockley-Read-Hall fluctuations at the interface and the phonon modes within the resonance scale.
These two velocity components are coupled, and the magnitude of the coupled components increases as the pulse interval decreases.

The coupled velocity components remain significant when the pulse intervals exceed approximately 0.3 picoseconds, which corresponds to the driving force being insufficient to overcome the energy barrier of the separated interface modes.

The results were discussed in the context of effective interface temperature and from the perspective of the feedback effects caused by interface fluctuations; both aspects are crucial for understanding energy transfer and energy landscape fluctuations in surface nanostructures.
Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) are large-scale clouds of solar plasma and magnetic fields released from the Sun into space.
Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) can cause significant disturbances in the Earth's magnetosphere, leading to the loss of satellite signals and instability in power grid voltage.
Due to high-resolution numerical simulations, we have discovered two different CME dynamic patterns: one is fast, and the other is slow.
A fast coronal mass ejection (CME), usually originating from sunspots, can reach speeds of over 1000 kilometers per second.
It is driven by the rapid reconnection of sheared magnetic fields, and its impact on the magnetosphere is immense.

In contrast, the slow coronal mass ejection (CME) originates from sunspot regions and is released through small magnetic X-points, with a speed of about 300 kilometers per second, which is much lower than that of other types of CME.

These coronal mass ejections will not significantly disturb the magnetosphere, but due to the large amount of flux involved, they may still lead to major power grid disturbances and satellite signal loss.
We suggest that slow coronal mass ejections (CMEs) are more common than fast ones, but they are often overlooked because they usually do not cause severe disturbances.

With the advancement of nanotechnology, there has been a great interest in the electrical and mechanical properties of nanoparticles.
One of the main problems in these studies is that it is very difficult to use continuous models to simulate the behavior of nanoparticles in real materials due to the enormous differences in scale.
In this article, we developed a discrete dynamical model for the collisions and evolution of a finite number of nanoparticles, inspired by recent composite materials continuum theory.

The model was derived as an approximation of a continuous model with a finite number of particles, incorporating coupled nonlinear delay equations to describe the time-dependent position and shape of the particles.

We use the model to study the scaling characteristics of nano-plasmas and find that for certain ranges of parameters, the particle dynamics are ergodic. In this case, the average can be estimated by time averaging the particle positions and shapes.
We demonstrate that in the traversing state, the size and shape of the nano-plasmon are well approximated by the radius of particle equilibrium positions and the inverse convex hull.

Recent papers have proposed new equations of state (EOS) for quantum hard spheres (QHS), which are more consistent than the widely used quantum ideal gas (QIG) equations of state in quantum many-body theory and nuclear experiments.

The majority of these proposed equations of state (EOS) are based on transformations of many-body quantum Hamiltonians, making the quantum many-body systems resemble an equivalent mean-field system, while introducing corresponding "quantum liquid" equations of state (EOS) for nuclear quantum many-body systems.
This paper critically assesses the status of the new proposed category of equations of state.

By conducting a general critique of the assumptions underlying various proposed equations of state (EOS), we performed a detailed analysis of the proposed equation of state for neutron matter, and the results obtained are significantly better than those previously proposed.

We then applied these analyses to a proposed equation of state for symmetric nuclear matter, and the resulting analytical outcomes showed improvements compared to the widely used QIG equation of state and the previously proposed neutron matter equation of state.

The improvement in this performance is achieved by imposing new constraints on the equation of state (EOS), which are based on the nuclear saturation properties at low density, and by conducting a more complex fitting of the EOS behavior at high density.

Finally, we present analytic and numerical results for a proposed equation of state (EOS) for isospin nuclear matter, which is consistent with the general criticisms previously raised and with the detailed analysis of neutron matter and isospin nuclear matter equations of state.

This article presents a new class of nuclear matter equations of state that are more consistent with nuclear many-body theory and experiments than the widely used quantum ideal gas (QIG) equation of state.

These new equations of state, which we call the Quantum Hard Sphere (QHS) equations of state, are derived by rewriting the many-body Hamiltonian in second quantization, using creation and annihilation operators that satisfy the usual commutation relations.

Next, the many-body Hamiltonian is transformed so that the nuclear quantum many-body system resembles an equivalent non-interacting particle system (the "mean-field" system), which can be analyzed using standard classical many-body theoretical techniques.
This has led to a new proposed equation of state for nuclear matter.

The Hamiltonian of the equivalent mean-field system is parameterized by the effective interaction energy and the chemical potential, with the effective interaction energy given by the second virial coefficient of the original many-body Hamiltonian.
The parameterization of this Hamiltonian allows the author to fit the predicted equation of state (EOS) with results from nuclear many-body theory and the ground state properties of nuclear matter.

The proposed equation of state for symmetric nuclear matter has undergone detailed analysis, resulting in significantly improved analytical results that surpass the widely used quantum ideal gas equation of state and the previously proposed equation of state for neutron matter.
Finally, the proposed equation of state is shown to be consistent with a more general class of proposed equations of state, which is achieved by relaxing a key assumption of the model.

Objective: In this work, we modeled the high-frequency quasi-periodic oscillations (HFQPOs), also known as millihertz quasi-periodic oscillations (mHz QPOs), observed from certain black hole X-ray binaries.

We focus on a specific example, namely the European Photon Imaging Camera (EPIC) instrument on the European Space Agency (ESA) XMM-Newton space telescope, which detected several high-frequency quasi-periodic oscillations (HFQPOs) in the X-ray emissions from the low-mass X-ray binary Serxajs A at frequencies of 30 and 300 Hz in early 2015.

clean_wm_text: The energy dependence of these high-frequency quasi-periodic oscillations (HFQPOs) cannot be well described by current accretion disk models, in which the observed frequencies are determined by the Keplerian orbital frequency of the material in the accretion disk around the compact object.
Therefore, we propose a new HFQPO model in which the QPO is caused by resonant-driven fluctuations generated within the accretion flow close to a black hole or neutron star.
The turbulence is driven by global instabilities in the accretion flow, particularly magnetic Rayleigh-Taylor instability.
The model can successfully describe the energy-dependent behavior in HFQPOs.

In addition, we also demonstrate that the model can simultaneously explain other observed spectral behaviors of Serxajs A, such as the variability of the iron Kα fluorescence line and the observed X-ray spectral lag phenomenon.
The cooling flow clusters in galaxies have an extremely high cooling rate on the scale of galaxy clusters, reaching up to 30 million degrees per square degree.
Although the interstellar medium in such star clusters has low entropy, it is still observed to be cooling in the X-ray band.
Z3146 is one of the most dramatic cold-flowing meteor clusters, and its name comes from its extreme X-ray temperature of Z=3146 keV, which is the highest temperature known among any star clusters.

Observational results from Chandra and the XMM-Newton X-ray Observatory, as well as data from the Keck II Telescope and the Very Large Telescope, have been used to study the morphology, physical state, and dynamics of cooling flow gas.

We found that the gas is distributed in two large-scale and distinct flows: one is a western cooling flow that extends to most of the cooling radius, while the other, a smaller eastern flow, is located at the offset position of the cold core and is more concentrated.
Both types of flows are smooth, without bubbles or irregular phenomena, and the distribution curves of temperature, abundance, and entropy perform well.

The total mass of the gas in the cooling flow is estimated to be \(2.8 \times 10^{massiveyon} (h_0 = 0.704 - see section 5.1)\), with approximately \(3.3 \times 10^{massiveyon}\) of that mass potentially existing in the form of galaxies, making Z3146 one of the heaviest known galaxy clusters.
In the context of stellar pulsations, a thermal instability that leads to the formation of oscillatory long-period patterns is described.
This instability is manifested in the presence of a temperature gradient, where the cold side of the interface is unstable.
The oscillations resulting from this are similar to the famous Kelvin-Helmholtz instability, but the dependence on the wave number is periodic rather than monotonic.
Using modern opacity calculations, the possible locations of instability were explored, and the conditions for its occurrence were identified.
The results of the numerical calculations confirm the validity of the proposed theory and demonstrate the emergence of oscillatory secular patterns.

The authors suggest that oscillatory secular patterns similar to those described in this paper may also occur in other astrophysical systems (such as in accretion disks, gas halos of galaxies, etc.), indicating that these patterns may be universally present.

The long-term oscillation patterns are particularly noteworthy because they can explain certain characteristics of older and warmer stars, such as their oblate shapes and the presence of equatorial features (such as bright spots and bright rings).
For this paper, we consider the general case of a MIMO system with limited-rate channel state feedback and switching power strategies.
We first describe the limits of achievable rates as the length of the feedback channel approaches infinity.
To illustrate the tightness of this characteristic, we provide a counterexample where the attainable rate is strictly lower than the limit.
Then, we characterize the best switching power supply strategy.

Interestingly, for a fixed feedback length, we demonstrate that the switch exhibits threshold behavior in terms of channel realization, and that the off state is most likely to occur when the channel is in a weak interference state.
Additionally, in environments with strong interference, even if more power can increase the achievable data rate, it will also increase the feedback burden.
We further study the optimal strategy during the intermediate interference phase and characterize the optimal switch ratio based on the effective channel gain.
The numerical results confirm the insights from the analysis.
In string theory, Wilson loops provide a powerful tool for analyzing the configurations of classical strings.

For more general normative theories, especially quantum chromodynamics (QCD) under large nucleon momentum transfer, color confinement is more appropriately described by quark-antiquark bound states or mesons, rather than free-moving colored fermions.

In particular, in the calculations of hadron spectra using classical quantum chromodynamics (QCD) with strong interactions, a fundamental quantity is the Wilson loop. In the light-front formalism, the Wilson loop is defined as the path-ordered exponential of the gluon field along a closed path \( C \) in spacetime.
The sentence translates to: "Usually choose the basic representation of the standard group."
The dependence on the Wilson loop and its relationship with the dynamics of the loop is more complex.
Especially for large rings, the area law no longer holds.
For the small loop, the area law has been modified to be proportional to the circumference \( C \) of the loop.
This phenomenon is called the boundary law.
The relationship between the laws of area and perimeter has been observed for over 40 years.
Recently, a string theory has been proposed that implements long Wilson loops in the fundamental representation of the \( SU(N_c) \) group using eleven-dimensional supergravity.
The corresponding string configuration is a graviton with infinite spacetime size.
This allows for a detailed comparison between field theory and gravitational results.
For finite-sized rings, new phenomena similar to quantum mechanics may arise.
For example, it may acknowledge discrete energy levels, whose spectrum is linearly proportional to the area of the ring.
For this article, we propose a more general class of string configurations, namely finite-size gravitons corresponding to rings of arbitrary shapes.
We use the second fundamental representation of $SU(N_c)$ to represent the loop.
The corresponding gravitational background is the truncation of type IIB supergravity on \( S^5 \times T^{11} \).
Under such a backdrop, spectra similar to those of quantum mechanics have already been studied.
Specifically, rings of different classical shapes exhibit different behaviors in quasi-quantum states.
We also proposed a string interpretation of the observed spectrum.
Finally, we briefly discuss the implications of our results for quantum chromodynamics (QCD) and consider potential future work.
We introduce and study a type of fibrosis promotion called explosive fibrosis.
These fiber diagrams promote the concept of fibrations, allowing for fiber bundles that may have non-empty boundaries and permitting the fibers to be manifolds with boundaries.
We study these objects through the filters of the mapped heap.

"We have proven that explosive fibrillation with surface fibers is a smooth, bounded whorl body, and we have demonstrated a mapping to a classified superposition decomposition, as a union of a smooth mapping with another smooth mapping, which maps to a certain homogeneous superposition of the classified superposition."

We provide two examples of explosive fiber structures: one is the mapping of a mapping stack of Riemann surfaces with two boundary components, and the other is a classification map of a surface fiber stacked on a surface.
We also discussed the same theoretical framework of explosive fibrosis.
We define *explosion fiber* as a homotopy fiber, which is the homotopy fiber of a mapping of topological fibers.
We indicate that the homotopy types of explosive fibers can be classified by a well-degenerated simplicial set.

We introduce the concepts of "exploded weak equivalence" and "exploded fibration," and provide two examples of these mapping categories: the mapping space of exploded morphisms and the mapping space of topological fibrations are weakly equivalent, and the homotopy fibers of exploded fibration mappings are exploded fibers.

We demonstrate that the homotopy type of an explosive space can be constructed from its egg stairs through a series of functors that conform to the models, which represent fibrations, explosive fibrations, and weak equivalences.
We speculate that these model category structures describe higher-order compression at the level of homotopy categories.
We expect that these Hofhofer transformations will serve as an algebraic model for weak mappings between appropriate mappings, genuine mappings, and explosive spaces.
One main example of an explosion space is the classification space of explosion groups.

We demonstrate that this is weakly equivalent to the mapping stack of unit intervals with marked points, and that its underlying space is homotopically equivalent to the infinite permutation space of a pointed topological space.
Finally, we discuss the parallel transport of vectors in explosion fiberization.

We define a *smooth vector* or instanton as a quadruple that includes a vector located in the total space, a path traversing the structure group, and two tangent vectors on the fiber over the base, where the tangent vector on the base is the given vector, and the tangent vector that is parallel transported along the path in the fiber is equal to that vector itself.
We demonstrate that the parallel transport of smooth vectors is an exploding fiber structure, and we provide an example of an exploding vector bundle.
We conclude with unresolved questions and directions for future research.
We have provided new ALMA data on the infrared emission of the luminous far-infrared molecular hydrogen CN (HC3N) v=0-1 in the Antennae galaxies (NGC 4038 and NGC 4039).

The analysis of this data provides us with a preliminary perspective on the central 10% region of the system, revealing the characteristics of its bright infrared core starburst (even in the presence of an active galactic nucleus) and its potential relationship with similar galaxies and their nuclear activity.
The bright infrared nuclear starburst in NGC 4418, known for many years as the main contributor to the infrared luminosity in the antenna system (Braine et al. 1993, Downes & Solomon 1998).
The origin of this starburst and its relationship with the buried active galactic nucleus has long been a mystery.

The new ALMA data provides a clear perspective on the dynamics and energy sources of the system’s center within 10 parsecs, based on bright far-infrared molecular hydrogen CN (HC3N) v=0-1 infrared emissions.
"We have detected high outflow motions of up to 400 km/s in this region."
This contrasts sharply with the expected pure gravitational collapse speed, which is estimated to be only 50-100 kilometers per second at that distance.

These high-speed motions may be due to interactions between the molecular gas and undetected components of the reverse molecular gas, as previously suggested based on other clues about the situation in the Milky Way (Bronfman et al. 2016; Zhao et al. 2017).
Our data is completely consistent with the latest findings of Fu et al. (2019), who discovered a star-forming strong radio Seyfert-1 nucleus in NGC 4418.

This indicates that the growth and activity of supermassive black holes are closely related to the growth of their host galaxies and the occurrence of nuclear starbursts, similar to the situation in the Milky Way.
In summary, the ALMA data on the starburst in the Tianyan galaxy provides us with a clear view of its nature and dynamics.
This may be driven by the gravitational influence of both: one is an undetected counter-rotating molecular gas component, and the other is a buried active galactic nucleus.

We detected a high-speed outflow driven by molecular gas within a range of 10 seconds of our system's center, which is consistent with the recent findings of Fu et al. (2019), who detected a radio-bright active galactic nucleus in this source.
This indicates that the growth of supermassive black holes and their activity are closely related to the growth of their host galaxies and the onset of nuclear starbursts.
Overall, the ALMA data on the starburst in the nucleus of the Scorpius galaxy provides us with a clear perspective on its nature and dynamics.
Planets are an important component of any planetary system, and gas giants are particularly noteworthy because they may harbor life.

Although planetary exploration is usually the first step in determining whether a planet is located in the "habitable zone," where temperatures are suitable for water to exist in liquid form, there are very few observations regarding this critical area around young stars.
This work is the first to directly detect infrared radiation from the region around a giant planet in the habitable zone of a nearby star.

This is accomplished through L-band (3.78-3.84 micrometers) spectral technology, but because observations from space are more difficult than in other bands and the details provided are not as rich as those from shorter wavelengths, this technology has not yet been widely used in planetary exploration.

Through the infrared telescope on the Spitzer Space Telescope, we obtained high-quality spectral data for two nearby stars, namely Tucanae and Beta Pic, which belong to their corresponding age groups of moving clusters.

We observed the performance of each star under the L' (3.74-3.81 microns) and L" (3.84-3.94 microns) water vapor filters, which are highly sensitive to the infrared radiation reflected by planets in the habitable zones of these stars.
No planets were discovered in these observations, and upper limits for the planetary water abundance in the Tucana galaxy and the Beta Pictoris galaxy were set at 1.2×10−5 and 1.3×10−5, respectively.
These results are consistent with theoretical predictions, namely the water abundance on typical planets within the habitable zones of these stars.
A0620-00 is an X-ray binary located in the center of the globular cluster NGC 6206, most likely composed of a black hole that is accreting material from a Be star companion (Menou et al.).
