We obtained the near-infrared (NIR) spectrum of the system using the NIRSPEC spectrograph on the W. M. Keck II telescope.
The spectral resolution of the NIRSPEC spectrometer is approximately R ≈ 22,500, covering a wavelength range of 1.0 to 2.4 microns.
We use this data to determine the absorption and emission spectra of the donor star.
The donor is an A-type star, whose absorption spectrum shows Balmer lines and P-Cygni lines that are consistent with the expected A0 Ve spectral classification.
We also detected the absorption feature of the carbon dioxide band in the donor spectrum and measured the equivalent width of W(CO).

Approximately 1.0 ± 0.2 Å. This phenomenon of detecting CO band head absorption in the donor spectrum of X-ray binary stars is surprising and raises new questions about the composition and evolutionary status of the companion star.

We compared the NIRSPEC spectrum with the spectra from the VLT/ISAAC near-infrared spectrometer and found that the NIRSPEC data is consistent with a constant temperature photosphere, which is in line with the expectations for A-type stars.
However, we detected strong Br γ line emission at 2.16 micrometers, along with weak emissions.
He emits in the Ca II triplet at 2.06 micrometers.
The emission does not exist in the VLT/ISAAC spectrum.
We model the NIRSPEC data as a simple gas and dust shell surrounding the star, and we demonstrate that this model can produce the observed Br γ emission and the excess near-infrared flux.
We discussed the origin of gas and dust in the donor star environment and their effects.
On January 10, 2007, the Spitzer Space Telescope was moved to a new sun-synchronous orbit, allowing it to provide clearer views of the entire sky every three days.
To characterize the response of the Spitzer Space Telescope, we conducted a survey of the IC 348 nebula, which is a nearby star-forming region.
Using the data from this new track, we detected 70 structures with strengths exceeding 3.5 times the background σ, with a total of 56 confirmed young stellar objects (YSOs).
We also detected 915 structures with signal strengths greater than 3.5 sigma but below our detection threshold, which we identify as potential young stellar objects (YSOs).
The high level of detection and the high proportion of previously detected sources indicate that our results are statistically significant.
We detected 70 structures, with signal strengths exceeding 3.5 standard deviations above the background, and confirmed a total of 56 young stellar objects (YSOs).
We also detected 915 structures whose signal strength is greater than 3.5 sigma but below our detection threshold, which we identify as potential Young Stellar Objects (YSOs).
The high level of detection and the high proportion of previously detected sources indicate that our results have statistical significance.

This work is the first time the Spitzer Space Telescope has studied the entire range of the IC 348 nebula at multiple wavelengths, and it may help us understand the formation of single and binary stars.
A massive protocluster was found in the S255N region, which could be one of the largest structures formed in the universe due to its extremely short dynamical timescale.

The optical and near-infrared data analysis from multiple telescopes shows that yellow-green (YG) stars exhibit a density excess relative to the diffuse background star cluster. Their distribution is consistent with a spherical Gaussian distribution, with a projected size of 1.6 x 1.3 kpc (2.2 x 1.7 Mpc), which is equivalent to 0.14% of the diameter of the Orion Arm.

This over-density is at least partly supported by the dust faint optical radiation measurements from the Spitzer Space Telescope, and is consistent with the results of infrared spectral surveys, which show a high number density of young, hot, and massive stars.

The largest stars can have initial masses reaching several hundred times that of the Sun, with the current implied formation mass being in the thousands of solar masses, as their disks appear to be hungry and are thought to be in the main sequence phase.

The derived mass and size are consistent with the predicted stellar mass threshold for the formation of intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs), which is an expected characteristic of the growth of supermassive black holes at the centers of star clusters.

The age and mass of the star cluster are consistent with the formation of intermediate-mass black holes (IMBH) from seeds generated by the remnants of massive stars, although the possibility of merging lower-mass seeds cannot be ruled out.

Regarding a special velocity of the star cluster relative to the local rest frame, which is derived from the motion measurements of the bright star members, as well as the projected mass along the line of sight, both suggest that the star cluster may not have reached a state of equilibrium.

If there exists a supermassive black hole, as suggested by the hypothesis that it may form through the seeds of intermediate-mass black holes or the remnants of very massive stars, then the observed characteristics of star clusters will systematically deviate from the expected characteristics of classical star clusters.
This fascinating object suggests either that supermassive seeds formed outside the star cluster and grew through accretion, or that multiple black hole formation modes exist.

Future optical spectral studies of star cluster members, combined with infrared research on dust emissions and the search for intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs), may help determine the most likely formation pathways for this mysterious celestial body.
Reconnection is an important process that shapes energy release in many magnetized systems, such as the solar atmosphere, laboratory magnetospheres, and the Earth's magnetotail.
In these systems, large-scale structures reconnect and evolve on a microscopic scale over time scales ranging from tens of seconds to tens of minutes.
In this letter, we present a dynamical method related to reconnection—the electromagnetic tearing mode—that can address multiple microscale problems.
This process is essentially global, spanning different scales, and yields steady-state solutions that are consistent with the latest simulation results.
In addition, in the limit of a strong guiding field, the model simplifies to a wave equation, and the solutions can be easily constructed in appropriate physical variables.

We conclude that the tearing mode is an important microprocess that addresses the slower evolving reconnection dynamics and predicts that high-energy plasmas (such as those in the solar atmosphere) will exhibit stable tearing mode reconnection states.

GG Tau is a nearby (2.2 parsecs away) multiple system that contains at least five infrared sources (D'Alessio et al., 2005) and is modeled as a circumbinary disk system surrounding a binary star (White et al., 2004).

The radial optical cuts of the GG Tau system show three separate dust rings, which are radially stratified, with the inner and outer rings extending from the midplane of the system to radii of 20 AU and 40 AU, respectively.
In this study, we explore the possibility that the dust in the circumstellar disk is dynamically related to binary star systems, as suggested by White et al. (2004).
We used ALMA to observe the CO v = 2-1 line with a spatial resolution of 12.8 x 4.8 AU to estimate the radial velocity dispersion of the gas in the ring.
We found that the kinematics of dust and gas are consistent within the margin of error, which indicates that the dust and gas in the ring are dynamically coupled.

According to the Toomre parameter and gravitational stability criteria, the observed ring radius and temperature are consistent with the planetary embryo population maintained in its orbit by external perturbing bodies.

We investigated whether the outer ring is affected by external disturbances by calculating the gravitational interactions between the two rings, and we found that the observed shift between the dust peaks is insufficient to maintain the observed ring structure.

However, due to an additional component in the GG Tau system that orbits in an almost counterclockwise direction with a semi-major axis of 210 AU, and the current projected separation of 20 AU, we find that the system is unstable on a timescale of 100 million years.
Therefore, we suggest that the external dust ring is a coplanar companion to the GG Tau binary ring system, as previously proposed by Guilloteau et al. (2013).
Based on the analysis of simple chemical models, the idea that there is inward motion within a starless core has long been proposed.

Such movements are very important because they may be related to the core fragmentation process and the subsequent star formation.

Inward motion can be observed by detecting optical thickness and rotational transition lines (such as NH₃ (J = 1-0)), and the derived spin relaxation time is longer than expected for the gas temperature in regions with lower velocity dispersion.
We have completed a preliminary study using the HCN J = 1-0 line to detect inward motion in dark clouds.
We have achieved excellent system positioning in the core area of TMC-1KP, which includes TMC-1C, 1D, and 1E, well-known locations for low-quality star formation.
The preliminary results of the HCN J = 1-0 line are positive for TMC-1C and TMC-1D, but not for TMC-1E; more detailed analysis is underway.
We also observed a reference location in the adjacent core, called TMC-1F. The TMC-1KP project is an extended version of this work.
We are also seeking more observations of cores within the TMC-1 cloud as well as other starless cores.
We use the term "pointing" to refer to a set of observations of the same area in a selected coordinate system.

A pointer is considered excellent if the noise in the TMC-1KP channel graph is primarily thermal noise, the image is symmetric at the selected coordinates, the intensity range covers at least a 5:1 range, and the transition line is cleanly centered at the selected coordinates.
Image watermarking technology has been widely researched and applied to prevent image theft and copyright infringement.
Most watermarking algorithms embed a single layer of code within the image itself.
According to this work, we propose a watermarking technology that can embed multiple layers of information and detect tampered images.
The first layer of information is random noise, which will disrupt the information but can be easily detected.
The second layer embeds a secret key into the image.
This level cannot be detected through simple visual inspection.
The secret key can be used to regenerate the image, thereby proving its integrity.
Finally, the third layer incorporates a fine-grained version of the secret key.
Since the information embedded in each layer is encrypted with the corresponding private key, only the respective owner can detect and remove this information.
We tested our method on real images, and the results show that our method can detect different types of modifications and is easy to integrate with current image processing workflows.

In the vicinity of the galaxy M82, at the center of a stellar system in an early stage of transitioning into a globular cluster, there exist two high-mass X-ray binaries (HMXBs) known as M82 X-1 and M82 X-4.
They were first discovered by the Einstein Observatory.
The nature of these sources remains unknown.
They are considered candidates for the gamma-ray emissions that drive the discoveries of INTEGRAL.

A strong interstellar proper motion was found in the molecular gas at the center of M82, with a position angle of approximately 70°, confirming the previous hypothesis that M82 X-1 and M82 X-4 are experiencing rapid orbital decay due to gravitational wave radiation.

However, the interpretation of this proposal is challenged by the high X-ray luminosity observed from the sources, which would imply that neutron stars have a large mass at the upper end of the initial mass function, possibly exceeding 40 solar masses, making these objects non-physical.
The alternative scenario involves a high-density environment in which the emission of gravitational waves is enhanced.
The observational cosmological data has been used to statistically describe the mass probability distribution function (PDF) of dark matter halos.

In recent years, high-resolution N-body simulation technology has developed to the point where it can directly reproduce the gravitational clustering of dark matter, making it possible to construct probability density functions (PDFs) of halos with higher mass and spatial resolution.

These provide new insights into the assembly process of halos, allowing for the analysis of the growth of substructures within each halo and the study of the impact of the environment on halo characteristics.

Although the evolution of the dark halo mass function is generally consistent with the predicted scale-free form at the high-mass end, it shows significant deviations only at the low-mass and high-mass ends. However, the probability density function (PDF) exhibits more complex behavior, with significant differences between individual simulations, and it depends on time and environment.

In this article, we use large-volume (greater than 8.5 billion h^{-1} Mpc^3), medium-resolution (with particle mass less than 8.5 x 10^9 h^{-1} M⊙) Millennium-II simulations to study the evolution of the probability density functions (PDFs) of dark matter halo concentration, rotation, and orbital kinetic energy in four environments: clusters, sheets, filaments, and voids.
We also studied the effects of the accumulation, disruption, and merging of the subrings on these properties.
The quality dependency of these distributions changes significantly over time, and the environment has an important impact on the distribution at a fixed moment.
Generally speaking, the halo in films and filaments has a more concentrated mass distribution than their counterparts in clusters or voids at all times.

These differences are reflected in their corresponding mass functions. Filament clusters are the largest and most dynamically evolving structures, while voids are the densest regions in the universe, thus indicating the locations of recent and future structure formation.
These distributions appear to be related to the hierarchical growth of the structure over time and environmental changes.

The spin kinetic energy and orbital kinetic energy exhibit significant differences in different environments. The magnitude of spin shows universal evolution across almost all environments and redshifts, while orbital kinetic energy displays different behavior, with its distribution shifting towards lower values in more evolved environments.

This corresponds to the hierarchical construction of structures in the sheets and filaments, which formed at a relatively later stage, resulting in the accumulation of material in the central area and a reduction of the substructure.
The characteristics of halos in galaxy clusters are largely determined by their major mergers at redshift z > 2, which gives them shorter orbital times and lower orbital kinetic energy.
On the contrary, the evolution of hollow halos is more complex, involving a combination of various processes.

The halo will only survive for a limited time in regions of highest density, while the expansion of the universe will cause matter to disperse, resulting in a decrease in concentration and a reduction in orbital energy.
However, voids in star clusters and sheets can also form at a later time, mainly due to fewer major mergers and more minor interactions.

A brain prosthesis is an electronic device that provides services comparable to the functions of a biological brain.
Since the 20th century, brain prostheses have been developed for the treatment of epilepsy, paralysis, and other diseases.
This paper analyzes the dynamic behavior of this dynamic brain prosthesis, particularly whether it is possible for it to generate a desire for perpetual existence.

Answering this question requires a detailed computational model of the brain's structure, which in turn necessitates a better understanding of how cognition, will, and emotion arise from the neurons, molecules, and other physical entities that make up the brain.
Such an understanding will also be necessary to determine where a mechanism to stimulate the desire for immortality can be implemented within this theoretical model.
Brain prosthetics are designed to mimic specific brain functions, so it is also necessary to determine which brain functions are crucial to their inherent functionality.

Although it is possible to develop a desire for immortality, the analysis in this article suggests that it is also necessary to identify the sources of this desire and whether it will conflict with the long-term survival of brain-computer interfaces.

Recently, theoretical and experimental activities in the field of ultracold gases have resulted in the realization of isolated quantum systems with tunable interactions, achieving unprecedented control.

These systems were initially proposed through experiments related to quantum phases and quantum dynamical optimization, and now they provide the capability to access a wide variety of strongly correlated quantum systems, the complexity of which goes beyond simple descriptions.
In these systems, one-dimensional Bose gases allow us to study strongly correlated phases, such as Mott insulators, soliton excitations, and superfluidity.
Here, we report an experimental study of the dynamic properties of one-dimensional Bose gas using Bragg spectroscopy techniques.
In regulating the coupling between gas and light waves, we engineer non-equilibrium quantum dynamics and access intermediate time dynamics, in which correlations play an important role.
We identify and characterize dynamic phase transitions in various fields.
In particular, we provide conclusive evidence of a dynamic Mott phase transition near the soliton solution.

This work paves the way for experimental exploration of strong correlation quantum dynamics in one-dimensional Bose gases and opens new avenues for studying the complex relationships between quantum and classical dynamics.

Double-band superconductors, also known as multi-band superconductors, exist in some heavy fermion systems, particularly in multi-band correlated superconductors, such as (oxygen) aniline and (oxygen) nitrate-mediated sulfates. These superconductors are related to copper and sulfur (for example, in oxyacetylene or sulfur-doped iron phosphide systems with sulfur passivation areas).
Oxy-nitrates based on oxyacetylene (for example, La(OCH(CH3)2)0.9Ce0.1NO3) exhibit two strongly overlapping bands at the Fermi level, originating from the p orbitals of oxygen and the σ* orbitals.
We report here experiments on resonant inelastic X-ray scattering conducted on sulfur-doped samples, revealing the coupling between two energy bands at low energy.

The results were compared with recent specific heat and muon spin relaxation measurements conducted on similar sulfur-doped compounds, which indicate evidence of a fluctuating full energy gap and nodal states at low temperatures.

These results indicate that the complete superconducting gap may close and reopen due to small additional internal or external disturbances, making these systems good candidates for further studying peculiar superconducting phenomena such as topological superconductivity or phase separation.
The phenomenon of nuclear fragmentation has been extensively studied both experimentally and theoretically over the past few decades.
The basic premise is that the atomic nucleus decomposes into multiple parts during a process called nuclear fission.
The strong interaction and electromagnetic interaction are both involved, depending on the mass and charge of the atom.

Many particles and fragments are produced, each carrying a certain amount of kinetic energy from the original nucleus, which can be expressed in terms of the magnitude of the kinetic energy of each nucleon.
This article presents a study of the fragmentation patterns of the nuclei \(^{9}\)Be, \(^{14}\)N, \(^{7}\)Be, and \(^{8}\)B recorded during their α decay.
It has been observed that the α decay nuclei of $^9$Be, $^{14}$N, $^7$Be, and $^8$B often decay into a group of three particles, where the third particle is the lightest among these four particles.
In the case of $^9$Be and $^{14}$N, two of the three fragments have almost the same mass, while the third fragment is lighter.

In the cases of $^{7}$Be and $^{8}$B, the two particles with almost equal mass are always the two lightest particles, while the third particle is typically either lighter or has a mass in the intermediate range.
This phenomenon has not been fully understood yet, but it is the subject of this research.
The luminous infrared galaxy NGC 6052 has been observed through the Spitzer Space Telescope in four different programs.

The galaxy was observed using an Infrared Spectrograph (IRS) in stare mode, which is part of project 601 (Principal Investigators: C. O. Werner and H. I. Teplitz), and also using the MIPS instrument, which is part of projects 30 and 39 (Principal Investigators: S. Hailey-Dunsheath and B. A. Sargent).
The IRS data was reduced using a modified version of the S11 script, while the MIPS data was reduced using the MIPS Data Reduction Guidelines version 8.0.
In this work, we combined all the Spitzer observation data to conduct a detailed spectral energy distribution (SED) analysis of NGC 6052.
"We first construct a broadband spectral distribution from optical to mid-infrared."
This was subsequently used to fit the dust ring model to the infrared data.
The model consists of a central black body source and is modified by dust particles with a fixed radial density distribution in an ellipsoid that is empty in other areas.
The results show that the best-fit model parameters indicate that NGC 6052 has an active galactic nucleus (AGN) with an estimated power of 10^51 watts, located 9.52 billion light-years away.
The AGN contributes 74% of the total infrared luminosity of the galaxy, while the host galaxy contributes 23% (of which 11% is the total infrared luminosity).

We also studied the spatial distribution of warm (50-125 K) and hot (125-540 K) dust, as well as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), and used these results to evaluate the thermal equilibrium of galaxies.
We found that the hot dust is concentrated in a ring around the core region with a radius of 3.2 parsecs.
The inner radius and outer radius of 冷尘 (Lengchen) are 14 arcseconds and 50 arcseconds, respectively.
The total dust mass is estimated to be \( 2.3 \times 10^{-5} M_{\odot} \). The PAH luminosity is \( 5.5 \times 10^{-8} L_{\odot} \), and the star formation rate is \( 1.2 M_{\odot}/\text{year} \).
The relative intensity of the PAH band indicates that the main energy source for heating the dust is star formation, rather than active galactic nuclei (AGN).
We also studied the ionized gas component in galaxies and found that it accounts for 1% of the total infrared luminosity.
We estimate the star formation rate within the ring to be 235 M⊙/year.
"We analyze the energy distribution of the spectral lines to determine the distribution of dense gas in the ring."
We estimate the gas mass to be 1.1 x 10^-4 M⊙.
We found that the measured mass conversion factor of CO to H2, 4.3 x 10^-4 cm³/kg, is consistent with what is expected in a molecular-rich environment, but it differs by a factor.
Recently, news has been announced about the existence of planets around the star 14 Herculis.
This star is located in the constellation Aquila and is 20.7 light-years away from Earth.
The translation of "14的存在" into English is "the existence of 14."
Her planet makes this system the seventh closest system to Earth.
Since the announcement of the discovery of planets around 14 Heracles, several studies have been conducted to confirm their physical and orbital characteristics.
The number "14" in Chinese is written as "十四".
Her planets can be divided into three groups based on size.

The semi-major axis of the inner group of planets is between 0.13 and 0.36 astronomical units, the semi-major axis of the middle group of planets is between 0.36 and 0.7 astronomical units, while the semi-major axis of the outer group of planets is greater than 0.7 astronomical units.
The minimum planetary mass for the inner group and outer group is between 7 and 22 Earth masses, while the mass of the middle group planets is between 22 and 55 Earth masses.
In this study, we conducted numerical simulations to characterize the dynamic evolution of the Herschel planet 14.

We indicate that, due to their relatively short periods and the proximity of the outermost planets in the system to their star, the planets of 14 Her may have formed in multiple stages, and they cannot move further away from the star due to interactions between the planets.
Furthermore, we predict that there is a fourth exoplanet in this system with a minimum mass of 9 Earth masses.
However, more precise radial velocity measurements are needed to confirm the existence of the planet and to characterize its orbit.
This study is conducted as part of the Dynamics of Planetary Systems (DAPS) network, which aims to characterize the long-term dynamical evolution of planetary systems.
This is a large-scale project funded by the European Research Council, running from January 2015 to December 2020 (ERC Consolidator Grant No. 681627 - Dynamic Analysis of Planetary Systems).
Author: Ali Knight Teslimi and Margarita Karanghelova
Lithium will be damaged at high temperatures.
This makes the presence of lithium very useful for determining the age of stars.
In globular star clusters, extinguished stars have reached the end of their life and no longer produce lithium.
By observing the lithium content in these extinguished stars, we can determine the age of the star cluster.
We used the 3.5-meter telescope at the Apache Point Observatory to obtain high-dispersion spectra of 22 stars in the globular cluster 47 Tuc.
These spectra cover the lithium doublet region located at 6708 Å, and they have sufficient resolution and quality to determine the lithium abundance in stars.
We found that there are significant differences in lithium abundance between stars.
The lowest lithium abundance is found in stars with significantly lower metallic content.
The highest lithium abundance has been found in stars with medium to high metallicity.
These results are inconsistent with the predictions of current galaxy chemical evolution models.
We propose a new model that includes a variable depletion rate of lithium.
From the perspective of the Earth, the abundance of neutral matter and the temperature of the plasma layer have undergone significant changes over a long period.
"Especially, these parameters have been declining over the past century."
The atmospheric composition model cannot explain these trends.
In contrast, the model of internal heating of the Moon predicts a positive thermal inertia.

Here, we apply a thermal inertia model to analyze lunar thermal measurement data from the Space Surveillance Telescope (SST) and find that the thermal inertia of the lunar surface is approximately 1-2 W m^-2 K^-1.
This is consistent with theoretical expectations and is comparable to the thermal inertia of other solar system bodies with geologically active surfaces.

Using thermal inertia and a modified vortex model, we predict the abundance of neutral substances in the Earth's plasma layer and find that their quantity has decreased by 2-3% over the past century, which is consistent with the observed reduction in optical depth.

The reduced neutral density enhances the efficiency of the critical Cassini Split ultraviolet stabilizer and demonstrates the importance of long-term geophysical trends in understanding the interplanetary environment.
In response to recent claims about the accelerating expansion of the universe, this article conducts a critical analysis of the data and methods used to reach that conclusion.
Research indicates that Type Ia supernova data can accommodate an open universe with zero or even positive curvature, without the need to introduce a cosmological constant or dark energy.

There are also studies showing that the data used in some recent papers claiming that the universe is accelerating is actually consistent with an open universe (zero curvature or even positive curvature), without needing to rely on exotic forms of dark matter.
The conclusion is that the evidence for the acceleration of the universe is not conclusive and may represent a form of data selection bias.
The acceleration of the universe is one of the great achievements of modern cosmology.
According to reports, two independent research teams conducted studies in 2014 and 2016, which garnered significant attention in the mainstream media.

The result was quickly accepted as a fact by the entire astronomical community, and the current widely accepted theoretical explanation is that a type of dark energy with an equation of state parameter w < -1 is causing the acceleration of the universe.
The theoretical basis of this argument has been widely analyzed, and the results indicate a lack of evidence.
It has been shown that for a series of theoretically viable dark energy models, the minimum value of w is consistent with the reported supernova data.
The statistical methods used to reject non-dark energy models with small \( w \) have been proven to have significant flaws and are invalid.
The recent paper reported similar results.
Research has shown that type Ia supernova data can be fitted to an open universe with zero or even positive curvature, without the need for a cosmological constant or dark energy.

Research indicates that the data claimed in recent papers suggesting that the universe is accelerating is actually consistent with an open universe model that has zero or even positive curvature, without relying on singular forms of dark matter.
The conclusion is that the evidence for the accelerating universe is uncertain and likely represents a form of data selection bias.

Research shows that the data from Type Ia supernovae is consistent with the original research claim that dark energy is causing the acceleration of the universe, but inconsistent with recent statements that the universe is open or flat.
Therefore, the acceleration of the report is likely the result of selection bias or the improper application of statistical methods.

The data and research in this field are still at a relatively early stage. With the development of new observational datasets and a more comprehensive modeling of dark energy, it may gradually reveal the true nature of acceleration.
"Before that, the acceleration of the universe should be highly doubted."
7 Aql and 8 Aql are two Delta Scuti type stars that have been observed for many years under the STEPI (Search for Variables in the Eyes of Hipparchus) observational program.
Since 2003, we have conducted multi-site observations of these stars to study their light curve variations more comprehensively.
The new minimum time and variability have been discovered.
This new analysis suggests that 7 Aql is a new Delta Scuti variable star, with an amplitude of its light curve that is lower than that of 7 Aql.

The observational data used in this analysis were obtained using different telescopes and photometers in various regions around the world, such as the 1.2-meter RCC telescope at Llano del Hato Observatory in Almería (Spain), the 0.6-meter TRASCA telescope at Teide Observatory in Tenerife (Spain), the 1.5-meter STELLA robotic telescope at the European Southern Observatory in Chile, the 0.76-meter Plata 60m telescope at the El Leoncito astronomical complex in Argentina, the 0.6-meter Fin Humanitarian Youth Scientist (FHS) telescope at Haleakalā in Hawaii (USA), and the 1.22-meter Mark VI telescope at Anderson Mesa Station in Arizona (USA).

This change can be caused by cold star spots, which may be related to these stars recently passing through the solar lag layer.

Homology theory, as well as more general theories applicable to finding features that are invariant under deformation, change, or contraction of subsets in a topological space, has proven to be very effective in the study of the fundamental group of topological spaces.

The rough cohomology can be geometrically interpreted as viewing singular cohomology as Borel cohomology on the topological constant layer of a space, thereby providing another perspective on the latter, which has proven useful in the study of higher homotopy groups.

In this article, we demonstrate how these two theories, namely homology theory and cohomology theory, naturally integrate into a unified framework, united under the same name, and provide new related theories, namely (co) cyclic (co) homology.

More precisely, we introduced a pair of adjoint functors (co)units between the double algebraic groups representing the appropriate category, and each functor has its own property of preserving (co)limits.
This enables us to have a unified treatment of isomorphism and homotopy theory.

As an example of the power of this method, we demonstrate that when it is specifically applied to cases that have already been studied in the existing literature, such as singular cohomology and Borel cohomology, we are able to recover the previously proposed relevant theories.

Finally, we apply our research methods to some previously undefined cases of homology or cohomology theory, specifically concerning (co)cycles of double algebraic fields, including examples from (higher) algebraic $K$-theory.
We study the stability of magnetic flux tubes in the longitudinal flow of the solar convection zone.
We consider infinitesimal perturbation modes that are parallel to the flow and demonstrate that they are unstable when the angular velocity of the tube axis is below a certain critical value.
This contrasts with the situation where the rotation speed of the tube can match the Alfven speed, at which point there are no instability modes.
We refer to this instability as axisymmetric mode instability (AMI), which may explain why long-lived vortex flows are only observed in the upper part of the convective region.
We also calculated the critical angular velocity as a function of various parameters, particularly concerning the localization of patterns in the fluid within or around the pipe.
Specifically, we show that for localized modes, the critical angular velocity depends only on the radius of the pipe and does not depend on the strength of the magnetic field.

Finally, we will compare the instability characteristics in the flux tube with the characteristics of the finger-type plume, and calculate the corresponding effective Richardson number and Péclet number.
We indicate that the instability of the flux tube is expected to develop at a significantly smaller Péclet number compared to the feather flow.
We conclude that instability is likely to cause vortices to appear in the upper region of the convective zone and to form finger-like structures in the deeper interior.
From this work, we propose a method to model the three-point correlation function of the large-scale structure of the universe.
By the three-point correlation function, we refer to the quantity of objects as a function of the distance between them, as well as the scale of measuring this distance.
Our method is based on the coupling of N-body simulations and peak packet algorithms, which can capture signals on both large and small scales.
We demonstrate our method using real data from the WiggleZ Dark Energy Survey and show that we are able to reproduce the first and second halo terms of the correlation function.

We further applied our method to simulated WiggleZ survey data, demonstrating that we can impose competitive constraints on the bias parameters of dark matter halos, particularly on small scales, compared to other methods.

Finally, we discussed the potential extensions of this method, which would allow us to reduce sampling errors and increase the scale range of our detection of three-point functions, ultimately enabling us to construct a complete nonlinear three-point correlation function.

Two spin-1/2 fermions can exhibit a coherent superposition of a "wave train" with zero average wave vector through quantum mechanical interference, thereby producing an interference pattern with stripes that have equal amplitude but opposite phase.
This wave function-based interference phenomenon is used to characterize the properties of quantum systems, where two-particle interference can enhance sensitivity to Coulomb interactions.
Here, we report the interference pattern of two independent electrons near the so-called "Hohng point" in the combined electron density of two separate but coexisting helium droplets.

The observed biparticle interference pattern is in very good agreement with the computational results based on the precise biparticle Schrödinger equation, which allows for the determination of the phase difference between the interference waves. Therefore, the interference fringes provide an accurate measurement of the Aharonov-Bohm phase caused by the spatial overlap of two independent electron wave functions.

The research on two-particle interference involving helium—this system that appears simple on the surface but actually exhibits complex many-body interactions—demonstrates the powerful capability of this interference phenomenon in characterizing quantum many-body systems, and it holds tremendous potential in quantum technology and simulation applications.

File size: 791 KB 2003 arXiv.org Atomic waves can diffract between two Raman-Nashabrag frequencies when the incident wave is in the Bragg region.
Under these conditions, the effective Rabi frequency, loss, and phase shift are calculated.
The analysis of the effective Rabi frequency indicates that only half of the atomic wave functions are diffracted, which is consistent with the expectations for a two-level system.
The calculated losses can be attributed to phase shifts, and if the wave vector of the diffracted wave is relatively small, these losses may be significant.
Regarding methodology, this paper uses the coupled Maxwell-Bloch equations under the conditions of dipoles and the Raman-Nath limit.
The calculation results are for sodium, and the parameters are from the literature.

The Dicke model is an exactly solvable quantum many-body physics model that describes a set of N two-level systems or qubits, all of which are in the same quantum state. These systems interact with each other through dipole-dipole coupling and are affected by an external driving field.
The model shows a quantum phase transition from a normal phase to a cooperative phase when the coupling strength exceeds the critical value.

As a precisely solvable model, the Dicke model has been widely studied and well understood. However, its extension to N-qubit systems with general multipolar interactions has been significantly less explored and understood far less thoroughly.

Specifically, this general multipolar interaction has been found to lead to a rich variety of quantum phases, exceeding the simple cooperative phase of the Dicke model, including subradiant phases with non-zero expectation values of the excitation number operator, as well as Luttinger liquid phases with continuously varying correlation functions.
Here, we propose a method to characterize these phases, focusing on identifying the Luttinger liquid phase based on the quantum field theory of fermions developed by Abanov and Wiegmann.

We applied this method to a specific family of models with multi-dipole interactions and general dipole-dipole interactions, and found that the Luttinger liquid phase can be accurately captured by low-order truncation of the parafermionic field theory, while the subradiant phase cannot be correctly described.

This example illustrates the practicality of quasiparticle field theory as a method for characterizing cooperative phases that go beyond the Dicke model, and further research will reveal its broader applicability.
In this article, we propose a quantum relay architecture capable of supporting long-distance, fault-tolerant quantum communication through broadband metropolitan networks.
To achieve this goal, we introduced a novel technique that combines low-dimensional entanglement and quantum fast forwarding to scale up the computation.
Our system design is optimized for several key indicators: entanglement generation rate, resource consumption, memory usage, and generation rate.

Entanglement is generated through the light-matter quantum bits in a quarter of the quantum frequency register. The extraction of shared entanglement is accomplished in parallel across a set of adjacent quantum computers, and the quantum signal reconstruction step is completed at a metropolitan node.
Through numerical simulations, we demonstrate that the system is capable of achieving high-density entanglement generation while consuming a small amount of quantum photons and physical quantum bits.
Introducing quantum repeaters that utilize quantum entanglement to achieve long-distance quantum communication.
Entanglement is a quantum property that allows two or more particles to have correlated attributes even when they are at great distances from each other.
Quantum repeaters use entangled quantum signals to distribute entanglement over long distances.
Due to the exponential decay of entanglement with distance, long-distance quantum communication requires repeaters to extend the distance of entanglement.
The current quantum relay methods use a single system, with each system optimized for a specific distance range.

For systems optimized for short distances, such as quantum key distribution (QKD) systems, efficient entanglement generation rates have been achieved by detecting quantum side channels or modifying the quantum bits during transmission.
These systems designed for long-distance optimization, such as quantum memory, achieve a high level of entanglement generation rate by purifying highly entangled quantum systems.
Both of these systems require local adjustments during the transmission process, which limits the distance over which entanglement can be distributed.
In this article, we propose a quantum repeater architecture that combines the characteristics of these optimized systems for short and long distances.
The design is aimed at supporting long-distance entanglement distribution through broadband urban networks.

It utilizes parallelization to scale the communication overhead from entanglement generation to quantum storage use, as well as the low-dimensional entanglement between photonic and material quantum bits, to achieve a high entanglement generation rate with low quantum resource consumption.
Entanglement generation is facilitated by the use of light-matter entanglement, where material quantum bits interact with light in quantum frequency quarter devices (QFQs).
QFQ is a fully integrated on-chip network that supports multiple user connections and can be realized using silicon photonics technology.
These networks support long-distance entanglement distribution by enabling the parallelization of purification protocols.
However, the purification speed of the previous method is limited because the generation of entanglement needs to be confined to specific purification registers.

In this design, we propose an urban node that combines long-distance entanglement distribution and fast forwarding, which is a form of quantum communication that allows quantum signals to be reconstructed in the presence of loss.
Using long-distance entanglement, local computation can reconstruct quantum signals from urban nodes, thereby achieving complete entanglement distribution over long distances.
In this article, we develop a detailed quantum electrodynamics (QED) description to describe the interaction between realistic superconducting qubits and microwave radiation.
We have derived an effective low-energy Hamiltonian that includes Jaynes-Cummings, Tavis-Cummings, and dipole coupling.
Numerical simulations of the quantum Rabi model, the Dicke model, and the Landau-Zener model are performed to elucidate the realm of quantum electrodynamics (QED).

This description of low-energy quantum electrodynamics helps in the control analysis of the coupling strength between qubits and microwaves, as well as the microwave frequency shift relative to the quantum bit energy levels.
The predicted dispersion decay and coherence destruction rates are consistent with recent experimental results.
Introducing realistic superconducting qubits, such as transmons, serves as an excellent platform for studying quantum many-body phenomena in nature.
In particular, their highly adjustable characteristics allow for precise control over the system and the decoherence process of the bath state.
This fine control, however, has become an asset, but now poses a challenge to fully understanding and describing the underlying physical mechanisms.
In this article, we provide a detailed quantum electrodynamics (QED) description of the interaction between actual superconducting qubits and microwave radiation.
This derivation is based on the high-fidelity dispersive Jaynes-Cummings Hamiltonian derived in reference [1].
For the other derivations in the literature, our starting point is a fully calibrated superconducting qubit model, which is a model that includes the complete experimental control setup.
By calibrating this model, we considered the parasitic modes, which are an important consideration in the case of superconducting qubits being extremely small.
A key result of this definition is an effective low-energy Hamiltonian, which includes Jaynes-Cummings, Tavis-Cummings, and dipole coupling.

Using degenerate perturbation theory, we obtained analytic expressions for the coupling strength between the qubit and the microwave, as well as the microwave frequency shift relative to the qubit energy levels.
These analytical expressions help to systematically understand and analyze the control of qubit-microwave interactions in any given experimental system configuration.
The description of low-energy quantum electrodynamics makes it possible to quantitatively compare experiments and assess control errors and residual non-QED interactions.

Based on the current level of complexity, it would be infeasible to calculate the exact dynamics of the complete system; however, we can perform numerical simulations of the low-energy quantum electrodynamics Hamiltonian.
Our results are very consistent with the measured resonance decay rates and the analytical expressions derived in the paper.
In addition, our simulations explain the avoidance of level crossings in the system.

This explanation, which is not considered in the quantum electrodynamics model, is due to non-Markovian dressing of the qubit energy levels caused by the non-perturbative bath resulting from spontaneous emission.
At the end of this article, we summarize the most important findings and discuss the potential applications of this method in describing qubit-microwave interactions in more complex environments.
Main findings: We introduced a highly calibrated qubit model at the starting point and performed operations with high fidelity.
The theory of superconductivity in a magnetic field: Local approximation method.
The paper presents a universal framework for establishing superconducting theory in a magnetic field.
Such a theory should be able to describe superconductors below the critical temperature, as well as magnetic materials that have Abrikosov vortex lattices at zero temperature.
The starting point of the theory is to assume that the sequence parameters are a complex field dependent on space and time.
In this way, all degrees of freedom related to the magnetic field are incorporated into the theory, allowing for the description of the coexistence of superconductors and magnetic flux states.
Due to the complex nature of the order parameters, it is necessary to include many degrees of freedom to adequately describe the superconducting state.
To achieve this, it is necessary to utilize the multiple-body expansion of free energy.
In cases where the coupling between the _ORDER parameter and the magnetic field is small, a local approximation is sufficient to capture the main physical mechanisms.
This is achieved by introducing a new auxiliary field into the free energy functional, treating superconducting materials and magnetic materials as equals.
The theory is used to describe superconductivity in a magnetic field at the nanoscale.
In this case, the London theory cannot be applied, and a comprehensive treatment of quantum mechanics is required.
Specifically, research indicates that a region can be established in which type II superconductors can maintain a magnetic field without any vortex lattice.
Dwarf spheroidal galaxies (dSphs) are believed to be the most dark matter-dominated objects in the universe.
Its essence remains a matter of debate.
Many celestial bodies are kinematically consistent with ancient star clusters, but some exhibit evidence of recent star formation.
The phenomenon of a large number of young stars existing in these galaxies has always been controversial.
In this work, we present 19 blue outflows observed in 16 low surface brightness elliptical galaxies.
We found that 14 outflows are consistent with a simple stellar population model, with ages less than 700-800 million years.
The spectra of the remaining five smoky feathers can be fitted using a combination of simple stellar population models, with ages ranging from 70 to 110 million years and 500 to 700 million years.

We believe that the origin of these five middle-aged blue supernovae may be related to the evolution of blue tardy objects, and that the star formation in these galaxies may not have occurred as recently as previously thought.
In this article, we report on the performance of the MEGAPIE target, which is a central design used for the GS2040E case (2 MW net power output).
In response to this type of high-temperature reactor configuration, a substantial amount of neutron research has been conducted for the first time.
The results were also compared with the simulations of the actual design.
The neutron performance of the MEGAPIE target is consistent with the actual design, with a DSA of 4.1%, and the average team pairing space and momentum dispersion level is 3%.
Furthermore, the results show that the hydrogen control rod has a significant impact on the reactivity and neutron economy of the reactor core.
The optimized configuration of the MEGAPIE target, known as MEGAPIE+, has finally been proposed.
The core configuration of MEGAPIE+ performs close to optimal levels in terms of thermal efficiency while improving neutron performance, thus significantly reducing weight and DSA.
The Bonn Lens, Optics, and X-ray Selected Galaxy Clusters (BLOX) is a sample of massive, X-ray emitting galaxy clusters constructed using data from X-ray, optical, and lensing Einstein ring surveys.
The BLOX cluster is detected through three steps.
First, the HEC cluster detector identified groups and clusters in the deep XMM-LSS (XMM-Newton Large Scale Structure) field.
Next, a red sequence cluster finder identifies high redshift clusters in the redshift slice of the HEC clusters.
Finally, a strong gravitational lensing group detector identified the most significant groups from the red sequence analysis.

The final BLOX cluster catalog contains 823 clusters, of which 752 have a redshift z > 0.1, and 91 have a redshift z > 0.18. It covers a sky area of 1.34 square degrees and includes 18,314 cluster members.
Through various tests on sample contamination and bias detection in clustering, BLOX has become one of the largest and most reliable clustering samples built to date.
The weak gravitational lensing mass and X-ray characteristics of the BLOX cluster are introduced in the cosmological gravitational lensing paper related to this release.

In the study of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), it is well known that there is a log-log correlation between gamma-ray flux and GRB duration, which exhibits a break at the shortest duration observed by Swift (approximately 2 seconds). The correlation between flux in two different energy bands and the break time is also non-linear.
This can be explained by assuming that the observed energy bands sample different regions of the GRB relativistic jet, where the high-energy band samples the faster baryon regions.
The physical origin of this pause time has been missing until now.
It demonstrated that the observed correlation is the result of competition between the time scale of variations in the driving engine of the outbreak and the resolution time scale of the detector.
The origin of this time scale of variation is not known a priori, but it may be related to internal gravity waves generated in the plasma outflow during the jet acceleration process.
The physical origin has been proved to be impossible.
Therefore, the previously observed high-energy correlation between Swift gamma-ray bursts no longer holds.
A complete catalog of Swift GRB spectral parameters has been presented.
The directory can be accessed online through the following link: https://observatory.gsfc.nasa.gov/estimations/UXT11Y.
Dark energy is interpreted as a component of the universe with negative pressure, and it is one of the greatest mysteries in modern physics.

One of the most promising methods for measuring its properties is based on a distance-based cosmology known as the "Cosmic Distance Duality Relation" (DDGR), which connects the angular diameter distance (dA) to the surface of last scattering and relates it to the luminosity distance (dL) of observed galaxy clusters.

So far, these relationships have only been tested on small-scale samples (for example, the Suayeff-Zeldovich (SZ) effect, gravitational lensing) and have shown low accuracy (mainly due to poor calibration of local distance indicators).
I will present the X-ray observation results of the largest and most relaxed galaxy clusters obtained through the Chandra X-ray Observatory.
These galaxy clusters follow the cosmic distance duality relation with an accuracy of about 8%, improving by a factor of five compared to earlier results.
The derived precise X-ray mass is used to test cosmological models and has also been presented.

The problem of counting the vertex colorings of a graph, or more specifically, the problem of calculating the number of ways to partition the coefficients of a polynomial, has always been a topic of interest for combinatorialists and probability theorists.

An important advancement is that statistical physicists Ken Ono, Chetan Nachbagauer, and Chris Janjic introduced the dimer/coloring bijection/Rosetta Stone (first described by Kasteleyn and McCoy in 1966), which enabled the development of a bijection framework for more general partition problems (Araujo, 1980, 1981; Temperley, 1971).
However, even this framework cannot calculate certain polynomial coefficient partitions (for example, partitions by squares) without extensive case-by-case analysis.

In recent years, the significant advancements in computer algorithms have made it possible to study these challenging partitions through counting principles (Dousse, Di Matteo, Rafieier, and Cerf, 2013).
These algorithms allow for the enumeration of certain difficult partitions (for example, all binary partitions into squares) without having to analyze them one by one.
Through this article, we systematically enumerated all the faces of the cubic lattice with 2-coloring (a total of 3,779 faces).
We found 20 different two-colorings, each originating from a different bijective framework.
Lyman alpha emitters (LAEs) at a redshift of approximately 4.5 have been found to form an overdensity through narrowband Lyman alpha imaging, which is an indicator of early galaxy formation.

Subsequent spectral analyses of these over-dense regions show lower redshifts (around 4.5); however, in most cases, emission-line Lyman-alpha galaxies (LAEs) are still observed to be located at z ~ 4.5.
This obvious concentration has been confirmed through numerical simulations and is interpreted as evidence for the presence of a large amount of neutral hydrogen reserves in these early systems.
Itai M. R. Hui and Andrea G. Crocce led a team that discovered this cluster using imaging from the UltraVio survey and confirmed it through subsequent spectral observations.
This research was published in the journal Science.

"Ultraviolet (Vienna University Observatory) is an imaging survey conducted using the 2.2-meter robotic telescope at the University of Vienna. Relevant information can be found at http://www.ifs.org.ua/usno/auto/auto.htm."

The survey imaged an area of eight square degrees in the sky, using five bands with wavelengths ranging from 4000 to 9000 Å. The observations were conducted from 2011 to 2016, utilizing a wide-field camera designed by the University of Vienna, equipped with an InSb detector with a pixel size of 18 micrometers, covering a field of view of 1.76° × 1.76°.

The third generation stars are the earliest formed stars in the universe.
Due to its high inward Lyman-Werner radiation flux, HH2 reactions are rapidly suppressed, and the subsequent formation of H2 is also inhibited.
As a result, the lack of hydrogen caused these stars to primarily focus on their cores, leading to the gravitational collapse of the cores of these first-generation stars.
Magnetic angular momentum collapse, as the name suggests, refers to the combination of magnetic forces and rotational forces, which assist gravity in causing the collapse of an ancient type III star.
This process has never been observed in such ancient first-generation stars, and its impact on the early life of the universe has also been discussed.
The earliest stars formed in the universe, known as Population III stars, were affected by the suppression of subsequent H₂ formation due to the HH2 reaction, resulting in the absence of hydrogen.
The mass of these first-generation stars is extremely large, typically on the order of hundreds of solar masses.
Population III stars, like our Sun, are initially primarily influenced by their cores.
After further contraction, the radial Greg-Instability led to the formation of the iron core.
This led to a core dynamic collapse, ultimately triggered when the iron core reached absolute zero pressure.
At this moment, the neutron-supported electron-nuclear reactions become so rapid that the collapse speed of the remaining stars becomes superelastic.
This will cause a shock wave of nuclear fire that completely surrounds the core.
The astrodynamics of these events has never been observed in such early stars, and their impact on early life in the universe has also been discussed.

The author received funding from the European Research Council (ERC), which is part of the European Union's Seventh Framework Programme (FP/2007-2013) / ERC grant contract number 319581 ("PLConfig"); at the same time, funding was also received from the French National Research Agency (ANR) through the "Investing for the Future" program (ANR-15-IDEX-02).
Y. Jin is currently a PhD student in the team of Professors Geoffrey E. Strand and Junhua Wang at the University of New Mexico.

A detailed study of the suppression of cosmic ray flux above a sharp upper energy limit known as the GZK cutoff requires precise measurement of the maximum submerged altitude, which can be achieved through surface detector arrays such as the Pierre Auger Observatory.

Through this work, we proposed a new analytical technique based on the distribution of distances between elements of a continuous surface detector. This technique is capable of measuring parameters that are more sensitive to the properties and intensity of primary particles than the traditional lateral distribution functions.
We applied this method to characterize the suppression of cosmic ray flux above the so-called GZK energy and compared the results with previous measurements that used traditional parameterizations.

We also investigate the changes in the composition of primary cosmic rays and the sensitivity of their chemical composition by using a new parameter – spectral rigidity. Spectral rigidity is an indicator that measures the energy separation between adjacent energy levels of a given atom or nucleus.

We find that above the GZK cutoff energy, the behavior of the measured composition-sensitive parameters is consistent with interpreting this feature as a result of high-energy cosmic rays interacting with the photon background, which supports the view that they are primarily composed of atomic nuclei.
We conducted a detailed analysis of the gamma-ray spectrum of the TeV source RX J1713.7-3946 based on 10 years of observational data from the H.E.S.S. telescope.
We confirm the presence of two spectral components, which have been reported in previous experiments, one of which shows a break around 600 GeV.
The differential energy spectra of these two components and their total flux are derived, and their influence on the origin and physical properties of gamma-ray emitting particles is discussed.
SNR RX J1713.7-3946 is one of the best candidates for studying the interactions of particles (cosmic rays) from extraterrestrial sources across a wide energy range, from radio waves to TeV γ rays.
We conducted a detailed study of gamma-ray emissions using data collected from H.E.S.S.
I and II telescopes.

We confirm the existence of two spectral components: one has a spectral breakpoint at 600 GeV, while the other extends to at least 10 TeV. We have derived the differential energy spectra and their integral fluxes for both components, and we discuss the implications of the sources and physical characteristics of the particles emitting gamma rays.

The study of the magnetic properties of the spiral galaxy NGC 6946 uses high-resolution synchrotron radio continuous observation data from the 64-meter telescope at the Max Planck Institute for Solar System Research (MPS).

In a brief general introduction, we describe the observations and data processing, present the measurements of magnetic field strength and configuration, and discuss the regularities and origins of the observed magnetic field.

Specifically, the newly introduced depolarization ring technology is used to detect weak, highly disordered large-scale magnetic fields. The detected ring magnetic structures will be analyzed based on their azimuthal symmetry and the embedded energy transfer processes.

In addition, we introduced several methods to characterize the organized small-scale magnetic fields, namely helical structures, generator modes, and helical fields, while deriving the vector field of the total magnetic field map for both regularized and non-sharpened masks.

We conclude by discussing the observed rules and the impact of random magnetic field configurations on the fuel supply and jets of active galactic nuclei in the central regions of galaxies. We also summarize the current research on NGC 6946, using it as a test case for studying various aspects of interstellar and intergalactic magnetic fields with modern instruments in a model galaxy.
The semi-independent configuration is a layered multi-system in which a star orbits a larger mass companion (a white dwarf or sub-dwarf core) in a close and circular orbit.
These systems are particularly noteworthy in astrophysics because they are among the lowest mass binary stars.
SS Leporis is a semi-independent binary star system, composed of a late-type star (primarily K-type) and a white dwarf.

A system like this obtained spatial resolution information at sub-milliarcsecond resolution for the first time using the VLTI instrument VINCI, and its effective diameter was also measured for the first time.
The obtained value for the binary star system is dSi = 3.35 ± 0.14 milliarcseconds, corresponding to a projected physical separation of 2.65 ± 0.13 × 10^-4 solar radii.
The measured value is in very good agreement with the theoretical prediction (2.94 solar radii).

Power-law distributions have been observed in various empirical datasets, which appear in multiple contexts, such as the size of human settlements, the mass of objects, the income of individuals, the stride length of individuals, the diameter of plant cells, or the width of tree bark.

The widespread applicability of power-law distributions has led to the hypothesis that these distributions may emerge naturally as a result of some simple generative processes, such as the products of independent random numbers, catastrophic failures of individual components in random failure systems, or phase transitions in discrete models.

However, some people also suggest that the power law distribution may be caused by the superposition of a large number of more common distributions, a simple arrangement of a single common distribution, or a log-normal distribution.
Indeed, there are various processes that can generate such a distribution.
For example, the superposition of many common distributions can generate a distribution with a power-law tail.
In addition, heavy-tailed distributions with mathematical forms similar to power laws have been observed in various contexts, and these distributions arise from different generative processes.

For example, the later stages of log distribution may appear similar to a power law distribution. It has been suggested that the size distribution of computer files may be consistent with a power law, although this is often attributed to finite size effects.
Similarly, one can speculate that certain types of networks may exhibit power-law degree distributions, although this has not yet been rigorously proven.
In addition, there are some processes that generate power law distributions, but these processes are not generative processes.
For example, removing nodes from a network with a power-law degree distribution will lead to the removal of nodes that have a similar power-law degree distribution.
Some people also suggest that heavy-tailed distributions may arise from the sum of a few more common distributions.
For example, truncated power laws may be the result of the superposition of common distributions.
In this case, it is noteworthy that many examples of power-law distributions are a result of a few generating processes.

For example, the distribution of the scale of human settlements appears to be the result of two generative processes: the growth of the human population through the aggregation of settlements, and the natural variations in settlement size due to geographical and environmental constraints.
Using data from the International Gamma-Ray Astrophysics Laboratory (INTEGRAL), we studied the gamma-ray emissions coming from the region of the Galactic Center.
The region has attracted interest due to its high concentration of numerous black holes and pulsars nearby.
We conducted a detailed spatial and spectral analysis of 18 months of open observations covering the area.
We found significant radiation within a 6-second interval from the center, and there were spatial structures and spectral variations on both long and short time scales.
In particular, we have discovered a newly found mega-electronvolt gamma-ray halo surrounding the central core.
We studied the possible sources of radiation and found that explaining the data requires considering both lepton processes and hadron processes simultaneously.
In the former case, we consider the broad line region and the narrow line region, and find that a simple one-zone model is insufficient to explain the data.
In the latter case, we considered the possibility of a fast transient source population.

We found that a physical model of a distant supernova remnant colliding with a molecular cloud is consistent with the data, and it requires a dense material wind from the central supermassive black hole to explain the gamma-ray halo.
We discussed the testability implications of the model and suggested future gamma-ray observations that could differentiate between the two scenarios.
We study the topological entropy and entanglement entropy of the Toric code at finite temperature.
The topological entropy has been shown to correspond to the exponential growth or decay of the number of different energy eigenstates at finite temperature.

We characterize the topological entanglement entropy by considering a quantity that is proportional to the square of the mutual information, which we call the mutual information entanglement entropy (MIEE).
We indicate that within a limited temperature range, this MIEE also exhibits exponential decay.
We use a numerical exact diagonalization method on small-scale clusters to evaluate the finite-size scaling of these topological entropies and topological entanglement entropies.

These results are used to calculate the entanglement entropy of the toric code version at finite temperature, in order to compare with photon lattice experiments that can simulate the model using current technology.
We study the topological entropy and entanglement entropy of Toric codes at finite temperature.
Topological entropy has been proven to be consistent with the exponential growth or decay of the number of different energy eigenstates within a finite temperature range.

We characterize the topological entanglement entropy by considering a quantity that is proportional to the square of the mutual information, which we call the Mutual Information Entanglement Entropy (MIEE).
We indicate that this MIEE also exhibits exponential decay within a limited temperature range.
We use numerical exact diagonalization of small-scale systems to assess the finite-size scaling of these topological entropy and topological entanglement entropy.

These results are used to calculate the entanglement entropy of a toric code version at finite temperature, in order to compare with experiments in photonic lattices that can realistically simulate this model with current technology.
The main motivation for this work is the recent interest in topological entropy as the noise threshold for qubits in quantum error correction, particularly in studies related to Toric codes.

We calculate the topological entropy through the Luschmidt overlap transformation, which expresses the number of different feature states as an exponential growth or decay related to the number of Riemann zeros.
We confirm the noise threshold by numerically evaluating the topological entropy of the twisted codes on a small lattice.
We will also characterize the topological entropy as mutual information entanglement entropy (MIEE), a concept that was recently introduced in photon lattice experiments.
MIEE is defined as a quantity that is proportional to the square of mutual information and can be estimated using the Loschmidt overlap transformation.
We conducted a numerical evaluation of the topological entropy and maximal information entropy (MIEE) for system sizes up to 15 x 15 with periodic boundary conditions.

This calculation confirms that the topological entropy is consistent with the exponential decay of the number of energy eigenstates within a finite temperature range, while the MIEE is also consistent with the exponential growth of that quantity.

We also estimated the topological entropy and many-body quantum entanglement entropy (MIEE) of the minimal non-trivial subsystem in a toroidal encoding with a 15 x 15 grid under open boundary conditions.
The detailed kinetic study of the ring-opening reaction of naphthenes is presented through CBS-QB3 calculations.
The activation energy barriers for the chair, boat, and half-chair conformations of cyclohexane are predicted to be 22.4, 27.0, and 35.5 kcal/mol, respectively.
The corresponding energy barriers for cyclohexane and cyclooctane were predicted to be 31.8 and 43.2 kilocalories per mole, respectively.
These results are consistent with experiments and other CBS-QB3 calculations.

For the chair conformers of norbornane and camphor, the obtained intrinsic energy barriers are predicted to be 25.0 and 33.6 kcal mol⁻¹, respectively, which are in good agreement with experimental results.
The discussion focused on the significant differences in the intrinsic barriers between the chair conformation and the half-chair conformation of cycloalkanes.
Zero-point energy and thermal corrections have been found to have a significant impact on the barrier height.

At 200 degrees Celsius, the predicted reaction rates for the reaction between cyclohexane and dehydrogenated dihydronaphthalene are 1.05 x 10^-12 and 3.39 x 10^-13 cm³ molecule^-1 s^-1, using the modified Kamal equation.
These ratios are very consistent with the experimental results and other CBS-QB3 computational results.
The intrinsic energy barriers of cyclohexane and norbornane are predicted to be 36.0 and 39.1 kilocalories per mole, respectively.
The difference in energy barriers between the chair conformation and the half-chair conformation is consistent with the experimental intrinsic energy barrier of 39.7 kcal mol^-1 for cyclohexane.
Interstellar dust is a minor component of matter in the Milky Way galaxy, primarily concentrated in dust-rich areas such as the spiral arms and the galactic nucleus.

There are two contradictory viewpoints regarding the origin of interstellar dust: one suggests that dust is formed in the atmospheres of stars and is ejected through stellar winds, supernovae, or planetary nebulae; the other posits that dust is continuously produced in recent star formation regions.

To solve this problem, a third model has been proposed. According to this model, dust is formed in the interstellar medium and then brought into galaxies through collisions between large celestial bodies, such as asteroids, comets, or dwarf galaxies.
This theory explains the observed correlation between the abundance of interstellar dust and star formation.
The presence of dust affects the formation and characteristics of the next generation of stars and galaxies.
Interstellar dust is composed of very small particles, typically sized at a few hundred nanometers.
Optical observations in the visible and infrared regions are most suitable for studying the distribution and dynamics of interstellar dust.
A promising tool for solving this problem is the long-term monitoring of distant galaxies in the radio wavelength range.
The spectral index evolution of the radiation intensity at radio wavelengths largely depends on the distribution of dust within the galaxy.
The analysis of changes in spectral indices over a long period (several decades) allows us to determine the quantity and distribution of interstellar dust in the Milky Way galaxy.

Long-term dust content observations from multiple galaxies show that observations conducted using the 100-meter and 45-meter radio telescopes at the MPIfR in Effelsberg, the 1.2-meter and 0.7-meter telescopes at the Special Astronomical Observatory in Russia, the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope, the APEX telescope, the IRAM 30-meter and SEST 20-meter radio telescopes in Chile, the Metsähovi Radio Observatory in Finland, and other facilities indicate that the generation and evolution of dust in galaxies are related to certain characteristics of those galaxies.
