clean_wm_text: It has been confirmed that in late-type spiral galaxies, the intensity of radio wavelength radiation increases over time, indicating that dust gradually accumulates in the interstellar medium due to the merger of large celestial bodies.
In early-type spiral galaxies, the intensity of radiation remains almost constant, indicating that the amount of dust produced in these galaxies is very small.
In elliptical galaxies, the level of radio radiation decreases over time, which may indicate that dust in these galaxies is being removed due to the strong and persistent influence of hot gas.
On the Gamma-ray Large Area Space Telescope (GLAST), the Large Area Telescope (LAT) will study the isotropic gamma-ray emission from our galaxy while operating in a diffuse science mode.
This radiation is produced by the high-energy interactions of Galactic Cosmic Rays (GCRs) with interstellar gas and radiation fields.
To accurately study the gamma-ray sources in our Milky Way galaxy and compare them with the diffuse radiation model of the galaxy, it is necessary to properly model this component.
In this work, we present the development of GCR simulations that will be used to construct the galactic diffuse emission model for GLAST.
The simulation was developed using the GEANT4 toolkit, which includes models for gas and radiation field components as well as primary and secondary Galactic Cosmic Rays (GCR).

We described the simulation setup, simulation results, and the data analysis steps performed to construct the GCR simulation output, including three-dimensional spatial maps of the spectrum, spatial distribution and temporal variations of the primary and secondary gamma-ray fluxes, and discussed the future improvements we are considering to develop a complete GLAST galactic diffuse emission model.
Within the framework of Regge theory for fundamental particles, the rho meson has been studied for the first time within the K-matrix theory framework.
The role of the ρ meson is very important for clearly interpreting the experiments on π meson electroproduction conducted at JLab (Mainz, Bruin, C-exchange, and A2).
In particular, research shows that including the rho meson in the analysis significantly improves the description of these experiments.
This work is carried out within the framework of Regge theory, which is a fundamental theory of strong interactions.
Regge theory indicates that the total cross-section of hadrons exhibits an approximate power-law dependence as the energy level increases.
This approximation is effective for heavy strongly interacting particles, such as mesons.

Regge theory is based on the assumption that the exchanges of particles between different reactions exhibit a common pattern, which can be described by the exchange of fundamental particles called reggeons.
"The intermediate state corresponding to the two hadrons in quantum field theory."
In the framework of simple Regge theory, G.V. Efimov proposed the first description of high-energy hadronic interactions within the framework of quantum field theory.

In later theoretical and experimental studies, the numerical confirmations of high-energy interactions supported the main assumptions of simple theories, particularly the universality of reggeon exchange.
In the description of high-energy interactions, mesons emerge due to the unique possibilities of the electromagnetic interactions of quasi-particles.

The SJC (Simple Isobar Model) describes the interaction between two mesons, where the maximum momentum of each particle is constrained by values related to the physical decay channels of the mesons (soft mesons).
Within the framework of quantum field theory, the first description of high-energy hadron interactions was developed by G.V. Efimov within the simple Regge theory framework.
Some later theories and experimental studies of high-energy interactions have confirmed the main assumptions of simple theories, particularly the universal characteristics of reggeon exchange.
In the description of high-energy interactions, mesons appear due to the unique possibilities of the electromagnetic interactions of quasi-particles.

The SJC (Simple Isotope Model) describes the interactions between two mesons, with the maximum momentum of each particle being limited by values associated with the physical decay channels of the mesons (soft mesons).
The simplest implementation of SJC is the Born-Riley partial wave representation, which considers the contribution of an exchange meson.
G.P. Lepage indicates that in the framework of the Born approximation and the high-energy approximation of hadronic interactions, Pomeron exchange can be regarded as the sum of two Reggeon exchanges.
Therefore, mesons appear in the description.
Neutral genetic drift is a type of genetic polymorphism caused by random genetic mutations, which may contribute to the evolution of protein sequences.
Such a scenario may have occurred frequently during the early evolution of proteins, when long protein sequences were unlikely to contain strongly deleterious mutations.
In this model, although most new mutations are harmful, some mutations are weakly beneficial or even neutral.
These weakly beneficial mutations randomly fix in a population because their slightly increased frequency is caused by genetic drift.
Due to their minimal impact, these weak beneficial mutations do not contribute to an organism's Darwinian fitness.
However, they promote the evolution of protein sequences by helping to compensate for the negative effects of strong deleterious mutations.
Through this "fine-tuning" of neutral drift, the protein function and Darwinian fitness of organisms can be improved, even if their average fitness remains close to zero.

In contrast to the previously proposed protein adaptation scenarios, this model explains how protein functions can be maintained over a longer period of time in the absence of positive Darwinian selection.
The threshold cross section for the electrolysis of deuterium is one of the main approaches to studying the interaction between electromagnetic fields and nuclear fields.
This process has been studied in the past using various models at low and medium energy, but the accuracy is limited.

In recent years, powerful numerical methods have become available to solve problems in relativistic quantum mechanics, enabling calculations to be performed for the first time at higher energies, close to the deuteron breakup threshold.
We propose a simple method based on the distorted wave Born approximation for calculating processes at relativistic energies.
This form of formalism is applied to studying processes at a laboratory energy of 1.2 GeV, which is relevant for the production of thermal dense matter in current and future accelerator facilities.
We found a good agreement between the results from the optical model and the expected deviation at backward angles.
The manuscript is partially based on a presentation made at the INT workshop "Electroweak Astrophysics and Fundamental Interactions" (September 2024).
Brent Everly's paper "Examples against The Generalized Jacobian Conjecture" is an interesting paper that demonstrates that the Generalized Jacobian Conjecture (GJC) does not hold in general.

The GJC was proposed by Louis Barreira in 2001, presenting a bold idea that general topological chaos—a key characteristic of irregular dynamical systems—exists universally in a broad class of dynamical systems.

Examples opposing the generalized Jacobi conjecture indicate that a specific dynamical system known to exist within this class of systems, which do not exhibit universal chaotic behavior, does not satisfy the generalized Jacobi conjecture.

Examples from the generalized Jacobi conjecture indicate that the conjecture is generally false. However, there remains the possibility that the generalized Jacobi conjecture may hold true in smaller categories of dynamical systems, such as those that possess certain additional general properties.
The impact of this result is far-reaching and resonates with many aspects of various scientific fields.

For example, examples related to the generalized Jacobian conjecture have applications in areas such as classical mechanics, the foundations of statistical mechanics, certain dimensions in coding theory, the statistical properties of weather and clouds, as well as combinatorial mathematics of words.
This paper is well written and expresses ideas very clearly.
Examples from the generalized Jacobi conjecture have attracted widespread interest among scientists and mathematicians studying various dynamical systems.
This paper presents a formal method that categorizes N=8 supergravity theory into five distinct families and demonstrates their bosonic field content.
It first reviews the structure of N=8 supergravity theory and the embedding of its maximum SU(8) bosonic subgroup in the N=8 supersymmetric Poincaré group.
Next, it systematically classifies these theories into five families.
The first family includes the so-called maximal supersymmetry theories, which encompass all N=8 supergravity theories and their consistent toroidal truncations.
The second family includes theories with SO(7, 1) invariance, which are based on the cofactor space G/H, where G is the symmetry group of maximal supergravity, and H is one of its subgroups.
The third type of theory is based on the exceptional group E$_{7(7)}/$SU(8).
The fourth family is based on the SO(p, 4) x SO(7−p) symmetry, where p is the number of spacetime vector fields.
The last family contains theories with SO(p, 3, C) symmetry, where C represents the reality of the supergravity C prior to the membrane.
Sandstone is one of the most important rock types in the world, having significant impacts on both the economy and culture.
One of these influences is architecture and structure.
Sandstone is used in the construction of various architectural structures, such as bridges, buildings, and skyscrapers.
Fountainbleau sandstone is one of the most famous types of sandstone and is widely used in the construction of the exterior walls and staircases of the Miami prison.
Although it is significant in the construction industry, there is not much research on Fontenay-aux-Roses sandstone.
This is largely attributable to the complex hierarchical fracture networks in sandstone, which make the research challenging.
This paper uses optical microscopy and statistical analysis to study the fracture patterns in fractured Fengtingbu sandstone.
The results indicate that the fractured sandstone conforms to the Weibull statistical distribution.

In addition, the research indicates that the failure surface is not smooth and exhibits non-Gaussian statistical characteristics, which may have significant implications for the fracture mechanics of Toyama Castle sandstone.
Real-time renormalization group (RT-RG) is applied in quantum dot systems under the influence of Coulomb screening.
The conductivity of the quantum dot is calculated as a function of system parameters, which include the gate voltage, bias voltage, and the number of push rods (i.e., orbitals) in the quantum dot.

The separation between low-energy and high-energy scales is established through a small parameter, which is assumed to be the result of the bias voltage scaled by a large energy (for example, the piston energy).
By truncating the integro-differential equation system to the second term, an exact solution was obtained.
In this approximation, the conductivity is parameterized through the solution of a set of coupled differential equations.
Our solution approach allows us to explore a wide range of system parameters.
Specifically, we calculated the crossing point at which the system transitions from a nearly empty point charge to a fully charged point charge while tunneling into the charge transfer state.

In addition, we calculated a truncation energy and a truncation scale to separate the slow scales in the system (i.e., those that vary along the flow of the system parameters) from the fast scales (i.e., those that are independent of the system).
The dependencies of the former are captured by effective theories, while the latter is absorbed into the running (i.e., evolution) cutoff scale.
This provides a powerful approach to explore the nonequilibrium quantum dot problem under varying numbers of confined (orbital) states and gate voltages.
Specifically, this allows people to find a range of parameters within which a given nonequilibrium steady state is not reached during the evolution of the system from certain initial conditions.

For example, we found that if the initial state of the quantum dot is nearly empty (or filled), then the conductivity exhibits a minimum (or maximum) at the Coulomb blockade peak of the conductivity through the quantum dot.
Sigma Orionis is a small, rich star cluster located about 1,200 light-years away from Earth.
It is located at the center of the Orion Molecular Cloud, which is a vast stellar formation complex situated about 420 light-years away from Earth in the constellation Orion.

At the relatively young age of approximately 7 million years, Sigma Orionis remains deeply embedded in its parent cloud, providing an excellent laboratory for studying the substellar components of very young star clusters.
The first comprehensive survey of brown dwarfs and ultra-low-mass stars in this cluster was presented by Belikov et al. (2012).
Here, we present optical, near-infrared, and IRAC/Spitzer photometry measurements for over 130 additional cluster members, bringing the total number of members to more than 200.

This enables us to characterize the substellar initial mass function (IMF) more precisely. The data shows that within the substellar mass range of 0.1–0.015 M⊙, this function is closely related to a power-law relationship with an exponent of -1.3.

The mass function is significantly lower than the mass function of trapezoidal clusters in the Orion Nebula (e.g., Kroupa et al., 2007) and is comparable to the mass function of much younger clusters (on the order of tens of millions of years), such as the Nice model of solar system formation (Boss & Bernstein, 2012).

Its flatness is noticeably lower than the field measurements obtained from recent near-infrared imaging (e.g., the N TOP algorithm, McElwain et al. 2014) and much steeper than the measurements obtained from IRAC/Spitzer data, which are significantly affected by considerable incompleteness in the low-quality samples.
We used this new group quality function to update the projected group core and core aggregation rate, obtaining values of 3.4 × 10⁻⁵ M⊙ yr⁻¹ and 8.6 × 10⁻⁵ M⊙ yr⁻¹, respectively.

These estimates are significantly higher than previous ones, but they are consistent with theoretical core accumulation models for very low-quality stars and brown dwarfs at the young age of Sigma Orionis.
A new set of comprehensive elemental abundance data is presented for the weakened damped Lyman-alpha absorber (DLA).

The dataset is based on high-resolution spectral observations of 19 quasars, focusing on the Zn and Y spectral lines, covering the ranges of 18 < Z/H < 27 and 26 < Y/H < 0.5, and it almost spans four orders of magnitude in the abundance of DLA [N$_2$H$^+$](+)[H$_2$]{}.
In addition to these zinc (Zn) and yttrium (Y) spectral lines, we also analyzed the abundances of other zinc and yttrium from the previously published data of B13 and HS15.
The paper includes a reanalysis of the B13 and HS15 data, as well as new results for the elements O, Si, Ti, V, Cr, Co, and Ni from previous analyses.
It also includes preliminary results for aluminum, copper, and manganese.
The complete dataset allows for a detailed study of the star formation histories (SFHs) of DLA galaxies for the first time.
The new relationship between the Y/Zn atomic ratio and metal abundance allows us to rule out constant star formation history models that vary over time (including exponential decay models).
This significantly increases the number of single-family homes (SFH) allowed by the data.

We found that the double burst model, which features a secondary star formation burst aged 5 billion years, is the best model for most galaxies, while a small portion of galaxies is best described by a constant star formation history.
The new dataset will be of great value for studying the early evolution of galaxies, understanding the chemical evolution of galaxies, and testing models of galaxy formation and evolution.
In the standard model (SM) of particle physics, the gauge fields of the weak force and the Higgs field are the foundations of the particles and interactions that we observe in this world.

Specifically, the weak force is transmitted via the W and Z bosons, as well as the Higgs boson, but the interactions of these particles are described by a single coupling constant that connects the strong force, weak force, and electromagnetic force.
The renormalization group (RG) tells us that this single coupling constant must evolve from a unified value at high energy scales.

By introducing an additional symmetry between the strong interaction and the electroweak interaction, as well as a singlet scalar field under both, we can naturally set the coupling constant of the weak interaction to be less than that of the strong coupling constant, without the need to introduce any new particles.
This symmetry breaking is realized through the vacuum expectation value (vev) of the Higgs field, which is precisely what gives particles their mass.
This scalar field and its corresponding symmetry breaking is called the Higgs mechanism.
Although the Higgs particle has no specific charge, it can couple with weak bosons, and the Glashow-Iliopoulos-Maiani (GIM) mechanism can suppress unwanted interactions between electrons and photons.
This stems from the cancellation of tree-level flavor-changing neutral currents (FCNCs) and the observed patterns of quark and lepton masses and mixing.

By introducing a small explicit symmetry breaking term, we can obtain a Higgs boson whose interaction with electrons and quarks appropriately becomes negligible while maintaining the successful unification of the electroweak and strong interactions described above.
The complete theory should also be able to reproduce the correct results of nuclear physics and scattering processes.

We introduced the theoretical motivation and phenomenological aspects of the model and demonstrated that it provides a reasonable framework for the electroweak and flavor sectors of the standard model.
The relatively close elliptical galaxy Leo Elliptical Galaxy NGC 3379 contains a low-mass satellite galaxy, Leo IV.
Spectral analysis of its moon reveals that this satellite had a higher star formation rate in the past and that its orbit was more eccentric than it is now.
The simulation shows that the growth of the main galaxy NGC 3379 can transform a low-mass satellite galaxy into a faint dwarf galaxy like Leo IV.

This discovery suggests that low-mass satellite galaxies within large mass halos can still undergo transformation by their host galaxies. The study found that there is diffuse material in the form of neutral hydrogen surrounding this satellite galaxy, which has a highly eccentric orbit. This is an excellent example of transformation occurring in low-mass systems as a result of interactions with their host galaxies.
The Leo elliptical galaxy NGC 3379 is a large elliptical galaxy located approximately 30 million light-years away from Earth.
It is a relatively nearby galaxy, and its characteristics have been well studied.

One of its satellites, Leo IV, was discovered in 2015 through the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. Observations of its stars indicate that its orbit is more eccentric and that its past star formation rate was higher.
The simulation shows that NGC 3379 can change its properties through interactions with this low-quality satellite.
Specifically, Leo IV may evolve from a faint dwarf star into a system of greater mass.
This is evident from the detection of a large amount of neutral hydrogen around the satellite, a phenomenon that was first observed in 2015.
This finding suggests that even in massive halos, low-mass satellite galaxies can be influenced by the transformations of their host galaxies.

In the context of curved subfield scenarios, the fluctuations of the scalar field that determines the dark matter number density contribute to the gravitational wave parameter Omega_GW level, which is related to the speed of gravity during the inflation period.
However, due to the lower bound of the potential energy of the scalar field, the fluctuations of this field do not significantly contribute to gravitational waves.
From this work, we studied the maximum gravitational wave amplitude generated in a curvature sub-scenario, while considering the impact of the effective speed of gravity during inflation.
We found that in the curvature sub-scenario, the maximum value of the gravitational waves equals that of general relativity, Ω_GW = 1.
We indicate that this result will not change even if the potential energy of the scalar field has an upper limit.
For this work, we consider two cases of scalar fields: a real-valued inflationary field and a complex-valued curvature field.
The complex curvature field determines the density fluctuations of dark matter, while the real expansion field determines the changes in the rate of cosmic expansion.

During the oscillation in the expanding field, the speed of gravity is nearly equal to the speed of light, whereas in the process of evolving in a complex expanding field, its speed is below the speed of light.

Therefore, the fluctuations of the scalar field that determine the number density of dark matter are related to gravitational waves, represented by the parameter Omega_GW, which is associated with the speed of gravity.
We found that the maximum gravitational wave amplitude is equal to the value of general relativity, Omega_GW = 1.
Through addition, we studied the perturbations of gravitational waves at the sub-Hubble scale.
We found that the perturbation of gravitational waves depends on the effective speed of gravity during the inflationary period.
If the effective speed of gravity is equal to the speed of light, then the amplitude of gravitational wave disturbances is inversely proportional to the square of the effective speed of gravity.
This result has an upper limit: it is 1/3 for the two-field model and 1/7 for the multi-field model.
Finally, we discuss the gravitational wave background of the expanding universe.

If the effective speed of gravity is greater than the speed of light, then during the expansion period, there will be many modes comparable in scale to the Hubble radius, which will result in a huge background of gravitational waves.
In this case, it is difficult to explain recent gravitational wave experiments, such as the B-mode experiments and LIGO/Virgo.
However, if the effective speed of gravity is equal to the speed of light, then we can obtain a gravitational wave background consistent with the current value.

We can achieve a model that produces the maximum amount of gravitational waves by adopting a scalar field potential with a lower bound, which determines the maximum effective speed of gravity during cosmic expansion.
In this case, it is easy to explain the observed gravitational wave background value, while the fluctuations...
In this paper, we present a measurement of the sensitivity to the search for anomalous Wtb couplings in the top quark decay channel at the LHC.
We focus on the 13 TeV data and update the measurements we presented at the 2018 Moriond EW conference using the full dataset collected from 2015 to the present.

The results are interpreted in the context of a simplified model with non-standard Wtb coupling, with the aim of testing the fundamental symmetries of the Wtb vertex, namely its Hermiticity and gauge invariance.
We found consistent constraints with those obtained at the Moriond conference and updated our results in the case of non-zero scalar and pseudo-scalar coupling.
The results presented in this paper provide the strongest constraints to date on vector and scalar interactions, and we demonstrate the first constraints on tensor couplings.
We have also provided for the first time constraints on the anomalous Wtb coupling involving pseudovector interactions, which may arise in models beyond the Standard Model (BSM).
We expect that our results can be directly applied to the new phenomena characterized by these anomalous couplings. To illustrate this, we consider the case of minimal flavor violation (MFV).
A quantum information processor (QIP) consists of various physical qubits that can be entangled and measured to perform computations.
Although these operations are intended to maintain coherence, experimental errors inevitably lead to the mixing of entangled states.
We experimentally characterize this coherence loss through ultrafast interferometry and find that it can be well approximated by a Gaussian process.
We studied the relationship between these fluctuations and the computational parameters and device performance, and found that the noise introduced by the universal gates exceeds the coherence.

Finally, we examined the sensitivity of the results to the choice of experimental design and investigated whether random switching of events during the experiment would lead to significant differences.

We propose a framework that can be experimentally validated to optimize the coherence of quantum information processing as a function of computational parameters, and we demonstrate its application by optimizing quantum Fourier transformation.

This consistency optimization can be transformed into an automated program for optimizing quantum information processing, and we demonstrate this application as nearly optimal input states for quantum Fourier transform.

As the experiments progress, the complexity of Quantum Input Processes (QIPs) continues to increase. Therefore, the techniques used for coherence assessment and optimization will play an increasingly important role in the scale-up of these devices.
The Finite Volume Method (FVM) is widely used for solving partial differential equations (PDE) due to its robustness and efficiency.

However, model parameters (such as reaction rates in the reaction-diffusion equations) are often difficult to infer from finite volume method (FVM) solutions due to a mismatch between the realism of the solution and the regularity of the solution, which is necessary for accurately identifying model parameters.

This hinders the possibility of directly using finite volume method (FVM) solutions in areas such as real-time monitoring or uncertainty quantification, and encourages the development of methods that utilize the information carried by solution noise.
In this work, we developed a statistically optimal flow inversion method, in which the model is inverted using a probabilistic framework, treating the parameters as random variables.
To make the problem feasible, we utilize empirical Bayes (EB) to estimate model parameters from noisy finite volume method (FVM) solutions.

In order to further simplify the Bayesian inversion problem into a computational problem that can be easily handled by modern large-scale computing systems, we propose a sparse form of Bayesian inversion method.
We demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed method through several one-dimensional and two-dimensional convection-diffusion-reaction problems.
Finally, we demonstrated that Bayesian inversion can effectively utilize knowledge of initial conditions to accurately estimate model parameters.
This article examines the impact of the Oort Cloud on the anisotropic distortion of the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB).
The method is based on the idea that the Sun is located near the boundary of the Oort Cloud, where the gravitational influence of the Milky Way begins to dominate.
This article presents an analysis and estimation of the temperature variation within Planck units caused by the gravitational disturbances of perturbers located in the Oort cloud.
These calculations are conducted for several models of the Oort Cloud structure proposed in recent years.
Calculations indicate that perturbators in the Oort cloud can produce the observed anisotropy level of the cosmic microwave background radiation temperature.

This article points out that the method proposed in the paper for detecting the Oort Cloud signal can be used to test the structural models of the Oort Cloud and estimate some parameters of galactic potential energy.
Searching for photos on Flickr is a popular activity, and the search results can be sorted by most popular, most recently added, and most viewed.
To accomplish this task, we use neural networks to predict the click-through rate (CTR) for each photo and use the predicted CTR to reorder the photo search results.
The results indicate that using predicted click-through rates (CTR) instead of the original photo metadata can improve the performance of query-independent photo search.
Our model can be easily trained on publicly available Flickr datasets and can be quickly deployed to other photo search platforms.
Overall, this work indicates that using deep learning to model photo search ranking can be a promising approach to improving the photo search experience.
