"Yingzhe Yan, Quanquan Nie, Ping Zhou, Ming Liu. Paper link: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1710.10455.pdf"
Understanding the origin of ferromagnetism is one of the key issues in materials science.
In this article, we report an unexpected ferromagnetic (FM) behavior observed in the non-magnetic material TiO2.

When titanium atoms are removed from the lattice of titanium dioxide (especially from the Ti4+ sites), the crystal structure evolves into a rutile type and acquires a net magnetic moment, which is found to persist above room temperature.
The magnetism caused by the disorder of Ti4+ (TDIM) has been observed in various materials, such as TiO2 nanoparticles, TiO2 films, and nanotubes.
We hope that our work can stimulate more research activities in this field and inspire further experimental and theoretical studies on this intriguing issue.
In the supplementary materials, the author provided additional experimental data and also offered some theoretical explanations regarding TDIM.
Calculations based on first principles indicate that the substitution of Ti4+ in TiO2-rutile with O2- anions leads to the emergence of a net ferromagnetic moment.

In addition, our experimental research shows that the persistence of this moment reaches at least 300K. These observations contrast with previous reports regarding the non-magnetic nature of diamond-type TiO2.
It explores various mechanisms to ensure the sustainability of this net moment.
At the Ti4+ site, explaining the observed magnetic moment requires significant ionic coupling, while explaining the observed magnetic moment values necessitates substantial spin-orbit coupling.
The theoretically predicted ordering temperature of the magnetic moment is consistent with the experimental results.
Our work shows that the disorder of Ti4+ is an overlooked mechanism that can induce ferromagnetism in non-magnetic materials.
We provided possible evidence to support the hypothesis that Ti4+ disorder leads to the observed persistent ferromagnetism in various materials.
Due to the observation of Ti4+ disorder in various anatase-type TiO2 samples, our research proposes the possibility of persistent ferromagnetism in TiO2-based materials and related systems.

This research is inspired by recent reports on the persistent magnetism in disordered TiO2 with Ti4+. Although many studies have been devoted to understanding the origin of magnetism in metals, understanding magnetism in non-magnetic materials remains an active area of research.
Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is used as a semiconductor in many devices and is non-magnetic.

However, recent studies have shown that certain forms of titanium dioxide (TiO2) exhibit ferromagnetism. [2,3] Since ferromagnetism has been observed in some Ti4+ disordered materials, understanding the origin of ferromagnetism in titanium dioxide is of significant importance both fundamentally and in terms of applications.
This work explores the ferromagnetic mechanism of TiO2 rutile induced by Ti4+ vacancies.
To explore the TDIM mechanism of TiO2, we used sol-gel technology to synthesize TiO2 nanoparticles with a wide size distribution.
We explored three different synthesis methods to control the amount of Ti4+ disorder.
The Late M-type multiple system LHS 1070 has become a benchmark in the study of stellar magnetic fields due to its powerful and unique magnetic field.

We report the results of discovery spectrum observations of the system conducted using the WIYN 3.5-meter telescope, as well as subsequent Doppler imaging analysis of its components, focusing on the stable and unusual abundances of elements other than hydrogen and helium.

We found that the moderately rapidly rotating celestial body LHS 1070 B has a strong and stable magnetic field, which dominates its atmosphere and slows down its rotation at a rate consistent with solid body rotation.

In contrast, the components LHS 1070 C and D, which rotate faster, have much weaker magnetic fields, and their rotation rates are faster than expected for their spectral types. This is consistent with previous reports of magnetic braking acting on their surfaces.
The rapidly rotating LHS 1070 C has a magnetic field that is only slightly stronger than that of a typical late K-type star, while the almost non-rotating LHS 1070 D has no detectable magnetic field.

We conclude that LHS 1070 C and D will be the first example in which the faster-rotating component has a sufficiently strong magnetic braking effect, causing its rotation rate to be significantly lower than that of rigid body rotation.
We further speculate that the strong magnetic field of LHS 1070 B may be a clue to its anomalous chemical composition, which is rich in elements other than hydrogen and helium.

Using submillimeter wave arrays, we have conducted high angular resolution mapping of the H$_2$D$^+$ $J = 1 - 2$ emission from a sample of 14 Class 0 and Class I protostars (with a median distance of 0.4-2.3 astronomical units in our sample, which is comparable to the disk radius).
We detected emissions from ten sources and reported observations of two new protostellar cores, where we first detected the emission of H$_2$D$^+$.
The emission presents as an elongated structure with a large deconvolution width, indicating that H$_2$D$^+$ originates from shock-heated gas.
We detected H$_2$D$^+$ emission from two regions, which are both driving powerful molecular outflows and originate from a more tranquil environment.

The outflowing and enriched sources tend to have brighter H$_2$D$^+$ emission and higher molecular depletion factors, indicating that shocks more effectively heat and disrupt H$_2$D$^+$ in these environments.
In contrast, the source HH212, which only has an envelope, although it has a significant edge disk, its emission of H$_2$D$^+$ is relatively weak.

We propose two possible explanations for this difference: (i) the quiescent stellar core formed in HH212 contains less presolar material; or (ii) the H$_2$D$^+$ emission in HH212 traces a vertically extended ring rather than a curved or disk-like structure.

Future observations of H$_2$D$^+$ $J = 1 - 2$, as well as observations conducted with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), will test these and other hypotheses, while constraining the excitation and abundance of H$_2$D$^+$ and tracing different velocity components in material-rich star formation sources.
We have developed a polymer quantum mechanics (PQM), in which the fundamental variables are continuously twisted in a non-compact group, and its Lie algebra is an infinite-dimensional Hilbert space.

The Hilbert space of quantum polymers is a section space of a vector bundle defined over a group, with its standard fiber located at the identity element, and its Lie algebra is the same as the aforementioned Lie algebra.
The coordinate algebra of the polymer is completed with respect to a naturally invariant trace.
This enables us to construct an invariant Schrödinger equation applicable to the entire continuously curved space.

Quantum polymers have also been shown to continuously deform into standard (commutative) quantum mechanics, where the characteristics of the polymers appear as self-similar fine structures in the spectra of some completely solvable models.

We also indicate that polymer quantum mechanics can be approximated by a sequence of ordinary quantum mechanics corresponding to gradually increasing degrees of polymerization, with the error vanishing in the limit.
The extreme transition can be carried out in two steps.

In the first step, the continuous twist is replaced by the projective limit of a finite-dimensional matrix group, in which the normal subgroups retain only the diagonal elements and the corresponding subalgebras.
In the second step, these matrix groups are replaced by their projective limits, which are compact Lie groups.
Finally, we show that the strong operator limit of the corresponding ordinary quantum mechanics sequence corresponds to the commutative limit of polymer quantum mechanics.
The form of the Initial Mass Function (IMF) has been a topic of intense debate over the past few decades.

Although it was initially assumed that the initial mass function (IMF) follows a power law, it is now clear that most star formation regions (if not all) have a modified version of the initial mass function, which is a log-normal distribution, or more generally, a function with a density that is higher than exponential at low masses.
The universality of the IMF remains an unresolved issue.

It is still necessary to observe whether the International Monetary Fund (IMF) exhibits differences across different regions, and if so, whether these differences are related to the parameters of the region, gravitational potential, the intensity of local turbulence, or other certain aspects.
We report that the initial mass function (IMF) of individual star clusters in Orion Molecular Cloud 2 exhibits a power-law form, with an exponent consistent with the standard value of 0.7.
This result indicates whether the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is indeed prevalent within the range of observational uncertainty.
However, to fully understand the origins of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), it is necessary to determine the extent of variation of the IMF within and between stellar formation regions.
Using the data from the advanced LIGO first and second observation runs (O1 and O2), we search for intermediate mass ratio merger signals (S2 IMSs).
Such signals may carry unique signatures of their host's dense stellar core, enabling us to uniquely determine the structure and distance of the star.
We set the upper limit of the rate of such signals as a function of quality and strain.
We further provide a lower bound for the assumed radius and distance of the host star.
We discuss the impact of the radius issue and its effects on planetary systems around medium-mass stars.

We use data from the first two observational runs (O1 and O2) of the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Advanced LIGO) to search for signals from intermediate mass ratio spirals (S2 IMSs).
The asymptotic bodies of the intermediate mass ratio are a class of distant star groups, whose signals can convey unique imprints about the dense stellar cores of their hosts.

Using these signals to measure the structure of stars and their distances will enable us to answer long-standing questions about the radius issue and the existence of planets around intermediate-mass stars.
We set the rate of such signals as a function of the upper limit of mass and strain, and discuss its impact on the radius problem, as well as the possibility of planets existing around these stars.
We are searching for S2 IMS signals within a range of 15 to 45 seconds of difference, with the model expecting to detect one S2 IMS every 4 to 6 weeks.
We set upper limits on the mass and strain of these signals at a 95% confidence level.
Assuming a population of indicator stars (IMS) that are uniformly distributed in logarithmic mass, we can use these ratios to derive a lower limit for the assumed host radius.
We discuss the impact of the radius problem and the existence of planets around medium-mass stars.
For example, at a distance of about 15 seconds of arc, we can set a lower limit on the radius of the primary star, which is approximately 1.4 M⊕ for S2 IMS at 4.2 R⊕ and 1.4 M⊕ for S2 IMS at 6.3 R⊕.
Assuming that IMSs follow a logarithmic uniform distribution, we can use these ratios to derive an upper limit on the number of planets with a radius of R⊕ around medium mass stars.
We are also looking for signals from systems with almost equal-mass companion stars.
These can be used to measure the spin of companion stars, thereby testing general relativity.

We discussed the implications of these results for the radius problem and the existence of planets around intermediate-mass stars, and demonstrated how these results are used to test general relativity and determine the rotation of companion stars.
A single-walled carbon nanotube forest is grown by chemical vapor deposition, with a thickness of up to one millimeter. The catalyst used is ferrocene, and the carbon source is dioctyl sulfone.
These forests exhibit unique growth windows that require high-temperature annealing before growth, resulting in directional growth along the CVD feeding direction.

The simulation results indicate that the growth window corresponds to a nanotube forest containing only semiconductor nanotubes, and the directional growth is the alignment of the semiconductor nanotube segments in the supply direction of chemical vapor deposition (CVD).
The observed millimeter-thick forest has attractive potential for several applications that require high-capacity, high-concentration carbon nanotube dispersions.

We are currently exploring several methods for separating forests from their growth substrates, including supercritical fluid separation, wet chemical treatment of the forests to dissolve the growth substrates, and direct solvent extraction of the forests to allow for regrowth on different growth substrates.
Astrophysical jets are very powerful and directed outflows driven by compact objects, such as active galactic nuclei (AGN) and X-ray binaries.
They are crucial in the process of acquiring most of the energy and momentum in galaxies and galaxy clusters.
The formation of astrophysical jets remains a mystery, but various theoretical models have been proposed.
Especially, some propose that the magnetic field is very important in the generation, focusing, and maintenance of astrophysical material jets.

In this paper, we investigate the resonance coupling between fast Kelvin-Helmholtz waves and magnetosonic waves in a shear-relevant relativistic plasma, with a focus on astrophysical systems where this process can occur.
Our analysis is conducted within the framework of general relativity.
We found that in these systems, the resonant mechanism can effectively transfer energy from shear to rapid Kelvin-Helmholtz waves.
For simplicity, we consider a system consisting of a shear plasma moving with a Lorentz factor γ in a quasi-neutral plasma, with an external magnetic field B0 present in the y direction.
We study the patterns that may arise when the linear propagation speed of the magnetoacoustic wave equals the phase speed of the Kelvin-Helmholtz wave.
The least stable mode has a short wavelength in the y direction and a non-zero phase velocity in the x and z directions.

The growth rate of the least stable mode is proportional to the square of the vorticity of the fluid in the y direction, which means that instability is most effective for systems with differential rotation.

However, the least stable mode also depends on the ratio of shear to sound speed γShc, and it increases with the increase of γShc, which means that the stronger the shear, the higher the efficiency of the mode.
We also studied the stability of nonlinear effects in this most unstable mode.

When the amplitude of the magnetoacoustic wave is comparable to that of the Kelvin-Helmholtz wave, the nonlinear interaction between the two waves leads to the least unstable mode evolving into a stable shock wave with a smooth contact surface.

We conclude that the resonant coupling between Kelvin-Helmholtz waves and magneto-acoustic waves may have important effects on astrophysical jets, making this field an important direction for future research.

The resonance coupling discussed here may also be very important in microquasars, especially in the environment of black hole systems like SS 433, where a pair of mutually orbiting stars eject high-energy jets.
The stars move in nearly circular orbits, but the jets are highly relativistic and tend to be ejected in directions that are perpendicular to the orbital plane.
The parallel relationship between this track plane and the jet strongly suggests the extraction of energy and momentum from orbital motion.
Extracting energy and momentum from shear relativistic flows may provide a new mechanism for this parallelism.
Resonance amplification, using the Kelvin-Helmholtz effect and magnetohydrodynamic techniques.
The large-scale structure (LSS) of galaxies contains powerful information about cosmic models and our understanding of galaxy formation.

The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) luminous red galaxy (LRG) sample contains 27,000 galaxies, with a median redshift of 0.38 and a photometric redshift error of 0.03, covering a redshift range up to 0.7, making it the largest contiguous high-redshift large-scale structure sample to date.
We use this sample to measure the halo occupation distribution in a comprehensive Monte Carlo simulation of six popular galaxy formation models.
The measured correlation function obtained from the measurements is compared with the measured two-dimensional correlation function from the LRG sample.

These six comparative models allow us to constrain the properties of the dark matter halo of the host LRG, with a temperature sum greater than or equal to 4.5 keV, and a stellar feedback heating rate sum less than or equal to 12.7 keV.
These limits correspond to typical WIMP masses of less than about 15 GeV in the standard thermal WIMP model.
In high-energy heavy-ion collisions, particle production is strongly influenced by the dependence on the initial spatial anisotropic path length of the participating interactions.
The speed-dependent Hanbury-Brown-Twiss (HBT) interferometry can provide constraints on the spatial range and intensity of the initial pressure gradient of the reaction.
With the support of anisotropic flow calculations, two quantitative methods have been proposed to determine the charge correlation in the phase space of particles produced near mid-fast speeds.
Apply these methods to the published Bose-Einstein correlation data obtained by the NA49 and CERES collaboration at SPS, where charge correlations are identified as functions of rapidity and energy.
Research shows that under all energy and rapidity conditions, the correlation strength of like charges reaches a maximum, while the correlation of unlike charges weakens.
The rapid dependence of the relevant intensity shows a minimum at approximately 3.2 times the meson chemical potential and increases at greater longitudinal distances away from the midpoint.
We describe the Verlinde-type formula for degenerate fields in logarithmic conformal field theories (CFT) with a central charge \( c_{p,1} \).
We have demonstrated a one-to-one correspondence between the degeneracy of these fields and certain types of branched coverings of the Riemann sphere that branch at three points.
The number of coverings we refer to as n-fold branch coverings can be expressed through an explicit formula, which involves the residues of certain local analytic functions on the complex plane.
We also discussed an interesting connection between the Gaussian hypergeometric function and branch points.

Our formula not only generalizes the existing Verlinde-type formulas in conformal field theories with central charge \( c_{p,p'} \), but also encompasses the formulas for degenerate fields in logarithmic conformal field theories with central charge \( c_{p,1} \) proposed by Haglund, Hemmer, and Aulbach.
We provide two proofs of our formulas: one is based on the ideas of Toda form theory, and the other is based on the ideas of Gaussian hypergeometric function theory.
Type-II superconductors undergo a transition above the critical temperature \( T_c \), entering a state with zero electrical resistance, known as the Meissner effect.
In traditional superconductors, the impedance state is understood as a lossless state, referred to as the W Koszul state, named after the researcher who discovered this state.

In three-dimensional (3D) superconductors, the distorted magnetic field configuration is called vortex lines, which move from regions of higher temperature to regions of lower temperature, thereby forming the bosons of a Bose-Einstein condensate.
This overcooling phenomenon was first observed in type II superconductors under thin film configurations.
Here, we report the observation of bosons in the Bose-Einstein condensate in the thin film of strong type II superconductor Nb3Sn (tin-bismuth).
Unlike thin films, thin membranes are two-dimensional (2D), and therefore exhibit two-dimensional supercooling phenomena at lower temperatures.
We found that 2D supercooling was completely finished around...
For our thinnest film, 20 mK corresponds to a critical current that is about 500 times that of the Meissner state.
For lower temperatures, we observed thermally activated behavior and fitted the Arrhenius law to extract an activation energy of 25 microelectronic volts.

We demonstrate that this is consistent with the proposed energy gap of the strongly type-II superconductor niobium tin (Nb3Sn), and we believe that the observed large critical current is consistent with the three-dimensional supercooling phenomenon in our thin films.
Galactic globular clusters are typically identified by their high galactic latitude, low optical surface brightness, and red characteristics on the color-magnitude diagram.
However, a small number of globular clusters can also be found at the center of the Milky Way, within its historical brightness profile.
These "central" star clusters are particularly interesting because they are associated with the past of the galactic nucleus and may currently be identified as locations for nucleosynthesis.
Here, we report on the study of the central globular cluster NGC 2419.
We have obtained spectra of over one hundred red giants, from which we measured the chemical composition and mapped the metallic abundance and spatial distribution of the star cluster.
We discovered an previously unrecognized spatial structure in the calcium abundance distribution, which is related to the distribution of iron peak elements.

These component structures suggest the presence of multiple epochs of star formation in NGC 2419, with the iron peak providing evidence of chemical enrichment from the most recent generation of stars, possibly in the core.
NGC 2419 is therefore considered to be a very promising globular cluster related to the galactic nucleus that is known today.
The geomagnetic field is an important indicator of space weather.
It consists of a bipolar component mainly generated by core motion and a fluctuating component produced by atmospheric and solar processes.

The amplitude of the fluctuation component rapidly decreases with the increase in distance from magnetic north. It is necessary to comprehensively consider solar input and atmospheric responses in order to accurately determine its amplitude and dipole moment at the Earth's surface.
The Earth's magnetic field can be directly observed using magnetometers, or inferred through satellite measurements of topographic potential energy and overall plasma flow.

Although the most advanced level of direct measurement technology has significantly improved over the past fifty years, direct measurement remains costly, limited by availability, and unable to measure the three-dimensional field information of the Earth's surface.
Therefore, the combination of geophysical models and magnetic field data assimilation is used to determine the three-dimensional field amplitude and dipole moment at the surface.

This article reviews some specific advancements in the field of variational data assimilation, a recently developed technique used to assimilate indirect observational data in order to improve the estimation of dynamic system states.
The variational method is regarded as a constrained optimization problem in the J subproblem and the D subproblem, where J and D represent the Jacobian matrix and the Hessian matrix, respectively.
We demonstrate the effectiveness of this method by assimilating magnetic field data from a single point on Earth into a nonlinear, high-dimensional, and sparse magnetohydrodynamics model.

Applying variational data assimilation of the magnetic field to improve the accuracy of geophysical models is a promising new direction that will help deepen our understanding of the dynamo processes that generate the Earth's magnetic field in the long term.
A type of dust component has been discovered at a distance of 2,000 parsecs above the plane of the Sombrero Galaxy (NGC 891), by the discoverer NAOMI.
This component consists of Olivet refractory silicate with a median size of 0.1 microns and has a power-law size distribution.
Its peak wavelength is about 10 micrometers, indicating its presence in very small particles.
This part of the dust is unrelated to any observed stars, planetary systems, or molecular clouds.
Its origin remains a mystery.
NAOMI discovered dust components located 2 arcseconds above the plane of the Sombrero Galaxy (NGC 891).
The component consists of olivine refractory silicate with a median size of 0.1 micrometers, and has a power-law size distribution.
Its peak wavelength is about 10 micrometers, indicating the presence of very small particles.
This dust component is unrelated to any observed stars, planetary systems, or molecular clouds.
Its origin is still a mystery.
This component can also be found in NGC 3628, which is a spiral galaxy located about 2.5 Mpc from Earth.
Due to the similarity of this dust composition to the dust in our own Milky Way galaxy, it would take at least 5,000 years for this dust to move from NGC 891 to NGC 3628.
This discovery raises important questions about its origin and its impact on the evolution of the Mexican Hat Galaxy.
The asymmetrically charged surface is subject to a net force due to electrostatic interactions.
This is commonly seen in nature in phenomena such as the adhesion between two objects with different charges, or the adhesion of substances on cell membranes and pollutants sticking to clothes.
In this work, the electrostatic interactions between the uniformly charged plate and the asymmetrically charged film were studied both theoretically and experimentally.
The membrane has a uniformly charged surface and a non-uniformly charged surface.
In the limit where the film thickness is relative to the distance of the large sheet film, derive the exact expression for the interaction potential.
The interaction potential is displayed as the sum of the interaction potentials of two uniformly charged plates.
The interaction potential energy is experimentally measured using a neutron reflectometer.
The measured potential is in high agreement with the calculated potential.

The first three van der Waals coefficients are extracted from the measured potential energy, showing a sign opposite to that of the surface charge, which is consistent with the long-range nature of van der Waals forces.
The Multiband Imaging Photometer for Spitzer (MIPS) is an infrared camera that functions similarly to an infrared space telescope but operates on the Spitzer Space Telescope.
This camera is used to observe several galaxies that form stars in the 70-micron wavelength band.
The absolute calibration and characterization of the camera were performed at 70 micrometers.

The accuracy of the 70 μm transfer function was quantified by observing a set of photometric standards. The results showed that the error at 30 μm brightness was 5.3%, at 45 μm it was 6.1%, at 60 μm it was 7.7%, and at 90 μm it was 9.3%.

The color and temperature estimates of the stars were compared with the results obtained from the infrared array camera data, and the results indicate that the two sets of data show good consistency after accounting for the expected errors of the two instruments.

Next, the point spread function (PSF) for 70 micrometers was characterized. The measurement results indicated that the half-power resolution is 14.3 micrometers, the full width at half maximum is 23.2 micrometers, and the average background surface brightness within the PSF is 1013.2 MJ/sr².
The absolute calibration was conducted by observing Uranus at a wavelength of 70 micrometers, resulting in a flux of 357.8225 microjoules per kiloparsec squared.

In addition, observations of the external regions of five galaxies in the 70-micron band confirmed that the radiation at 70 microns is significantly extended, with its surface brightness being 23.2 microns⁻² lower than the background brightness at the 50% level.

Further analysis of these data indicates that the observed intensity is consistent with an exponential disk with a scale length of approximately 4.2 kpc at a wavelength of 70 micrometers. Although the scale length is smaller, it aligns with observations at other wavelengths.
L-type and T-type brown dwarfs are stars with lower temperatures and masses less than that of the Sun.
They contain a large amount of deuterium (deuteron), but no hydrogen (proton hydrogen).
Their spectra show the absorption bands of deuterium, as well as their own characteristic chemical bands.
Measurements of the spatial velocities of a group of L-type and T-type brown dwarfs show that their typical spatial velocities are similar to that of the Sun.

The space velocity of L-type dwarfs is similar to the velocity of the local standard of rest (LSR), while the space velocity of T-type dwarfs is similar to the velocity of the Sun relative to the LSR.
For many years, people believed that the core of heavy hydrogen is the deuteron, rather than hydrogen, and that the core of hydrogen is proton hydrid.
Their spectra show the absorption bands of deuterium as well as their own characteristic chemical bands.
Measurements of the spatial velocities of a group of L-type and T-type brown dwarfs show that their typical spatial velocities are similar to that of the Sun.

The spatial velocity of L-type dwarfs is similar to the velocity of the local standard of rest (LSR), while the spatial velocity of T-type dwarfs is similar to the velocity of the Sun relative to the LSR.
However, recent studies on the kinematics of metal-poor stars indicate that the spatial velocities of many stars are similar to the velocity of the local standard of rest (LSR).

These studies indicate that star formation in galaxies occurs almost simultaneously across most regions of the Milky Way, and the oldest stars, which have the lowest metallicity, possess the highest spatial velocities.
This means that deuterium is synthesized in the interstellar medium, rather than being transported to locations where low-mass stars are formed.
The presence of deuterium has been found in many metal-poor stars, but not in L-type or T-type dwarfs, which seems to contradict the theories of the early evolution of these stars.
The spatial velocities of L-type and T-type brown dwarfs indicate that their typical spatial velocities are similar to that of the Sun.

The space velocity of L-type dwarf stars is similar to the local standard of rest (LSR) velocity, while the space velocity of T-type dwarf stars is similar to the velocity of the Sun relative to the LSR.
However, recent kinematic studies of metal-poor stars have shown that the spatial velocities of many stars are similar to the velocities of local standard stars.

These studies indicate that nearly throughout most regions of the Milky Way galaxy, star formation occurred almost simultaneously, and the oldest, most metal-poor stars possess the highest spatial velocities.
This means that deuterium is synthesized in the interstellar medium, rather than being transported to the locations where low-mass stars are formed.
Deuterium appears in many metal-poor stars, but not in L-type or T-type dwarf stars, which seems to contradict the theoretical understanding of the early evolution of these stars.
The spatial velocities of L-type and T-type brown dwarfs indicate that the typical spatial velocities of these objects are similar.
Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain.
Its receptor, namely the cationic glutamate receptor, is crucial for normal brain development and function.
Most glutamate receptors are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum and then distributed to the cell surface through the Golgi apparatus.

The circulation between the cell surface and the Golgi apparatus is crucial for their normal functions, as the cell surface is the main interface between neurons and their environment, and the receptors on the cell surface are always ready to transmit signals in response to glutamate stimulation.
Here, we report that cell surface glutamate receptors continuously recycle between the plasma membrane and inside the cell in a ligand-dependent manner through at least two pathways.
The first involves diffusion from the storage room of the Golgi apparatus to the cell membrane.
The second process involves endocytosis, followed by recycling to the plasma membrane.
These two pathways largely rely on the GluA2 subunit of AMPA receptors, which provides a mechanism to regulate the number of glutamate receptors on the cell surface.

We also observed a similar cooperation between these two pathways in the mouse model of Fragile X syndrome, and found that the drug 4-aminopyridine can activate both pathways, leading to increased levels of cell surface glutamate receptors and improved behavioral responses in the mouse model.

Our research results indicate that increasing the number of cell membrane receptors in the brain may enhance cognitive abilities and serve as a potential treatment for neurological disorders caused by low levels of glutamate receptors.
Polymer simulations typically involve studying polymers in solution or molten states, where various aspects of polymer behavior are influenced by intermolecular interactions and the environment.
A widely used solvent model in such systems is Dissipative Particle Dynamics (DPD), which combines simple mechanics with pairwise screened interactions between particles.
Due to its dynamic behavior differing from that of real polymers, DPD provides a computationally efficient method to study polymer systems.
Recently, the standard DPD thermostat has been extended to weakly couple particle motion with an external heat bath, resulting in the Langevin DPD (LDP) thermostat.
The LDP temperature controller has shown better thermal stability and adjustability compared to DPD, but its effectiveness in polymer simulation remains unclear.
In this work, we compared DPD and LDP for non-equilibrium simulations of freely jointed chains in solution.
The balanced conformation and simulations under stress were conducted and compared with the results from all-atom molecular dynamics (using implicit solvent).
We found that, compared to DPD, LDP exhibits greater stability in conformation distribution.
However, for the free joint chain, LDP significantly decreased the sampling efficiency, especially under conditions of high persistence length and low temperature.
These differences are related to the momentum distribution, which is strongly correlated with the angular momentum arrangement of the polymer.
Overall, these results indicate that LDP is a promising thermostat for DPD, but its effectiveness depends on the system and the variables of interest.
A probabilistic cellular automaton (CA) was introduced and studied to simulate the evolution of prey populations in connection with predator populations.

The system consists of coupled mappings, where the density of the prey evolves according to discrete random iterations, while the density of the predators is controlled by a continuous deterministic approximation.
Each prey will randomly transform into a predator with a certain probability at each time step.

The population experiences two stages: one is the disordered stage, where the population evolves towards a uniform distribution; the other is the ordered stage, where the system converges to a non-trivial spatiotemporal pattern.
In the ordered phase, there seems to be a traveling wave that propagates at a constant speed.
Its shape and wave speed can be accurately predicted by a self-consistent equation derived from the mean field approximation of a probabilistic cellular automaton.

The self-consistent equation reveals two branches of solutions: one stable solution corresponds to wave propagation, while the other unstable solution leads to a uniform distribution of the population.
These results highlight the ability of the proposed cellular automata (CA) to capture local and non-local interactions, and reveal the impact of randomness on pattern formation.
This work is a contribution to the theory of everything initiative.
Reference: Bányai, E., & Thome, V. (2020).
"Stable oscillation of predator-prey probability cellular automata: Mean field approach."
The translation of the Chinese text is: "Physical Review E, 101(2), 022909."
A quantum key distribution (QKD) system has been developed that utilizes superconducting single-photon detectors (SSPDs).

The quantum key distribution (QKD) system using semiconductor detectors is susceptible to channel noise, which can lead to detection errors caused by the light emitted from the scintillators in the detectors.
However, the SSPD used in this paper does not detect noise during room temperature operation, allowing for high-bit-rate and secure key generation over high-noise channels.

In a channel with a loss of 40 decibels, a key generation rate of approximately 1 Mbit/s was achieved, and the capabilities of detection, identification, and rejection of accidental coincidences were demonstrated.

These results represent the first high-speed, high-capacity quantum key distribution (QKD) system using superconducting single-photon detectors (SSPD), and demonstrate the feasibility of this technology in future high-capacity, low-cost quantum networks.
The application of SSPDs in quantum key distribution (QKD) enables the development of systems that can achieve high bit rates and secure key generation over high-noise channels.
In the principle proof, a quantum key distribution (QKD) system using superconducting single-photon detectors (SSPD) achieved a key generation rate of about 1 Mbps over a channel with 40 dB loss.

This is the first quantum key distribution (QKD) system that achieves high-speed operation using superconducting single-photon detectors (SSPD), and it is also the first system to demonstrate secure key generation over high-loss channels.
The worm-like chain (WLC) theory has always been the standard model for describing the bending rigidity of biological polymers such as DNA, RNA, and proteins.
This model assumes that the biopolymer is a uniform chain of classical links connected by non-classical rigid bonds.

Although the model is widely used, the WLC model does not take into account the inherent heterogeneity of the chain itself as well as the potential effects of bonds that may be prone to partial rupture.
To address this shortcoming, several modifications to the WLC model have been proposed.
In this article, we propose an alternative theory based on breakable bonds for worm-like chains (WLCBB).
The proposed chain has multiple degrees of curvature freedom, as well as additional linear stiffness resulting from the breaking and reformation of the links.
The exact solution is obtained by mapping the problem to the classical intersection problem in the plane.
The theory is used to study the mechanics of a short DNA fragment that has a rigid obstacle at each end.
The results obtained indicate that the theory can explain the flexibility of DNA without considering the excluded volume effect.
The theory also predicts that as the length of DNA fragments decreases, their flexibility will increase until a critical point, after which it will decrease.
This paper is a revised and expanded version of [1].

Water has long been believed to have exceptionally strong hydrogen bonds, but recent measurements using various techniques have yielded a consistent and surprising result: the strength of water's hydrogen bonds is approximately one-third of its estimated strength.
This obvious contradiction is resolved by viewing the structure of water as a hydrogen bond network.
Although the strength of a single isolated bond can be estimated through basic principles, hydrogen bonds in water are significantly weakened due to their involvement in a network of bonds.
The result discusses the influence of water behavior in biological systems, engineering systems, and technological processes.

This work was carried out by a research team from the United States and the Netherlands, including Wim van Straten, Kris den Oudsten, J. Michael Cole, Jens K. Nijdam, Benjamin A. Mahoney, and Thomas R. Zarrow.

Water has long been considered to have exceptionally strong hydrogen bonds, but new measurements conducted using various techniques have yielded a consistent and surprising result: the strength of water's hydrogen bonds is approximately one-third of its estimated strength.
This obvious contradiction is resolved by considering the structure of water, specifically the hydrogen bond network.

Although the strength of an isolated bond can be estimated from basic principles, the presence of hydrogen bonds among water molecules significantly weakens their strength as they participate in a network of bonds.
This result discusses the impact of water on the behavior of biological systems, engineering systems, and technological processes.

This work was completed by a group of researchers from the United States and the Netherlands, including Wim van Straten, Kris den Oudsten, J. Michael Cole, Jens K. Nijdam, Benjamin A. Mahoney, and Thomas R. Zarrow.
Consider a cluster with a crystalline structure of water molecules.
This group of molecules interacts by sharing hydrogen atom pairs.
Typically, each hydrogen atom is shared between two different molecules, and the distance between the oxygen atoms in the two molecules and the two shared hydrogen atoms is about 0.98 Å.

The classic description of hydrogen bonds requires the existence of an attractive force between shared atoms, which is precisely the case for the water molecules in this cluster, as the forces between the oxygen atoms and the shared hydrogen atoms are all attractive.
However, the shared hydrogen atoms are not isolated; they are part of a network of paired atoms that forms a three-dimensional lattice within the volume of the water molecules.
This grid weakens the strength of the hydrogen bonds between individual water molecules.

The degree of weakening depends on the specific orientation of water molecules in the cluster, but if we assume that the lattice extends uniformly in the cluster, it is found that the force between shared hydrogen atoms is one third of the force between oxygen atoms in the water molecules.
The weakening of hydrogen bonds has significant effects on the behavior of water in different systems.
We propose the rotation measurements (RMs) of extragalactic sources located behind the southern galactic plane.

We analyzed 605 frequency channels in the RM synthesis images of these sources obtained using the multichannel correlation enhancement telescope (CIGALE) at the Purple Mountain Observatory (PMO) with a 13.7-meter telescope.

We detected rotation metrics (RMs) in almost all areas of the LOS, ranging from 23.5 pc cm⁻¹/rad s⁻¹ in the north to -69.0 pc cm⁻¹/rad s⁻¹ in the south, with a zero-point rotation metric of approximately -600 pc cm⁻¹/rad s⁻¹.
The RMs gradually change in the direction of the line of sight, and the rotation measurements of almost all sources are enhanced at low galactic latitudes.
We conducted simulations to demonstrate that these large-scale features are unlikely to be caused by the effects of atypical dispersion, and that the traditional Faraday screen model is insufficient.
We suggest that these features may be the result of the large-scale structure of the magnetic field within the Milky Way.

We also studied the correlation between random planets (RMs) from the same source at different frequencies and found that most of them are negatively correlated, which may be related to random interstellar variations.

This work is based on observational data obtained from the PMO 13.7-meter CIGALE telescope, which is jointly operated by the PMO node of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the Sternberg Astronomical Institute of Moscow University.
This paper studies post-model selection inference for binary response models.

We derived the distribution approximation of the Nelson-Aalen estimator after model selection, which can be used to assess the strength of the association between the outcome of interest and a given set of predictor variables.
We then derived the distribution approximation of the post-model selection prediction function, which is a widely used summary predictor.

We indicate that under the conditions of the rules, these two distributions have only minor differences, which allows us to use the previous approximation to develop a method for estimating the properties of the latter distribution based solely on the sample of the response variable.
Through multiple simulation studies and analysis of the Prostate, Lung, Colorectal, and Ovarian (PLCO) Screening Trial, we have demonstrated the practical benefits of our program.

We provide the R code for our model selection and prediction function approximation, as well as the original simulated data and simulation code, in the relevant Git repository (https://github.com/joerish/can-one-estimate).
In this article, we analyze the characteristics of zero-latency long-distance synchronization (ZL-LS) through dynamic relaying.

ZL-LS is a phenomenon recently discovered in dynamic systems, where two chaotic systems can not only synchronize their dynamics when interacting with each other, but they can also synchronize when a sensor system only observes the state of the latter system.
Under the original setup of ZL-LS, two chaotic systems interact with each other.
In this work, we studied a scenario of a "dynamic relay" that observes a chaotic system and passively transmits its state to another chaotic system.
In this way, the two chaotic systems do not need to interact with each other.
We deduce sufficient conditions for achieving zero-delay long-distance synchronization from passive observations.
In addition, we have presented three numerical examples to illustrate the validity of the derived conditions.
Finally, we discussed the relationship between our work and two existing synchronization scenarios, namely asynchronous synchronization and zero-latency long-distance synchronization.
The double micro-lens light curve can detect denser regions in lens galaxies, determine the time separation of multiple images, and break the degeneracy of the double system mass function.
These benefits, along with the relative ease of using existing survey methods for detection, make binary micro-lenses a promising tool in cosmology.
With the increasing number of events detected in lens monitoring, it is now possible to test for deviations from strict focal crossover behavior.

In this work, we studied a large number of light curves from OGLE-2015-BLG-0341, demonstrating that the deviating focal-crossing behavior can be explained by finite source effects, and we proposed an empirical model to predict the shape of light curves in the absence of focal-crossing features.

Through this empirical model, we accurately predicted the light curve shapes of 21 additional binary microlensing systems, and we demonstrated that these can also be explained by the finite source effect.

We compared our results with the theoretical model and found that the light curves generated by the one-dimensional dynamical model of lensing galaxies are qualitatively different from the empirical model we proposed here.

Our research results indicate that the dual microlens effect can provide additional measurements of lens systems, which can be used to distinguish theoretical models of lens galaxies. This will help to break the degeneracies present in cosmological studies using microlensing analysis.
The vulnerability of networks to cascading failures is increasing, which is a dynamic effect that occurs when existing failure scenarios are improved through incremental optimization.
Here, we consider a scalable network model that exhibits second-order phase transitions and becomes increasingly vulnerable to random failures as the network size grows.

We further demonstrate that this dynamic effect can be significantly amplified by optimizing existing fault scenarios in a non-intuitive way: specifically, we show that increasing the network's vulnerability to targeted attacks can exacerbate the dynamic effects of enhanced vulnerability to random faults, as long as these attacks further accelerate the vulnerability enhancement strategy that increases the network's susceptibility to random faults.
These results provide insights into the vulnerability of real-world networks to random and targeted attacks.

By combining targeted attacks with improvements to existing fault scenarios, networks may become more vulnerable to random faults. This finding has broad implications for the resilience of real-world systems.

In the past few decades, several models have been proposed to explain the smallness of the squared mass differences of the three active neutrinos relative to the grand unified scale, which is referred to as the relaxation mass problem.
One of them is based on the seesaw mechanism, which uses particles near the Grand Unified Theory (GUT) scale to provide small masses for neutrinos in the Standard Model (SM).
We propose an extension based on introducing several additional symmetries into the visible mechanism.
This has led to an understanding of the reverse swing mechanism.

We demonstrated that under the framework of this new category of models, in contrast to the original seesaw mechanism, a heavy Majorana neutrino can have a very large mass, even exceeding the TeV scale.
This means that there is a significant GeV-TeV collider channel for this neutrino, making it possible to test this model in the near future.
We demonstrated a practical implementation of this type of model, covering both normal and inverted neutrino mass hierarchies.

The non-unitarity deviation of the first column of the PMNS matrix is used to explain the normal hierarchy, while the non-zero deviation of the first row of the mixing matrix explains the inverted hierarchy.
This model can be tested by measuring the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon.
We presented the contribution of a loop involving the lightest active Higgs boson and the heaviest right-handed Higgs boson to this magnetic moment.
We find the upper limits of their masses for given values of the lightest neutrino mass.

This model can be seen as an example of an unbalanced seesaw mechanism, where the violation of conservation of one or more additional symmetries leads to the existence of massless and/or very massive particles.
This model also has some other interesting phenomenological implications, especially the existence of keV-scale sterile neutrinos.

We demonstrate that the model leads to the observed enhancement phenomenon when the Higgs decays into a pair of muons, which was presented as an anomalous result at the Moriond Electroweak Conference.
In the 1960s, to explain the oscillation of neutrinos in the sun and the Earth's atmosphere, the hypotheses of heavy neutrinos and massless neutrinos were proposed.
These oscillation experiments have profoundly changed the landscape of particle physics and cosmology.

The standard mechanism to explain these oscillations is the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix, which involves the Dirac theory of neutrinos, the Glashow-Weinberg-Salam (GWS) theory of photons, and the Fermi theory of electrons.
These three particles are now referred to as neutrinos in the Standard Model (SM), and they have zero mass.
The oscillation experiments prove that at least two neutrinos have non-zero mass.
However, observations in cosmology regarding the baryon asymmetry of the universe (BAU) suggest that at least two of these neutrinos should be completely massless.
These facts are now referred to as the problem of relaxed fibrils.
In the past few decades, several models have been proposed to explain this small phenomenon.
The translation of the Chinese sentence "手征对称性与激发强子弦描述" into English is "Chiral symmetry and the description of excited hadronic strings."
Chiral symmetry is the symmetry of the quantum chromodynamics (QCD) Lagrangian that involves massless up and down quarks, and it is a fundamental symmetry of the universe.

Spontaneous chiral symmetry breaking is the source of the mass of most hadrons and is one of the reasons for the physical world we are familiar with (GPIO). This is one of the most striking examples of spontaneous symmetry breaking in physics.
The states generated by the breaking of this chiral symmetry are referred to as π mesons, K mesons, and η mesons, and their interactions are governed by chiral perturbation theory.

On the other hand, string theory (referred to as strings) is a very successful theory of fundamental particles that possesses an unbroken global symmetry known as scale symmetry or chiral symmetry. This symmetry exists spontaneously, and its spectrum exhibits quite different characteristics compared to the spectrum of quantum chromodynamics (QCD).
The literature reports that these two methods should be compatible.

Here, we demonstrate how to achieve this goal by introducing the Southern-Goldstone bosons into the effective string theory action in a manner that is invariant under the specified norms, and dynamically deriving the corresponding string spectrum.
A fundamental measure functional has been proposed for aligned hard hexagonal fluids.

This functional is based on an approximation of the shape of hard hexagonal particles, allowing for analytical treatment. The resulting expression is a functional of weighted density, and this functional has not been considered in the theory of hard hexagonal fluids before.
A systematic gradient expansion is used to derive a direct correlation function for free energy and a simple Padé approximation.
The fluid obtained exhibits a square ordered state at high density, which was found in computer simulations and observed in actual hard hexagonal experiments.
However, for low density, we predict a phase transition to the hexagonal phase.
Furthermore, we predict a reentrant nematic phase that has not been observed in computer simulations.
Our functional form considers the solid angle between adjacent particles as a key variable for first-order phase transitions.

We discussed the connection between our findings and recent computer simulations of hard spherical fluids, and suggested that some computer simulations may have incorrectly identified the transition to the solid phase.

A review on biomolecular computers, focusing on bacterial cells and how they can be programmed to perform various tasks.
The various aspects of biological molecular machines were discussed, and an overview was provided on how to achieve this biocomputer by engineering proteins on surfaces.
It explores the possibility of living cells themselves as molecular computers and discusses how cells process molecular signals through transport and enzymatic reactions.

A survey was conducted on the various molecular tasks that cells can perform, and some experiments that can be carried out to verify the feasibility of cells as biological molecular computers were introduced.
When discussing the construction of biomolecular computers, several key issues that must be overcome were also addressed.
The possibility of programming bacterial cells to perform various tasks was discussed.
Discussed various aspects of biomolecular machines.
Living cells themselves can be used as molecular computers.
Molecular signals can be processed by the cells themselves through transport and enzyme reactions.
The investigation was conducted on multiple molecular tasks that cells can perform.
It also discussed several key issues that must be overcome in constructing biomolecular computers.
Biological bricks, logic gates, sensors, computers, robots, and networks can all be constructed from bacterial cells.
An important part of this technology is the use of reliable intracellular synthesis and assembly methods.
In this regard, a primary requirement is that the DNA template used must be obtained from within the cells.
The current direct biosynthesis methods based on in vitro transcription or DNA template PCR amplification are generally unreliable.

We believe that cells themselves can serve as an ideal host for DNA biosynthesis by providing an appropriate environment with suitable pH, temperature, and salt concentration, and by protecting against direct physical damage.

The theory suggests that significant obstacles to DNA synthesis within cells include the thermal stability of DNA in bacterial cells (which allows newly synthesized DNA strands to exist in their natural double-stranded form), the instability of the cell membrane (which prevents larger DNA fragments from escaping the cell before transcription begins), and attacks by nucleases (which can degrade DNA strands).
To address these issues, we designed synthetic DNA structures with optimized thermal performance and membrane properties.
In addition, we have identified highly effective DNA structures that are resistant to nucleases, which have not yet been applied in biomolecular manufacturing.
All of these DNA characteristics should help in producing and assembling complex nanoscale structures from within bacterial cells.
The multifunctional genetic information encoding capability in DNA allows any signal to be digitized for processing by the cell.
It can be likened to a molecular computer, which performs calculations by processing digital signals through a series of logical operations.
These logical operations can be encoded in the form of DNA.
Therefore, any biochemical signal can be converted into a digital form suitable for cellular processing.
We propose the concept of digital biochemistry, where all biochemical signals are converted into digital form and processed by cells.
The interactions between particles in a fluid are typically divided into long-range contributions and short-range contributions.
Long-range interactions are typically modeled using simple pair potentials, while short-range interactions are modeled using a series of pair distribution functions.
Under thermal equilibrium, the total interaction can be simplified to a screened Coulomb potential.
The system may be officially separated into a system that contains only long-range interactions, a particle system with periodic boundary conditions, and a particle system with vanishing velocity.
The former can be solved precisely, while the latter two can be solved using numerical methods.
In this work, the 3D Ising model is used as a test case for the method.

Using a novel technique to systematically eliminate short-range interactions, studies have shown that short-range attraction can reduce the thermal conductivity of fluids by up to four orders of magnitude without changing the critical temperature.
Further indicates that the decrease in thermal conductivity leads to the divergence of self-diffusion rate and the disappearance of viscosity, while the structural order remains limited.
These results further reveal the role of short-range forces in fluid thermal transmission.
In this article, we conducted a detailed study of the systematic production of soft particles at forward angles in Au+Au collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC).
Such research is particularly important for characterizing the degree of chaos/thermalization achieved in these collisions.
Our results are based on the analysis of 1.7 million minimum-bias events from the PHOBOS experiment.

We compare the spectra, elliptic flow, and high transverse momentum particle production of charged particles and neutral particles, covering 15% of centrality, from the most central Au+Au collisions to the most peripheral collisions.

We observed that particle production at high forward rapidity can be well described by a quadratic function of the number of particles per unit rapidity, where N represents either charged particles or neutral particles.
These results are compared with calculations from hadronic models (PYTHIA, HIJING, AMPT), lattice quantum chromodynamics, and models of weak coupling physics.

Our data demonstrate the most detailed and strongest constraints of these models, and highlight the importance of specific aspects of collision dynamics to different aspects of the observed particle spectrum.
We use a heat-based model to quantify these aspects.
This enables us to derive the thermal parameters of the system during chemical condensation and kinetic condensation.
These were compared with the predictions of the ideal hadron gas and transport models at the quark level and hadron level.
We found that the momentum freeze-out parameters are subject to stronger constraints from the data, and we extracted a conservative temperature range: 155 MeV < T < 175 MeV.
Preliminary results indicate that the hadronic gas phase is short-lived and rapidly transforms into a high-density medium with hadronic freeze-out.

Although the early stages of hard scattering and nuclear collisions appear to be consistent with perturbative nature, the final state of strong interactions can be well described by a quark-gluon plasma, with a centrality-dependent temperature ranging from 155 MeV to 175 MeV.
A one-dimensional directional model of rock and elastomers is used to study the dynamics of earthquakes.
The model takes into account the nonlinear elastic response of rocks and the viscoelastic behavior of elastomers.
Rocks and elastomers are represented by one or more coupled first-order differential equations.
In this article, we conduct a simulation study on the two-dimensional Burridge-Knopoff (BK) seismic model proposed by Holtz and McRacken (Physica D, 1984, 29, 335-352).
The model indicates that both peak and static stress conditions after the peak may lead to the occurrence of earthquakes.

The results under the maximum first vertical and horizontal principal stress conditions are similar to those found in experiments, but the model qualitatively fails to reproduce the stress triggering mechanism after the peak.
The model is extended to two-dimensional systems by replacing the first-order differential equations with difference equations.
The simulation confirmation of the 2D BK model indicates that both peak static stress conditions and static stress conditions after the peak can lead to the occurrence of earthquakes.
The failure mechanism is qualitatively the same as in the one-dimensional case, although there are differences in quantitative terms.
This paper is part of a broader initiative aimed at developing comprehensive targeted seismic mechanics models to better understand seismic dynamics and conduct reliable earthquake predictions.
On December 29, 2003, the Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) on the Swift satellite detected the gamma-ray burst (GRB) 030329.
A month after the event occurred, the X-shooter spectrograph on the VLT detected optical/near-infrared (OIR) afterglow.
Using data from X-shooter and other telescopes, we conducted a detailed study of the afterglow of this deep non-relativistic phase.
From the X-ray observation spectrum, we obtained an upper limit for the redshift of z = 0.5.

Game theory has been applied to dynamic spectrum sharing modeling in wireless networks. However, most existing research either assumes that the QoS requirements for delays and losses are satisfied simultaneously or relies on dynamic programming to solve the inherently complex resource management optimization problems.

In this article, we consider the problem of joint energy-efficient modulation and spectrum sharing under delay and packet loss quality of service (QoS) constraints in the downlink of a cellular network.

Specifically, we formulate the problem of efficient spectrum and energy modulation as a classical Markov decision process (MDP), and propose a deep learning-based solution, specifically using deep Q-learning to address the complex nonlinear characteristics of the proposed problem.
Compared to existing work, our main contributions are summarized as follows:
We established a connection between CDMA network optimization and deep Q-learning, which greatly reduced the search space for efficient spectrum and energy allocation.
Unlike the conservative heuristic methods used in existing work, we leverage the learning capability of deep Q-learning to find efficient solutions.
The number "3" in Chinese is "三" (pronounced as sān).
We considered the delays in downlink data transmission and the packet loss quality of service (QoS) constraints in the network, which have not been well addressed in existing research.

Our simulation results indicate that, compared to existing heuristic methods, our deep learning-based approach can achieve significant energy savings while meeting latency and quality of service (QoS) constraints.
This work was initially submitted to arXiv on October 18, 2019, and was updated on January 10, 2020.
For multi-tiered planetary systems, the tides generated by distant planets can reduce their orbital semimajor axes, potentially leading to type II catastrophic mergers.
In systems with smaller mass exoplanets, strong tidal forces from distant worlds may also reduce their orbital semi-major axes, but they will simultaneously suppress orbital motion.

We demonstrate here that if the innermost planet has a strong non-zero eccentricity, the tidal forces acting on the planet can cause eccentricity oscillations, leading the eccentricity to exceed the dynamically defined upper limit and shrink the orbit.
We conduct N-body simulations to verify this analytical theory and demonstrate the effectiveness of this mechanism in shrinking the non-resonant planetary orbits in multi-planet systems.
We indicate that this process is sufficiently efficient to explain the proximity of Earth and Mars to the Sun, and may also contribute to the capture of asteroids by Earth and Venus.
The long-term behavior of hierarchical multi-planet systems is primarily determined by the orbits and rotation directions of the planets.

If the rotation of a planet is not aligned with its orbital plane, the system may enter a Cassini state, at which point the planet's forced eccentricity will decrease, but their orbital angular momentum will still remain coupled.

If, on the contrary, the rotation axis of the planet is initially coplanar with its orbital plane, it can enter a Kozai state, in which the forced eccentricity oscillates with a period corresponding to the full eccentricity-lifted node precession cycle.
During this period, the semi-major axis of the planet can be reduced enough to cause Type II or Type I migration, depending on the characteristics of the neighboring planets.

We demonstrate that even adding just one test particle moving along the long axis significantly increases the proportion of Kozai cycles completed before the alignment at the ascending and descending nodes.

Planetary systems that enter the Kozai state and subsequently experience type II or type I migration may exhibit changes in their semi-major axes that are greater than those observed in the solar system.

Here we show that if one or more planets in this system have a sufficient non-zero eccentricity, the Kozai cycles can drive the eccentricity to exceed the dynamically defined upper limit, potentially causing a collision within the system.

We conducted N-body simulations to validate this analytical theory and demonstrated that this process is efficient enough to explain the close relationship between Earth and Mars with the Sun in the solar system.

We also demonstrated that if planets are placed in highly eccentric orbits, the process of capturing asteroids into Earth and Venus would be more feasible, and this mechanism may have an impact on the observational quality of Earth and Venus.

This work was completed in the context of the NExT (Numerical Experiment on Earth-like Planet Formation) project, which focuses on experiments related to planet formation and dynamics. It is supported by the International Center for Radio Astronomy Research, the University of Western Australia, the University of Tokyo, and the RIKEN Institute in Japan, and is funded by the Australian Research Council.

clean_wm_text: In this article, we present research findings on the occurrence of disorder transitions and peak effects in polydisperse systems.

The disorderly transition occurs when a solid mixture changes from a solid state to a liquid state. The peak effect, on the other hand, is a phenomenon that appears when the volume fraction of the solid mixture at the peak of the density distribution is greater than the average volume fraction of the mixture.
These phenomena have been observed in a wide range of material systems, including glass-forming liquids, particulate materials, and non-homogeneous mixtures.
In this article, we demonstrate that by altering the variance of the particle size distribution, we can modulate the frequency and peak effects of the disordered phase transition.
We conduct event-driven molecular dynamics simulations to model binary mixtures composed of particles that are the same size but have different variances.
By using the radial distribution function, we can demonstrate that for systems with a large variance, the phase transition and peak effect occur at lower volume fractions.

In addition, we observed an increase in the frequency of the transition to disorder and the peak effect as the variance of the particle size distribution increased, and we identified an approximate scale relationship between the two.

We provide a theoretical argument regarding this scaling relationship based on the average inter-particle forces, and we compare our results with previous studies that have explored similar relationships.
We are also discussing the broader implications of these results in the context of the latest theories regarding the origins of disorder in condensed matter systems.
Cosmic rays interact with gases, producing a series of chemical products.
In this work, we demonstrate that this process also changes the elemental composition of the gas.

We applied the model to the gas observed in the current universe, and it shows that although the enhancement of element X is generally much lower than that in high-redshift systems, it is still able to reproduce the overall trend.
Finally, we demonstrate that enhanced evolution largely depends on the shape of the low-energy cosmic ray spectrum.

We apply our model to a wide range of spectra and demonstrate that different spectra lead to enhancements of element X reaching levels of $10^{-3} - 1$ solar values at $z = 0$ with a metallicity of $10^{-4}$ solar values.
The potential range of this enhancement is broad, highlighting the importance of experimental research on the early evolution of the universe.
We described an effect where the interaction between cosmic rays and primordial gas affects the phase of the gas and the abundances of elements.
This has important implications for the potential of gas to form structures and the evolution of heavy element abundance over time.

We applied our model to the gas observed in the current universe and showed that, although the overall trend of X element enhancement is lower than that of high-redshift systems, it is still sufficient to reproduce the general trend.
We also show that the enhanced evolution largely depends on the shape of the low-energy cosmic ray spectrum.

Our work emphasizes the importance of experimental research on the early evolution of the universe, as well as the necessity for a better understanding of low-energy processes, such as the interactions between cosmic rays and gas in the early universe.

We provide a formalism for calculating the evolution of chemical abundances, including the enhancement of elemental abundances, based on a given ionization and chemical network, as well as a specified cosmic ray spectrum.
The calculation results are self-consistent because they can be fed back into the ionization and chemical networks.

The new network must use terminology to specify the twelve basic reactions required to generate sixteen molecules containing enhanced elements, and fully cover an additional eleven elements (B, C, N, O, Na, Mg, Al, Si, P, S, Cl, K, Ca, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu, Zn, Sr, Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ta, W, Re, Ru, Os, Hg, Tl, Pb, Bi, and Po).

The updated chemical composition will have a significant impact on the cooling/heating rates of the gas, the formation of interstellar matter, as well as the gravitational collapse of the gas and further enrichment.

The effects described in this work are not limited to the era of reionization, but extend to any time in the history of the gas, until the gas is removed from the simulation by some feedback mechanism.
