In this paper, we report the phenomenon of multiple captured Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) forming vortices through merging and interference.
We have prepared a dual BEC composed of seven different ultra-fine state atomic bosons, and successfully observed the merging and interference of two independent vortices.
The merging process of the two vortices is clearly manifested as a dark-bright pair, ultimately resulting in a single vortex with a distinct phase singularity.
We also observed the phase singularity of a single vortex under rotating oscillation and noted that the decay of this phase singularity is influenced by the interaction between the two vortices.
Our results indicate that by merging and interfering multiple independently prepared vortices, it is potentially possible to generate highly non-trivial and novel quantum many-body states.
This study was published on June 6, 2019, in Nature Physics, led by Dr. Dmitry Petrov from the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology.
According to the MUNICS dataset, a massive filamentous structure has been reported, extending over 120 Mpc (240 x 10^8 Mpc) in the northwest direction, with a redshift of 0.55.
The structure is a very good candidate for a large-scale filament, with a total mass of approximately 4.5 × 10^9 M⊙, equivalent to 2000 to 3000 galaxy clusters.

In this structure, several arcs and lenses can be seen, which appear to be very similar to some of the large structures found in deep field images from the Hubble Space Telescope in this region with low redshift.

The spectral analysis of 17 galaxies discovered in this field shows that 6 of them are strongly concentrated near the peaks of the filaments. It was found that over 50% of the galaxies have undergone recent intense star formation events (with a star formation rate of about 200 M⊙/yr).
"This is much higher than the star formation rates found in similar redshift structures, indicating that this filamentary structure is actively forming stars along with galaxies."
Based on this point and other recent findings, we suggest that the formation of large-scale structures at redshift z > 1.5 is triggered by galaxy formation within forming halos.
The aggregation of galaxies in high-redshift filaments is much higher than that of galaxies in the fields, which may be an additional characteristic of the formation of filamentary structures.
The genetic network describes the relationships between genes and the phenotypic effects produced by interference with gene expression.
Inferring these networks from expression data is challenging due to their high dimensionality, statistical noise, and regulatory complexity.
We use a novel algorithm to identify network modules and their regulatory factors from expression data.

The algorithm assumes that genes within the same module are co-regulated, and that the regulatory factors of the module mainly influence its expression through a small number of key regulatory factors.

According to this assumption, the algorithm first estimates the regulatory factors for each network module, and then infers the network structure by optimizing the balance between the number of links in the network and the sum of squared errors.
This algorithm can not only identify meaningful sub-networks but also discover key regulatory factors to explain expression patterns within the modules.

We applied this algorithm to a simulated dataset as well as three expression datasets of Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis, identifying network modules that represent known biological pathways and new pathways.
We also validate the predicted links by comparing them with carefully planned networks.
We have provided a code to implement this method.

Here is an example of the abstract of a paper published by this author: Inferring Dynamic Genetic Networks with Low-Order Independence. In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in understanding the gene regulatory networks that control cellular behaviors such as differentiation and development.
Inferring these networks from gene expression data is challenging, primarily due to high dimensionality, statistical noise, and combinatorial complexity.
Here we use a novel algorithm to identify network modules and their regulatory factors from expression data.

The algorithm assumes that genes within the same module are co-regulated, and that the regulatory factors of the module mainly influence its expression through a small number of key regulatory factors.

According to this hypothesis, the algorithm first estimates the modulation factor of each network module, and then infers the network structure by optimizing the balance between the number of links in the network and the total sum of squared errors.
We demonstrated the effectiveness of the method using simulated data as well as expression data from Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis.
"We also validate the predicted connections by comparing them with the planned network."
In the standard fireball model of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), the afterglow radiation is believed to be primarily driven by the shockwave that moves through the medium surrounding the burst.
In this paper, we point out that the circumstellar winds (CSW) surrounding stars from GRB progenitors can also form wind morphology circles (CM).
The speed of some parts inside the CSW reaches hundreds of kilometers per second, which is far higher than the speed of the Compton scattering shell of the light core.
Therefore, the wind will wrap the shell, forming a cocoon-like dense structure, and the material that is wrapped up will cool at the shock front, resulting in observable X-ray afterglow.
We demonstrated that this mechanism could explain the prolonged X-ray emission observed in some afterglows.
The model can also explain the optical/infrared afterglows of certain GRBs for some specific parameters of CSW and GRB, and it can naturally produce shallow decay phases in certain X-ray afterglows.
We conclude that the X-rays and optical/infrared afterglow of certain Gamma-ray bursts may be related to the wind-shaped circumstellar material (CSM).

Using data from peak luminosity and rise time measurements of 185 Type Ia supernovae, we conducted a systematic analysis of the diversity of these supernovae in terms of decay rate corrected rise time (settling time).
We indicate that a physical model with a single rise time distribution cannot describe these data.

A two-component decay model is given priority because in this model, a small fraction (about 15%) of supernovae exhibit fast rise times (rise time < 15 days), while the majority (about 85%) have rise times ranging from 15 to 40 days, achieving a significance of 4.3 standard deviations compared to a single component model.

Supernovae with a rapid rise time have a more negative peak brightness, a slower decay rate, and a longer rise time compared to supernovae with a normal rise time. This indicates that supernovae with a rapid rise time represent an intrinsically different subset of supernovae.
These results indicate that the physical properties of Type Ia supernovae begin to change early in their explosion phase.
This paper describes the results of searching for reactor antineutrinos using an exposure of 21.7 cm³·year at the Double Chooz nuclear reactor.

We study the spectral shape distortion of the electron antineutrino spectra produced by a point-like nuclear reactor through mixing with at least one type of sterile neutrino that is mixed with three active neutrinos.

We conduct a precise profile-based analysis using six measurements from the near and far detectors of the Double Chooz experiment, along with three parameters that describe three active-passive neutrino oscillation scenarios.
We did not find evidence for sterile neutrinos and set an upper limit on the mixing parameter Ω_sterile at 0.29 with 95% confidence level.
This is the first search for a massless neutrino conducted with an exposure of 21.7 cm³·years at the Double Chooz nuclear reactor.
We also conducted a global sensitivity study that includes previous reactor antineutrino experiments.

The motion and properties of particles play a central role in many important engineering and industrial processes.
A particularly important process is the fluidization of granular materials, which has wide applications in mining, metallurgy, chemical engineering, and the food industry.

However, the particle flux through the lower surface did not show this inverse relationship; instead, it increased with increasing depth.

These results indicate that the fluidized particle layer exhibits a depth-dependent three-layer structure, with the top surface being a shallow layer, the middle layer fluidizing according to the Beverloo law, and the bottom surface remaining completely non-fluidized.
This three-layer structure is similar to the sandpile dynamics observed in self-organized critical systems, except that the bottom surface has not been consumed.

The oldest known star in the universe is a blue-shifted star (BS star).

These stars are believed to have formed from the material in their parent galaxy after it had fully expanded and cooled, allowing for the main sequence lifetime of the stars that make up their composition to be sustained.
These BS stars are therefore iron-core stars, burning helium-3, and have converted nearly all of the primordial hydrogen and helium into helium-3.
However, the most unusual characteristic of these stars is that they are (clearly) extremely massive, with a mass exceeding that of 90% of similar stars in the local universe.

This has long been a mystery because current standard theories of star formation predict that such high-mass stars are relatively rare, and simulation results rarely produce more than 5-10% of massive stars.
Recently, observations from the Hubble Space Telescope and the 2.3-meter telescope at the Australian National University have revealed a potential solution that could overturn this paradox.
Using data from the Keck telescope, we observed nine blue superluminous stars out of three ultra-lithium deficient stars, all of which showed strong Be absorption in their spectra.
This type of absorption does not exist in the equivalent measurements of normal celestial bodies, and it is extremely difficult to produce in any theoretical model.

Although the abundance of Be must be very close to the half-life value in order to see absorption, it has been suggested that the standard cooling process cannot produce the observed amount of Be, and the late-stage accreted s-process material is also ruled out.
The observations presented here suggest a novel solution.
It has been suggested that many hot Jupiter stars may have formed through accretion events, with companion stars providing the material.

As the most common element, beryllium (Be) is particularly good at absorbing optical radiation from cooling low-mass companion stars. Therefore, its detection in the spectra of BS stars may be a characteristic of the formation process of these stars.
We suggest that these proliferation events are also likely to be highly contaminated by light elements such as lithium.
This discovery has profound implications for our understanding of star formation and binary star evolution models.

If a large amount of lithium can be synthesized in a binary star system, then these systems may represent an important nucleosynthesis site in the early universe and may provide a missing link between populations of very low-mass and very high-mass stars in early galaxies.
In this article, we argue that the finite process algebra method has profound limitations in its application areas—primarily quantum mechanics.

We recommend a fundamental revision of this method, namely, instead of using a finite process to approximate physical quantities, we should treat physical quantities as variables governed by a higher-order differential equation.

The method has a probabilistic interpretation, as the solutions of the corresponding stochastic partial differential equations, at least in special cases, reproduce the predictions of quantum mechanics.
We will apply the corrections to the field of quantum cosmology and propose a quantum mechanics model of the universe.
We indicate that, according to quantum cosmology, the early universe underwent a period of cosmic inflation.
We speculate on the possibility of testing the model against observation data.

The modern cellular signaling network performs important functions in cells by transmitting and responding to external and internal stimuli.
Proteins that interact with each other have signaling functions; they are densely connected to form a complex signaling network.
The signal network transmits and processes information through the combination of multiple signal pathways.
Proteins, as signaling entities, alter their conformation through covalent modifications such as phosphorylation, thereby transmitting information.
This paper proposes a method for reconstructing signaling networks from proteomic data.

This is a challenging problem due to the high dimensionality and complexity of the underlying signal networks, the high sensitivity of signal processes to variations in network topology and parameters, and the often required large numbers of cells and proteins to obtain statistically significant data.
The proposed method combines protein interaction networks with a new approach for sparse representation of signal networks to reconstruct the signal network.
The signal networks are sparsely presented in the interacting protein networks.
By using interacting protein networks, we are able to reconstruct signaling pathways while significantly reducing the potential thousands of interactions to a more manageable few.
This enables us to study signal networks from a statistical perspective and apply rigorous methods for network inference to reconstruct the network.
The signal networks were tested on multiple simulated datasets, and the results indicate that they can accurately infer the signal networks.
We also applied this method to the MAPK signaling pathway in yeast, reconstructing the signaling network using data from only five yeast strains.
This enables us to study the effects of genetic variations on signaling processes.

Finally, the signal networks demonstrated strong predictive capabilities across four types of mammals, with the mouse signal network exhibiting a particularly strong predictive ability for the human signal network.
We present the results of searching for diffuse optical light in a sample of 71 low redshift ($z < 0.2$) galaxy clusters and groups.

We used a gravitational wave long-duration telescope array (GRAvaroo) consisting of five small optical telescopes to conduct deep imaging in an area of 1.7 square degrees around the southern celestial pole.

Through careful application of various data quality filters, we have identified three candidate systems that exhibit coherent, faint, linear streams of stars consistent with the streamlined structure of the disrupted satellite galaxy.

Among these three candidates, the brightest one has a heliocentric retrograde velocity of 14,200 kilometers per second, which is consistent with the characteristics of other confirmed satellites of the Milky Way that exhibit lower heliocentric velocities, supporting its identification as a dark matter-dominated stream.

The heliocentric retrograde speeds of the other two candidates are 24,300 km/s and 32,300 km/s, respectively. The contamination from satellite systems is very low, and they can reasonably be associated with the identified clustering events in the fossil record, indicating that the physical properties of these streams are similar to those of previously observed cosmic streams.

If confirmed, these systems will represent the low-redshift galaxies that contain stellar streams formed by the disruption of satellite galaxies and will serve as records of some of the largest accretion events in the local universe.

These results suggest that broad, faint linear features may be a universal characteristic of low-redshift galaxy clusters and groups, indicating that even in the absence of a massive central galaxy, these systems might represent an important component of the overall cosmic flow of populations.
Galaxy clusters provide critical astrophysical constraints across a wide range of wavelengths, from radio waves to X-rays.
Despite achieving such success, the process of cluster assembly and its quality remains a core issue in modern astrophysics.

The analytical theory of cluster assembly (e.g., @rs82) has long been replaced by fluid dynamics cosmological simulations (e.g., @nm04 [@ds08]), which successfully reproduce key observables such as the cluster luminosity function and temperature function.

However, the maximum mass clusters predicted by these simulations appear to be somewhat insufficient compared to the number of clusters observed in the real universe (see @k07 [@l06]; also refer to the review in @s07).
The "cosmic discord problem" has sparked numerous explanations, including environmental filtering (@w84 [@k84]), self-destruction (@gm02), and giant group ancestors (@mm01).
However, although these astrophysical theories have been successful in explaining the total mass of star clusters, they do not address the question of how individual clusters acquire their mass.
Recently, we have found that the mass function of globular clusters in nearby galaxies may be directly related to the accumulated starlight around the clusters.

Unlike previous explanations, which suggested that cluster mass is gradually acquired over time through mergers or environmental processes, we have demonstrated that if most massive clusters form through the early dissolution of lower-mass systems, there should be a negative correlation between cluster mass and cluster luminosity.
Indeed, we found that this data is consistent with the disintegration scenario, which shows that in the universe, large galaxy clusters are relatively rare and more prone to disintegration.
However, our results are based on a smaller statistical sample.
Here we report a larger compilation of 22 star clusters, for which we have conducted a uniform kinematic analysis, providing strong evidence of stellar evaporation in 10 of these clusters.

We estimate that stellar evaporation is a reliable explanation for the dissolution of these star clusters, and it naturally explains the mass-luminosity relationship without the need for any additional dynamical processes.

Therefore, we suggest that stellar evaporation may represent a new mechanism for regulating cluster mass, which has the potential to significantly impact the total mass of clusters in cosmological simulations.

I proposed a complete solution regarding the quantum dynamics of the volume operator in loop quantum gravity.
This operator provides a natural "size" for the universe, but it has not yet been fully addressed using quantum methods.
The translation of "直到现在" into English is "Until now."
Using the techniques from full LQG analysis, I conducted a detailed operator analysis of the volume operator and demonstrated that it has a well-defined, discrete spectrum.
I continued to solve the complete quantum dynamics, proving that the spectrum is stable under small perturbations, indicating that this volume has a clear classical limit.

This solves the long-standing problem of quantizing the "size" of the universe in quantum gravity, and opens the door to the study of quantum dynamics of other operators with well-defined classical limits (such as Ashtekar variables).

The Millennium Simulation is a large-scale cosmological simulation conducted by the Virgo Consortium from 2000 to 2005.
One of its outputs is a galaxy cluster catalog that was publicly released in 2008.
I identified 21 red sequences in this catalog using a technique that matches the colors of galaxies in the cluster with the positions of the heaviest members in the cluster.
The dispersion of the red sequence is 0.17 or so, which is much lower than previous findings, and it is statistically significant only in the densest regions of the star cluster.

I also indicated that the observed spread is consistent with the observed color-absolute magnitude relation of member galaxies, which suggests that galaxy evolution may be the cause of this phenomenon.

The color-luminosity relationship has also been reflected in other observational samples, so this may be a more generally applicable explanation that can account for the scatter observed in the red sequence.

In the past few years, gravitational waves (GWs) have been successfully detected and their detailed properties have been inferred through various detector configurations.
The recent events are consistent with the system's estimated chirp mass frequency, thereby determining the accurate sky position of the source.
No existing observatories have detected electromagnetic (EM) counterparts, leading to the speculation that this compact object was formed by the merger of a white dwarf.
Although neutron star (NS) - neutron star mergers describe the observed signals very well, weak observational evidence suggests that this event could possibly be a collision of double white dwarfs.
In this case, the estimated parameters for merging compact objects are quite different.

Although the physics of double white dwarf collisions is quite credible, uncertainties in astrophysics and the observational process result in about a 30% probability of misattributing the same signal to neutron star mergers, which leads to ambiguous characteristics of the sources and incomplete observations of the gravitational wave universe.

In the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM), the vacuum expectation value (vev) of the Higgs doublet that triggers electroweak symmetry breaking results in a neutral Higgs boson having a minimum potential that is zero at tree level.
This minimum value causes a naturalness problem because the quadratic divergence corrections to the neutral Higgs mass squared parameter from standard model particles are unacceptably large.
To solve this problem, a superpartner particle with a supersymmetric (SUSY) spectrum is needed, with energy within a reachable range.
A minimal supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM) includes two additional Higgs bosons, namely the Higgsino and the heavy scalar, which appear in the supersymmetry breaking mass matrices.
These are the supersymmetric partners of the gold particles, the supersymmetric partners of the photon and the Z boson.

By appropriately adjusting the parameters in the supersymmetry-breaking mass matrix, these heavy scalars can be tuned to be relatively light, reaching the scale of supersymmetry breaking while maintaining electroweak symmetry breaking.

We conducted a phenomenological study of this potential correction to the alignment and demonstrated that it lowers the mass of these scalars to below 1 TeV, with some points in the MSSM parameter space having masses as low as 400 GeV.
The lightest of these new particles is a good candidate for dark matter.

We also studied the collider phenomenology of the model and demonstrated that this light Higgs component will be detected at the upcoming hadron colliders, namely the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the future circular collider, as well as the Folding@home distributed processing cluster.
We study the phenomenology of the minimal supersymmetric standard model with heavy scalar particles (MSSM-HS) using tree-level approximation.
These new particles appear in the supersymmetry breaking mass matrix, corresponding to the supersymmetric partners of the gluons, photons, and Z bosons.
We conducted a phenomenological study on potential corrections to the alignment, which allowed us to lower the masses of these particles to below 1 TeV in part of the MSSM parameter space.
We also studied the collider phenomenology of the model and demonstrated that this light Higgs component can be tested at the upcoming hadron collider.
Here, we study the following points: 1. We briefly introduce the MSSM-HS model and discuss the symmetry principles that must be satisfied by the supersymmetric partners.
We described the spectrum in the model.
Specifically, we discuss the Goldstino, which is the supersymmetric partner of the photon (photino), and the zino, which is the supersymmetric partner of the Z boson.
Use a mixture of two competing random number generators (RRG) to produce a large number of pseudo-random binary sequences with arbitrary periods.
A variable called the Partial Filling Factor (PFF) has recently been introduced to quantify the statistical distribution of these generated sequences.
PFF can be interpreted as a particularly fast metric used to evaluate whether a sequence contains a large number of zeros.
This makes it very suitable for identifying rare events in large amounts of data.
In this study, PFF was used to characterize the statistical properties of so-called rare event sequences, which are binary sequences generated with particularly few zeros.

These situations may occur, for example, in cryptography, if random keys are used to encrypt long messages, the repetition of zeros in the keys may lead to the termination of the encryption algorithm.
Research indicates that the generated PFF fluctuations follow a zero-range process, with the magnitude of fluctuations exhibiting a power-law tail distribution.
This corresponds to the strong spatial heterogeneity of low zero sequences and supports the mechanism in which these sequences grow from a small number of deterministic seeds.
For certain mixtures, it has been found that rare event sequences occur with a non-vanishing frequency, which makes them of interest in cryptography.

A new generation of spectrometer calibration technology based on optical frequency combs (OFCs) was introduced.
Optical frequency combs (OFCs) are highly coherent light sources that can be generated in various nonlinear optical cavities.
By measuring the frequency of light reflected from the target object, the optical frequency comb (OFC) achieves nanometer-level resolution and precise spectral measurements.
This article describes a calibration technology for spectral analyzers based on fiber Bragg gratings.
It consists of three key modules: a wavelength meter based on a Michelson interferometer, a tunable fiber laser, and a spectrometer.
OFC is used to measure the target spectrum with high precision.
Unlike the typical spectrometer calibration conducted with a commercial wavelength meter, the wavelength of the optical frequency comb (OFC) is measured directly rather than derived.
Therefore, this technology has the same resolution, but is more accurate and practical in many important applications such as optical communication, ranging, and sensing.
The block diagram of the calibration technology based on optical fiber communication (OFC) is presented.
This technology will measure the central wavelength, bandwidth, and intensity of the target spectrum with high precision.
This makes it suitable for many important applications, such as wavelength meters in optical communication networks, high-resolution spectral sensing, and monitoring of laser frequency and stability.

The experimental results indicate that this technique based on optical frequency combs (OFC) can measure the center wavelength and bandwidth, with related errors of less than 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively.
The resolution of the intensity measurement is 0.2% FSWM (Full Width at Half Maximum).

This fiber optic communication (OFC) technology has advantages such as a simple optical architecture, high precision, and ease of integration with spectrometers, making it very useful in many important applications.
A pulsar moving through the galaxy at a known speed [kilometers per second] is emitting a rapidly moving pulsar wind.
Due to momentum conservation, some of the fast-moving pulsar wind material may decelerate and accumulate to form a pulsar wind nebula (PWN).
Recent observations of the HESS J1809-193 gamma-ray source have discovered a coincident X-ray Pulsar Wind Nebula (PWN), which was detected by the High Energy Stereoscopic System (H.E.S.S.).
We propose a possible association between PWN and HESS J1809-193.
If this is the case, it could be the first PWN case discovered through gamma-ray observations.
We will also compare the expected spatial overlap of PWN and HESS J1809-193 with the existing spatial simulations of the diffusion of charged particles from the pulsars in that system.
The LANS-alpha model is a common dimensionality reduction technique used to simulate flow at high Reynolds numbers.
A reduced-order model was constructed by projecting high-dimensional flow variables onto a low-dimensional subspace formed by the solution set of certain differential equations.
This method works best when the solution of the reduced-order model is very turbulent.
In this article, we present the LANS-alpha model and its corresponding high turbulence solution in large eddy simulation (LES).
The results show the flow around the cylinder at a fixed angle of inclination.
The solution is calculated using spectral methods, which discretize the LANS-alpha and LES models on a non-uniform grid in spectral space.
The discrete LANS-alpha and LES models are solved using an asynchronous multi-core parallel solver.
These simulations were conducted under a range of CFL numbers to obtain the most turbulent solution for each CFL number.
The solution of high turbulence is projected into a reduced-order form using the gradient projection method.
The results were compared with high-resolution simulations, and good consistency in flow statistics was observed.
We present the first high-resolution images of the HD 100546 system taken with the High Contrast Space Telescope (HST) in Thermal Dispersive Spectroscopy (TDS) mode.
We combined the observational images from the previous continuum spectrum and strong spectral lines, modeling the system as a circumstellar disk around a bright Herbig Ae/Be star.
The inner edge of this disk is sharp, outlining the boundary of the empty subregion cleared by the planet, with an open angle of 3.4°.

We estimate that the particle size of the disk's surface is between 1 micron and 3 microns, the temperature ranges from 23 Kelvin to 25 Kelvin, and the stellar illumination intensity is between 6.7% and 8.4% of the interstellar value.

This is the first high-precision measurement of the physical characteristics of the disk around the Herbig Ae/Be stars, and these observations further demonstrate the powerful capability of TDS in characterizing exoplanetary systems.
Binary star systems provide a unique opportunity to study planetary systems in a more compact configuration than around single stars.
A key challenge in detecting planets around double star systems is their close proximity to the host stars, which increases the technical requirements for planet detection and characterization.

This paper summarizes the observational techniques for detecting planets in binary star systems, with a particular focus on methods that have the potential to be applied to planetary systems around binary stars.
After the introduction to binary star systems, different planet detection methods and their sensitivity to various system parameters are described.
In each method, examples of recent planetary exploration surveys are presented.

A preliminary analysis of the characteristics of known circumbinary planets has been conducted, and suggestions for future investigations have been made in order to extend this analysis to a larger sample.
With the development and verification of new planet detection technologies, these methods should also be tested on binary star planetary systems.
At the center of the galaxy, Sgr A* is a supermassive black hole (SMBH) located at the center of a galaxy cluster containing thousands of galaxies.
High-speed stars (with speeds reaching hundreds of kilometers per second) are escaping from the center of the galaxy due to unknown mechanisms and moving outward along parabolic orbits.
We found that in some of these hypervelocity stars, their trajectories are perpendicular to the jets of Sagittarius A*.
This discovery suggests that there may be a high-density and relatively young population of stars, less than 1 million years old, in the region beyond 0.01 parsecs from Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*).
This young star cluster may have formed through tidal disturbances caused by Sagittarius A* on the stars, or through collisions between stars within a supermassive black hole star cluster.

Our results indicate that the interstellar environment around Sagittarius A* is less relaxed than we previously thought, providing an effective setting for stellar capture and collisions, leading to the formation of black hole binaries.
The authors are Fang Tao Tao, Bao Xue Ning, and Cheng Lin, from the Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences.
This article is "Ultra-High-Speed Stars and the Environment of Sagittarius A*" (arXiv.org 1811.09776v1).
This paper explains how Einstein's general relativity is derived from first principles without relying on the axiom of choice.
It is well known that in most formulations of general relativity, the use of the Axiom of Choice is a relatively complex philosophical assumption.

By first presenting the fundamental equations of general relativity, we will demonstrate the equivalence of inertial mass and gravitational mass, as well as that the Poisson equation is two formulas that do not use the axiom of choice.

We will use these two principles to derive Newton's law of universal gravitation, and then demonstrate how to derive Einstein's general relativity equations using Riemannian geometry and the pseudo-Riemannian geometry from Einstein's gravitational theory in 1921.

Finally, we will explain why the 1977 edition of Stephen Hawking's general relativity textbook contains a mistake that led him to conclude that the theory requires the selection of axioms in order to be derived.
We will demonstrate that this error is based on the imperfect (implicit) Euler-Lagrange equation of using theory, rather than the perfect (explicit) Lagrange equation.
Using the perfect Lagrangian, we can conclude that the axiom of choice is not necessary.
We study the global polarization of quark-gluon plasma (QGP) in high-energy non-central heavy-ion collisions using perturbative quantum chromodynamics (PQCD).

Under the infinite top quark mass limit, the gluon distribution function in a longitudinally polarized hadron gas has been calculated using Witten's self-dual method, achieving a degree of one circle.

Induced gluon polarization has been shown to be uniform in the longitudinally polarized quark-gluon plasma, and it can survive even after scattering at quark spin anti-parallel to the gluon distribution function.
Induced polarization is long-range and has been shown to lead to global polarization of quark-gluon plasma (QGP) in high-energy non-central heavy-ion collisions.

In a smooth closed manifold, a special foliated leaf is called Morse if all of its leaves do not have singularities.
The smooth Morse flow and the stable ergodic Reeb flow appear as the transversal structure of the symplectic structure on the tangent bundle of certain closed manifolds.
We study the stable ergodicity in Reeb flows.

By performing spectral decomposition on the differentials of the basic Reeb flow, we show that stable ergodicity depends on the symplectic structure, and that it is unstable when the symplectic structure exhibits certain specific patterns.
We constructed some specific examples of smooth Morse structures with non-stable ergodic Reeb flows.
This article is a supplement to my previous article [1], where the same results have been established for a larger class of levels.
Yang Hamin, Volker Demuth, Wang Zhe, "A Morse Singularity with Non-Morse Stable Ergodicity," https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.05817

We conducted a detailed chemical and dynamical analysis of protostellar clusters in five regions formed by medium-mass stars, including sources I18198, I22134, I22134A, I22135, and I22134B. By combining data from methanol (CH3OH) and deuterated organic molecules (dcoms), along with dynamics observed from carbon monoxide (CO), we were able to determine the luminosity, gas mass, disk mass, and binding energy of the protostars and their associated Class 0/I outflows.
We found that the mass distribution of the original protoplanetary disk is similar to that observed in low-mass systems, with an average value of 0.015 M⊙.

These four younger sources (I18198, I22134, I22134A, and I22135) are still embedded in the original star cluster, and their binding energy is an order of magnitude greater than the energy measured for more evolved intermediate-mass protostars, such as IRAS 16293-2422.
In contrast, the older source I22134B has already separated from its original star cluster, and its binding energy is consistent with that measured for more developed systems.

We suggest that the evolution of the energy bound to the protostar is not driven by the energy effects of jets, as previously proposed, but is closely related to the evolution of its parent molecular cloud.

"The stimulus and noise distribution used for optimal information transmission is derived through super-threshold stochastic resonance (SR) and illustrated with examples, applicable to a typical nonlinear SR system—the diffusively coupled FitzHugh-Nagumo model."
The optimal information transmission is achieved when the information carried by the signal is white noise, that is, when its mean is zero, which applies to the entire range of coupling constants.
The optimal noise has a non-zero mean, and its variance disappears when the signal amplitude exceeds a certain critical value.
The results obtained provide clear design guidelines for maximizing the communication capacity of nonlinear dynamical systems through appropriate signal modulation.

Introduction  
For a long time, an important paradigm of information transmission in nonlinear dynamic systems is stochastic resonance (SR), in which a weak random signal is self-amplified, and the signal fluctuations induced by noise exceed the average amplitude level of the signal. Over the past three decades, this counterintuitive phenomenon has been verified experimentally and aligns with theories from various nonlinear systems, including both experimental and theoretical studies. Recent research has focused on information transmission through superthreshold stochastic resonance, where the signal exceeds a certain threshold level.

The optimal signal structure for superthreshold stochastic resonance has been shown to be white noise, meaning it has a mean of zero. Here, we derive the optimal stimulus and noise distribution for information transmission through superthreshold stochastic resonance.

We focus on the classic diffusively coupled FitzHugh-Nagumo (FHN) model, where the signal represents the spiking activity of the neuron model, and the noise represents background synaptic and neuronal noise.
Compared to previous studies, the optimal information-carrying signal is not white noise, but a signal with a non-zero mean.

Additionally, the optimal noise approaches zero variance when the signal amplitude exceeds a critical value, and optimal information transmission performance can be achieved across the entire range of coupling constants.
The results obtained provide clear design guidance for maximizing the communication capacity of nonlinear dynamic systems through appropriate signal modulation.

Materials and Methods: We investigate information transmission through suprathreshold stochastic resonance (SR) in a typical diffusively coupled FitzHugh-Nagumo (FHN) model, which describes the dynamics of neuron membrane voltage with FitzHugh-Nagumo dynamics and couples two linearly independent Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) processes.
The Langevin equation of the model is as follows, where {S_t} is the amplitude of the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, {ν_t} is the Gaussian white noise term, and ε is the coupling strength.
The model exhibits bistability, meaning it has two stable steady states, {S*±} = {−1, 1}, which correspond to the membrane potentials of the up state and the down state.
The stable phase is separated.
Using precise radial velocity measurements, evidence for a planetary companion around a nearby young star has been found.

This planet is designated as GJ 625 b, with a minimum mass of 7.5 Earth masses, about 2.7 times the mass of Earth. It orbits its host star at a distance of approximately 0.815 AU, which is less than one percent of the distance between the Earth and the Sun.
The distance of such an orbit suggests that GJ 625 b may have a surface temperature low enough for ice to be a stable form of carbon and water.
The relatively high eccentricity (0.29) of the planet's orbit is also quite fascinating, which may suggest the presence of additional undiscovered planets in the system.
GJ 625 b is the first planet discovered orbiting a star with a mass smaller than that of the Sun, and it is also the second known planet outside of our solar system (after Earth).
In order to determine the characteristics of GJ 625 b and the features of the system it orbits, more observations need to be conducted.
For example, it is suggested to conduct direct imaging surveys of the system to search for more planets.
Such follow-up observations can be conducted using instruments currently on ground-based telescopes, or using future "Large Ultraviolet/Optical Telescopes" and the "James Webb Space Telescope."
We present a set of X-ray observations of 23 normal galaxies from the Great Observatory Origins Deep Survey (GOODS).
These X-ray observations were obtained from the Chandra X-ray Observatory over a period of approximately 12 years, from 2003 to 2014.
We perform X-ray spectral fitting on the obtained dataset and calculate the X-ray luminosity functions (XLFs) for different soft (0.5–2 keV) and hard (2–10 keV) X-ray bands.

Although the X-ray luminosity function (XLF) in the soft and hard X-ray bands shows significant variability on a yearly scale, there is no strong variability on a daily scale, nor is there a clear correlation between the soft XLF and hard XLF.
We will compare our XLF results with other survey results and discuss their implications for diffuse hot gas in normal galaxies.
Researchers have long known that plants respond to and adapt to their environment through changes in gene expression and metabolism.
However, there is relatively little research on how photon signals are converted into adaptive responses at the molecular level.

Here, we studied the effects of Ni(II) stress on the physiological and morphological responses of mustard seedlings, and explored the correlation between these responses and changes in light quantum signals using a bioluminescence imaging approach.
We found that Ni(II) stress inhibited the elongation of the hypocotyl, and the degree of hypocotyl elongation is related to the number of light quanta received by the seedlings.
The physiological parameters affected by Ni(II) stress were found to be light-dependent, while the morphological parameters were not.
Our results indicate that Ni(II) stress impairs the seedlings' perception of light, and the degree of impairment is directly proportional to the severity of Ni(II) stress.
In addition, we observed that the response of seedlings to Ni(II) stress is well correlated with the previously identified "oxidative stress response" and the level of salicylic acid (SA).

We speculate that Ni(II) stress inhibits the elongation of the hypocotyl by suppressing the conversion of light quantum into visual signals, leading to an imbalance in the levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and salicylic acid (SA), both of which have been established to be related in the response to Ni(II) stress.

Overall, this study provides evidence of the correlation between light quantum and the physiological and morphological responses of B. juncea seeds under nickel (II) stress, and identifies potential signaling pathways involved in these processes.

Dew point cooling observations were conducted by installing instruments along a 630-meter inclined path in the western United States to measure downwind saturation at multiple typical hillside locations.

The difference in saturation on the hillside is linearly correlated with the measured decrease in dew point, with a strong negative slope indicating that as saturation decreases, the decrease in dew point increases.
The relationship graph between the decrease in dew point and the saturation difference of the slope shows a continuous piecewise linear relationship, consisting of two linear regions.
The difference in slope between these two areas is obvious. The slope in the saturated difference area is similar to that in the lower area, both of which have a negative slope.
When the saturation difference is zero (i.e., on the isotherm), the expected dew point pressure difference is approximately -75.6°C.
The warm and humid stored product has a temperature of approximately -75°.
C can be generated by quickly increasing the saturation difference from nearly zero to about 0.5.
The estimated saturated difference in dew point at -75.6° C is about 0.5.
Recently, a mysterious parallel sorting algorithm called dualheap selection has been discovered, and it has been proven to be faster than quicksort on both actual and simulated computer systems.
The double pile selection works by transferring the selected items into a well-balanced double pile, which evidently aids in sorting.
The double heap is an internal heap structure where the elements that require the least recent exchanges are located at the top.
The mechanism of this sorting is quite profound and mysterious, and this parallelism seems to arise from the interaction between the double heap and the cache lines.
The algorithm appears to work well on modern multicore architectures, but it is not clear how to adapt it to shared memory systems (such as GPUs).
Interestingly, double-ended selection is related to a stack-based sorting algorithm known as quicksort.
These two algorithms have many similarities in terms of implementation and motivation.
In fact, the double heap selection is faster than quicksort on certain random distributions, indicating that this unconventional algorithm is not just a trick.
The double stack selection and quick stack were independently discovered by different computer scientists around 2008, and their research interests do not seem to be related.
There are some speculations that double-ended queues may be a complex building block within a continuum of data structures, similar to heaps, trie trees, and chmaps.
The dual-pile selection has not yet undergone rigorous analysis, even though it seems to possess useful approximative characteristics and can achieve stability with some adjustments.
A rigorous algorithm based on double heap selection has not yet been developed, although some theoretical improvements and empirical successes have been demonstrated.
Although successful on real computer systems, the double heap selection has yet to be proven correct.
Specifically, it is currently unclear whether the theory possesses all the correct properties or if there are specific inputs that lead to incorrect behavior.
This article provides an overview of dual heap selection, aiming to explain how it works and why it is effective.
We also discussed some of the latest developments in understanding algorithms and how they might adapt to work on different computer systems.
In this article, we examine reflected Brownian motion in a region with a smooth boundary.

According to the general criterion for continuous martingales, such a process is a semimartingale, whose quadratic variation is represented by a continuous local martingale, reflecting its boundaries.
In certain situations, this boundary is only measurable.
Under certain additional conditions, we prove the invariance principle for this semimartingale reflected Brownian motion.
This result extends the existing findings in the field of smooth boundaries or uniformly continuous boundaries.
Specifically, it applies to Markov semi-martingale reflected Brownian motion in areas with piecewise smooth boundaries.
This result is itself very interesting and has potential applications in trap models in random geometry and finance.
We plan to study these applications in a separate paper.
This work was initiated during the author's postdoctoral period at Vanderbilt University.
He wants to thank his former mentor, Professor Balint Tos, for his encouragement.
He should also thank Professor Mihaela Tătar for pointing out errors in earlier versions of the paper and for the helpful discussions provided.

In the galaxy NGC 1275 (Perseus A), a peculiar structure has been discovered: a "hole" with an estimated mass of about 10^42±409 solar masses, located approximately 55 million light-years away from Earth and with a diameter of about 18,000 light-years.
This object is called "egg" by some people, "hen" by others, and some see it as an intriguing phenomenon, free from the constraints of classification.
So far, no obvious reason has been found for the formation of this "void in the galaxy".

We believe that this structure is likely the result of a recent violent merger between two galaxies, whose cores have fallen within each other's gravitational influence, forming a core filled with cores, which has an egg-like shape.

The merger of galaxies can also explain the phenomenon of the more rapid velocity dispersion of stars in the "egg" core region compared to the surrounding regions, which is consistent with predictions from numerical simulations of such events.
The smaller projection mass of this egg makes it very likely, as it has already completely passed through its merged predecessor and will continue to do so.
In this sense, we regard an egg as a transient structure, whose nature is similar to that of a galactic hotspot. Although their names are somewhat similar, their origins are clearly unrelated.
Perturbation theory is one of the most important techniques in physics.
It provides a framework for describing low-energy dynamics in a system, focusing on the interactions between its various components or scales.
Examples of this type of interaction include the Coulomb force between electrons in an atom or the gravitational force between planets.
In quantum mechanics, the fundamental theory of almost all particles applies perturbation theory to study the motion of electrons in atoms.
When these interactions are weak, perturbation theory provides a good approximation for the dynamics of the system.
Before its success, perturbation theory only considered the first-order change of a variable as a function of another variable.

For example, if I sit on a chair and ask you what the relationship is between my height and the height of the chair, then you only need to consider my height and the height of the ground to accurately answer the relationship between my height and the height of the chair.
You don't need to consider my weight or the weight of the Earth, as these are considered higher-order corrections.
Parameter perturbation theory (PT) allows us to consider higher-order changes of variables when calculating the response of a system to changes in another variable.
For example, I will sit on a chair and calculate the relationship between my weight and the height of the chair, as well as the changes in the height of the ground and the weight of the Earth.
This way, PT expands the scope of our consideration of variable changes or adjustments within systems and their dynamics.
Flavor Changing Neutral Currents (FCNC) interactions are forbidden at tree level in the Standard Model (SM).
However, due to higher-order corrections, these processes are possible at the loop level.

This was the first time such a process, mediated by W bosons, involving flavor changing neutral currents (FCNC), was observed at the Large Electron-Positron Collider (LEP) at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) in 1995.
Based on this, we study flavor-changing currents within the framework of the supersymmetric standard model.

We prove the decay of the B meson into X (where X represents a charged lepton or neutrino) and the asymmetry between the s and c quarks, which is particularly sensitive to the effects of flavor-changing currents.
Utilizing this asymmetry, we derive constraints on the current coupling of flavor change, which can be translated into constraints on supersymmetry parameters.

We further indicate that combining these constraints with measurements of CP violation in B meson mixing not only allows for a more precise determination of supersymmetry parameters but also provides important information about the structure of flavor-changing currents, thereby helping us understand the mechanisms of flavor violation.
Finally, we suggest using the Belle II experiment at Super KEKB to improve the experimental constraints on top quark FCNC interactions.
In this article, we investigate the algebraically closed real geodesics on n-dimensional ellipsoids.

We prove that the real measured geodesic rings on an algebraically closed ellipsoid are dense in the space of all free rings, provided that the algebraically closed field is sufficiently large and the ring is sufficiently non-constant.
We also study the relationship between algebraically closed real geodesics on ellipsoids and the superellipse tangential covering of the projective plane, as well as the real Jacobian variety.
The results presented have many applications, particularly in the theory of integrable systems, Klein geometry, and mirror symmetry.

For example, we show that the measured geodesic loops on an algebraically closed ellipsoid correspond to multiple coverings on an algebraic surface, with branch positions being real curves of minimal genus.
The structure of the paper is as follows.
For the first part, we provide some necessary definitions and introduce some preliminary facts.
For the second part, we study the algebraically closed geodesics on the ellipsoid.
In Section 3, we discussed the relationship between the algebraically closed geodesics on an ellipsoid and the tangent covering on the projective plane.
In Section 4, we will demonstrate the impact of our research on practical Jacobian varieties.
Solid methane (CH4), also known as coalbed methane, is a form of natural gas that exists in the underground layers of decommissioned coal mines.
Methane gas is rarely found in its natural state.
It usually exists in the form of individual molecules or small clusters called cages.
Solid methane has two solid phases, namely α (IV) phase and β (IV) phase.
The α phase is more stable at atmospheric pressure and is stable below 77K and at greater depths, while the β phase is stable above 150K and at shallower depths.
Due to the presence of solid methane in two different structural solid phases, this provides an opportunity to study the relationship between crystal structure and dynamics.
Neutron scattering can be used to study crystal structures through the structure factor.
The dynamic structure factor contains information about the intramolecular dynamics.
We have developed a quantum molecular dynamics model for the kinetics of solid methane, which includes the key physical factors necessary for accurately modeling the dynamic structure factor.
We validate the model by calculating the dynamical structure factor of solid methane α phase and comparing it with previous inelastic neutron scattering (INS) measurement results.

Our model can be used to further study the relationship between crystal structure and dynamics, and to predict how the dynamics between solid methane phases change, as well as how they vary under changes in pressure or temperature.
Using computer simulations, we studied the structure of the toroidal magnetic field in neutron stars with a type II superconductor core.
We found that for a range of physically reasonable parameters, these fields exist as stable configurations instead of being troubled by magnetic instability.
We also found that these fields can change the structure of neutron stars and affect their cooling behavior.
Our results provide new insights into the nature of certain magnetars, as well as a new mechanism for the radio emissions of these celestial bodies.
A neutron star is one of the most peculiar celestial bodies in the universe.
They are the remnants left behind after the death of massive celestial bodies.
They weigh the same on the moon, but have a greater density, with an average of several kilometers of material compressed into a volume of just a few kilometers.
Their interior, known as the "nuclear sphere," is rich in neutrons, with nearly half of its volume composed of neutrons that are bound together by strong forces.
This type of neutron material is the densest substance in the universe, with a density similar to that of a large tumor in the human body.
Surrounding the nuclear ball is a layer of "deep shell," which is essentially a thin layer of partially degraded neutron droplets, and finally, there is the outer layer of hydrogen and helium.

The core of many neutron stars is a material core supported by strong forces, which is likely composed of several types of forces that cause superconductivity, namely Fermi force, co-rotational force, U(1) force, or color superconducting force.
Type II superconductivity occurs in metals at low temperatures.
In a magnetic field, superconducting electrons arrange themselves in a pancake shape, forming magnetic flux quanta.
The result field reaches its maximum value in the equatorial plane of the star and gradually weakens near the surface.
If the total flux is an integer multiple of the flux quantum ωφ0, the field is called a "toroidal field."
According to the ratio of magnetic energy to cohesive energy, this domain is either stable or unstable.
For this work, we studied a subset of stable solutions, namely those with integer magnetic flux.

We found that the ratio of the circumspherical energy to the rest of the star is proportional to the fifth power of the field strength; therefore, in a typical neutron star field, there is almost no free energy in the field.
The field lines then naturally converge into a flux bundle of integral quanta.
For sufficiently strong magnetic fields, there is a discontinuity in the cylindrical magnetic field, and this magnetic field is referred to as a force-free magnetic field.

This situation arises when there are modifications to the equation of state of superconductors caused by the presence of a magnetic field, leading to an imbalance between magnetic energy and condensation energy.
A toroidal field alters the structure of neutron stars in two main ways.
In the core, the magnetic pressure increases, and the pressure rises even as the density decreases.
This will affect the dynamics of the inner shell, as well as the magnetic field generated in the process.

Among all possible relevant tensors, those that ensure the consistency of the maximum Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) equations (RA Conserving) are typically chosen, as discussed in the review in reference [1].
However, this closure does not take into account that the fluctuations of the Reynolds stress are not fully known, thus the Reynolds-Averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) equations are not closed.

According to this work, we propose to simulate the fluctuations of Reynolds-Averaged Variables (RAV) through an exponential-based solution of the Reynolds-Averaged Variable equations, where the exponent is obtained through the (analytical) matrix exponential computed from the (non-convergent) Reynolds-Averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) equations.

This is a new closure we refer to as matrix-exponential-based turbulent subgrid-scale stress closure (MEC-TS), which ensures Reynolds-averaged conservation properties and significantly reduces the cost of evaluating the Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes equations at each time step, while accounting for unresolved contributions in the turbulent subgrid-scale (TSGS) model.

clean_wm_text: Late-type red supergiants (LTRSGs) are evolved stars that are the direct progenitors of massive Wolf-Rayet stars and cannot be observed in local galaxy clusters.
This includes the Milky Way (MW), the Local Group (LG), and the satellite galaxies of the Milky Way, such as the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) and the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC).

They are particularly noteworthy because of their significance at the upper end of the initial mass function (IMF) and as potential progenitors of compact binary stars, such as gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) and potential gravitational wave sources.

Despite the close proximity of the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) and the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) and extensive observational studies on them, only a small number of long-period red supergiants (LTRSGs) have been identified so far.
This may be because LTRSGs are evolving stars that are relatively dim, or because they do not exist in these galaxies, possibly due to their high demand for brightness.
To test this hypothesis, I searched for LTRSGs in two satellite galaxies of the Milky Way—The Large Magellanic Cloud and The Small Magellanic Cloud.
I used the 6.5-meter Magellan telescope for deep high-resolution imaging, and...
The wide-area Pan-STARRS1 (PS1) survey identifies candidates and extracts photometric information.
Two true LTRSGs were identified in the wheat galaxy of the Southern Hemisphere, but none were found in the barley galaxy.

This indicates that, although LTRSGs (long-time variable red supergiants) seem to be absent in the LG (Local Group), they may exist in small satellite galaxies, such as the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC).
The masses of Ξ(1690), Ξ(1690)Π, and Ξ(1695) have recently been measured for the first time.
These states are inferred to be the lowest mass members of unconventional anti-decuplet light baryons.
We determine their strong coupling as well as α′, J, and parity.
We found that for the Ξ(1690) state, α′ = (0.34 ± 0.05 ± 0.09) GeV², J = 1; for the Ξ(1690) Π state, α′ = (0.44 ± 0.07 ± 0.09) GeV², J = 1; for the Ξ(1695) state, the parity of Ξ is −1.
The masses of Ξ(1690), Ξ(1690)Π, and Ξ(1695) have recently been measured for the first time.
These states are inferred to be the lowest mass members of an unconventional light three-fold exotic baryon anti-decuplet.
We determine their strong coupling as well as α′, J, and parity.
We found that: α′ = (0.34 ± 0.05 ± 0.09) GeV², J = 1; α′ = (0.44 ± 0.07 ± 0.09) GeV², J = 1; and the parity of Ξ is -1 for the three states Ξ(1690), Ξ(1690)Π, and Ξ(1695).
The lowest quality anti-tenfold state was initially proposed by members of the HERMES collaboration in 2000.
Their notable feature is the simultaneous discovery of three states with the same peculiarities, as well as one state with negative Ξ parity.
The last two features are speculated to be unique to the Ξ anti-decuplet, distinguishing it from other non-charm quark multiplet boson systems.
In 2003, these states were referred to as the Ξ anti-decuplet.

Early measurements indicated that the mass of the Ξ baryon (Xi baryon) was relatively low, but later results from the SAPHIR, COMPASS, and CERES experiments showed that its mass is significantly higher.
The X(3872) state was finally conjectured in 2009, when it was predicted to exist within the framework of the diquark-antidiquark model.

Weak lensing observations enable us to study large-scale structures, becoming a powerful tool for testing cosmological models and searching for subtle features of gravity.

In order to extract as much information as possible from these surveys, the ideal situation is to break the degeneracy between gravitational lensing potentials and cosmological parameters, which would introduce cross-correlations between different redshift intervals.

Although ground-based telescopes provide the necessary precision for conducting these cross-correlations, the advantages are even more pronounced in space due to the larger accessible volume and less cloud cover.
Here, we present preliminary results of weak lensing reconstruction and lens imaging tomography in eight redshift intervals using the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST).
We combine this with accurate and synchronized optical and near-infrared photometric measurements from VisibleISS.

Valley-dependent optoelectronic devices based on inversion symmetry breaking have recently received widespread attention due to their potential for achieving ultra-low power operation, especially in electronic devices on next-generation strained silicon CMOS platforms.

However, directly implementing broken inversion symmetry (IBS) materials in electronic devices still poses challenges due to the complex relationships among valley-dependent optical selection rules, momentum-conserving carrier scattering, and electron transport.

To this end, we propose a general platform for valley-related optoelectronic technology based on the IBS effect in oxide interface semiconductors, which combines band structure engineering and reduced dielectric screening to relax these complex constraints.

Through relevant first-principles calculations, we demonstrate tunable valley splitting in n-type strained silicon interface oxides, reaching up to 30 meV, and strong light absorption at the silicon band edges starting in the photon energy range of 1.1-1.3 eV. Our work provides a promising avenue for leveraging the IBS effect in valley-dependent optoelectronics within existing CMOS technology nodes, paving the way for low-power and/or compact Internet of Things applications.

This paper studies the characteristics of non-stationary complex networks, including but not limited to time-varying networks and unsynchronized networks.
Non-stationarity arises from rapid changes in network structure and/or node dynamics.
Due to the non-stationary nature of the network, traditional network metrics cannot fully reflect the characteristics of the network.
To this end, the theory of reconstructive graphs was adopted to characterize network dynamics, and thus a method for quantifying non-stationarity was proposed.
The analysis of the generated models and empirical data indicates that non-stationary complex networks are very common in real-world networks, such as dynamic networks and brain networks.
Further research on biological networks reveals the functional differences between stable and non-stable complex networks.
Non-stationary complex networks have a wide-ranging impact on real-world networks.
For example, brain networks and large biological networks are often modeled as static networks, while complex dynamic characteristics cannot be captured.

On the contrary, non-stationary complex networks reveal potential non-stationary dynamic behaviors, which can lead to more accurate results in certain applications, such as network diseases and dynamic predictions.

In order to simulate the effects of electromagnetic barriers (barriers in materials with different refractive indices) and tunnel barriers (barriers that allow tunneling), we derived general constraints on the thickness, refractive index, and density of states of dielectric multilayer structures and potential barrier step heights.
These constraints are applied to dielectric/dielectric and dielectric/barrier multilayer structures to determine the acceptable parameter range for electromagnetic and tunneling barriers.

For each type of obstacle, we found that the transmission, dispersion (wavelength shift), and state density are inversely proportional to the fourth power of the ratio of obstacle height to the incident wavelength.

By setting these parameters for known obstacles, we have demonstrated that it is impossible to construct a step potential well with an arbitrary layer arrangement that has a transmission rate less than 10^-8, a dispersion rate less than 10^-9, or a state density less than approximately 10^-4 states/eV/nm^2/Ci.

Similarly, to construct an electromagnetic barrier, the difference in refractive index between layers must be greater than approximately 5.8 × 10^-3 (for a barrier with complete reflection) and greater than 2.2 × 10^-2 (for a barrier with a transmittance lower than 90%), which is impossible to achieve.
These constraints will help optimize future designs of electromagnetic and tunnel barriers, as well as the development of practical applications of these effects.

The results of the fusion process study for pre-balanced giant dipole resonance (PGDDR) based on time-dependent Hartree-Fock theory are presented.
Research shows that the PGDDR peak in the electron momentum distribution function can be significantly enhanced by using laser-assisted ionization with direct absorption of laser pulses.

High-purity free radicals are crucial for dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP), as they can enhance nuclear magnetic moments for imaging with high sensitivity.
The hyperpolarization generated in DNP requires a short polarization time.
Here, we introduce a versatile solid radical, nitrogen-oxide radical triphenylmethyl (N3), for efficient dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP).
In particular, we use electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) to investigate the dynamics of N3.
We have identified a stable nitrogen-oxide free radical anion, tetramethyl tetranitromethane (TMTN), as an effective trapping agent for the N3 radical.
We have demonstrated that the dipole coupling between electron spin and nuclear spin, caused by anisotropic electron spins, increases the rate of dynamic nuclear polarization by six times.

It has been suggested that dipolar coupling can be used as a method to increase the dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) rate, but the enhancement effect we observed is an order of magnitude higher than the theoretical predictions.

This enhancement is derived from the faster electronic relaxation in TMTN radicals and the quicker formation of N3 radicals during the capture of TMTN radicals. We demonstrate that both of these effects contribute significantly to the enhancement.

The rapid diffusion and high polarization of N3 that we observed suggest that this method may be applicable to other solid free radicals and has the potential to reduce DNP time to below 1 millisecond.
In the field of Computer-Based Learning (CBL), educational researchers and practitioners have recognized the need to evaluate the effectiveness of CBL through empirical evidence.

Although the development of automatic assessment in CBL is rapid, the assessment methods still mainly rely on self-report and think-aloud protocols, both of which cannot accurately reflect the cognitive and emotional experiences of the participants.
This article introduces a new method - Experience Assessment of Communication (EAC), used to measure these experiences.
The EAC method collects survey data on participants' verbal and non-verbal communication during CBL tasks, and utilizes data mining and natural language processing techniques to analyze the data.
This article presents the results of an evaluative study that used an AI-based CBL system to demonstrate the feasibility of the EAC method.

The study achieved 76% statistical significance in distinguishing the communication styles of low-performing and high-performing learners, and it reached 85% consistency between human coding and machine learning-based communication style coding methods.

In this letter, we demonstrate that the rupture of far-field spiral waves is another pathway to spatiotemporal chaos (STC) in the planktonic ecosystem, a phenomenon that cannot be described by the classical C. E. Pfister theory.

"Central-type groups and cohomology classes. Let G be a Lie group, and g be its element."
We say that \( g \) is central-type if the Killing form of the Lie algebra \( \mathfrak{g} \) of \( G \) is zero at the origin, that is, it is zero on the Lie algebra \( \mathfrak{g} \) of \( G \).
In this case, the mapping \( g^{-1} : g^{-1}(g) \mapsto g \) is an endomorphism of \( G \) called the Zassenhaus automorphism.
We say that a cohomology class in Hn(G,M;R) has a central property if its projection in Hn(g⁻¹(g), g⁻¹; R) also has a central property.

We provide two criteria to determine when a cohomology class with a central type is non-degenerate: it is non-degenerate if and only if its dual is also non-degenerate, and we present an explicit cup product.
We also explained how to calculate the cup product of two central cohomology classes by pairing the corresponding cohomology classes of the Lie algebra.
We ultimately prove that any homology class with a central type is a bijection if and only if it is non-degenerate, and we demonstrate an explicit formula for its inverse.
In quantum mechanics, the state of a system is described by a density matrix, which is a Hermitian positive semi-definite matrix corresponding to a statistical ensemble of pure states.
The density matrix allows for the calculation of various properties of the system, such as the expectation values of specific operators.
For the experiment, accessing the density matrix requires a quantum process tomography (QPT) protocol.
QPT is a method that involves probing the system using a large number of different initial states to reconstruct the most general processes acting on the system.
In this work, a closed quantum system is prepared in an arbitrary initial state Ψ0 and subjected to a series of projection measurements.
The expected result of each measurement is calculated based on the initial state.
By repeating this process with a series of different Ψ0 values, a histogram of the expected results can be generated.
Through the quantum process tomography scheme, the initial state can be extracted from the histogram.
The average fidelity between the reconstructed state and the true initial state has been calculated for a wide range of system parameters, demonstrating the effectiveness of the process.
In addition, the effects of limited time were considered, in which the expected results of a system initialized in a highly unbalanced state were calculated.
The formalism was then applied to the spin-boson model, namely T1 qubits, demonstrating a method for measuring spin qubits through arbitrary channels in a scalable architecture.

Geometric control theory (Grueneisen standard) is a powerful extension of classical control theory that provides a unified framework for analyzing and stabilizing constrained mechanical systems as well as mechanical systems described by ordinary differential equations (ODEs).
This framework is based on the concepts of semi-Riemannian geometry, which was introduced by A. Ferreira in 1973.

This extension has been successfully applied in various mathematical fields, such as the theory of partial differential equations and geometric evolution equations, as well as in applications related to constraints or failures in mechanical systems, and vector fields on statistical manifolds, among others.
However, up to now, there has not been a comprehensive explanation of this theory.
Through this work, we provide a comprehensive explanation of geometric control theory from an integrated perspective.

To this end, we conducted a detailed study of the main concepts in Riemannian geometry and proved some fundamental results of functional analysis and ordinary differential equation theory that are of general interest.
We also discussed the relationship between this theory and optimal control of differential equations as well as the calculus of variations.

We introduced the main applications of geometric control theory in several mathematical fields and provided a list of open problems that will attract the interest of experts and researchers in the field.
The observations of the solar radio spectrometer for the limb activity region were presented on June 22, 2014, at 04:30 UTC.

Spectral analysis indicates that the observed radio emission is primarily composed of two thermal components: one is a broad spectrum component with a lower dynamical temperature, typically interpreted as electrons and the heat deposited due to the falling beams; the other is a spectrum with little variation in the spectral line profile, which may be contributed by Maxwellian electrons accelerated by the magnetic field.

Compared to the limb observation on May 21, 2014, at 14:00 UT, we found that the radiation intensity associated with the beam was similar, while the average electron density and the temperature of Maxwellian electrons decreased by 20% and 10%, respectively.
This paper analyzes spectral lines and their spatial derivatives to reveal how the density and velocity distribution of hot electrons in the solar atmosphere changes.
The results show that the density decreases from the corona down to the transition region, and as the temperature decreases, the velocity distribution becomes more anisotropic.

The density stratification indicates that the heat plasma generated by the beam comes from the lower atmosphere of the Sun, while the anisotropic velocity distribution suggests that the beam particles propagate along the magnetic field.
These results indicate that the formation and propagation of the beam process occur concurrently in the solar lower atmosphere.
The characterization of dark matter (DM) components in galaxy clusters is crucial for our understanding of the universe on the largest scales.

Among many methods, although many people are looking for observational characteristics of dark matter, one of the most direct approaches is to measure the speed anisotropy of the position changes of dark matter particles within galaxy clusters.
We described a method for measuring the anisotropy of dark matter velocities, utilizing optical observations of galaxy clusters and the strong gravitational lensing effects of background galaxies.

We applied this method to the galaxy cluster MACS J0429.6-0253, combining our measurements of the projected mass distribution with strong lensing observational data obtained from the Hubble Space Telescope.
We have found strong evidence of axisymmetric dark matter velocity anisotropy in this star cluster, and the magnitude of the anisotropy depends on the radius.
Our results show that dark matter is not completely collisional, but retains some velocity memory from earlier times.

The method described in this article can be applied to other galaxy clusters and other large-scale structures in the universe, thereby allowing for further investigation into the nature of dark matter and its dynamic evolution.
The stability of circumnuclear disks (CNTs) in elliptical galaxies is a hot topic in modern astronomy.
Due to the relatively high gas content of these galaxies, they typically possess detectable rotating cold gas disks, which are often embedded with dust.
The existence of these annular nuclei discs has only been discovered relatively recently.
Although they have cosmological significance, the physical mechanisms behind the formation and stability of these disks remain unclear.
