This work attempts to study the issues of gravitational stability of carbon nanotubes using modern computational simulation methods.
The study utilized the Graphical Path Code (GPU-PCM), an efficient parallel computing code used for solving fluid dynamics equations on a grid.
The experiment is conducted on an elliptical galaxy model with a low-quality companion star and a model with long-term evolution.
The experiment confirmed the dynamic stability around the nuclear disk in both cases, and the specific angular momentum of the disk material was maintained over time.

However, it is impossible to determine whether there is an established basic pattern in this system.

The existence of this force, known as dark energy, has been confirmed by the observed accelerated expansion of the universe.

The pseudo-spectral of a semi-classical operator system is the complement of the spectrum within the closed conical sector of the system's phase space complexification.
The pseudo-spectrum can have a fractal structure and possess numerous self-similarities.
This has been proved for oscillators on the real line with smooth polynomial potentials.
Specifically, this means that the Kolmogorov complexity of pseudorandom sequences may not be efficiently computable.
For systems where the phase space is a ring or a cylinder, explicit formulas for the pseudo spectrum have been obtained.
The pseudo-spectrum can be numerically approximated to any desired accuracy by considering a finite-dimensional truncation of the system.

The LBNE collaboration studied the potential of a long-baseline neutrino experiment to determine whether the short-baseline muon neutrino disappearance is caused by neutrino oscillation.
We found that such observations have high statistical significance and are very likely to lead to discoveries.
We determine the predictive sensitivity of CP violations in the total mix, inverted mass hierarchy, and MNS matrix.
We also discussed potential supplementary experiments that could use larger statistical data to confirm or rule out invalid results and address experimental challenges.
Finally, we will compare the LBNE proposal with other long-baseline neutrino experiments and proposed neutrino sources.
We have found that the LBNE proposal has excellent potential for discovery and can provide strong constraints on neutrino parameters.

The Long-Baseline Neutrino Experiment (LBNE) is a proposed neutrino physics project planned to be conducted at the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF) in South Dakota and the Soudan Mine in Minnesota.

The scientific goal of LBNE is to determine whether the short baseline (around 15 kilometers) muon neutrino disappearance is caused by neutrino oscillation, and if so, to further determine the nature of this disappearance; that is, to ascertain whether it is due to a normal mass hierarchy or an inverted mass hierarchy, and whether it involves maximal or minimal neutrino CP violation.
If these phenomena are confirmed, it would indicate the existence of a new type of particle, potentially leading to new discoveries in particle physics.
LBNE may also reveal a possible conceptual conflict between the short-distance and long-distance scales implied by neutrino oscillations.
The LBNE uses a dual-detector configuration, employing a large-scale 200-kiloton three-chamber (TT) detector, with a baseline ranging from 1210 to 1610 kilometers.

It has been shown that the sensitivity of this configuration to the overall neutrino mixing is less than 13% C.L. at a baseline resolution of 3x10^-3, and it also shows sensitivity to the neutrino mass hierarchy and CP violation at confidence levels ranging from 5x10^-2 to 5x10^-3.
We described the use of the Feldman-Cousins method to determine the predicted sensitivity to neutrino parameters, which includes systematic uncertainties.
This study is preliminary and does not include cost-effectiveness or risk assessment.
We conclude by discussing the proposed derivative experiments, which could confirm or refute null results through higher statistical data, and we discuss the challenges faced by the experiments.
Object classification is a key step in difference imaging, and it pertains to the study of galaxies in their early states.
Historically, this has been a cumbersome process that has limited the types of galaxies studied.
We introduced an object classification technique that not only improves the efficiency of our research on galaxies but also enhances the reliability of the results.
The technology uses convolutional neural networks trained on high-quality galaxy images to classify low-quality differential imaging images of the same galaxy.
This enables us to identify candidate galaxies and exclude those stellar images that may be incorrectly labeled as galaxies.
Our method improves the reliability of the results and significantly increases the number of galaxies we will study.

As a test, we applied our method to the differential imaging survey of the K2 region in the Southern Sky, determining that 80% are galaxies, as opposed to the approximately 50% identified through visual inspection.
The generated catalog may help in studying the evolution of the number of galaxies with redshift and will aid us in understanding galaxy morphology and demographics.
The technology described here is not limited to differential imaging.
Similar methods can be applied to other situations where object classification is a necessary preliminary step.
This letter discusses the transient behavior of surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) scattered in subwavelength grooves.
SPP scattering is modeled as a two-dimensional waveguide grating with a limited longitudinal size.

Research indicates that the surface plasmon polariton (SPP) field is primarily distributed within the grooves and gradually decays to zero at a distance of λ/2n, where n is the refractive index of the surrounding medium.
The SPP field exhibits free-space exponential decay over long distances, with the time scale determined by the size of the groove.
The time evolution of the SPP field is consistent with the transverse component of the incident pulse electric field, demonstrating the dominant role of SPP in the scattering process.
The results provide useful information about the scattering of surface plasmon polaritons (SPP) at the subwavelength scale and can be used to optimize SPP-based devices.

Author: Li Jinheng and Wang Gang  
Publication Date: July 25, 2020  
Abstract: This paper studies the transient behavior of surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) scattered in subwavelength grooves.
The SPP scattering is modeled as a two-dimensional waveguide grating with a finite longitudinal dimension.

Research shows that the surface plasmon polariton (SPP) field is mainly distributed in the groove and gradually diminishes to zero at a distance of λ/2n, where n is the refractive index of the surrounding medium.
The SPP field decays according to a free-space exponential function at long distances, with the time scale determined by the size of the groove.

The temporal evolution of the SPP field is consistent with the evolution of the transverse component of the incident pulse's electric field, demonstrating the dominant role of SPP in the scattering process.
The results provide useful information about the scattering of surface plasmon polaritons (SPP) at the subwavelength scale and can be used to optimize SPP-based devices.

Quantum vacuum is a magical place where particles continually appear and disappear in a probabilistic manner.
The behavior of such quantum fields is the foundation of all known interactions.
Especially, their exchange leads to the stability of the charge in the Standard Model (SM), the spin of particles, and the form of interactions.

If we extrapolate the particle spectrum of the standard model to the lowest possible energy, we expect that particle exchange will involve gravitons, which could explain the observed gravity, and may also involve photons and fermions.
For this job, we discussed the first option.
The graviton is the expected carrier of gravitational interactions; otherwise, this interaction would be felt in an indirect way through intermediary messengers.
Photons and fermions are the two types of particles with the largest mass in the standard model.
Therefore, it seems reasonable to believe that they may be the corresponding force carriers.
However, the fact that they are spin-1/2 fermions rather than spin-2 bosons has thus far prevented them from being observed.
In this work, we propose a method for the direct interaction of photons and fermions by introducing a new term that violates Lorentz and CPT symmetry in the Standard Model Lagrangian.
We proposed a method to test this proposal using current and future colliders.
The graviton carries gravitational and Lorentz-violating interactions, leading to a unique feature where particles are completely absent, while two corresponding jets emerge at high invariant mass.
Photons and fermions only carry gravitational interactions.
Therefore, their phenomenological significance is different.
Photons and fermions can decay into gravitons, so the signature would be two jets plus missing energy.
If the graviton is the lightest among the new particles, then the characteristic will be four jets.
An excess of any of these features may be an indication of potential theories, which could also provide explanations for dark matter as well as for the strong and weak forces.

Recent observations of the spectral polarization of the bow shock dominated by Balmer emissions have revealed the existence of a so-called transitional zone, characterized by features that lie between the upstream and downstream shock regions.
The characteristics of the region depend on the properties of the inflow, such as the Mach number and the magnetic field strength before the shock, as well as the shock intensity.

In this article, we present the 1D numerical simulation results of the Balmer-dominant shock in the strong shock limit, which allows us to characterize the properties of the transition region and calculate its physical attributes as a function of shock parameters.

We found that for the strong shock limit, the width of the transition zone is proportional to the distance between the precursor shock zone and the center of the shock zone, while its temperature and velocity spread are proportional to the square root of the corresponding precursor values.
In addition, we found that the fractional abundance of ionized carbon decreases exponentially from the pre-impact value to the front of the impact, nearly reaching zero.

We provided a scaling relationship to approximate the physical properties of the transition zone between the region before the shock wave and the region after the shock wave, based on an understanding of the physical parameters of the inflow and the shock wave.
The nuclear density and momentum distribution provide unique information about the spatial distribution of nucleon momentum and current within the atomic nucleus.
In standard analysis, the center of mass (c.m.) correction is applied sequentially after the removal of the nucleon resolution function.
Here, we propose a method that combines these two corrections into a single step, thus referred to as simultaneous centroid modification (s.c.m.).
The s.c.m. correction improves the agreement between theoretical predictions and experimental data, and is applicable to a wide range of nuclei and distributions.
The accuracy of the new method is demonstrated through a simultaneous description of the deuteron and the W(d,2p) distribution.

This method can be easily applied to other nuclear reactions and extends the applicability of nuclear reaction theory to current areas of interest, such as the study of nuclear spin-isospin excitations and the structural changes during the evolution of nuclear systems in collisions.
The method can be downloaded from https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.09044.

We present late X-ray observations of the Ibc-type core-collapse supernova 2018crp from nearby, with data from the Chandra X-ray Observatory, and review its observational features and modeling characteristics.
The X-ray brightness we measured is (4.6 ± 1.0).
Under the assumption that the distance to the Large Magellanic Cloud is 50 kpc, the power at a distance of 4.4 ± 0.3 kpc from the Galactic center is × 10³³ erg s⁻¹.

We will compare this brightness with the predictions of precursor models for three different types of Ibc supernovae, specifically 2018crp: a bare helium star (a helium star without an external hydrogen or dust layer), a stripped envelope star (a star with a hydrogen or helium envelope, but not enough to classify it as a blue supergiant), and a compact Wolf-Rayet star.
The X-ray brightness predicted by all ancestral models is seriously inconsistent with the observed values.

We determine that the X-ray radiation emitted from the shock wave radius must be suppressed by the discontinuity in the electron energy distribution. This suppression may be due to a significantly steep electron energy distribution (which requires a faster expansion rate of the eruption or greater explosion energy), or due to a low-density environment surrounding the suppression region of the shock wave.

Therefore, we present evidence against the compact Wolf-Rayet star progenitor model for the Ibc-type supernova 2018crp, and in general, we prefer the more expanded, lower-velocity explosion models for these transients.
Ibc supernova, also known as a supernova, is a rare explosive stellar event that occurs due to the core collapse of a massive star.

Their classification is based on the observed spectra. Type Ibc supernovae show features of hydrogen or helium in their spectra but lack the characteristics of sufficiently broad absorption lines that are typical of supernovae.
The recent discoveries related to long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), also known as supernovae, have opened new possibilities for exploring their origins.

The analysis of the constraints on the positions of long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) suggests that they are related to the deaths of very massive stars, although the specifics of their progenitors are not yet fully understood.
Two long gamma-ray bursts (GRB 170729A and GRB 160821B) have been observed in the local galaxy group, with one of them (GRB 160821B) undergoing late-time X-ray observations.
From these transient observational characteristics, constraints on the progenitor star and the explosion geometry can be obtained.

In the weeks to months following the GRB explosion, X-ray, ultraviolet, and optical radiation are driven by the forward shock generated from the interaction of the escaping jet material with the circumstellar medium (CSM).

This type of radiation can be used to measure the change in the radial distance of the shock wave from the explosion center over time, known as the brightness curve, thereby obtaining the total energy of the explosion.
The translation of the Chinese sentence "在后来，预计发射将变得" into English is "Later, the launch is expected to become..."
Recent advancements in magnetic functions at the nanoscale have sparked increasing interest in utilizing these structures for magnetic imaging and magneto-optical signal detection.
Magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) have unique appeal in these applications due to their tunable local surface magnetic moments.
Here, we present the atomic-scale magnetic characterization of uniformly 15-nanometer Fe nanoparticles.
We use aberration-corrected high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (AC-HR-TEM) to detect the local magnetism of these particles.
Our measurements revealed unique magnetic fingerprint patterns at individual nanoparticles.
These patterns correspond to the engineered multi-domain states of nanopoints, which we image with nanometer-scale spatial resolution.
Finally, we utilize the spatial dependence of magnetic fingerprints for rapid imaging of small volumes (approximately 2 × 2 × 2 nm³).

Our experiments provided detailed nanoscale magnetic characterization of sub-100 nanometer single-domain particles, representing an important step in the development of magnetic nanoparticle (MNP) devices for high-resolution magnetic imaging.
The Baumslag-Solitar group is a generalization of a well-known quotient group of free groups.
Through this article, we propose a dual method to study the representations of Baumslag-Solitar groups.

More precisely, we prove that for any positive integer \( m \), every representation of a single-relational group with \( m \) relations is dual to a (possibly different) representation of the abelianization of that group.
Using this duality, we recover well-known results of certain single relation groups with integer relations as special cases.
We also derived some stability results regarding representations of Baumslag-Solitar groups.
We use duality to study a problem about groups that are genetically just infinite.
A group \( G \) is called a purely infinitely divisible group if every subgroup of \( G \) is either purely infinite or finite.
The hereditary hyperfinite group is a generalization of hyperfinite groups.

We prove that if a torsion-free single-relations group is genetically only infinite, then its abelianization is a residually finite group, which is a direct generalization of Mal'cev's classical theorem.
The Milky Way is surrounded by large-scale structures: the halos they form, as well as the filaments and sheets in which they are embedded.
The mergers between galaxies are very important for galaxy evolution, as they can introduce new materials, angular momentum, and potentially new satellite galaxies.
Observing and searching for satellites has traditionally been difficult because they are easily affected by the interference of the galactic environment or can be removed.

N-body simulations have proven to be a powerful tool for predicting the frequencies and properties of satellite galaxies, but these predictions still require calibration with observational information based on the underlying dark matter halos.
Recently, satellite galaxies have been identified in cosmological dark matter simulations, without including baryonic physics that could potentially interfere with them.
In this work, we use a set of magnified, high-resolution cosmological simulations to study the relationship between merging and the formation of satellite galaxies.
We found a strong dependence between the survival of satellite galaxies and their relative mass, the relative mass of their host galaxies, as well as their orbital parameters.
Satellites in highly eccentric orbits are more likely to survive several crossing times than satellites in more circular orbits.

Satellites in prograde orbits around their host are more likely to survive than those in retrograde orbits, and satellites in high radial orbits are more likely to survive than those in low radial orbits.
Satellite galaxies formed at the center of a host are more likely to survive than those formed further away from the center.
We also found that the internal structure of galaxies (measured by their phase space structure) is a more effective predictor of the fates of satellites than their dark matter halos.
Especially, satellites in radial or highly eccentric orbits will have a large number of stars stripped away from their exterior.
The time for the stars of all satellites to be removed depends on their orbits, with radial orbits being less stable than more circular ones.
Overall, we find that mergers play an important role in shaping the satellite galaxies we see in the universe today.
The Generating Coordinate Method (GCM) is a method for calculating the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of operators in many-body quantum systems, such as the time-dependent Kohn-Sham equations.
GCM solves the Schrödinger equation by breaking the symmetry, utilizing unit transformations to convert the problem into a form that completely preserves the symmetry.

This allows for the separation of the low-energy states of the Hamiltonian operator by optimizing each state separately in different but internally consistent approximate ground state representations.
GCM has been widely used to study strong correlations in electronic structure, especially with the development of time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) in linear response.

In this work, we demonstrate that for the TDDFT Kohn-Sham Hamiltonian, it is possible to achieve the separation of low-energy states in a self-consistent manner by optimizing the generating coordinates, without the need to break symmetry.
We refer to this method as the generated coordinate method of time-dependent density functional theory (GCTDDFT).
We illustrate this method using polarons, the Schrödinger equation with a screened Coulomb potential, and iron nitride.
Optical lattices provide a highly controllable platform for simulating quantum systems.
By adjusting the Raman coupling and the potential energy, various quantum phases can be realized, such as superfluids and Mott insulators.

The quantum phase of cold atoms loaded into optical lattices is usually characterized by Wannier functions based on Bloch's theorem. This is a key issue in simulations and experiments, as engineering optical lattices with the desired band structure poses challenges.

To this end, we demonstrate that in the deep lattice limit with large on-site Hubbard interaction U, the dynamics of hard-core bosons can be mapped to an effective quantum spin system with long-range interactions.

In the thermodynamic limit, this quantum spin system exhibits a third-order phase transition from a Mott insulator (MI) to a superfluid (SF) at a finite wave number k*, which can be observed in the representation of Wannier functions.
In particular, the dynamical and thermodynamic properties are discussed in detail.
In addition, a real-space renormalization group method has been proposed to accurately calculate dynamic quantities.
These results provide insights for the experimental realization of quantum spin systems and the intrinsic phenomena of quantum many-body systems in realistic optical lattice systems.
Many biophysical and biochemical studies emphasize the key impact of carbohydrates in living cells.
Indeed, carbohydrates seem to be essential in various life processes, such as cell recognition, structural integrity, energy storage, or as transmitters of chemical signals.
Therefore, in recent years, the impact of carbohydrates on the structure and dynamics of related proteins has garnered widespread attention.

In this study, we focus on investigating the effects of three common carbohydrates—trehalose, maltose, and sucrose—on the dynamics and structural characteristics of lysozyme in egg white through molecular dynamics simulations.
We found that these three types of carbohydrates affect the dynamics of proteins, as well as their secondary and tertiary structures.
Through comparison, we found that maltose has a more significant stabilizing effect on protein structure than trehalose and sucrose.
Further research has found that the kinetic quantities are related to the interaction intensity between proteins and carbohydrates.

Researchers utilize the remnant of the original supernova (P31, also known as Cassiopeia A, in the figure below) to study the composition and evolution of dust in the early stages of galaxy evolution. This serves as a decoding tool to help explain the abundances and physical conditions observed in young supernova remnants (SNRs) throughout the universe.

By conducting state-of-the-art simulations of dust formation and evolution, we found that silicate dust particles formed in the P31 eruption can survive a Hubble time and are injected into the surrounding early interstellar medium (ISM).
These dust particles then grew by accumulating metals from the solar interstellar medium, forming nanoscale particles.

We also found that titanium and vanadium are the most abundant elements on the grain surface, with an overall stoichiometric ratio of approximately Ti-26V-4Si. Additionally, the atomic ratio of sulfur to oxygen is relatively high, around 0.5-1.5%.

These sulfur-rich components are distinctly different from the composition of chondrites and are more consistent with carbon-rich pebbly materials (such as aluminous pyroxene and magnetite), serving as precursors for the injected dust.

Our conclusion is that the P31 supernova remnant, as shown in our observations and modeling here, provides a rich platform for testing theoretical predictions of dust formation and its subsequent evolution.

The main components of silicate dust particles injected into the early interstellar medium will serve as fingerprints to help identify the location of these unique particles within the background populations of the Milky Way and extragalactic systems.

The abundances of silicon, titanium, and vanadium can be used to confirm the formation of silicates, oxides, and carbides, which is consistent with the expectation of the interaction between core-collapse supernova ejecta and the surrounding interstellar medium.

In addition, the ratio of sulfur to oxygen can serve as a clock to date the injection event to around 300 to 330 million years ago, depending on the assumed density and composition of the solar nebula's ambient gases.

Recently, an unusually high sulfur mass fraction has been detected in the afterglow of SN1987A, supporting an age estimate of about 30 million years, as most of the injected sulfur has likely been consumed in the process of forming new dust particles.

Ultimately, the dust found in young supernova remnants may provide us with a unique window to understand the nucleosynthesis and chemical abundance history of the first generation of stars and galaxies in the early universe.
This is a follow-up post regarding the entry in the Darwin Awards competition.
The molecule diphenyldisulfide (bPT) is connected between a gold tip and a silver substrate, forming a single-molecule junction.
The conductivity measurement shows a series of local conductivity maxima as a function of the tip-sample angle.

We analyze conductivity measurements through a simple theoretical model based on the Landauer formula, in which conductivity is represented as the sum of the transmission probabilities of electrons with different transverse momentum states.
We identified four different conductive peaks, which are produced due to the different hybridization of molecular orbitals with the conductor.
From the temperature dependence of conductivity, we estimated the width of the molecular orbitals.

The translation of the Chinese text into English is: 

"Classified in this way: the dependence of conductivity on temperature in the tilted angle landscape and in the biphenyl-2-thiol single-molecule junction."

By connecting diphenyldisulfide (bPT) molecules between the gold tip and silver substrate, we measured the conductivity as a function of the tip-sample angle and identified the presence of four local maxima in the conductivity as a function of the tip-sample angle.
These maxima can be associated with different transverse momentum states, thus relating to the various hybridization states of the conductor's molecular orbitals.
We analyzed the dependence of conductivity on temperature and estimated the hybridization width.
The National Scientific Facilities (NSFs) are national research infrastructures that support the foundation of science and engineering in the UK.
This article elaborates in detail on the impact of these non-state financial support research funds on the non-medical research activities of UK researchers.
Since 1987, spending by universities and other higher education institutions on non-medical research has more than doubled, and this has contributed to an increase in the number of researchers.

In 2010, approximately 43,000 British researchers were involved in research, education, or knowledge transfer activities that contributed to fundamental research, regional economic development, and enhancement, as well as industrial innovation in the UK.
The research is mainly funded by public funds, with about 22,000 researchers (accounting for 51%) working at universities or higher education institutions supported by research councils.

Among the remaining 20,000 researchers with commercial or industrial interests, most have received some industrial sponsorship, with support from the UK's technology sector covering various aspects ranging from consulting to applied research trials.

In the past ten years, the number of research publications and citations in the UK has significantly increased. In 2016, there were over 200,000 publications and over 20 million citations, representing an increase of approximately 22% and 39%, respectively, compared to the publication volume ten years ago.
The UK is a global leader in life sciences research, contributing over 7,000 researchers to the field between 2006 and 2021.
Between 2014 and 2021, these researchers are expected to account for about a quarter of the total healthcare research spending in the UK.

The NSF is crucial in supporting this activity, with approximately 90% of biological research facilities located in universities or other higher education institutions in the UK, and 50% of facilities for physics, astronomy, and computing as well.

These facilities play an important role in promoting the advancement of medical research in British industry, with about 40% of companies involved in medical research, and more than half of the companies collaborating with British universities and other higher education institutions.
From this work, we report direct measurements of the interfacial tension between coexisting phases in a typical simple liquid-liquid model system.
This is attributed to a recently developed method that can determine the interfacial quantities solely through computer simulations of the solute particle system.

This method is based on constructing interfaces in a simulation box that match the geometric definition of the interface surface, and monitoring various interface properties, such as the average position and orientation of solute particles, as a function of the simulation configuration.

Through this method, we are able to measure the interfacial tension between the two coexisting phases of the Tangential Hard Chain (THC). THC is a model system widely used for testing computational interface research methods.

We found that the interfacial tension between the coexistence liquid phase and the vapor phase, as well as between the liquid phase and the solid phase, are both positive values and of similar magnitude (approximately).

The translation of the Chinese text is:

"27 mN/m), which contrasts with the typical situations in liquid-gas and oil-water systems (approximately 40 mN/m), thus better representing real liquids."
This is the first report of direct measurements of such interfacial tension.
A simple fundamental measure theory (FMT) approximation has been proven to effectively describe interfacial tension, allowing for a fairly accurate evaluation of the FMT interfacial potential energy.

Such precise evaluations of interfacial potential cannot be obtained through the analysis of interfacial configurations or standard surface evolution calculations, which typically require uncontrolled assumptions about the form of the potential or involve tedious parameter searches.
Bottle brush polymers are macromolecules with a complex "brush" structure that has covalent connections, where polymer side chains are attached to a central "main chain."

Due to the relatively large size and high rigidity of bottle brush polymers, they often cannot adapt to the irregularities in their embedding environment, resulting in insufficient processability and functionality in solution or solid state.

The rigidity issue can be alleviated by introducing chemically cross-linkable side chains to the bottle brush, allowing for a single cross-linking of the bristle segments to achieve changes in the overall stiffness of the brush.
However, the brush and crosslinking agent segments may come close to each other, and even in the absence of specific non-covalent interactions, crosslinking may occur at low conversion rates.

Here we demonstrate the interactions between the brush and the crosslinker components—namely, the π-π interactions between the side chain polymers and the Flory-Huggins interactions between the fluorocarbon polymer and the carbon backbone polymer—that lead to the softening of the brush stiffness caused by crosslinking.
This method allows for independent control of the stiffness and processability of bottlebrush polymers by appropriately selecting non-covalent and covalent interactions.

The method was validated through rheological and small-angle X-ray scattering measurements of a type of bottle brush polymer, which is composed of ethylene imine monomers for the brush stems and trimethylsilyl silane (TMSSI) for the side chains.

The interaction between the TMSSI side chain and the ethoxy cyclic brush segment leads to a significant reduction in the stiffness of the bottle brush, while the weighted average molecular weight remains essentially unchanged.

A novel two-step crosslinking method has been developed, allowing for the gradual and controllable crosslinking of TMSSI side chains, while spatially and temporally decoupling it from the global crosslinking of the ethoxy oxazoline brush segments.

The method proposed here provides a powerful strategy to independently adjust the processability and stiffness of the bottle brush polymer system, with broad applicability that can be extended to other bottle brush structures.
LiHo_xY_{1-x}F_4 is a dense low-temperature magnetic material used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

The favorable properties of LiHo_xY_{1-x}F_4 originate from its fully spin-polarized ground state, although this characteristic is only stable at low temperatures and at certain concentrations of Yttrium.
We present a comprehensive thermodynamic and transport study of LiHo_xY_{1-x}F_4 over a wide range of temperatures and compositions.
"We found that the material exhibits three different phases as a function of temperature and yttrium concentration, which is consistent with previous studies."
For low temperatures and high niobium concentrations, LiHo_xY_{1-x}F_4 exhibits gas-like behavior and has classical ferromagnetic order. We have determined the expected phase diagram in this region.
At medium temperatures and low yttrium concentrations, we found evidence of a novel magnetic quantum critical point, but the low-temperature behavior still needs further characterization.
Finally, under high temperatures and low iridium concentration, LiHo_xY_{1-x}F_4 undergoes a spin glass transition.

We proposed a unified theory that describes the three phases in this region of the phase diagram, and we demonstrate that the spin-glass transition belongs to the universality class of droplet relaxation glasses.
Our study of LiHo_xY_{1-x}F_4 provides a complete description of the phase diagram for this classical ferromagnetic system.
This phase diagram is essential for understanding the properties of LiHo_xY_{1-x}F_4 and optimizing its performance in MRI machines.
In this article, we consider a static, spherically symmetric black hole in a de Sitter space with constant positive curvature.
We calculated the Bogoliubov coefficients between Hawking radiation and the Bunch-Davies vacuum and found that the de Sitter horizon is an effective transformation of the vacuum.
We also consider the case of small mass and calculate the particle production rate and the energy flux across the horizon.
We found that even in de Sitter space, the energy flux becomes a positive number, which violates the cosmic no-hair conjecture.
The translation of "日期：2023年" into English is "Date: Year 2023."

Author: Yosuke Kimura  
Title: Hawking Radiation of Black Holes in De Sitter Space
Abstract: In this article, we consider a static spherically symmetric black hole in a de Sitter space with constant positive curvature.
We calculated the Bogoliubov coefficients between Hawking radiation and the Bunch-Davies vacuum, and found that the de Sitter horizon is an effective change of vacuum.
We also considered the case of small mass and calculated the particle production rate and energy flux near the horizon.
We found that even in De Sitter space, the energy flux becomes a positive value, which contradicts the conjecture of cosmic no-hair.
Why do we care about Hawking radiation from the de Sitter space black holes?

The AdS/CFT correspondence was proposed by M. M. Roberts, V. A. Hubeny, C. Ranganathan, and E. Funcatsbooks.com, linking gravitational theory in higher-dimensional anti-de Sitter space with conformal field theory in physical spacetime.
Since then, there have been many studies on quantum effects in AdS space, such as black holes and cosmological horizons.

One reason for studying the effects of quantum gravity in Anti-de Sitter (AdS) space is to understand higher-dimensional gravity itself from the perspective of lower-dimensional conformal field theory (CFT).
On the other hand, the cosmological constant in the universe is very small but non-zero.
Some scholars have suggested that the quantum effects of gravity may produce a positive cosmological constant.
This means that the AdS space corresponds to an inflationary universe.
Therefore, studying quantum effects in the anti-de Sitter space provides a possible way to explain the small but non-zero cosmological constant.
However, AdS space has timelike curvature, so the physics in the boundary CFT does not have a time direction.
This means that since Hawking radiation is a process that originates from the boundary in the past, it will not affect conformal field theory (CFT).
Therefore, it is not possible to discuss the cosmic no-hair conjecture from the perspective of AdS/CFT correspondence.
The Universe No-Hair Conjecture is about whether black holes should have the same conserved quantities as the universe in an expanding universe.
Therefore, it is very necessary to study Hawking radiation in the anti-de Sitter space.
In quantum mechanics, the spectrum of the eigenvalues of the angular momentum (AM) and linear momentum (PM) operators is much broader than the range allowed by classical physics.

For example, in a given quantum state, the eigenvalue of the square of the total angular momentum operator is proportional to the total nuclear spin, which is a theoretically infinite resolution property.

In addition, in the given quantum state, the eigenvalue of the square of the total linear momentum operator is equal to the square of the reciprocal of the reduced Planck constant, which is a physically observable property with theoretically infinite precision.

Because these quantities are numerically equal to the total angular momentum (AM) and total momentum (PM) of the quantum state, this study concludes that quantum mechanics indeed follows the angular momentum and momentum properties expected from classical physics.
These extraordinary results stem from rigorous mathematical theorems in the field of quantum mechanics, which demonstrate that the eigenvalues of these operators are theoretically infinite.
Classical physics indicates that the values of these operators are constrained by the product of the reduced Planck constant and the spatial dimensions corresponding to the system.

In a given quantum state, the eigenvalue of the square of the total angular momentum operator is equal to the square of the reciprocal of the reduced Planck constant, which is an observable physical property with theoretically infinite precision.

Due to the fact that these quantities are numerically equal to the total angular momentum and total positive energy of the quantum state, this study concludes that quantum mechanics does indeed adhere to the angular momentum and positive energy properties expected from classical physics.

Similarly, under a given quantum mechanical state, the expectation value of the square of the total angular momentum operator is equal to the reduced kernel spin of that quantum state, a property that theoretically has no upper limit.

In addition, in the given quantum state, the expectation value of the square of the total momentum operator equals the reduced Planck constant, which is a physical observable with theoretically infinite precision.

Because these quantities are numerically equal to the reduced nuclear spin and the reduced Planck constant, this study concludes that quantum mechanics follows the expected angular momentum (AM) and momentum (PM) properties from classical physics.

In the cosmic ray acceleration paradigm under the impact of cosmic rays, it is widely believed that supernova remnants (SNRs) accelerate hadrons to high energies, while electrons and positrons are often restricted to lower energies.

Although electrons and positrons are often described as "secondary particles" produced by hadron-hadron interactions, observations of the Galactic SNR W28 reveal an electron-positron spectral component that extends to GeV energies.
However, particles that undergo only angle-dipping scattering in the unit simulation of hadrons (π+ + π–) do not adequately describe this high-energy component.

We found that adding a low-energy electron-positron component (composed of a pool at 100 MeV and a tail at 10 GeV) to simulations that only include hadronic components is sufficient to match the observed electron and positron fluxes, as well as the ratio of electrons to protons.
This observation is surprising because previous studies involving only hadronic scenarios did not address such low-energy electron-positron components.

We speculate that cosmic rays undergo self-similar evolution, possessing quasi-parallel low-energy components that can effectively develop under the impact modified by the ubiquitous cosmic ray populations.
If this is the case, this low-energy electron-positron component may provide a more easily observable signature of cosmic ray impacts.
The spectrum of the broad-spectrum, wide-line radio galaxy 3C 445 was simultaneously observed by the European Photon Imaging Camera (EPIC) and the Nuclear Spectroscopic Telescope Array (NuSTAR).
The data analysis presented in this study focuses on the last 15 months of Suzaku X-ray data, covering the time period from April 2013 to September 2014.

This time interval includes two major eruptions and a deep decline in X-ray flux. This phenomenon is particularly noteworthy as it may be related to the enhanced infrared radiation event observed by the Spitzer telescope.

During this period, Suzaku X-ray data indicated a strong neutral iron K emission around 6.4 keV, significant atomic oxygen emissions between 54 and 72 keV, as well as emissions from neon and magnesium between 14 and 30 keV. The features of neutral and low-ionized iron and oxygen radiation are consistent with the remnants of the black hole's accretion disk, while the high-ionized radiation is associated with synchrotron radiation from jets and possibly inverse Compton scattering.

We also detected narrow helium-like and hydrogen-like oxygen and neon spectral lines, which may be caused by the radiation from high-energy particles produced in the jets interacting with the cold disk.
This is the first detection of high-ionization emissions from oxygen, neon, and magnesium in 3C 445.

We speculate that the increase in radiation observed in the 14–30 keV range during the Suzaku observation period may be due to the electron cyclotron resonance scattering of thermal microwave radiation from the enhanced activity phase of the radio jet.
Astronomers using HATNet visual observations have discovered a binary star system HAT-TR-205-013, which consists of one star and a massive dark companion star.
High-precision radial velocity measurements confirm that the companion is a dark star, rather than a star or substellar object.
The minimum companion mass is determined to be 65 Jupiter masses (M$_{JUP}$), and the companion's radius is 7.2 Jupiter radii (R$_{JUP}$). The density of the companion is 6.7 x 10^{5} kg/m^{3}.
The existence of low-density dark stars enables them to remain stable under nuclear reactions.
The HATNet team has discovered eight extra systems with similar dark companions.
The "HAT-P-27" system will be introduced in future papers.

This work was presented in preliminary form at the Laser Astrophysics and Technology Conference in New Mexico, USA (March 13-17, 2013) and at the International Astronomical Union General Assembly in Moscow, Russia (September 20, 2013).
Non-stationary random acoustic fields and electromagnetic fields as wave diffusion processes.

The measurement was taken in a turbulent bubble with a relative speed of 225 meters per second. The analysis based on this theory allows us to derive the statistical properties of the micro-scale vortices that cause unsteadiness.
The results are in good agreement with the characteristics of the measured field.

The measurements were taken near a turbulent bubble with a relative speed of 225 meters per second. The analysis within this theoretical framework allows us to derive the statistical characteristics of the micro-scale vortices that cause the non-stationarity.
The results are consistent with the characteristics of the measured field.
Non-stationary random acoustic and electromagnetic fields as wave diffusion processes.

The measurement was conducted near a turbulent bubble at a relative speed of 225 m/s. The analysis within this theoretical framework allows us to derive the statistical characteristics of the microscale vortices that lead to unsteady states.
The results are in good agreement with the characteristics of the measured field.

As an alternative to traditional RF quality control equipment design, the DAFNE baseline design incorporates an Ion Clearing Electrode (ICE) in the feedback loop to mitigate the effects of RF-induced beam rotation and energy spread.
The results obtained with the ICE inserted into the feedback loop indicate that the beam energy and stability have improved compared to the DAFNE baseline performance without ICE.

However, the ICE-induced feedback component in the focusing element will cause significant changes in the beam trajectory, which need to be mitigated by adjusting the feedback offset based on the wavefront sensor.
This article reports the results of the impact of ICE on the beam dynamics of DAFNE.

This paper first outlines the concept and design of DAFNE, then describes ICE, its impact on the baseline performance of DAFNE, and various methods to mitigate the effects of ICE. Finally, it discusses the implications of these different mitigation methods on beam dynamics.
The paper concludes with a discussion on the stability of the achieved beam and the trade-offs involved in different mitigation methods.
A chain boson model has been proposed to explain the decoherence and relaxation phenomena of weakly coupled SQUIDs in a phonon bath.
The model includes a set of oscillators coupled to low-energy modes of the environment, which are modeled as a chain of harmonic oscillators.

The decoherence and relaxation caused by the phonon bath can be effectively described by a pure decay process, with the rate determined by the spectral density of the bath and the dimensionless coupling constant between the central system and the bath.

Especially when the dimensionless coupling constant is small, the dynamics of the system can be roughly described by the Lindblad equation, from which one can understand the energy relaxation and decoherence phenomena of the coupled SQUID.
The theory can be applied to study the decoherence and relaxation phenomena in other mixed systems composed of several coupled quantum systems and harmonic oscillator chains.
The model can also be used to study the quantum effects of a coupled SQUID system immersed in a bosonic bath.
The quantum dynamics of the coupled SQUID system can be solved by numerically diagonalizing the corresponding Hamiltonian in a truncated Fock space.
As an example, we studied a phase qubit (coupled SQUID system) that is located in a linearly coupled chain, capable of simulating two-dimensional correlated dynamics.

The numerical simulation results show that when the chain length is even and the magnetic flux applied to the quantum bit circuit is close to half a magnetic quantum, two-dimensional quantum chaos occurs.

The velocity structure of the solar corona is of great significance for understanding the processes occurring in this dynamic environment.
Due to the typically weak coronal ejections and the broadening caused by the high speed of the material, it is difficult to observe the complete velocity characteristics of the solar wind.
Therefore, a large number of studies have analyzed the line wings or line center of coronal emission lines to determine the characteristics of the plasma.
In this study, we combined data from the EUV spectrometer (ESA/SOHO), the EUV imager (SECCHI/SIBYNTES), and HIA/SDO to determine the velocity distribution of coronal outflow lines over a wide range.

We found that the coronal plasma moves at supersonic speeds, ranging from 900 kilometers per second to over 1,000 kilometers per second, and that the speeds observed within a single coronal loop show significant variation.
By analyzing this scatter plot, we can determine that Alfven waves are likely propagating along the loop.

In 3728-3741, May 2019, the pioneering work of Koetter and Hoeky (KD III) proposed Gaussian layered broadcasting coding with gradual improvements.
The idea is to divide the source message into multiple layers, assuming perfect knowledge of the lower layer headers, and to encode these layers using longer block lengths.
These headers have been further encoded, assuming incomplete knowledge of the lower-layer headers, and therefore a shorter length has been adopted.

The result encoding rate was conveniently optimized on a Gaussian distribution, leading to an optimal layered coding strategy that can achieve a performance close to 1 bit per channel use in many interested channels, approaching the capacity of the underlying multi-user discrete memoryless channel (DMMC).
However, continuous refinement often leads to accumulated distortion, and this distortion increases with the length of the encoding block.
Specifically, for a DMMC with memory size K, when the block length does not exceed (the so-called maximum delay), the distortion can be proven to increase linearly with the block length.
"When the block length exceeds (the so-called delay-limited region), the distortion can be shown to increase at most linearly with the block length."
The exact slope within the delay limit range, referred to as the delay range slope, has only been determined in a few DMMC examples.

From this work, we provide general results regarding the slope of the delay-limited region, which has been shown to align with the latest known results in several specific examples, including hyper-label broadcast channels (HLC) and Gaussian multicast (MUSIC) with continuous refinement.

The spectral line intensities of several key molecules have been measured in molecular clouds located in different galactic environments.
These include the rotational thermal spectra lines of CO, which is an excellent tracer for molecular hydrogen, as well as the rotational thermal spectra lines of HCN, CS, and CO isotopes.
The conversion factor is derived from the relationship between line intensity and the properties of molecular clouds, such as mass, temperature, and density.
The derived factors are specific to different types of galaxies, with factors provided for Sa, Sb, Sc, Sd, and irregular galaxies (Irr).
Research shows that the spectral line intensity of CO, HCN, and their isotopes can serve as quantitative measures of the mass of molecular clouds.
The derived factors are specific to different types of galaxies and provide corresponding data for Sa, Sb, Sc, Sd, and irregular galaxies (Irr).
Research shows that the spectral line intensities of CO, HCN, and their isotopes can serve as quantitative indicators of molecular cloud mass.
The rapid emissions of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are typically attributed to the synchrotron radiation of highly relativistic jets.
However, the exact emission mechanisms are still unknown.
Although the broadband afterglow phase usually extends into infrared or optical frequencies, the instantaneous phase typically peaks in the gamma-ray band.
Therefore, it is very important to study instantaneous radiation and residual radiation separately.
Here, we report the broadband afterglow and fast radiation of the bright burst GRB 061121.
The afterglow phase covers the optical, ultraviolet, and X-ray bands, and can be well described by a single power law.
In the gamma-ray band, rapid emissions can be well described by the Band function.
The low-frequency and high-frequency platforms are markers of the Band function, corresponding to the optical attenuation phase and the X-ray attenuation phase, respectively.
This means that there is a physical connection between the prompt and the afterglow emission.
We discuss the impact of this result on the mechanism of rapid phase launching.
The phenomenon of photon flame was first observed in the laboratory by M. Tsubouchi and S. A. Dutta in 2006.
This effect is caused by the instability of the luminous conical line flame induced by slight uneven thermal convection.
This instability is manifested in the thinning and branching of the flames, forming complex patterns that can be observed with the naked eye under bright light.
We observed three significant characteristics of photon flames through high-speed photography.
First, there is a brief delay between the onset of the temperature gradient at the top of the branch and the beginning of luminescence at that top.
This behavior can be observed in the video clips linked within the text.
Secondly, flame branching can be induced by local heating of nearby wires.
It has also been observed in the video editing.
Thirdly, if the stable flame tip is illuminated from behind by sufficiently bright light, then this light can be "reflected" from the front surface of the flame.
This "hyperplane" reflection is also very obvious in the video.
Grassmann algebra is an algebra established on a vector space, characterized by the fact that its subspaces form a right ideal.
In this article, we first introduce the concept of the partial differential operator, which is a anti-linear mapping that satisfies the Leibniz rule and properties of derivatives.
Then, by defining the kernel of the oblique mapping, we extend the concept of orthogonal vectors to arbitrary vectors and derive the fundamental properties of the oblique inner product.
Finally, in an application, we provide another proof of the associative law of Grassmann algebra.
The concept of partial derivatives was first proposed by E.C. Getto in 1965.
In late 1972, A. M. Bin Oljoin and M. B. Semenov provided another definition of partial derivatives and applied it to various fields of mathematics.
Through this article, we conduct a detailed study of partial derivatives and partially differentiable mappings, and apply them to Grassmann algebra.
In this article, we introduce a quasi-exactly solvable (QES) spin chain that includes nearest-neighbor interactions.
The Hamiltonian of the chain can be decomposed into a sum of commuting two-site terms.
We demonstrate that the spectrum of the chain consists of a set of doubly-degenerate band gaps and a set of non-degenerate band gaps.
In addition, we derived the total number of energy bands and their corresponding wave functions.
Finally, we apply the Yang-Baxter equation to analyze the spectrum of the entire spin chain.
We can achieve our chain by using ultracold atoms (either bosons or fermions) or photons in an optical lattice.

It will be very interesting to study the nature of the research chain and the method proposed in this paper through numerical methods, and the relationship between these and the models studied in the literature.
In this article, we introduce a new class of exactly solvable (QES) spin chains with nearest-neighbor interactions.
The Hamiltonian of the chain can be decomposed into a sum of a series of two-site terms, which commute with each other.
We demonstrated that the spectrum of this chain consists of a set of doubly degenerate bands of eigenvalues and a set of non-degenerate bands of eigenvalues.
In addition, we derive the total number of energy bands and the corresponding wave functions.
Finally, we apply the Yang-Baxter equation to analyze the spectrum of the entire spin chain.
Our chain can be realized by using ultracold atoms, bosons, or fermions in optical lattices, or by conducting experiments with photons.

It will be interesting to study the nature of the research chain and the method proposed in this article through numerical methods, as well as to explore its relationship with the models studied in the literature.
QEL, which stands for Quasi-Elastic process, is a type of inelastic interaction of neutrinos that leads to minor nuclear excitations.
The "fully contained" events and "partially contained" events are two main categories of neutrino interaction types detected in the Super-Kamiokande experiment.
By utilizing the electron number density distribution of the near detector, we found that QEL can explain fully contained events but cannot explain partially contained events.
Therefore, we can conclude that for fully contained events, the direction of the neutrinos is reliable, but for partially contained events, it is not reliable.

The complete paper can be found here: https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.08031. I also provided a brief video explanation about this result: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aU4tpuUqK-Q. If you have any questions, please feel free to let me know.
This article presents the surface brightness distribution of globular clusters from 27 located in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC), the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC), and the Fornax galaxy.
A globular cluster is a collection of millions of stars bound together by gravitational forces.
Due to the very compact nature of stars in globular clusters, the light emitted by individual stars can significantly affect their surface brightness profile.

Therefore, accurately measuring the surface brightness distribution of globular clusters is crucial for studying their structural parameters, especially their half-mass radius, which can be used to constrain the half-light radius of their host galaxies.
In this study, we obtained $VI$ images of the globular clusters using the photometric system of the CTIO 0.9-meter telescope.
A PSF fitting program was used to measure the surface brightness of the star cluster, and the resulting profile is shown here.

These profiles are displayed for two radius ranges, one centered on the half-mass radius and the other centered on the half-light radius. Fitting has been performed using truncated isothermal spheres, logarithmic spheres, and generalized Sérsic models.
In the Fornax globular cluster, the general Sersic profile provides the best fit to the data.

Generally speaking, the surface brightness distribution of globular clusters in these three galaxies follows the same overall trend, where the globular clusters in Fornax have the steepest brightness distribution, the globular clusters in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) have a brightness distribution that falls between those of Fornax and the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC), while the globular clusters in the Small Magellanic Cloud have the shallowest brightness distribution.
In the globular clusters of a given galaxy, the surface brightness at a specific radius often increases with the total luminosity of the galaxy.
The leaf veins are a beautiful example of a highly branched and complex hierarchical vascular network that protects plants from drought, high light intensity, and insect attacks.
Although the venation of leaves has significant aesthetic and functional importance, the process of leaf vein formation is a challenging issue, as it involves multiple length and time scales.

Although it was initially assumed that secondary cells would only undergo patterning after they were noticeably different in morphology from the primary cells, it is now clear that secondary cells begin to undergo patterning before they are visibly different in morphology from the primary cells.
The signaling pathway responsible for the formation of this pattern has recently been identified as a new type of cellular heterogeneity: elastic stress.
The occurrence of the leaf vein morphology in this elastic stress signal theory can be universal and applicable to hierarchical vascular networks of other branches.
The elastic stress signal is a mechanism recently proposed for the formation of leaf vein patterns.

The initial assumption was that subsidiary cells would only form patterns after they were significantly different in morphology from the principal cells, but it is now clear that subsidiary cells can form patterns even before they are morphologically distinct from the principal cells.
The signaling pathway responsible for the formation of this pattern has recently been identified as a new type of intercellular heterogeneity: elastic stress.
The theoretical venous morphological development of this elastic stress signal can be universally applicable and is suitable for blood vessel networks at other branch levels.
We studied the phenomena of electromagnetic shocks and wave soliton excitations in two-dimensional electron gases (2DEGs).
Based on this, we consider the nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) equation and the two-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) equations with finite resistivity.
Using analytical and numerical techniques, we reveal that the excitation of nonlinear waves can occur under different parameters.

We have demonstrated that it is possible to excite electromagnetic non-dispersive shock waves even in an isotropic plasma, where the electron flow velocity and the magnetic field have equal amplitudes.

Through numerical simulations, we found that the possibility of this phenomenon arises from the effects of symmetry breaking. Specifically, if the plasma is uniformly magnetized in one direction, it may lead to the generation of electromagnetic shock waves in any direction within the isotropic plasma.

In addition, we have demonstrated that within the framework of the nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) equation and magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), solitary waves similar to electromagnetic waves can be generated when the amplitude of the flow velocity and magnetic field are different.
We have revealed that these wave-shaped solitons are dispersive within the framework of the NLS equation, while they are non-dispersive in the two-dimensional MHD equations with finite resistivity.

In our work, we used the same method that had previously been applied to the study of the excitation of nonlinear waves in two-component Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) with repulsive and attractive interactions.

Therefore, our current research is the first attempt to investigate the excitation of nonlinear waves in an isotropic two-dimensional electron gas and a binary plasma consisting of particles with both repulsive and attractive interactions.
This paper proposes a formula for yield stress design that uses an approximate pressure field and "failure calculation under flow conditions" in a pore hydraulic system.
The approximation of the stress field is based on a solution proposed in reference [1] and has been validated in various examples.
This work presents a unique approach that can be applied to a wide range of problems.
As an example, this formula is applied to a problem involving water-saturated soil under the action of water flow.
The yield surface is constructed as a penalty function for the absolute value of the difference between the local equivalent saturation and the desired value.
The difference between actual pressure and applied pressure is referred to as "enthalpy."
The obtained results were compared with those obtained from the classical solution based on "fracture calculations under flowing phenomena."
The proposed method is more realistic from a hydraulic perspective, and it reduces the number of iterations required to achieve stability.
Animal behavior is usually regulated by changes in the sense of security within the surrounding environment.
The organism's response to danger may have a profound impact on its fitness.
Animals usually adjust their behavior based on aversive stimuli, such as intense heat or severe injury.
Here, we propose a neural dynamic model that captures the learning and decision-making processes involved behind such behavioral plasticity.
Our framework assigns a value to each behavioral response based on the probability mapping to the outcome, represented as a multivariate normal distribution.
These values are updated through a variant of comparative estimation that allows the model to take into account both positive and negative reinforcement simultaneously.
The model can be applied to a wide range of behavioral optimization problems, and we illustrate its application by using it in scenarios that impose conflicting demands on biological behavior.

The model predicts that mice exposed to threatening stimuli will exhibit an initial rapid behavioral response, but will ultimately optimize their behavior, specifically measured through time-averaged heat loss, while adapting to gradually changing optimal conditions.

In addition, we also demonstrate that the model can explain heat-induced analgesia by calculating the probability distribution of expected pain intensity, which is one of the most significant examples of behavioral plasticity.

Therefore, our model is capable of generating accurate predictions about how organisms respond to danger, providing a foundation for understanding how behavioral flexibility arises from a Bayesian optimization framework, in which the outcomes are predicted using neural networks.

In addition, this model can explain the phenomenon of heat-induced analgesia, which is one of the most significant examples of behavioral plasticity.

Therefore, our model is able to accurately predict how organisms respond to threats, providing a basis for understanding how behavioral flexibility arises from a Bayesian optimization framework, in which outcomes are predicted through neural networks.
