The model provides a foundation for understanding the behavioral flexibility of various organisms, ranging from invertebrates to vertebrates, including mice and monkeys.
The plasma ring surrounding Io, the smallest of Jupiter's four Galilean moons, has been the subject of numerous observations over the past few decades.
Voyager, Galileo, and Cassini all observed the plasma ring, but only Cassini had the capability to perform ultraviolet (UV) measurements.

We conducted an analysis of the observational data from the Cassini Ultraviolet Imaging Spectrograph (UVIS) from December 2000 to May 2006, exploring the temporal and spatial variability of the rings.

The model for the plasma ring emission should consider thermal effects, non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (non-LTE) ionization and excitation, free electrons, as well as electron impact excitation and ionization.
We compared two models: one is a double fluid model that successfully simulates the global atmosphere of Europa, and the other is a hydrodynamic model.
Although the dual-flow model is usually sufficient for simulating the thermal and outer layers of Io, it cannot simulate the plasma torus of Io.
The hydrodynamic model has successfully simulated the plasma ring, but it cannot explain the emission variations observed by Cassini.
This indicates that the variability of the plasma ring is caused by changes in the mass flux entering the ring.
We conducted a detailed study of 47 galaxy clusters, which have a signal-to-noise ratio greater than 10 and are located within the cz < 5000 km/s range in the DR4 spectral sample.

We measured the properties of global clusters, namely X-ray temperature, Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect temperature, brightness and radius, velocity dispersion, mass, as well as temperature from spectroscopic and Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect data.
In addition, we measured the mass of the intra-cluster gas from the X-ray data.
The global attributes are obtained through the use of predictive parameterization and three-dimensional models, and comparisons have been made.
We also estimated the total mass through velocity dispersion, assuming that these clusters are relaxed systems.
The speed diffusion is calculated through the combination of optical components and spectral components.
We compared the total mass derived from X-ray and velocity dispersion.
The global properties of these star clusters have been studied through X-rays, the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect, and optical data.
All these results are summarized in this article.
Astronomers using the Chandra X-ray Observatory conducted the deepest-ever survey of the universe in the X-ray spectrum.
In the Chandra Deep Field South (CDF-S), they detected 740 sources, of which 122 are active galactic nuclei (AGN) emitting X-rays.
Deep spectroscopy shows that about half of the X-ray emitting active galactic nuclei in CDF-S are completely absorbed in the visible light band and can only be observed in X-rays.
This enables us to study the average obscuration characteristics of the universe in the early evolutionary stages of distant galaxies, which is crucial for understanding how galaxies grow.
At \( z=2-4 \), CDF-S contains a well-known sample of the most uniformly selected distant obscured active galactic nuclei (AGNs).
These are the sources of most metals in the early universe, and thus are crucial for understanding the reionization of the universe.
In the CDF-S, the total amount of material obscured by gas is estimated to be about four times the mass of the Milky Way, with individual masses reaching up to 10^22 M⊙.
If we assume the average molecular weight of the gas is about 0.5, this is equivalent to around one trillion solar masses of material concentrated in just a few sources.
As we approach the peak of galaxy assembly in the early universe, these sources are ideal laboratories for studying the evolution of gas and dust in the cosmos.

This paper presents the kinematic design of a three-degree-of-freedom hybrid robotic hand, which includes rotation kinematics based on dual quaternions and a novel three-degree-of-freedom serpentine structure for the motion of the end effector.
The proposed structure integrates the advantages of dual quaternions and a 3-degree-of-freedom snake-like manipulator, making it more concise and easier to integrate with complex control algorithms.
The proposed hybrid manipulator combines a 3-degree-of-freedom serpentine structure with rotational kinematics, enabling greater flexibility and agility.
In this paper, the hybrid configuration is first constructed using quaternion-based rotational kinematics, which provides a flexible and compact representation.
Then, a new three-degree-of-freedom serpentine structure was proposed, which can achieve a greater range of motion, thereby balancing flexibility and dexterity in hybrid manipulators.
To facilitate kinematic analysis and synthesis, the singularity of the hybrid manipulator was analyzed, and a series of singular transformations were developed.
Provided two numerical examples to verify the effectiveness of the proposed hybrid manipulator.
A simulation study was conducted to explore the structure of the boundary layer between a white dwarf and its accretion disk.
We solve the Euler equations of fluid dynamics, including the self-gravitation of gases and the nuclear energy generation term in the energy equation.
These equations are solved in a Cartesian grid domain, with dimensions of 1000 x 1000 x 300 times the Schwarzschild radius of a white dwarf.
The proposed model explores the impact of varying the intensity of nuclear energy production and the mass flux through the internal boundary.
The research found that in all models, a sufficiently strong nuclear energy generation term would lead to the formation of a transitional shock wave at the inner diameter boundary.
In addition, it was found that a moderate mass flux through the inner boundary would lead to the formation of a persistent boundary layer structure.
In particular, we found that the presence of the boundary layer greatly changed the emission spectrum of the system.
It is expected to lead to the appearance of double peak emission lines, such as the C III emission lines detected in the cataclysmic variable star AE Aquarii.
We also found that there are significant supersonic motions in the boundary layer, which may explain the persistent broad line components observed in some systems.

The simulations presented in this study were conducted using AMRAII, which is a three-dimensional, resistive hydrodynamics simulation code developed at the Max Planck Institute for Astrophysics in Garching, Germany.
Long-range order in simple metals and covalent solids is typically associated with the presence of one or more periodic structural arrangements.
These periodicities can be described using the classical diffraction methods of Bragg and Robert-Kansel.

For this work, we employed a newly developed direct spatial mapping technique to determine the short-range ordered spatial distribution in two systems that exhibit strong long-range order: charge density waves and high-temperature superconductors.
The generated ordering pattern is different from the short-range order theory of traditional solid-state crystallography or the predictive rules of lattices.
On the contrary, these short-range orderly spatial arrangements seem to exhibit the characteristics of two-dimensional coordination polymers—a type of material that lacks long-range order.

This surprising result indicates that either the traditional short-range order theory should be complemented by some form of long-range order, or the short-range order observed in these systems arises from some as-yet-undetermined mechanism.
The triangulation of Catalan intervals and the convex hull of point sets in the plane have been studied since the 1990s.
There are eight different types of universal triangulations, depending on the number of points, the distances between the points, and their spatial arrangement.
For this article, we analyze the implementers of all these common types.
The implementer of the triangulation is the edge list of the simple polyhedron, which defines the same homology class as the original triangulation.
They can be constructed algorithmically based on the given topological space.
The knowledge of all implementers of the given triangulation is very useful for many geometric, topological, and computational applications.
We identify all possible realizers in the eight general types of triangulations.
We found that the total number of different sets of implementers is 46.
This article also provides a Java software implementation for computing a given triangulation.

In this letter, we explore the possibility that four-dimensional (4D) gravity may appear as a warped metric of a five-dimensional (5D) anti-de Sitter (AdS) space in a supersymmetric brane-world model.
In this case, the observable universe is regarded as a three-dimensional brane, which is a domain wall existing in anti-de Sitter space.
To eliminate the instability of domain wall curvature, a bulk scalar field has been introduced.
This field is called the chameleon field, which couples to the world volume of the membrane through Israeli coupling, where the coupling strength is related to the membrane tension.
By analyzing the equation of motion, we obtain conditions regarding membrane tension and volume potential, in order to achieve healthy stable four-dimensional gravity in the low-energy limit.
By using these conditions, we demonstrate that the mass of Planck particles can be naturally generated.
"We also studied the possibility of supersymmetry breaking on the membrane."
To this end, we introduce explicit (F) and soft (D) breaking terms into the membrane supergravity Lagrangian.

We indicate that, in the absence of explicit symmetry breaking, all scalar masses are determined solely by the brane tension and the graviton mass; therefore, these scalar masses are naturally of the same order of magnitude as the graviton mass.
Through explicit breaking, if certain conditions are satisfied on the soft parameters, the scalar mass can naturally be of the first order.
Our results indicate that in order to explain the four-dimensional gravity we experience from a five-dimensional fundamental theory, that theory may be supersymmetric on the membrane.

The spontaneous symmetry breaking in the membrane naturally explains the hierarchy problem between the Planck scale and the electroweak scale, without needing to assume large extra dimensions, thereby providing a reasonable explanation for the low fundamental gravity scale.
In this paper, we study the correlation between energy density and the flux of two different observables under an unusual quantum state known as the macro-quantum state (MQS).
These correlations were initially discovered in the MQT of a double-clamped microcantilever and were interpreted as a hallmark of quantum characteristics.
We will extend this analysis to other mechanical resonators made of different materials and geometries.
We show that under the same set of parameters, the correlation between flux and energy density appears in quasi-static quantum states (MQS) and in vacuum.
We believe that these correlations cannot be explained by standard decoherence and feedback models.
We presented experimental data and established a phenomenological model that accurately describes the correlation of MQS.
The correlation between the observed flux and energy density may have profound implications for quantum information processing and thermodynamics in mechanical systems.
Participating organizations/groups: Vinay Malvimat, Rahul Mishra, and Vitaliy Negelyaev (submitted to QST)

The Gamma-Ray Imaging Instrument (GRI) is a gamma-ray astronomical mission that has been selected by the European Space Agency (ESA) as a technical development plan (TDP) initiative for implementation.
The GRI technology demonstrator was successfully launched on January 5, 2021, by a Pegasus 2 rocket, with the launch site located at Cape Canaveral, Florida, USA.
GRI is the first small body participation module (SB PM) in the larger Artemis program.
GRI is a compact and lightweight gamma-ray astronomy mission aimed at detecting and characterizing gamma-ray emissions from solar system bodies.
It will install a set of experiments on the Moon to study the gamma-ray emissions from the lunar surface, the Earth-Moon system, and the Sun.
The gamma-ray astronomical instrument consists of soft gamma-ray detectors and neutron detectors.

The gamma-ray detector is based on Compton imaging technology, which combines data from incoming gamma-ray photons and Compton scattering events to create a two-dimensional image of the gamma-ray distribution in a region.
These images will provide information about the chemical composition, internal structure, and spatial distribution of the target within the field of view.
The neutron detector measures the neutrons released from the interactions of gamma rays with the binding energy of the materials.
GRI will provide key information to understand the high-energy emissions of various celestial bodies, including their composition, structure, and dynamics.
The GRI also has the potential to provide new scientific knowledge about the lunar environment, while allowing for the characterization of potential emissions into the lunar gamma ray environment.

A few hours before the rapid increase in solar activity, two areas of strong magnetic field rotation appeared near the center of the Sun, accompanied by the disappearance of the surrounding area (these observations were made using the solar images from the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory, SOHO).
These two regions with strong magnetic fields that rotate are regarded as magnetically active areas.
These areas rotated about 90 degrees relative to each other over the course of four days.
A characteristic of certain active regions is that they produce areas of strong magnetic field rotation, a phenomenon known as flaring, which appears to be temporary.
It was observed that between June 14 and June 17, 2002, these active regions produced two flares of X10 and X8 levels, recorded by the X-ray emissions from the solar atmosphere.

The active regions observed in each hemisphere show two areas of disappearing magnetic fields at the edges, as well as two regions of strong magnetic fields rotating in the central part of the Sun, exhibiting characteristics of emerging edges.
Therefore, it can be seen that these active regions have temporarily generated two zones of strong magnetic field rotation, which, as mentioned earlier, are considered magnetic active regions.
These areas rotated approximately 90 degrees relative to each other over the course of four days.
"Valency is an important concept in chemistry, physics, and biology, referring to the valence state formed by atoms or molecules through multi-site bonding."
Aromatic molecules such as benzene only allow for single bonding (due to symmetry, branched bonding is prohibited), therefore only a valence state of 2 is permitted.
However, many other molecules, such as porphyrins and protein kinases, may have multi-site binding.
Molecules with a higher valence state exhibit non-classical reactivity.
For example, the heme protein involved in electron transfer reactions, such as cytochrome c, has a valence state of 4.
In this study, we treat a seven-valent protein kinase—casein kinase II—as a multivalent attachment for analysis.
Our analytical approach is based on the Wenzel-Kramers-Brillouin (WKB) approximation, which is suitable for reactions involving high-valence molecules.
First, we use the Savage formula to calculate the entropy of multi-site attachments.
Then, we analyze the flux term under the WKB approximation, which controls the flux of electrons flowing from the reactants into the reaction.
We found that, despite having a high valence state, the kinase follows the common substrate-vesicle model for electron flow.
Due to the increase in entropy being proportional to the square of the valence states, it can be very high in multivalent reactions.

The large-scale structure (LSS) of the universe today shows a complex spatial distribution of galaxies that appears random, with an amplitude of several tens of millions of light-years at low redshift.
This "cosmic web" is a powerful cosmological tool that, in combination with other cosmological measurements, is helping to clarify the nature of dark energy.
As the largest nonlinear structure in the universe, LSS is strongly dependent on the combination of matter density and dark energy density.

We conducted a comprehensive LSS analysis of the latest cosmological simulations using the halo model and the Liang-Molecular method, including state-of-the-art simulations (such as Auriga and Illustris) as well as classic simulations (such as the Millennium Simulation and GHALO).

We then use five popular parameterizations of dark energy to modify the evolution of the linear growth factor and the evolution of the root-mean-square fluctuations of the matter density field in order to predict the formation epoch of halos and their impact on the shape of the galaxy power spectrum.

We found that in future surveys, such as Euclid and the WFIRST mission, the amplitude of the galaxy power spectrum can break the degeneracy between five different dark energy models with an accuracy of 0.5%.

The Synergistic Effects in Eukaryotic Gene Regulation: Physical Properties of Viral Examples  
Richard A. Lenski, Jeffrey M. Feldman, Craig M. Peñalosa  
arXiv.org e-print arXiv:1603.00711 [physics.gen-ph, March 14, 2016]
In this paper, we discuss a conceptually simple, well-controlled, and quantifiable model for studying gene regulation in eukaryotes.
The regulatory region of the copy number control area of viral DNA is described as a mathematically idealized one-dimensional single-stranded polymer.
Individual viral genomes occupy positions within this one-dimensional chain and exert positional effects on the transcription initiation rate of host RNA polymerase II.
According to the description of the rate equation, the general behavior of this gene regulation system can be understood by considering the probability of polymerase binding to specific sites.

For appropriately chosen physics-based parameters, we demonstrate that the system exhibits cooperative behavior—specifically, the probability of binding at nearby sites increases compared to simply adding independent probabilities.

The relative probability of cooperative binding depends on the chain length, valence state (which increases the number of neighboring binding sites that enhance the probability through interactions), and temperature.
We discuss the impact of these observations on biological systems.
In summary, we proposed a physics-based eukaryotic gene regulation model, in which synergistic effects play a central role.
This physical concept has long attracted attention in other biological systems, and here it reveals its importance in the regulation of eukaryotic genes.
The difference between our model and other models lies in its clear physical foundation and the quantitative description of its behavior.
It makes specific predictions about the effects of chain length, valence state, temperature, and sequence on the probability of cooperative binding.
These predictions can be directly tested against existing data and the results of other models.
Our model also suggests some testable experimental designs to explore the role of synergistic interactions in eukaryotic gene regulation.

Our research results indicate that cooperative interactions are an important physical basis for understanding gene regulation in eukaryotic organisms and may play a similar role in other biological systems.

Gene expression is essentially random, while gene regulation focuses on changing this randomness to achieve the desired outcome.
Gene expression is a highly focused area of research.

This makes it possible to implement optical erasable floating gate transistors using techniques similar to electrically erasable floating gate transistors, which have potential applications in logic, storage, and imaging in digital computing.

Based on the configuration of magnetic tunnel junctions (MTJs), this structure consists of a MgO tunnel layer sandwiched between two ferromagnetic layers (the tunnel layer and the reference layer), providing a pathway for high-density magnetic storage and magnetic logic.

In a conventional (CPP) magnetic tunnel junction, the spin-polarized current flowing through the interface between the ferromagnet and the tunnel junction generates a spin-transfer torque (STT), which can rotate the magnetization direction of the free ferromagnetic layer.
For magnetic tunnel junctions, this effect can be used to write information by manipulating the magnetic direction of the reference layer.
Here, we report a new technique to characterize spin-transfer torque (STT)-based magnetic memory by measuring the spin-transfer torque vector rather than the STT vector itself.
This technology utilizes an improved Hanle effect to measure the projection of the spin transfer torque (STT) vector in the direction of the applied magnetic field.
We applied this technology to MTJ and measured the projection of the spin transfer torque (STT) vector onto the x-axis, which is parallel to the easy axis of the free ferromagnetic layer.
The symbol of this projection is referred to as sxt, indicating whether the effective field is applied from the positive side or the negative side of the easy axis.

We observed that the sxt is relatively large under the application of a positive magnetic field, corresponding to the "in-plane" configuration, while the sxt is smaller under the application of a negative magnetic field, corresponding to the "out-of-plane" configuration.
The technology allows for measuring the projection of the STT vector in a fixed direction, rather than measuring the STT vector itself, which has been the standard practice for decades.

The advantage of this method is that it is applicable to any spin-transfer torque (STT)-based device, including STT magnetic random access memory (MRAM), STT spin valves, and STT thin-film transistors.
Therefore, it can be used to characterize device performance and map the write fields and switching currents of the device.

This work was conducted in collaboration with the IBM Almaden Research Center and was supported by the Department of Energy's Office of Science, Basic Energy Sciences, Materials Science and Engineering Division.
We propose a spectral analysis method called VESPA, which uses automated algorithms to measure the star formation history and metallicity of galaxies from the spectra of medium-band filters.
We use our code to extract star formation rates (SFR) and median metallicity from the Lick index spatial spectra in four redshift intervals (0.07 - 0.2).
We found that, in all epochs, the median metal abundance is higher than that of the Sun, while at low redshift, the median star formation rate is less than 10% of the volume-averaged value.
The star formation rate history we derived is consistent with the results from the population of Lyα emitters selected from the same data.
We have demonstrated that our method can robustly recover these indicators with a measurement uncertainty of less than 10% at all redshifts, and typically achieve 5% at high redshifts.

Finally, we show that at high redshifts, the star formation rate (SFR) of VESPA is consistent with the SFR of the Lyα emitter population selected with less IGM absorption, further indicating that reionization was nearly complete at z > 6.
In this work, we studied the cosmology of the improved Galois-Bonnet gravity.
The Gauss-Bonnet term is one of the higher-order curvature terms that appears in the low-energy limit of string theory.
This modification of the Einstein-Hilbert action introduces several new features in cosmodynamics.
One of them is the existence of a critical surface energy density that separates two states with different outcomes.

With the existence of such surface energy density, the Big Rip will not occur, and the universe will transition from the expansion phase to the deceleration stage, without crossing the surface energy density.
In this work, we studied three different examples and showed that according to the form of this critical energy density, the properties of the universe can be dominated by different entities.
For example, if the energy density of the critical surface is positive, it could represent the energy density of some form of dark energy fluid.
On the other hand, if the value of the critical energy density is negative, then it can be the energy density of ordinary matter.
In addition to these two examples, the critical energy density may also be a mixture of two different types of matter.
The characteristic of this critical energy density makes the model very flexible and applicable to many different situations in cosmology.
In this article, we propose a cosmological solution of superstring theory with positive vacuum energy and positive spatial curvature.
These solutions describe an early phase of expansion, followed by a desert period.
The possibility of the existence of positive spatial curvature is discussed in superstring theory, while only closed string theory has negative curvature.
Inflation, which refers to the rapid expansion of the universe in its early stages, has been supported by observations and theoretical considerations from superstring theory.
For string theory, the vacuum energy usually has a positive value.
However, the vacuum energy generated by different types of supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking has different signs.
Therefore, if we hope to have an inflationary period in string theory, we need to ensure that the vacuum energy is positive.

In this paper, we demonstrate that the combination of compactification, axion fields, and various uplift fields leads to an expanding de Sitter solution with positive vacuum energy in superstring theory.
The de Sitter solution for inflation has been obtained through supergravity.
Here we obtain these solutions from string theory.
This distinction is very important because it may lead to observable features that differentiate the two situations.
For example, baryon zero modes have a non-zero contribution to vacuum energy in supergravity, whereas in superstring theory, they do not contribute to vacuum energy.
Therefore, observations of cosmological parameters, such as the scalar spectral index and the tensor-to-scalar ratio, should be able to distinguish between these two scenarios.
Another important distinction lies in the energy range of the proposed collider experiments.

In superstring theory, the predicted mass scale of gravitons and other particles is approximately \( 10^{15} \) GeV, while in supergravity theory, these mass scales are much lower, on the order of \( 10^{16} \) GeV.
Therefore, if future experiments can detect a non-zero gravitational wave background, it may indicate that inflation occurred in the early universe, and that this phase happened after string theory.
This paper is a preliminary study on inflation caused by string theory.
We still have many interesting open questions that have not been considered.

For example, since we also hope to obtain a period of $N$-dimensional expansion, where $N$ is greater than two, the analysis needs to treat the higher-order corrections of the superpotential and the Kähler potential in a more detailed manner.
We also need to consider the range between various moduli and external field values, as well as the dependence on the complete string theory landscape.
Another important issue is the effect of module stability on vacuum energy, as well as the possibility of obtaining realistic cosmology.
The proposed collider characteristics also need to be modified within the complete framework of superstring theory.

Therefore, although this paper presents a new possibility for obtaining inflationary cosmology from superstring theory, we also recognize the need for further work to practically realize this possibility.
The inflation in string theory may have significant effects on the landscape of the vacuum, featuring supersymmetric periods.
Star clusters are important tools for studying various astrophysical phenomena, such as star formation, stellar feedback, and gravitational dynamics.

These compact star clusters are often found to exhibit a wide range of characteristics; while some clusters are simple groups of coeval stars, many clusters form through dynamic processes that bring together previously independent stars with similar ages and chemical compositions.

The diversity observed in these cluster systems suggests a complex evolutionary history, but direct observational evidence has been difficult to obtain due to the crowding and dimness of clusters in distant galaxies.
Here, we use archived space telescope imaging spectrograph data to identify and characterize the spatial distribution of star clusters in the grand design spiral galaxy M51.

The Full-Spectrum Environment Cluster (FCOE) catalog contains 122,695 independent cluster candidates, which were identified through machine learning algorithm training on archived data from the Hubble Space Telescope. The training utilized high-contrast images from the advanced survey camera.

We estimate the age of the star cluster by measuring the intensity of the hydrogen Brackett transition at 2.166 microns, and we demonstrate that its age approximately follows a log-normal distribution, with a peak at log(age/year) ≃ 7.6 and a standard deviation of 0.4.

We determined the systemic velocity of the star clusters by cross-correlation with the model spectral library, and found that these star clusters exhibit an almost Gaussian velocity distribution, with a peak velocity of approximately v ≃ 265 km/s and a standard deviation of 39 km/s. Finally, we demonstrated that the star clusters along the major axis of M51 show two different distributions, with more than 60% of the star clusters located within a range of 2.5 kpc near the plane of the galaxy.

Wireless communication systems that utilize multi-carrier signals, such as Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) and Multi-Carrier Modulation (MC) technologies, have been widely adopted in current wireless networks due to their efficient bandwidth usage and ease of implementation.

However, the antennas used in these systems that are spaced far apart often cause the channel to exhibit sparse multipath characteristics, meaning that the channel is flat in the frequency domain but exhibits impulses at specific delay points in the time domain.
This work studies the capacity and reliability of such sparse multipath channels within a broad frequency range.
The capacity is shown to have a logarithmic dependence on the coherence time, while the reliability exhibits an exponential decay relationship with the coherence time.
The trade-off between capacity and reliability is therefore studied from the perspective of the logarithmic exponential of coherence time.
The numerical results validate the accuracy of the derived expressions for capacity and reliability, and demonstrate that in all cases, the latter consistently outperforms the former.
This work has significant value in assessing the potential performance improvements of multi-antenna deployment in broadband mode for current and next-generation wireless networks.
Remote digital data transmission is the core of modern societal operations, and the development of ultra-long-distance quantum communication will bring profound benefits to global communication.
Using multi-core optical fibers, we demonstrated a quantum communication channel consisting of 10,000 optical segments, with a transmission distance of over 2,000 miles.
Each light segment is encoded in a single hyperfine spin state of the atom and connected via a NOT gate programmed by an ETele.
The fidelity of the transmission status exceeds 90%, and the logical error rate is below 0.5%.
This result represents a significant improvement compared to previous optical long-distance quantum communication.

Hybrid networks have been widely used in recent communication systems due to their advantages in increasing network capacity and enhancing network support.

However, the existing localization support for the injection point election (LSE) mechanism in hybrid networks cannot ensure that the same injection point (IP) is elected across all networks, which limits their applicability in hybrid networks.
In this article, we propose a locally supported injection point election mechanism (LSIPE), which ensures that all networks will select the same injection point.
In addition, we demonstrate that LSIPE is close to optimal in maximizing the minimum network utility, while ensuring that the same injection points are selected across all networks.
Extensive simulations have verified the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed LSIPE mechanism.
The LSIPE mechanism is an innovative local support injection point selection (LSE) mechanism designed for hybrid networks.
In a hybrid network, some physical networks and virtual networks coexist, and each physical network or virtual network can connect to multiple other physical networks or virtual networks.
Therefore, network injection management in a hybrid network has become a multipoint-to-multipoint issue, which is much more complex than the point-to-point problem in a single network.
The existing LSE mechanism cannot ensure that the same injection point (IP) is elected in all networks.
Therefore, we propose an LSIPE mechanism that can achieve the goal of having all networks select the same injection point.
In addition, we prove that LSIPE is close to optimal in maximizing the minimum network utility, while ensuring that the same injection points are elected across all networks.
Large-scale simulations validated the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed LSIPE mechanism.
The rest of this article is organized as follows.
The related work is described in Section 2.
The system model is introduced in Section 3.
The proposed LSIPE mechanism is introduced in Section 4.
The performance evaluation and analysis are presented in Section 5. Section 6 summarizes this paper.
From this work, we study the inclusion of the effects of domain walls in double flavor dynamics QCD simulations.
We use two types of domain wall algorithms and compare their performance.
We found that for the two types of domain walls, the equation of state and some other dynamic quantities did not show any signs of damage.
However, the chiral condensate is significantly reduced in the domain wall types X and V. To understand this, we apply lattice QCD chiral perturbation theory to analyze the measurement of quark mass.

We found that in domain wall type X, the effective mass of the light quark is much lighter than that of the strange quark, while in domain wall type V, the effective mass of the strange quark is much lighter than that of the other quarks.

The masses of these strange quarks, along with the much larger mass of the strange quark in the domain wall proposal, lead to an astonishing result: the contribution of strange quarks to the chiral symmetry breaking is much greater than in the conventional case.

The result of the strange quark condensation is 2.9(5) MeV/3 = 0.9(1) MeV, where the error includes the fitting error and the systematic error arising from neglecting the effect of domain walls on the mass of the heavy strange quarks.

We also considered the impact of the physical K meson and η meson mass, and discussed the possibility that strange quark condensation can be determined by the masses of the physical π meson as well as the K meson and η meson.

This paper defines higher K-theory and higher traces as universal invariants, and proves their relevance by determining the higher K-theory of the one-point compactification of hyperbolic groups.
These universal invariants satisfy the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence, which is used for topological K-theory, calculations of fundamental groups, and the universal coefficient theorem.

In this framework, the Strong Novikov Conjecture (which indicates that the high signature of a closed manifold is universal in the first homology classes) is equivalent to the homotopy invariance of higher K-theory.
This means that higher K-groups satisfy the Hirzebruch signature theorem, and under certain assumptions, they can also detect singular elements in the stable homology of manifolds.
We have also established distorted versions of these universal invariants and applied them to the Bessmertny cross formula, the Borel regulator children, and the elliptic generating children.
This method, which is based on high K-theory and universal invariants, has been extended to other stable homotopy theories, such as boundary homotopy and generalized homology.
In particular, we define the distorted variants of these theories and demonstrate how to use the invariants defined here to calculate these variants.
This method unifies the study of K-theory, boundary theory, generalized homology, and stable homotopy by localizing these theories as a single universal theory of stable derived functors.
In particular, the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence appears as a key element in the localization process in topological K-theory.
In addition to defining the universal theory of this stable exported functor, we also computed its rationalization.
This provides a powerful method to determine the rational homology of the single-point compactification of the hypersurface family, which may have independent interest.

Finally, we proposed a framework for studying twisted stable homotopy theory, in which various structures, such as vector bundles and operators, are replaced by connected covers and corresponding universal invariants.
We provide some examples of these distorted theories and explain how to calculate their universal invariants.
I would like to thank David Gisen, Sean Tamah, and Robert Yag for their advice and support.
The theory of high K via universal invariants captures the key features of continuous cohomology by considering all homotopy groups simultaneously.

This is a theory of homotopy of spectra, also known as the theory of internal homotopy, which means it allows for a normalized spectrum whose homotopy is the same as the homotopy groups of the K-theory spectrum KU.

These homotopy groups can be given the structure of a ring by coefficients; the Hopkins-Miller theorem identifies this ring as topological cyclic homology TC, allowing the study of K-theory through universal properties.
This field of study contains a wealth of information.
The basic theorem of K-theory describes it as a set of segments separated by unique extensions, whose elimination requires Elliott invariants.
At the same time, the periodicity theorem and Bott periodic isomorphism generalize the classical Bott periodicity and its results at the pro-spectral level.

We present a catalog that includes 98,653 discrete sources detected in the first survey of this region by the Gaia Survey, located within a 5 square degree area of the Carina Nebula observed over three months.

We combine this catalog with a source catalog detected in a more in-depth survey of the Carina Nebula published in an accompanying paper to study the overall characteristics of the Carina Nebula and its distribution in the energy spectrum.
We found that the energy budget of the nebula is 6% - 21%, rising to 21% - 30% in its densest regions.

The distribution of stars around the HII region of the Triangulum Nebula is approximately uniform at about 6%, while there is a more concentrated state to the south and west. This distribution pattern typically exhibits characteristics of sequential energy input.

We indicate that this clumpiness has an environmental origin, as the dense gas in the Southern Cross is shielded from external influences, and its density is lower than that of the more sparse interstellar medium in the surrounding areas.
The strong chemical bonds between molecules and the high opacity of particles at low to moderate temperatures limit the study of ultracool dwarfs (UCDs) and exoplanets.
The maximum mass of ultra-compact dwarfs (UCDs) has a temperature below 20,000 K, with an effective temperature of about 300 K; they are in a gaseous state.

The opacity project (OP) calculates the theoretical line and average opacity of plasma at different temperatures and compositions. These opacities can be used as input for radiation transfer simulations, which are then used to fit the observed spectra of these ultra-low-mass stars and exoplanets.
In this work, the author calculated the line and mean opacity of plasmas with temperatures below 20,000 K and effective temperatures below 300 K.
The addition of impurities and trace metal elements (such as H2O, CO2, NH3, CH4, etc.) has expanded the range of computational opacities for such plasmas.

For example, for a plasma with a temperature of 10,000 K, where hydrogen accounts for 90% and carbon for 10%, the author calculated that the results of spectral lines and mean opacity in the pressure range of 10^-7 to 10^-9 torr differ from the OP simulation results by less than 10%.
Therefore, the spectral lines and average opacity obtained from these calculations can be used to accurately simulate the thermal radiation and re-radiation spectra of ultracold stars and exoplanets.
The expanding universe is an experiment conducted by Lawrence Krauss, aiming to observe the resulting entropy effects by gradually melting metal at a constant temperature.
This experiment was conducted in three different locations, depending on the temperature at which the metal was heated.
The temperature in the first stage is 330°C. The heat generated between 330°C and 310°C is sufficient to provide energy for a theme park castle, but the results are inconsistent.

After melting at a temperature of 310°C, the metal underwent nucleation annealing over a specific period of time. The main reason for the nuclear hardening is that atoms diffuse into the vacuum under a powerful X-ray beam. Many experiments have shown that this is a successful experiment, but other scientists argue that the results obtained are invalid due to the lack of heat in this ignited nucleus.
The heat generated is insufficient to melt the metal block, nor is it enough to produce the entropy required for advanced proof.

There is also an issue related to energy in this experiment, as the metals must be heated to very high temperatures, while it is primarily composed of metal batteries, which have significantly higher energy utilization efficiency.

"The Expansion of the Universe" is a report by Lawrence Krauss, in which he presents the conclusions of an experiment aimed at studying the effects of entropy generated. In light of recent developments, Krauss submitted the experiment he conducted for review.
The criticism mainly focuses on the lack of heat generation at the core, whereas this heat could have produced the hypothesized entropy effect.
According to Klaus's estimation, the heat generated by the core is insufficient to melt the metal blocks, while they fully meet this condition.

In a non-collinear magnetic field, a single negatively charged self-assembled InGaAs quantum dot with an effective Landé g-factor of -0.44 was studied.
By using optical detection of electron spin resonance, we measured the spin relaxation times of electrons and holes to be more than 4.5 microseconds and 0.7 milliseconds, respectively.

The long hole spin relaxation time far exceeds the value predicted by the Fermi golden rule and the Herglotz inequality, and is consistent with the best theoretical estimates of the effective mass of the conduction band in GaAs.

We discussed whether the unexpectedly long hole spin relaxation time is caused by the suppression of the transition between the heavy hole valence band and the split conduction band due to the strong quantum dot confinement in the vertical direction, which inhibits electron-hole correlation.
The author thanks Dr. Roman Skroczki for the productive discussions and the experimental data provided.

Triple doublet neutrino mixing, proposed by H. Liu and X. Zhang in 1998, is regarded as one of the best models of neutrino mixing and has recently attracted increasing attention [1,2].
The threefold quantum mixing angle θ_{23} of neutrino mixing can be expressed as 2/9π - 1/9, and the deviation from the maximum mixing angle can be considered as a perturbation parameter α.
The latest neutrino experiment results show that the neutrino mixing angle is moving away from the tri-bimaximal neutrino mixing.
For this paper, we consider a type-II torsion mechanism, adding an additional singlet lepton, and generating the baryon asymmetry of the universe through a lepton generation mechanism.
We will demonstrate that the perturbation parameter α can be derived from the baryon asymmetry of the universe.
The absolute values of the perturbation parameters for the mixing angles θ_{23}, θ_{13}, and δ are 0.09, 0.047, and 0.014, respectively.
We found that these absolute values are consistent with the current experimental results.
Through the near-infrared K2-3Ne standard mask photometric survey of the N2K alliance, five new planets were discovered orbiting a nearby star.
The masses of the host stars of these planets range from 0.7 to 1.4 solar masses, and the distances are approximately 19 to 60 light-years.
The relative semi-major axis of these planets ranges from 0.025 to 0.15, and their equilibrium temperatures are between 34 and 59 Kelvin.
Assuming these planets have typical masses and radii of Uranus and Neptune, their equilibrium temperatures would be 34 and 59 Kelvin.

The lowest quality host star discovered through this survey has a mass of 0.7 solar masses, while the most distant planet located 55 AU from its star has an equilibrium temperature exceeding 59 Kelvin.

The detection rate of these planets is related to their estimated equilibrium temperatures, which is much higher than expected for hot Jupiters. With predicted temperatures between 58 and 63 Kelvin, the detection probability is 48%, corresponding to bodies similar to Neptune and Uranus.

Due to the formation pathways of these planets being similar to that of our own solar system, their initial positions should be located outside the snow line of their stars. The most likely scenario is that these planets formed farther away and then migrated inward.

Therefore, the results of this investigation provide strong evidence for the stability of the external regions of the system in resisting material loss, in which case the substellar objects could be super-Earths or true Neptune-sized planets.
In this article, we propose a new solution to the hierarchy problem in particle physics.

The solution is based on the existence of a large number \( n \) of dark matter types, with each dark matter particle having a mass of approximately 1 GeV. These dark matter particles interact through a new force with coupling strength parameter \( \lambda \), and due to the large compact volume \( Ω \), the strength of these interactions is suppressed.
Therefore, the freeze-out temperature of the lightest dark matter species Δ is approximately λΩ, and its abundance is consistent with current observational constraints.
As Δ subsequently annihilates into standard model particles, it releases enough energy to offset the vacuum energy density indicated by current observations.
The relationship between λ, Ω, and the hierarchy problem has been discussed.
Research indicates that by having Ω depend exponentially on n, large-scale n species can derive the correct relic density of dark matter without the need for a global-level cancellation.
We finally outlined a mechanism for implementing this model, which involves non-Abelian dark matter.
The Mira variable star photometer on the 3.5-meter telescope at Las Campanas Observatory has been in operation since 2012.

During this period, we achieved a photometric accuracy of 3 milli-arcseconds for bright stars and 7 milli-arcseconds for faint stars, and obtained time series photometric measurements for tens of millions of stars.

Based on this data, we studied the pulsation patterns, period-luminosity relationships, and color-magnitude relationships of Mira variables, as well as the structure and pulsation geometry of semiregular variables, the rotation and multiplicity of pulsating stars, and how these quantities vary with mass, luminosity, and wavelength.
This article summarizes our research findings and discusses the implications of these results for our understanding of these fascinating celestial bodies.

We studied the pulsation modes, period-luminosity relationship, and color-magnitude relationship of Mira variables, the structure and pulsation geometry of semi-regular variables, the rotation and multiplicity of pulsating stars, and how these quantities change with mass, brightness, and wavelength.
These findings were presented and discussed.

A popular scenario of supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking is the constrained minimal supersymmetric standard model (CMSSM), which assumes minimal supergravity (mSUGRA) hypotheses regarding the initial conditions of soft supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking parameters.

In this case, the parameters of the CMSSM are completely determined by four input parameters: the universal scalar mass parameter \( m_0 \), the universal trilinear scalar coupling parameter \( a_0 \), the ratio of the vacuum expectation values of the two Higgs doublets \( \tan \beta \), and the sign of the Higgs mixing parameter \( \text{sign}(\mu) \).
The current experimental data, particularly the measured physical mass values of quarks and leptons, can be used to determine the preferred values of these CMSSM parameters.

We refer to the new, significantly more generalized CMSMS scenario as the Constrained Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (CMSSM).

The precise measurement results of the radio frequency magnetic susceptibility of ferromagnetic and (anti)ferromagnetic materials have been presented.
The variation of the magnetic susceptibility of ferromagnetic materials with temperature, external fields, and direct current magnetic bias fields has been determined.
The temperature and external field dependence of the magnetization of (anti)ferromagnetic materials has been determined.
Research indicates that in (two-dimensional) antiferromagnets, applying a DC magnetic bias field will induce a net magnetization, which varies with the square of the bias field.
The magnetic susceptibility of an antiferromagnet can also be expressed as the total number of spins, which is the sum of the magnetic susceptibilities of individual atomic spins.
The latter has been shown to lead to the saturation of the total magnetic susceptibility at high fields.

The provided susceptibility measurements can be used for the characterization of materials and can serve as a sensitive and specific tool to help investigate new types of magnetic materials, for example, in the search for high-temperature ferromagnets and antiferromagnets.

Multiple VLBI observations of the radio source at a peak spectrum (GPS) from 1.6 GHz to 19 GHz were conducted, yielding the following results: 1.
The flux density at 1.6 GHz and 19 GHz is consistent within the margin of error.
"If 19 GHz is generated at the base of the relativistic jet, this is unexpected in GPS sources."
The position angle (PA) difference between 1.6 GHz and 19 GHz is consistent with zero, which is also unexpected if the 19 GHz is generated in the jet.
The translation of "3." into Chinese is "三。".

Three sources indicate that, in the expected direction, the phase angle (PA) rotation at 1.6 GHz corresponds to the characteristics of GPS sources, specifically that the gradient of the phase angle exceeds 10 degrees per decade.
These results are consistent with those generated at 19 GHz in the GPS source core.
The last sentence is the most important.
19 GHz is considered to be generated at the core of the GPS source, so this result is consistent with that hypothesis.
IEEE 802.11e has been widely accepted as the main standard for Wireless Network Management (WNM).
However, it relies on announcing and confirming using asymmetric leased bandwidth, which may be unfair to low traffic sites (LTSs).
In this article, we propose a design for an efficient bandwidth sharing mechanism at Layer 2 of IEEE 802.11e to reduce implicit bandwidth leasing of LTS.
The mechanism was implemented and evaluated in a simulated 802.11e IBSS.
The results indicate that, compared to the state-of-the-art unloaders, our mechanism can reduce the L5-L14 delay of the simulated IBSS by about 13.5% on saturated channels.
In addition, our mechanism will not reduce the Wi-Fi service quality for non-long-term service (LTS) clients, while maintaining high fairness and low leasing costs for LTS.
This article presents a cosmological framework for explaining the co-evolution of quasars, supermassive black holes (SMBH), and elliptical galaxies.

This framework is essential for fully understanding how quasars and supermassive black holes are nurtured by their host galaxies, as well as how they nurture their host galaxies in return, and how the co-evolution of these components affects the host galaxies themselves.
We proposed a hierarchical model of galaxy mergers that includes both dry and wet mergers, and we show that this model naturally produces elliptical galaxies with large nuclear star clusters.
We further believe that this framework can simultaneously reproduce the observed abundance and evolution of elliptical galaxies as well as the luminosity function of quasars.

In conclusion, we demonstrate that significant merger events can effectively trigger quasar and radio activity, and this radio activity provides a continuous feedback source that can suppress the growth of supermassive black holes and elliptical galaxies.
This work was completed within the framework of the H2020 Twin Project "Connecting Fundamental Physics and Cosmology with Active Galactic Nuclei," contract number 654004 (SURF).
NGC 1904 is a globular cluster in the Milky Way galaxy located about 18,000 light-years from Earth.
Although previous studies have been conducted in multiple passbands, this is the first comprehensive study of the entire star cluster in the blue and green parts of the spectrum.
The star cluster was found to be brighter and larger than previously indicated by earlier studies, with its brightest star reaching a visual magnitude of 8.5.
The brightest stars have also been found to possess blue companions, which are a characteristic of stars evolving from the main sequence.
The mass function of luminous stars is fitted to a Kroupa distribution, showing deviations from a normal distribution. The authors attribute this deviation to the mass segregation effect.
The radial profile of the cluster has been studied in the core, transition, and external regions.

Although the density of stars monotonically decreases with distance from the center of the inner cluster, the distribution curve in the intermediate region becomes flat, clearly showing a distinct separation between the substructures.

The study of speed dispersion in the core, transition, and external regions showed that it increases with radius in the transition region, while it decreases with radius in the external region, clearly indicating the separation between the core and the halo.
The star OO Serpentis is a young B-type star.
It has a surrounding dust reduction disk and an erupting counterpart, which can be visible as electromagnetic radiation.
In this article, I describe the outbursts of this star between 1995 and 2006, noting that it entered a low activity phase starting in 2005, and new outbursts were observed again from 2012.

By using Spitzer's infrared observations and ALMA's millimeter observations, I studied the properties of the outburst and its environment, which allowed me to propose a model regarding the explosion and its evolution.
Indeed, since 2005, we have seen OO Serpentis enter a new phase of low activity, but this has not prevented the formation of newly ejected material.
At this moment, the dust disk moves outward and reaches a stable distance of 2.5 astronomical units from the central star.
Since 2012, the eruptions have become noticeable again.

Based on infrared observations, I demonstrated that the increase in the brightness of the stars leads to new material ejections, as well as an enhancement in the ejection rate throughout the entire outburst.
Using millimeter observations, I characterize the density of the jets and the surrounding medium of the stars.

I proposed a model for the ejection of eruptive materials, based on the variations in the dust deceleration disk, which explains the sequence and temporal correlation between dust and eruptive materials.
In this article, we study Lorentz-type and signature-changing membranes in the context of different high-spin theories.

We first consider the general action of multiple parallel branes in arbitrary high-spin theories, derive the equations of motion, analyze the cases of Lorentz-type and signature-changing branes, and obtain the general expressions for different geometric conserved quantities.
We consider specific cases of the high-spin superalgebra \( hs(n|n) \) and \( ds(4|1) \), including general matter, analyze their Killing equations, and specifically study certain indices.

Our results are related to the study of the AdS/CFT correspondence and holographic theory, indicating that the conserved quantities of high-spin theories reflect similar properties of gravitational theories in AdS and dS backgrounds.
There are several papers with similar titles in the arXiv.org repository, so we present a new analysis of Lorentz and signature-changing membranes in different high-spin theoretical contexts.

The WMAP satellite detected a cold spot in the polarized sky, with a brightness temperature of 1.3 K. Although relatively small, it is statistically significant, while the average temperature of the areas surrounding the cold spot is 2.2 K. The lack of corresponding structure in the unpolarized and tabular data has led to several hypotheses regarding the nature of this cold spot.
One hypothesis is whether this is a result of systematic effects in the WMAP data.
Such system effects have been observed in the past, and the WMAP team is conducting extensive investigations into possible residual thermal noise and sources of contamination.
Another hypothesis is that the cold spot is a marker of an undiscovered structure in the universe.
If this is the case, it would have a significant impact on cosmology and the very early universe.

We conducted a detailed analysis of the temperature and polarization data from 84 radio sources in external galaxies based on WMAP data, in order to investigate the characteristics of the cold spot reported.
We did not find any such features, thus concluding that the reported low-temperature region is not a systematic effect in the WMAP data, but rather a real feature of the universe.

Late-phase long-term potentiation (L-LTP), also known as long-term memory, relies on the presynaptic activation of Group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) and postsynaptic protein synthesis.
Maintaining the activity of NMDA receptors is required for new protein synthesis.
From this work, we propose a late L-LTP model that incorporates these three essential elements.
The model can produce long-term depression (L-LTD) and long-term memory, which has also been observed in later long-term potentiation (L-LTP).
Therefore, this model may be a useful tool for elucidating the fundamental mechanisms of late long-term potentiation (late L-LTP).

Late-phase long-term potentiation (L-LTP), also known as long-term memory, relies on the activation of Group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) on the presynaptic side and protein synthesis on the postsynaptic side.
The maintenance requires the activity of NMDA receptors and new protein synthesis.
We propose a late L-LTP model that includes these three basic components.
The model can produce long-term depression (L-LTD) and long-term memory, which are also observed in late long-term potentiation (L-LTP).
Therefore, this model can serve as a useful tool for elucidating the fundamental mechanisms of late long-term potentiation (late L-LTP).
The model includes three parts: the presynaptic component, the postsynaptic component, and the interaction between the two.
The presynaptic component includes an mGluR, which is activated when the concentration of neurotransmitters increases in the presynaptic space.
This leads to the mobilization of calcium through the diacylglycerol/protein kinase C cascade.
This influx of calcium ions leads to the synthesis of key proteins involved in the maintenance of L-LTP.
The postsynaptic part includes synthetic glutamate receptors, which have a half-life of several hours.

Finally, the interaction between these two parts includes the generation of long-term depression (L-LTD) when there is a reduction in postsynaptic glutamate and presynaptic neurotransmitter concentrations.
Our results indicate that this model can produce long-term inhibition and long-term potentiation similar to late-phase L-LTP.
We conclude that this model may be a useful tool for elucidating the fundamental mechanisms of late-phase L-LTP.
Acknowledgments: This research was funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), with grant numbers 1719653, 1719564, 1820822, 1834991, and 1900094.
We would like to thank Dr. Vladimir Zabalon for his comments on the manuscript.

The maintenance requires the activity of NMDA receptors and new protein synthesis.
In this work, we propose an advanced L-LTP model that includes these three basic components.
The model may produce long-term depression (L-LTD).
Dying radio galaxies are useful cosmological tools because they can be used to trace the large-scale structure of the universe.

These galaxies exhibit weakened radio emissions associated with active cores and some thermal spot emissions, and there is a noticeable cutoff at the edges of the large-scale structure in which the galaxies are located.
Although the dying radio galaxies have significant value for cosmology, there is currently no clear sample available for statistical studies.
We have conducted this source search in the publicly available data of the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array archive.
We have discovered 19 sources, whose decaying radio emissions resemble those expected from an impending extinct radio galaxy.
We discussed the impact of this discovery on large-scale structure studies and the future search for such sources.
This work was carried out as part of the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array Public Science Program 13B254.
We thank the staff of the array, as well as the VLASS Project Office and the McGee department of NRAO for their assistance and support in preparing this project.
The de Haas-van Alphen study has been conducted on the filled skutterudite compounds PrOs₄As₁₂ and LaOs₄As₁₂.
The filled skutterudite compounds exhibit heavy fermion behavior, making PrOs₄As₁₂ and LaOs₄As₁₂ candidate materials for realizing Kondo lattice systems.

We observed that the two compounds exhibit a field-dependent magnetic susceptibility component that is nearly independent of mass at temperatures down to 1.8 K. This mass-independent component is likely caused by crystal electric field (CEF) effects.
The CEF energy level scheme has been analyzed, revealing nine excited state energy levels.
This study is one of the important experiments for understanding quantum criticality in filled graphene systems.

Authors: Takehiro Hirabayashi, Jun Hashimoto, Osamu Senta, Takehiro Takahata, Hideki Yamamoto, Yoshihiko Kuroki, Atsushi Kawabata  
Journal: Physics Procedia

In this paper, we consider the problem of determining the minimum bankruptcy probability in a jump-diffusion risk model.
We provide a characteristic description of the minimum probability of bankruptcy through a convex game that includes stopping the game and controlling the game.
At each point in time, players must choose between continuing the risky process until the moment of bankruptcy and terminating the game at a certain safe level of liquid wealth.
The game is controlled as it progresses, where the strategy chosen by the first player determines the timing and level of the jumping process.

After applying an extended version of the Sion’s Minimax Theorem to this game, we are able to characterize the value function of the stopping game as the unique classical solution of a degenerate elliptic partial differential equation.
Finally, we prove that this value function is both the minimum bankruptcy probability and the unique maximum survival probability.
This work is of significant importance to risk managers, researchers, and students interested in determining the minimum probability of bankruptcy in jump diffusion risk models.
Magnetic fields are believed to exist in most stars and planets, playing a crucial role in their evolution.
For systems that lack a clear focus and ordered magnetic fields, such as stars and planets, our understanding of magnetic fields is much less.

Observations of continuous radiation and line emission from a large number of low-quality pre-main-sequence stars (T Tauri stars) provide evidence for the presence of significant magnetic fields in these systems.
In these systems, the most likely topology of the field is a dipole aligned with the stellar rotation axis.
Here, we present the Zeeman-Doppler imaging of the existence and characteristics of the dipole field in the T Tauri star Hen 3-4008.
The dipole field is shielded in the large inner disk but manifests in the outer disk, while slow magnetoacoustic waves propagate throughout the disk.
We demonstrated a quantitative modeling of the field characteristics and established a lower limit of approximately 650 Gauss for the magnetic field strength of Hen 3-4008.
The existence of dark matter is established through its gravitational effects on the visible matter in the Milky Way.
However, the nature of dark matter is still unknown.
Regarding its nature, the most popular theory is the cold dark matter theory, which posits that it is composed of fundamental particles that neither emit nor absorb electromagnetic radiation.
The evidence has been established that dark matter exists in clumps or concentrations large enough to be observed in particles and galaxies.
These star clusters are believed to have evolved through the gravitational interactions between their constituent particles and galaxies.
Due to the fact that dark matter neither emits nor absorbs light, directly observing it is challenging.
Studying the dynamics of these star clusters can help understand the nature of dark matter.
B514 is a globular cluster located in the M31 galaxy, approximately 25,000 light-years away from Earth.
Using the Hubble Space Telescope, I have determined that B514 has an extended halo, which based on its structure and dynamical characteristics, is most likely composed of dark matter.
I have determined that the average density of this dark matter halo is 0.105 halo particles per cubic light year, with a diameter of 1.33 kiloparsecs or 17,650 light years.
A muon, an electron, and a tau particle interacting with a neutrino in a nuclear target can lead to multiple channels.

In neutrino oscillation experiments, we are particularly interested in those channels that produce charged current signature particles through charged current interactions and involve missing transverse momentum.
In this article, we prove that these channels can be simplified into a complex symplectic invariant, which we call s.

The structure of this invariance allows us to predict the structure of the interaction matrix for charged current neutrino interactions in the Standard Model, namely the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix.
We use experimental data to obtain the leading-order structure of the CKM matrix and demonstrate that it largely simplifies to the structure predicted by invariance.
We applied our analysis to a precise global fit of the neutrino mixing matrix and showed that the corresponding structure predicted by \( s \) is consistent with the data at the 1.7σ level.
We also discussed the connection between this result and high-dimensional physics as well as flavor symmetry.

This article introduces the development of a new general relativity fluid dynamics code called WHAM (WENO-HARDM).
This paper presents the numerical methods implemented in the code, as well as some issues and solutions encountered during the development process.
The code is written in a modular fashion, which allows it to be easily extended to other fluid dynamics equations, embedded equations, and mathematical flux functions.
The author conducted several code tests to demonstrate the ability to accurately capture smooth solutions and physical discontinuities.
The results are consistent with the exact solutions of various fluid dynamics equations and the published literature.
WHAM can be obtained from https://bitbucket.org/carrerr/wham.
The main repository contains all the development code, while the directory https://github.com/carrerr/wham/tree/master/doc contains all the documentation.

WHAM: A WENO-based Numerical Scheme for General Relativity I: Hydrodynamics  
Hydrodynamics is the description of fluid motion and falls within the realm of fluid mechanics.
Fluid mechanics is the discipline that studies the behavior of fluids without involving radiation or mechanical phenomena.

The dynamics of viscous fluids are described by the equations of fluid dynamics: as described below, the continuity equation expresses the conservation of fluid mass; the fluid velocity, which is an expression of Newton's laws of motion, as well as appropriate velocity conditions, such as no flow at boundaries (no-slip) or in channels (zero shear); and momentum conservation, which is an expression of the forces generated by contact friction and other sources that have not yet been included in the fluid mass equation.
General relativity is the study of the influence of gravity on the propagation of light.

General relativity is one of the most comprehensive and successful descriptions of the laws of physics, explaining all known forms of energy, including mass-energy, matter, electromagnetic energy, and nuclear energy.
It also describes the dynamics of spacetime and the structure of spacetime itself.
The emergence of this theory aims to combine Isaac Newton's universally unique and elegant theory of gravity with a correct description of the motion of planets and stars.
In particular, general relativity accurately describes the behavior of light on the scale of planets and stars, while Newton's theory seems unable to fully explain these observations.

Einstein's field equations are the most famous example of a nonlinear structure in general relativity, and usually there are no known solutions; therefore, Einstein supplemented his theory with the assumption of the existence of solutions.
The noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) is an important aspect that is often overlooked when studying this novel quantum state of matter.
In the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE), it has been theoretically predicted that emission noise and absorption noise will occur.
Although launch noise can affect the transport measurements through the sample, absorption noise does not, and can be observed through noise spectroscopy.

We proposed two different experimental implementation schemes for this noise spectroscopy: one using microwave radiation and the other using optical Raman scattering. Both methods are quantitatively consistent with the theoretical calculations of emission and absorption noise in fractional quantum Hall effects.
This noise spectroscopy is an important tool for studying transport in fractional quantum Hall effects and will enable future research on many-body dynamics in this quantum many-body system.
This study on the noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) is particularly important, as research on this novel quantum state often overlooks the noise aspects of FQHE.
The noise from the launch will affect the transmission measurements through the sample, but the absorption noise will not be affected and can be observed using noise spectrum methods.

We demonstrate two different experimental implementations of this noise spectroscopy: one using microwave radiation and the other employing optical Raman scattering. Both are in good quantitative agreement with theoretical calculations of emission and absorption noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect.
We study the collapse of very massive stars, starting from one solar mass and evolving to a black hole under full general relativity with a rotational speed of 600 times the speed of light.

These collapses occur in a region with extremely high angular momentum, where black holes pierce through the sky and shrink to about 30 kilometers, the Schwarzschild radius, at which point general relativity requires it to become infinite.

We conducted simulations with a resolution of up to 2048*1024, showing that the fluid forms an oblate spheroid configuration with a maximum radius of approximately 1000 meters, a core radius of a few meters, and it rotates slowly.

After an initial phase of about 0.5 milliseconds, the collapse process proceeds in a manner very similar to a direct collision between two black holes with masses of 30 and 10 times that of the Sun, forming an event horizon approximately 20 kilometers in size, and it is estimated that the energy released is about 2.5% of the total mass, which closely matches the values obtained in previous disturbance calculations.

We studied the properties of the formed black holes and demonstrated that several physical parameters, such as the irreducible mass, spin parameter, curvature invariants, and the gravitational pull at the event horizon, closely match the values obtained from perturbative calculations, even for the final non-perturbative rotating stars.
The data on the internet is continuously evolving with the development of the Web and the introduction of new concepts such as social networks and mobile applications.
The volume of this batch of data is increasing rapidly, and there is an urgent need to conduct new research in the field of data management in order to effectively analyze this data.
In this article, a distributed data model for web data integration in data warehouses is proposed.
The main advantage of this model is that all data related to the website is represented as a row in the target relational database, which makes it easy to join this table with other tables.
The model uses case conversion style rules to add new columns to the base table to represent new concepts, and these rules can be easily extended to add additional concepts.

The proposed model has been implemented in a MySQL database, and the performance of the model has been evaluated using actual data. The results indicate that this model can handle a large volume of network data compared to other models.

Recently, various anomalies have been discovered in the WMAP data, such as the correlation between the arrangement of high (positive) and low (negative) intensity regions and the direction of the solar wind, as well as the correlation between temperature in the KQ75 directed dataset and the various components of the WMAP data.
These anomalies have been widely interpreted as indirect signs of the presence of electromagnetic interference and/or potential contamination from solar system dust.
In this article, we report several other alignment and intensity anomalies found in WMAP data that were not previously reported and are more difficult to explain.
We have also provided reasonable physical explanations for these anomalies, which are caused by interference from artificial radio signals.
We demonstrate that the anomalies recently observed in the signed intensity and cross power spectrum are also caused by the same interference.
The interference we are reporting here may originate from artificial radio signals in the frequency bands of 128 - 137 MHz, 143 - 149 MHz, and 333 - 349 MHz.
The radio waves emitted by these sources will spread from North America to the northern hemisphere of the sky (where the WMAP satellite is located) from May 2003 to November 2003.

In this article, we propose a method for constructing free fermions for the supergroup WZNW model. This method utilizes the free fermion decomposition of the supergroup and combines it with a spectral flow to connect models at different levels.
We have provided a free field realization of the WZNW model based on the decomposition of free fermions.

We use operator product expansion to calculate the correlation functions and demonstrate that they are consistent with known results in the case of the supergroup \( GL(1|1) \) and the superconformal model with central charge \( c=6 \).
In particular, we confirm the correctness of the recently proposed four-point function with conditions of general symmetry and global consistency.

We also discussed how to apply this method to construct free fermions for WZNW models with other supergroups and showed that models based on free fermions can be obtained from general supergroup models.

Bipolar spintronics combines the advantages of ferromagnetic materials and spintronics by utilizing the spins of both electrons and holes.
In this method, spin-orbit interaction (SOI) is utilized to generate or detect spin polarization, and ferromagnetism can be used for information storage.
The first application realized was the observation of the spin Hall effect in 1977, marking the beginning of bipolar spintronics.

Since then, a large number of in-depth studies have been conducted in this field, and various applications have been proposed, including the anomalous Hall effect, pure spin current injection, and spintronic-based logic.
This paper provides an overview of bipolar spintronics, from spin injection to spin control logic.
