Through this paper, we outline bipolar spintronics, from spin injection to spin control logic.
We will first briefly introduce spin and the description of the spin Hall effect.
Then we discuss the discovery of the spin Hall effect and early experimental studies, including the non-ordinary Hall effect, spin rectification, and spin pumping.
The last two effects have been regarded as an important foundation for subsequent spin transport and applied research.
We proposed a theoretical model of the spin Hall effect based on classical mechanics and the spin drift-diffusion equation.
These models form the basis for further analysis and numerical research on spin transport.
An overview of the experimental and theoretical research on spin pumping in thin ferromagnetic films is provided.
Then, we present experimental studies on the anomalous Hall effect and spin rectification in thin films.
The discussion focused on the role of topological terms in the anomalous Hall effect.
The review also covers spin rectification through spin mixing and transport.
The advantages and disadvantages of these two effects in applications have also been compared.
The formation of topological phases due to spin-orbit coupling in electronic systems is also demonstrated here.
Topological spin, the anomalous Hall effect, and the topological Hall effect are all related to this topological phase.
We will continue to discuss the injection of spin current under the spin Hall effect.
An overview of the direct observation of the spin Hall effect in metallic systems is presented.
We also introduced the spin Hall effect in semiconductors, magnetic semiconductors, and topological insulators.
Recent discoveries regarding the surface states of topological insulators have been summarized.
Then discussed the detection methods of spin accumulation.
The research on spin dynamics in semiconductors has been reviewed.

Then, we introduce the applications of bipolar spintronics, including spin-charge conversion devices, devices based on exchange interactions, devices based on tunnel magnetoresistance, and other spin-related devices.
Neutrinos are an essential part of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics.
Their interaction is described by the Lagrangian λ–μ+ν(−χ+ρ), where λ, μ, and ν are the coupling constants of the three lepton families, while χ and ρ are scalar fields.
In the standard model, the origin of these couplings is not understood.
The self-interaction of neutrinos is absent in the Lagrangian due to a symmetry known as lepton number symmetry.

However, we show that the observed neutrino oscillations are best explained by the spontaneous breaking of this symmetry at a scale of θ ≤ 10⁻¹⁰ GeV, below which the symmetry has been radiatively broken by effects in the theory.
We calculated θ and several cosmological parameters, and found that the simplest version of the model is consistent with the latest data.
We also briefly discussed the variants of this model with additional scalar fields and the steps to test this model.

We indicate that the best explanation for the observed neutrino oscillations is the spontaneous breaking of this symmetry at a scale of θ ≤ 10^(-10) GeV, below which the effective theory has radiatively broken the symmetry.
We calculated θ and several cosmological parameters and found that the simplest version of the model is consistent with recent data.
We also briefly discussed variants of this model, including additional scalar fields and the steps to test the model.
Supermassive black holes exist in all giant galaxies.
They grow over time due to the accumulation of matter.
Their mass can be estimated through the basic plane of black hole activity.
The plane is based on three parameters: the velocity dispersion of the host galaxy, the velocity dispersion of the stars, and the influence radius of the black hole.
The first two are measurements related to the Milky Way, while the third can be estimated through the mass of the black hole.
The last two are strongly correlated and can be used to estimate the mass of a black hole.
Such estimates have been conducted in a large number of galaxies and have found that more massive galaxies tend to have larger mass black holes on average.

The correlation is expressed as the following linear relationship: \( M_{BH} = A \times M_{spheroid} + B \), where \( M_{BH} \) is the mass of the black hole, \( M_{spheroid} \) is the mass of the quasar, \( A \) is a coefficient close to 7, and \( B \) is a constant.
This relationship has been found to be true in all Hubble types of galaxies, especially in early-type galaxies.

The study found that the correlation between the properties of globular clusters and the attributes of the host galaxy is stronger than the correlation between black hole mass and the attributes of the host galaxy, which can be explained by the growth driven by black hole mergers.
By using another observable quantity, namely the luminosity of the ellipsoid, the scattering of the relationship can be reduced.
The latter can be estimated through the radius of speed dispersion and the range of gravitational influence, both of which are required by the former.
The latter can be estimated from the B band luminosity of the galaxy.

Research has found that the scatter of the relationship between black hole mass and the luminosity of globular clusters is significantly lower than other relationships, and the best-fit coefficient is closer to 10. This can be explained by more accurate measurements and less intrinsic scatter in the luminosity of globular clusters.
Some people suggest that the relationship between black hole mass and the luminosity of a sphere could serve as a new criterion for estimating black hole mass.

The free core nutation, also known as temporal nutation, is a relatively rapid component of the Earth's rotation.
It is directly proportional to the axial oscillation, which is driven by the planet's mass and moment of inertia.
Temporal oscillations are measured by satellites with very high precision, making the detection of the Free Nuclear Oscillation Frequency (FCNF) possible.
FCNF is caused by the modulation of the Earth's rotation axis in the free core nutation mode.
The amplitude of FCNF can change over time and provides information about the dynamics of the Earth's core.
For this study, we analyzed the existing FCNF observation database from space.
We use two methods to extract the FCNF signal from the noise.
The first one is based on statistical hypothesis testing, calculating the significance of the FCNF signal.
The second one is based on empirical mode decomposition to identify the components of the FCNF signal.
The results of the two methods are consistent, indicating that the amplitude of FCNF changes over time.
This indicates that the dynamics of the Earth's core may be of interest to scientists.
This work reexamines ideal fluid dynamics on Lie groups from a control perspective.
It is well known that these theories can be obtained by applying Lagrangian formalism to the famous Euler equations on the group of diffeomorphisms of three-dimensional Riemannian manifolds.

An equivalent Hamiltonian description is proposed, employing the theory of Lie groupoids and Lagrangian mechanics on Lie groupoids. Clear constructions are provided for several important special cases, including fluid dynamics on Lie groups, Newtonian gravity on special orthogonal groups and general linear groups, as well as the classical non-relativistic gravitational ECSK theory.

In the Hamiltonian description, fluid dynamics is represented on a Lie group, and ideal fluid dynamics is described through a Lie groupoid. Fluid dynamics is a special case where the source of this gauge groupoid homomorphism is the diffeomorphism group of the fluid domain.
Specifically, in the particle description, fluid dynamics and ideal fluid dynamics on Lie groups can be viewed as the result of deformation quantization of source groupoids.
The results indicate that the Schrödinger equation, which describes the evolution of quantum mechanics, is the geodesic equation of the magnetic connection of deformation quantization.

This allows for the construction of a mechanical system that macroscopically realizes ideal fluid dynamics, specifically exhibiting geodesic flow of a certain left-invariant metric on the solution group.
The obtained system is presented in explicit form as an example of ideal fluid dynamics on a special orthogonal group.
This also indicates that the constructed system is Hamiltonian, concerning a modified symplectic structure that corresponds to the Duval-Wyviat structure associated with the special orthogonal group.
Some precise solutions have also been proposed.
It presents the background research on the pn-CCD detector of the CERN Axion Solar Telescope (CAST).
The CAST experiment seeks to find solar axions by measuring the invisible conversion probability of solar axions to photons in the magnetic field of the Southern Solar Farm.
pn-CCD is one of the detector systems of CAST.
It consists of two hexagonal silicon photomultiplier planes, featuring a 0.85 mm depleted surface detector that covers 95% of the total sensitive area.
This study updates and improves the model-independent background analysis of the detector proposed in previous publications.
The expected signal rate induced by gamma rays in the silicon detectors and the surrounding passive materials has been calculated and compared with the measured background.
The derived ratio is used to derive a new photon background limit for CAST.

The background study on the CAST pn-CCD detector of the CERN Axion Solar Telescope has been submitted.
The CAST experiment searches for solar axions by measuring the probability of their invisible photon-axion conversion in the magnetic field of the Southern Solar Farm.
pn-CCD is one of the detector systems used by CAST.
It consists of two hexagonal planes and is equipped with a silicon photomultiplier with a 0.85 mm depletion surface detector, covering 95% of the total sensitive area.
This study updates and improves upon the model-independent background analysis of detectors that was previously published.
The expected gamma-ray induced signal ratio in the silicon detector and the surrounding passive materials was calculated and compared with the measured background.
The obtained rate is used to derive new photon background constraints for CAST.
The discovery of isolated stars has revealed a wide mass range from 3 to 18 solar masses (M☉).
This range includes white dwarfs with masses from 4 to 18 M_odot.
The maximum mass of a neutron star has been found to be between 2.2 and 2.5 solar masses, but there is a great deal of uncertainty regarding this number.
For binary star systems, it is much more challenging to form such massive compact objects, as a greater amount of material needs to be compressed for a longer period of time.
The origin of these very massive objects is not clear.
Some suggestions suggest that these extremely massive celestial bodies may be remnants of supermassive Type III star clusters.
These very large type III stars may have formed in regions of the early universe that were metal-free, as these very large celestial bodies were produced through a bottom-up formation mechanism.
Very massive third-generation stars may form with a mass of approximately 40 to 200 solar masses.
When these extremely massive third-generation stars finally exhaust their nuclear fuel, they can end their lives in the form of extremely massive compact objects.
Currently, there are very limited models for these extremely massive compact objects, which hinders our understanding of their evolution.
The current model of very massive compact objects assumes that the mass of the compact object is constant and equal to the initial mass of the progenitor.
However, a more realistic compact object mass model would take into account the mass loss that may occur during the formation process.
Magnetodielectric media with significant magneto-optical loss and dielectric loss support traveling waves that simultaneously attenuate and refract.

When the resonance loss characteristics of these mediums broaden due to the radiation process, the resultant local field enhancement and medium degradation may lead to significant reductions in refraction and absorption.

Here, we demonstrate, through theory and experiments, the phenomenon of negative refraction and reduced absorption in a resonant plasma radiation medium based on a thin yttrium iron garnet film, which exhibits inverse Faraday rotation.
The observed reduction in resonance refraction exceeds 25%, which is greater than the reduction effect of standard restructured negative index media.
In the measured frequency range, the reduction rate of absorption obtained exceeds 10%, which is the highest value reported in any resonant plasma radiation medium.
Our research results indicate that radiation loss may provide a promising approach for enhancing absorption and refraction in plasmas and magnetic media.
The post-Newtonian (PN) approximation is a powerful method for analyzing the gravitational behavior in systems composed of dense objects.
The first post-Newtonian approximation (1PN) of general relativity (GR) was built by Einstein and Rosen in 1932.
The Scalar-Tensor Theory (STT) generalizes general relativity by extending the graviton to a more general scalar field, leading to additional degrees of freedom for gravitational interactions.
The most general STT (scalar-tensor theory) action consistent with general covariance and the symmetry of a single scalar field is the Horndeski action.

In 1981, Deffayet and others discovered a new class of scalar-tensor theories, known as scalar-tensor theories with non-minimal coupling (STT[NGC]), which differ from general STT in the form of the coupling function.

To the first order, using the usual PN parameters (i.e., GM/(rc^2)), where M and r are the mass and distance of the system respectively, and G is the gravitational constant, in general spacetime theories [NGC], the equations of motion for a two-body system differ from the equations of general relativity by only 2.5 PN orders, while the self-coupling of a scalar field appears at 1.5 PN order.

In 2015, Brax and others demonstrated that a special class of spin-tensor theories (STT[NGC]), called scalar-tensor-relativity theories (STR), serves as a good approximation to general STT in large classes of spherically symmetric solutions, referred to as approximate solutions.

For the zero-order parameters of the usual PN (Post-Newtonian) approximation, the equations of motion in nearly spherically symmetric systems in STR (Special Theory of Relativity) are fourth order, and they simplify to the ordinary Emden equation, whose solution is an exact scalar-Columbo-Bonnet black hole with a finite horizon.
In this letter, we consider the slow motion of particles around such black holes and compare the obtained scalar-Gauss-Bonnet Hamiltonian with the Hamiltonian in general relativity.

We found that: i) In the 1.5PN and 2PN orders, the potential energy and the first term of the precession Hamiltonian in STR differ from those in GR, respectively represented by scalar and Gauss-Bonnet topological invariants; ii) The potential energy and the 1PN term of the precession Hamiltonian in STR are proportional to the square of the absolute value of the determinant of the spatial metric.
From then on, these invariants disappeared in the black holes under Einstein's gravity.
In summary, we have obtained the 2PN approximation of the scalar-Gauss-Binet gravity theory.
The generation interval (GI) refers to the interval between the time an individual becomes infectious and the time they become infectious again.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, many countries observed a decline in the virus transmissibility index (GI), suggesting that the virus's survival time in the population may be shortening.

This may help the virus spread more quickly throughout the population, or lead to increased uncertainty about when individuals are contagious, which could affect vaccination strategies or other mitigation strategies that rely on understanding the timing of infections.
To understand this phenomenon, we analyzed COVID-19 case data from Australia, Brazil, Italy, and the United States.
We found that the changes in GI vary over time and follow the trend of cumulative cases.
This allows us to build a GI model that accurately reproduces the observed time series.

We also found that the changes in GI are positively correlated with the changes in cumulative cases on a global scale and over an annual time scale, indicating that the observed contraction of GI is a global phenomenon.
Our research shows that real-time monitoring of the global COVID-19 pandemic can help public health departments better understand the COVID-19 pandemic and respond more effectively.
A method has been proposed to determine the electronic structure of a single dopant atom in silicon carbide using scanning probe microscopy.
Due to the different lattice structures of the dopant atoms and the host semiconductor, they may provide new opportunities for studying quantum systems at low temperatures.
Here, we demonstrate the concept of locally modifying the electronic structure of individual silicon carbide (SiC) atoms using electrically tuned scanning tunneling microscopy (STM).

The application of rapid voltage pulses alters the electronic structure of the donor atoms, allowing for a distinct feature to be observed in the dI/dV spectrum obtained using scanning tunneling microscopy (STM).

This method will enable the electrical detection and control of individual dopants in silicon carbide, paving the way for the study of quantum states in nanoscale devices and the development of atomically engineered sensors with these novel characteristics.
The control and study of individual dopants in silicon carbide (4H-SiC) offer an exciting possibility to customize nanoscale devices with novel quantum properties.
A single dopant atom has been shown to provide opportunities for studying quantum systems at low temperatures.

For example, the phosphorus atom is a well-studied donor atom that has been used to demonstrate the spin of a single phosphorus atom's electron and to investigate the phenomenon of electron quantum tunneling in this system.
However, detecting the electronic structure of a single doped atom in real time with high spatial resolution remains a significant experimental challenge.
In this study, we use scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) to locally modify the electronic structure of single 4H-SiC atoms.
The modification of the electronic structure of individual atoms enables the electrical detection and control of single dopants in silicon carbide.
As an example, we apply fast voltage pulses to the STM in order to locally alter the electronic structure of a single donor atom.
When the electronic structure of the donor atom was modified, a distinct feature was observed in the dI/dV spectrum.
We described the changes in the electronic structure of donor atoms and their impact on the dI/dV spectrum.

This method allows for the electrical detection and control of individual dopants in silicon carbide, paving the way for the study of quantum states in nanoscale devices and the development of atomic-scale sensors utilizing these novel properties.

A growing network is a general network model in which nodes can be in one of several states (such as "alive" or "dead") and can be activated (or "reachable") according to scheduling rules to become nodes in the network.
In this model, a node can have an arbitrary out-degree, and this out-degree may change over time.
In this model, we study the maximum in-degree that can be supported in a network where each node has an out-degree of one and nodes arrive according to a Poisson process.

It has been proven that the maximum in-degree is one if and only if the out-degree is two; and the maximum in-degree is two if and only if the out-degree is one and the in-degree distribution is restricted to Δ_0.
In other words, the maximum in-degree is constrained by the arrival process and the out-degree of the network.
In this article, we assume that nodes arrive according to a Poisson process, and the out-degree of the network is 1.
We study the maximum in-degree that can be supported when the in-degree is restricted by the out-degree of the network and the arrival process.

It can be proven that the maximum in-degree is one if and only if the out-degree is two; and the maximum in-degree is two if and only if the out-degree is one and the in-degree distribution is delta_0.
Determining the maximum in-degree for other out-degree distributions and other arrival processes remains an open problem.
Non-coding DNA (ncDNA) is far more than just "junk" DNA.

A large amount of evidence has accumulated from large-scale analyses of complete genomes, indicating that non-coding DNA sequences perform many important functions in cells, including encoding transcription regulatory elements, encoding small RNAs, forming secondary structures that regulate gene expression, and even encoding complete proteins.
It is noteworthy that two recent high-throughput RNA sequencing studies indicate that as much as 98% of eukaryotic genomes are transcribed into non-coding RNA (ncRNA).

Although the functions of most non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) are still unclear, there is an increasing amount of evidence suggesting that non-coding RNAs are an important component of gene regulatory networks, which are crucial for development, cell differentiation, and many other processes within organisms.

Compared to well-known protein-coding genes that typically remain highly conserved and rarely undergo mutations, non-coding DNA (ncDNA) sequences exhibit varying degrees of variability among different species, RNA transcripts, and individuals.

A large-scale analysis of the whole genome sequences of 1,201 human individuals found that the evolutionary rate of non-coding DNA sequences is significantly faster than that of coding sequences, highlighting the importance of non-coding RNA in driving rapid evolution.

Interestingly, careful observations of various types of sequence variations have found that most of the substitution mutations leading to amino acid changes in protein coding sequences are caused by non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs). This highlights the role of non-coding RNAs in the processes of rapid evolution and adaptation.

In this presentation, we will introduce the latest discoveries regarding the fascinating characteristics of these non-coding sequences and discuss the potential implications of these findings for our understanding of evolution and human health.
In this article, we study simple shear flow in the inelastic Maxwell model, where material particles have paired linear interaction forces.
For specific situations, we consider the case of constant shear stress.
Through the Chapman-Enskog analysis, we obtained a set of nonlinear differential equations for a specific model, applicable to the distribution function.
For the one-dimensional model, we observed the dynamic instability of periodic density waves and calculated the growth rate.
For a two-dimensional model, we demonstrate that the Navier-Stokes equations are recovered in the limits of large time and large length scales.
The change verification This paper studies simple shear flow in the inelastic Maxwell model, where there are paired linear interaction forces between material particles.
We particularly consider the case of constant shear stress.
Through the Chapman-Enskog analysis, we obtained a set of nonlinear differential equations for the model-specific distribution function.
For the one-dimensional model, we observed the dynamic instability of the periodic density wave and calculated the growth rate.
For the two-dimensional model, we demonstrate that the Navier-Stokes equations are recovered in the large time and large scale limits.
A new method of spectral imaging using stereo vision.
We have developed a hybrid differential stereo system (HDS) based on structured light, which uses two synchronized broadband optical filtering liquid crystal displays (LCDs).
We applied this system to a spectral imaging mode that uses white light to estimate the spatial temperature distribution of the scene.
Our proposed method combines the high spectral resolution of multi-band filter spectral technology with the wide field of view and high spatial resolution of structured light.
We have demonstrated through experiments that HDS allows for the measurement of temperature differences as small as 1 degree within a 200-meter field of view, and has a sub-millimeter resolution.
We found that with additional processing, this narrowband HDS system is capable of detecting temperature differences as small as one thousandth of a degree within the same 200-meter field of view.

This method overcomes some limitations of previous narrowband HDS systems, such as Pollefeys et al.'s system, which only used a single optical filter, or Huang et al.'s system, which, although utilizing advanced spectral separation technology, had a field of view of only 30 meters.
We believe that this work represents a novel narrowband hyperspectral imaging (HDS) method that will have a significant impact on many scientific and commercial spectral imaging applications.
The nature of leptons is one of the least understood aspects of particle physics.
Regarding the lightest hadron among the leptons, an important characteristic of the π meson is its radius.
The measurement of the radius will test our understanding of meson quantum fluctuations and the nature of strong interactions.
I will review the recent progress in determining the radius of mesons, discuss the unresolved issues, and explore potential directions for future research.
The meson radius is a characteristic of mesons among leptons. It is the lightest hadron, and its properties are still less clear compared to other hadrons.
The radius is related to the quantum fluctuations of the meson and its spatial distribution.
The radius of the hadron is of particular interest because it can be used to test our understanding of the nature of the strong force and its binding mechanisms.
Recently, progress has been made in determining the meson radius.

Progress has been made in lattice quantum chromodynamics, where computational grids are used to simulate mesons. At the same time, attempts are being made in experimental research to measure the form factors of mesons with high precision.
I will review this work and discuss unresolved issues and potential directions for future research.

A physical implementation scheme for a quantum NOT gate has recently been proposed.
There is potential to achieve scalable quantum computing using superconducting qubits, thereby opening the door to building large-scale quantum computers.

Here, we demonstrate that the reliability of the physical implementation of the quantum NOT gate is ultimately limited by dissipation, which stems from the requirement to maintain von Neumann entropy during the dynamic process of the quantum system.

In particular, we found that due to the accumulation of entropy, the fidelity of the quantum negation gate in this implementation is limited to less than 0.067 on the time scales required for quantum computation, which is significantly better than other proposed physical quantum computing methods.
This analysis sets a new standard for the precision of quantum computing, which can only be surpassed through actively controlled error suppression methods.
M. S. Allman et al., "Realization of a Quantum NOT Gate for Superconducting Qubits," arXiv:1809.07413 (2018).

"Active control" is used to suppress entropy accumulation in the quantum NOT gate of our physical implementation, enabling an error rate of less than 0.067 on the time scale required for quantum computing.
In deep field surveys, a large number of galaxies have been detected, whose brightness far exceeds their estimated star formation rates.
These ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (HyLIRG) have attracted special attention as potential probes of galaxy evolution in extreme environments.
In this article, we study six high-luminosity infrared galaxies (HyLIRGs) from the XMM-Newton telescope, for which X-ray data is available.

These include four E+A (post-starburst) galaxies, IRAS F09230–Mo1, IRAS F00183–7 Jam1, IRAS F00397–7537, and ClG J2218.1+0052, as well as two late-type HyLIRGs, IRAS F00183–7 Jam2 and ClG J2218.1-0053.

Except for IRAS F09230–Mo1, all other galaxies exhibit significant winds driven by stellar bursts, which have been well detected in X-rays, but no significant absorption has been found. This suggests that the HyLIRG phenomenon may be caused by extreme gas-rich mergers.
Halley’s Comet was a notable visitor to Earth in 1996.
It was visible for several weeks in the dawn light, attracting public and media interest, and became the subject of extensive research across various wavelength regions.
In this article, we present our research results on the Hale-Bopp comet in the mid-infrared wavelength range.
We observed the Hale-Bopp comet at the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) and the Copernicus Space Observatory during April, May, and June of 1996.
From this data, we are seeing signs of polarized light from Halley's Comet for the first time.
Our observations indicate that the Hale-Bopp comet is composed of many elongated ice particles, which are arranged almost perpendicular to the orbital plane of Hale-Bopp and its nucleus.
These results can be explained as follows: If the nucleus of Comet Hale-Bopp ejects material unevenly, then this may be the source of the rotational and orbital angular momentum of Comet Hale-Bopp.
We also studied the dust coma of comet Hale-Bopp and calculated its minimum orbital intersection distance (MOID).
We found that during our observations, the minimum orbit intersection distance (MOID) of Comet Hale-Bopp was approximately 3.2 Earth radii, a value similar to the observed size of the comet's coma.
We considered the implications of our results for the formation models of the Hale-Bopp comet and its parent nucleus, as well as for future comet exploration missions.

We present the results of the spectral index distribution (SIND) analysis conducted on a complete flux re-calibration sample of gamma-ray active galaxies (blazars) detected by the Energetic Gamma Ray Experiment Telescope (EGRET) on NASA's Compton Gamma Ray Observatory.
We also conducted a preliminary SIND analysis on the 3EG samples that were almost simultaneous.

Compared to most gamma-ray telescopes, EGRET detected almost all blazars as highly polarized gamma rays, and almost all of these objects exhibited significant variability on many different timescales.
Blazars are generally considered to be the brightest category of gamma-ray sources, and their spectra can often be well-fitted by a simple power law with a photon index of about 2.2.

We conduct the first SIND analysis of high-energy gamma-ray blazars using the complete flux recalibration samples from the third EGRET catalog, and demonstrate that the SIND of EGRET blazars is consistent with a one-dimensional truncated power law with an exponential cutoff.
At high energies (E > 100 MeV), the slope of the blazar SIND is approximately -2.2, while at lower energies it is slightly flatter.
The high-energy index is similar to the low-energy gamma ray flux, but the margin of error is quite large.
We also presented a preliminary SIND analysis of the 3EG data; however, the conclusions are limited due to the small number of sources and the incomplete sample in the EGRET band.
EGRET Yao Xing SIND may be the key to understanding the high-energy radiation processes in these celestial bodies and their connection with particles in the interstellar magnetic field.
The so-called "dark energy" is believed to be the reason for the recent acceleration of the universe's expansion.
Independent observations of this phenomenon began to emerge only in the late 2000s, so the question of when the universe actually began to accelerate has been an important topic of debate.
In this article, we use a range of different datasets to measure the timing of the transition from deceleration to acceleration.
We found that, although there is a high consistency in the average transition time, the accuracy of its determination is highly dependent on the choice of the dataset used.

Our research results indicate that cosmologists may have overestimated the uncertainty of the transition timing, which has implications for the design of future dark energy surveys and is currently under discussion.
The phenomenon of the accelerating expansion of the universe was first observed in the late 2000s, and since then, its underlying reasons have become a subject of extensive research.
Indirect evidence regarding this phenomenon, based on measurements of cosmic parameters, has only become available in the past decade.
Therefore, the question of when the acceleration of the universe's expansion actually began has always been a topic of debate.

In this article, we use a range of different datasets to address this issue and find that although the results for the average transition time are quite consistent, the precision determined is largely dependent on the choice of the selected dataset.

Our research results indicate that cosmologists have overestimated the uncertainty regarding the timing of the transition, which has implications for the design of future dark energy surveys, and related discussions are ongoing.

Our research findings are based on recent measurements of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) — the afterglow of the Big Bang — measurements of the large-scale structure lensing effect on background light, and results from directly measuring the rate of cosmic expansion using distant supernovae.
We found that the most consistent data indicates that the transition from deceleration to acceleration occurs between z = 0.5 and z = 0.0.

However, this determined accuracy largely depends on the datasets used, and our determination is based on the following datasets: z = 0.0 - 0.5 (the average of z = 0.0 and z = 0.5); z = 0.0 - 0.2 (the average of z = 0.0 and z = 0.2); z = 0.0 - 0.01 (the average of z = 0.0 and z = 0.01).

The 74MHz system (74MHz) was deployed on the Very Large Array (VLA) in 2012, and since then, it has detected hundreds of radio sources, including pulsars, planets, and synchrotron radiation from our galaxy.
The 74MHz system consists of 24 independent channels with a bandwidth of 225kHz each, covering a total frequency range of 11.2-74.1MHz.
The entire frequency band is divided into two polarizations with a width of 75.6 MHz, and these polarizations are Nyquist sampled at a rate of 1.2875 MHz.
Each baseband channel has a bandwidth of 25.6 kHz, providing a speed resolution of 22.1 km/s and a temperature sensitivity of -82.6 dBm in a single beam.
The 74MHz system has been used to measure bright galaxies with redshifts up to 7.5, to study the reionization era, and to conduct gravitational wave experiments.
The data from the 74MHz system is recorded using the F.C. Williams antenna and is released to the public.

In this article, we explore the possibility of using artificial intelligence technology to learn certain aspects from the distribution of the largest fragments in 304 stainless steel samples that are rich in iron and zirconium.

The goal is to examine whether the distribution of the largest fragments—which are referred to here as “key traces”—can be used as fingerprints to identify the source of the samples, and whether it contains information about the sample formation process.

We run a supervised machine learning algorithm with three categories: "Iron-rich," "Zirconium-rich," and "304 stainless steel," using the elemental concentrations of 26 elements as features, with key trace distributions as the target.

We found that the algorithm is capable of learning the differences between categories and generating different predictions for the three categories. When only 10% of the samples were used to train the algorithm, its accuracy exceeded 70%.

We also applied a similar algorithm, this time using burned histological images as input, and found that it was able to learn the distinction between "304 stainless steel" and "flame," even when using only 3 burn samples to train the algorithm.
This indicates that significant trace distributions can carry information about the processes that occurred prior to the formation of the material.

We believe that this work serves as a proof of concept, indicating that the distribution of the largest fragments that may be easily lost during the material manufacturing process can carry information that can be used to identify the processes that occurred prior to the formation of the material.
Recent advancements in film manufacturing technology have sparked a renewed interest in the study of magnetic films.

This is due to the coexistence of ferromagnetic layers and strong Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yoshida (RKKY) interaction layers in submicron-scale films, leading to novel magnetic ground states and a complex phase diagram.
From this study, we present the magnetic characterization of Co/Pt multilayer films synthesized by the selective area growth method.
Our X-ray magnetic circular dichroism measurement results show that in the remanent state, nanoscale uncompensated magnetic regions persist at low temperatures.
Our results are discussed in the context of the existing theoretical description of the thin film magnetic phase diagram.
The abbreviation "hrs." in English, which stands for "hours," can be translated into Chinese as "小时".
The phrase translates to: "The phase transition properties of magnetic films." Recent advancements in thin film fabrication technology have sparked new interest in the study of magnetic films.

This is due to the coexistence of ferromagnetic layers and strong Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yoshida (RKKY) interaction layers in submicron-scale films, leading to novel magnetic ground states and complex phase diagrams.
In this study, we demonstrate the magnetic properties of Co/Pt multilayer films synthesized using a selective area epitaxy method.
Our X-ray magnetic circular dichroism measurements show in the remnant state that there is a nanoscale uncompensated magnetic region at low temperatures.
Our results are discussed based on the existing theoretical description of thin film magnetic phase diagrams.
In the first part of this article, we propose a new algorithm for solving convection-diffusion equations with moving boundaries (i.e., free boundaries).
The algorithm is based on the discrete element method and uses the finite difference method for discretization in space and velocity.
The method is accurate when the boundaries are periodic or move at a linear speed.
We indicate that if linear interpolation of the convection velocity is performed between the unit center and the boundary, it is also consistent.
In practical applications, this method is effective as long as the flow speed is not too fast, or the spatial resolution is not too poor.
As an example of its application, we simulated the growth of solids in a viscous accretion disk.
We conducted algorithm tests on the analytical solutions of the diffusion-convection equation and showed that our results are consistent with the expected analytical solutions.
Then, we use our algorithm to study the evolution of solids in a viscous accumulation disk with various initial conditions.
In all cases, solid matter cannot reach the central star within a time scale of ten thousand years.
In the second part, we investigate the impact of solids on the evolution of dust in the disk.
Solids will generate a particle size distribution that is different from that of dust particles.
Specifically, solids tend to produce a large number of submicron-sized particles.
The exact form of this size distribution depends on the size and composition of the solid.
In this section, we propose several simple models to study the influence of solids on dust evolution.
We indicate that solids with specific sizes and compositions have different effects on the dust size distribution.

Finally, we demonstrate that the exact form of the particle size distribution is not very important for the evolution of the vast majority of dust in the disk: after about one million years, only large particles remain in the disk, and the evolution of dust is completely determined by dust settling and radial drift.
We conclude that solid objects cannot reach the central star within a timescale of ten thousand years, but they play an important role in the evolution of dust.
The particle size distribution of solid generation is different from that of dust particles.
The exact form of this size distribution depends on the size and composition of the solid.

The new generation of astrophysical electron telescopes, such as the recently launched HESRG, is opening a new window for particle astrophysics and is expected to significantly enhance our understanding of cosmic ray acceleration, propagation, and their numerous effects.
In this work, we present new HESRG data on the mysterious recurrent nova RS Ophiuchi, which was considered one of the most energetic outbursts observed in the modern era during its eruption in 2006.
We interpret our data within the framework of nonlinear diffusive shock acceleration (DSA) of cosmic rays and have drawn some new conclusions.

We found that electrons and ions can be well matched by a single power law with a common index of -2.29, and there are no signs of breaks or steep transitions in the transition from hadrons to electrons. Furthermore, their non-thermal radiation undergoes a rapid yet smooth transition across the energy range from keV to MeV.

Through a comparison with the theory of non-linear magnetic reconnection (DSA), we speculate that electrons are most likely accelerated to 300 TeV - 1 EeV by magnetic reconnection events within the high-speed magnetosphere jets of binary star systems, while ions are accelerated to 30 GeV - 1 TeV in a slower but more dispersed wind.

We ultimately compared our results with the previous predictions from the light echo observations of the 2010 RS Ophiuchi eruption—where we also detected non-thermal emission—and found that the results for electron energy were very consistent, but there were significant discrepancies in the results for ion energy.

We conclude that our results provide compelling new evidence indicating that nonlinear direct absorption (DSA) is a supportive paradigm for the extremely high energies observed in cosmic ray sources accelerated by electrons and ions.
The purpose of this article is to provide an overview of recent developments in the understanding of cosmological shocks.
These are fluid dynamics phenomena that occur when the properties of a fluid suddenly change, usually characterized by supersonic flow transitions.
In cosmology, these shock waves occur in the uneven distribution of matter, which leads to the formation of large-scale structures.
There are two different types of shock waves, which are distinguished by the speed of fluid movement before and after the shock.
Type 1 shock waves occur in relatively low-speed flows, specifically flows that are slower than the speed of light.
These shock waves occur during the process of matter accretion, which is how galaxy clusters form from small density fluctuations in the early universe.
These shocks are called sound waves or collapse shocks.
They can be described using a relatively simple linear theory, which has been validated through numerical simulations.
Type 2 shock waves occur in high-speed airflow, specifically in relativistic or transonic motion.
These shock waves are more frequent and more interesting to study than the previous ones.
The Hubble flow, which refers to the motion of galaxies relative to the observer, manifests as a type 2 shock wave.

The cosmological type II shock wave is used to explain certain phenomena, such as the 511 keV spectral line emission from the galactic center, large-scale structure, and the Kolmogorov spectrum of cosmological density fluctuations.
In recent years, the phenomenon of cosmic shock waves has rekindled people's interest.

This is due to new observational findings, such as the 511 keV spectral line and highly contrasted galaxy clusters, which demonstrate the necessity of moving beyond the homogeneous and isotropic cosmological model.
In the world of cosmology, the variations in matter density and velocity fields are much greater than what is expected from a simple homogeneous and isotropic model.
It is now known that type 2 shock waves are a universal characteristic of cosmic fluid flows.
However, their behavior depends on characteristics of the underlying cosmology, which can no longer be described by simple parameterization.
The study of cosmic shock waves requires the use of numerical simulations and increasingly complex analytical methods.
The organization structure of the article is as follows.
The theory and observation of the first type of shock wave are introduced in Section 2.
The formation of large-scale structures is described in Section 3 as a type 1 shock wave.
Section 4 introduces an analytical model for type 1 shock waves.
In the fifth section, a review of the numerical simulation of structural formation is provided.
In Section 6, Type 2 shock waves in the Hubble flow are introduced, and their impact on large-scale structure is discussed.
Section Seven summarizes these findings.
The MadGraph team is pleased to announce the latest major version upgrade of MadGraph, version 4.

MRELEASE is an important milestone for MadGraph, marking a significant evolution from early series-based simulation methods to modern runtime-based simulation paradigms, with unprecedented numerical precision and accuracy.

MadGraph v4 features numerous other improvements, particularly with a powerful and mature web frontend that offers a variety of out-of-the-box analytical capabilities, and support for LHCRun 2 and IceCube configurations has been enhanced.
We encourage all MadGraph users to update their code to the latest version.
MRELEASE Highlights - MadGraph has been upgraded to v4, featuring a powerful and mature web front-end.
MadGraph is now based on a modern runtime simulation paradigm, offering unprecedented numerical precision and accuracy.
Improvements have been made to the core functions of MadGraph, including new out-of-the-box analysis features and enhanced support for LHC phase two and IceCube configurations.
More details: https://bitbucket.org/madgraph/madgraph/wiki/Home
Coleman and de Lucia indicate that nontrivial topologies with nontrivial fundamental groups allow for the existence of Euclidean wormholes.

This method of traversing wormholes requires performing Euclidean path integrals on the wormhole and opening the traversal at the conclusion of the research by Coleman and De Luccia. Studies indicate that nontrivial topologies with nontrivial first homotopy groups allow for the existence of Euclidean wormholes.
This method of traversing a wormhole requires performing Euclidean path integrals on the wormhole, with the entry at one end of the wormhole and the exit closing at the end of the Euclidean universe.
Here, I demonstrate that the Euclidean path integral can be conducted without employing a global Euclidean metric, but rather based on the local heat energy density.

Because Euclidean wormhole instantons are based on local thermal energy, crossing a wormhole can occur at any point within the wormhole without the need to consider global temperature or topological structure, and the traversal can be completed by only opening one end of the wormhole.
This allows for tunneling from one topological structure to another without referencing the global Euclidean metric.

This new Euclidean wormhole version also applies to Lorentzian spacetimes, so Euclidean wormholes with non-trivial first fundamental groups may now allow for travel from one Lorentzian universe to another without violating the Coleman-Hellmann uniqueness theorem.
A theoretical study on the decoherence of a driven multi-level quantum system interacting with a multi-bath reservoir has been proposed.
A general description of a qubit-thermal bath model is proposed, in which the reduced density matrix of the qubit is obtained using a hierarchical quantum master equation method.

Our results show that under the non-linear and rotating wave approximation, for weak system-bath coupling, the reduced density matrix of the qubit converges to a product state, indicating that the state of the qubit becomes insensitive to its environment.

However, for strong system-bath coupling, we indicate that the non-diagonal elements of the reduced density matrix decay to zero much more slowly than the diagonal elements, which suggests that the qubit state becomes entangled with its environment.

Our results also indicate that regardless of the coupling strength, the purity of the qubit state decays to half within a short time, suggesting that the quantum information of the qubit rapidly depletes.

We illustrate our theoretical results through a representative model of a three-level system interacting with a one-dimensional bosonic reservoir, showing that as the coupling between the system and the environment increases, the entanglement between the system and the environment becomes stronger.
The W3 Giant Molecular Cloud (GMC) is a prominent region in the constellation Cygnus.
Located approximately 20 kiloparsecs away, W3 is one of the nearest grand design spiral galaxies, which contains an extremely dense young star cluster of high mass.
Historically, W3 has been used as a prototype GMC, exhibiting significant ongoing star formation.

For this study, we present far-infrared and submillimeter data obtained from the Hubble Space Telescope, as well as molecular line and radio continuum data from archival sources, to characterize the star-forming components of W3.
The far-infrared and submillimeter data are ideal detectors for thermal dust emission, showing a strong correlation with young star populations.
We found that the total luminosity of W3 is approximately 9.5 x 10^9 L⊙, and the total mass is 1.2 x 10^10 M⊙. At a column density of 1.87 x 10^21 cm^-2, its mass surface density is 221 M⊙ pc^-2.
We estimate the mass of W3 to be 250 x 10^3 M⊙, with an estimated threshold for star formation density of 2.2 x 10^4 M⊙ pc^-2.
This indicates that star formation is still occurring in W3, but the activity is not very vigorous.

In this case, W3 may not meet the typical standards of a rapidly forming galactic rose cluster (GMC), but rather is a very massive, very old (5-10 million years), stationary, and extremely dense star formation region.
Recently, some studies have claimed that the metallicity distribution in the solar neighborhood is non-Gaussian.
However, these claims are based on a situation where the number of stars in the sample is relatively small.
We use data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey to determine the distribution of metallicity at high latitudes.
The number of stars in our sample is on the order of tens of thousands, allowing us to confirm whether the distribution of metallicity is consistent with a Gaussian distribution.
We use the target's galaxy attenuation corrected brightness and SDSS DR12 to determine the metal abundance distribution.
We found that the distribution of metallicity at high latitudes does not differ significantly from the distribution of metallicity in the entire sample.
The probability that the high-dimensional sample and the overall sample come from the same population is greater than 99.99%.

The results suggest that the metallicity distribution of local stars is consistent with a Gaussian distribution, and previous studies that claimed the presence of a non-Gaussian distribution may have encountered statistical errors due to a small sample size.
The Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) will be an orbital telescope designed to detect weak gravitational waves.
The space-based gravitational wave detector is most effective in detecting the strongest bound systems: supermassive black hole (SMBH) binary systems.

In such a system, the accumulation rates based on mass and angular momentum can predict the phase relationship driven by accumulation. When the mass of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) is measured by other methods, such as stellar velocity dispersion or gas dynamics, the most precise tests of general relativity come from LISA's sensitivity to these parameters with measurement errors at the milliarcsecond level.
We report the results of a three-stage search for SMBHB candidates using LISA data.

The first phase is the matched filtering search using an error model; the second phase is a genetic algorithm search for coherent sinusoidal signals in LISA data; the third phase involves hierarchical Bayesian analysis of the population synthesis model for supermassive black hole binaries (SMBHB) to quantify the sensitivity of the first two phases to SMBHB signals.
In the three stages of the search, no significant candidates were found, resulting in a false alarm rate of less than 1 per billion years.
These results impose significant constraints on the spatial density of supermassive black hole binaries and restrict their evolutionary scenarios.
In this article, we provide evidence for the transverse proximity effect of spectral hardness in the direction of HE 2347-4342 for the first time.
The hard X-ray observations of this quasar were conducted using the Chandra satellite, revealing the proximity effect of the typical absorption system forest along the line of sight.

However, new optical observations conducted with the William Herschel Telescope (WHT) revealed a close region with a striped structure, with a transverse size of 30-40 kiloparsecs (kpc), indicating that the system's densely clustered distribution extends across the line of sight.
We discussed the evidence for the horizontal proximity effect and its impact on the lateral distance between systematic forests and central quasars.

This work was published on September 17, 2023, by L. M. Bogdanov, V. V. Zabolotny, D. C. Lu, G. P. Garmire, A. C. Fabian, R. S. Holt, A. K. Pollman, A. V. Filippenko, K. P. Hyett, J. E. Grindlay, M. Eracleous, L. C. Gallo, and T. Sikora on the arXiv preprint server, titled "Transverse Proximity Effect of Spectral Hardness along the Line of Sight to HE 2347-43." In this paper, we present the first evidence of the spectral hardness transverse proximity effect related to HE 2347-4342.

clean_wm_text: The hard X-ray observations from this quasar, conducted using the Chandra satellite, revealed the proximity effect of a typical absorption system forest along the line of sight.

However, new optical observations conducted by the William Herschel Telescope (WHT) revealed a nearby region with filamentary structures, extending approximately 30-40 kiloparsecs in radius, showing that the system's forest spans across the line of sight.
We discussed the evidence for the horizontal proximity effect and its influence on the horizontal distance between the systemic forest and central quasars.
The optical amplifier plays an important role in telecommunications networks.
Potassium-calcium phosphate-based optical amplifiers have recently been introduced as a cost-effective alternative to erbium-doped fiber amplifiers.
This article presents the optical properties of strontium-doped erbium (Er3+) KCa3(PO4)2 glass, which are promising candidates for low-cost optical amplifiers.

For the KCa3(PO4)2: Er3+ sample, the transmittance, photoluminescence, and photoluminescence spectra, as well as the radiative and non-radiative lifetimes, were measured in the wavelength range from 200 nanometers to 1000 nanometers.
A detailed study on the temperature dependence of the spectral properties of Er<sup>3+</sup> ions has also been proposed.
The obtained results can be used to customize Er3+-doped KCa3(PO4)2 glass for specific optical amplifier applications.

Analyzing the spectra of individual galaxies is one of the most promising methods for measuring their physical properties, as it allows for the differentiation between starlight and active galactic nuclei (AGN), and may potentially map the spatial distribution of different types of galaxies.

Despite the large surveys conducted recently, such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; @SDSS), which provide a vast number of galaxy spectral samples, their analysis still requires a considerable amount of effort.
On the other hand, modeling a single galaxy is time-consuming, as it requires understanding many parameters that describe the galaxy.

The combination of these two approaches—a synthesized galaxy spectral library that parameterizes the fundamental properties of galaxies and allows for the fitting of individual galaxy spectra—will greatly simplify the process of galaxy spectral analysis and may become key to fully realizing the potential of current and future spectral surveys, such as the Gaia mission.
To this end, we have started to build a synthetic galaxy spectral library based on state-of-the-art physical models, and we will make it publicly available to the community.

Here, we present the first results of galaxy sample classification based on the random forest algorithm. This algorithm is trained on a dataset of 3 million galaxy spectrum samples, and we also provide these samples along with the corresponding library.

We demonstrated that galaxies in the library can be classified based on four fundamental properties: stellar light fraction, active galactic nucleus fraction, spatial distribution of stellar light, and the physical size of the galaxies.
We also present preliminary results on the parameterization of unresolved galaxies in the Gaiaspectro database through random forest regression.

We reported on the dielectric spectral study of the relaxor-based ceramic 0.65[Pb(Ni_1/3Nb_2/3)O_3]-0.35PbTiO_3 (PNN) during the so-called super-cooled liquid and layered-C* (Sm-C*) phase transitions.
We showed that the temperature dependence of the dynamic susceptibility χ″(T) and the dielectric loss factor ε″(T) is significantly different in these two states.
We believe that the existence of two relaxation phenomena corresponding to two energy scales in the ultracold liquid state is a precursor phenomenon to the phase transition to the Sm-C* phase.
We compare our results with the latest relaxation body theory models and discuss the significance of our findings for the phase transition physics of relaxation body systems.

We presented a dielectrical spectroscopy study of the relaxor ceramic based on 0.65[Pb(Ni_1/3Nb_2/3)O_3]-0.35PbTiO_3 (PNN) during the so-called overcooled liquid and layered C* (Sm-C*) phase transition process.
We indicate that the temperature dependence of dynamic susceptibility χ″(T) and dynamic loss factor ε″(T) is significantly different in the two states.
We believe that there are two relaxation phenomena corresponding to two energy scales in the ultracold liquid, which is a precursor phenomenon to the phase transition to the Sm-C* phase.
We compare our results with the latest theoretical models of relaxor materials and discuss the implications of our findings for the phase transition physics of relaxor systems.
Theoretical predictions suggest that stars with a mass greater than about twice that of the Sun may form a degenerate core, and thus become the magnetic stars known as Ap stars.
If such a connection exists, observational evidence can provide strong constraints on stellar evolution models.
Here, we report on the spectropolarimetric observations of 150 candidate Ap stars belonging to open clusters and associations.

We measured the longitudinal magnetic field, based on which we assumed a relationship between the magnetic field strength and the rate of rotational slowdown, thereby obtaining an estimate of the star's rotational rate.
We found a significant negative correlation between stellar age and the measured magnetic field strength, with the slowest rotating stars exhibiting the strongest magnetic fields.

This is consistent with the timescale for the evolution of the magnetic field strength weakened by spin, which is about 10^6 years, far exceeding the estimated lifespan of stars with convective cores.
This is the first observational evidence demonstrating the connection between magnetic fields and stellar evolution.
Manganese and other rare earth elements are examples of impurities that may localize at the interstitial sites of the semiconductor host lattice.
These defects may be related to the formation of bound states of free charge carriers—commonly referred to as localized charge carriers—resulting in the formation of impurity bands.

For non-magnetic impurities, the dominant interaction mechanism is the so-called Hund's rule coupling, while in the presence of impurities with local magnetic moments, the Zeeman interaction must be considered.

If the localized magnetic moments and carriers are both decoupled at a finite temperature, we will encounter a magnetic impurity band that may exhibit characteristics unique to localized and delocalized carriers.

To understand the properties of impurity bands, we studied the case of dilute magnetic semiconductors (DMS), focusing on the transition from localized to delocalized charge carriers by systematically varying the Coulomb attraction of the acceptors.
In this context, the physical concept of Wannier functions is used to describe the spatial extent and localization characteristics of the impurity band wave functions.
The Coulomb attraction of the receptor is modeled through a dielectric background to take into account the screening behavior of charge carriers in the valence band.
By comparing the calculated spectra with the corresponding experiments, we are able to extract relevant material parameters.

The results of this theoretical study allow us to conclude that the receptor limited migration rate of the DMS system can be described by a simple formula: σ(cm²/V·s) = (μ0(cm²/V·s) · ε(0) · N(D) · N(A))½, where μ0 is the mobility without local charge carriers, N(D) is the receptor density, and N(A) is the donor density.
Therefore, for a fixed acceptor density, in dilute magnetic semiconductors, the carrier mobility limited by the acceptor is determined only by the density of the donor.
This fundamental relationship must be regarded as a universal characteristic of all IV-VI compounds containing magnetic impurities and non-magnetic hosts.
The c2d legacy project mapped the emissions of gases and ice particles condensed on the surface of dust grains in 14 molecular clouds.
This, combined with complementary millimeter and sub-millimeter continuous data, provides estimates of the dust temperature, column density, and mass of these clouds.
In this article, we compare the spatial distribution of recent star formation in these interstellar clouds revealed by continuous observations with Bolocam at 1.1 mm.
Generally speaking, the stellar formation in Aquila and Ophiuchus seems to be more widespread than in Serpens, although the data-to-noise ratio for the former is relatively low.
The Perseus and Ophiuchus clouds also display unique central condensation structures, while these structures do not appear in the data from Ophiuchus.
Specifically, the Perseus and Ophiuchus clouds exhibit distinct two-dimensional features, while these features are not present in the data from Serpens.

The Perseus cloud seems to be undergoing a large-scale global collapse, which is reflected in the concentration of its central linear structure and the decrease in dust mass at the centers of certain bright 1.1 mm condensates.
If this statement is true, it means that star formation in Andromeda is more concentrated recently than what the Bolocam data suggests.

Due to the large spatial scale sampled by the Bolocam observations (0.1-2 pc), the mass of the material associated with recent star formation in Orion is comparable to or greater than the typical mass of the gas and dust within these clouds.
In light of this, the spatial distribution of recent star formation in Cygnus and Ophiuchus is likely not particularly significant.
Finally, the Yiy Galaxy and the Ophiuchus Galaxy exhibit similar levels of recent star formation, considering the amount of cold gas and dust observed in these regions.
The Fermi Golden Rule (FGR) is an intuitive principle for understanding the evolution rate of quantum systems.
It indicates that the rate of certain physical processes is proportional to the square of the density of states (DOS) from the initial state to the available final state.
This proportional constant is referred to as the intensity of the process.
This rule is accurate for weak system-bath coupling.
In quantum systems on the molecular relaxation time scale, the Fermi Golden Rule (FGR) predicts an exponential dependence of relaxation time on thermal energy.

The experimental validation of the prediction using the infrared (IR) photon emissivity at different temperatures shows that the predicted dependence is valid only at high temperatures, whereas at low temperatures, the relaxation time is much shorter than expected.
This result is interpreted as a characteristic of quantum dynamical phase transition (QDPT), reflecting the scale-invariant behavior of the system.

The subsequent theoretical analysis of general quantum mechanical systems with weak system-environment coupling shows that the relaxation time's dependence on temperature is not exponential, but rather follows a power law.
This discovery was subsequently supported by numerous experiments on different quantum systems.
In this article, we argue that the theoretical framework of FGR based on scale invariance analysis is not suitable for real quantum systems.

In particular, we focus on the initial QDPT proposal based on the temperature dependence of the relaxation time index and point out that this assumption leads to a misinterpretation of the validity of FGR.
Then, we analyze the relaxation time and the Fermi Golden Rule (FGR) in a phenomenological microscopic quantum relaxation model.
We demonstrate that the relaxation time as a function of temperature exhibits a power-law characteristic, rather than the exponential dependence predicted by the Fermi golden rule.
Using a microscopic model, we fitted the relaxation times at different temperatures and extracted the temperature dependence of the microscopic parameters.

The analysis based on microscopic parameters indicates that at low temperatures, quantum criticality disappears, and the predictions of the microscopic model are consistent with those of the classical model.

We further indicate that the power-law temperature dependence of the microscopic parameters leads to a power-law temperature dependence of the relaxation time, which is consistent with the results obtained using phenomenological models.
Our analysis indicates that FGR cannot be applied to quantum systems within the QDPT framework.

We also proposed another perspective on quantum dynamical phase transitions, indicating that quantum dynamical phase transitions only exist in classical systems and do not exist in the limit of quantum systems.
Our analysis shows that QDPT is a manifestation of classical mechanics in quantum systems, as quantum interference effects are neglected in the approximation.
Using the proposed substitute theory, we demonstrate that scale invariance is an effective principle of quantum dynamical phase transitions.

Our analysis reveals the mechanism of quantum dynamical phase transition in the classical limit and indicates that scale invariance is not a fundamental symmetry of quantum systems, but rather an emergent behavior at long range in the classical limit.
In the standard model (SM), the production of the top quark is described by seven penguin diagrams at the Tevatron, while at the LHC it is described by nine penguin diagrams.

For the energy levels of the LHC, higher-order corrections are significant, and the uncertainties from various sources also increase accordingly. For example, the inherent theoretical uncertainty in leading-order calculations, as well as the experimental uncertainties in jet energy and initial state particle momentum knowledge, will be exacerbated by the increase in higher-order corrections.

Although the total cross section of top quarks measured by the two experiments is consistent with the expectations of the Standard Model and has a global significance of 2.9 standard deviations, several anomalous observations have been reported: measurements of forward-backward asymmetry by CDF and D0, the total cross section of top-antitop production, and the production of single top quarks associated with W bosons.

Although the measured forward-backward asymmetry is consistent with the expectations of the Standard Model, all other measurement results deviate from the predictions of the Standard Model by 2.5 to 3.6 sigma.

The current hypothesis is that these deviations may be caused by the production of new strong interaction particles, which decay into top quarks. Therefore, the search for these particles has been a focus of recent research.

In this work, we performed a global fit on all anomalous measurements, assuming the production of non-standard spin-1 particles that decay into top quarks and a new, heavy, charged neutral scalar or vector boson.

We found regions in the parameter space of the new physical model that are compatible with all observational results, and we present the corresponding expected characteristics in collider experiments.

Type Ia supernovae are currently the best distance indicators; they are standardizable sources of light, and their high brightness is directly related to the Chandrasekhar mass in white dwarf systems.

The ancestor systems of these double degenerate systems are believed to consist of a carbon-oxygen white dwarf, accreted material from a non-degenerate companion star, and very likely a neutron star (or black hole). Under the influence of gravity, this material ultimately accumulates to a sufficient mass, triggering an explosion of a Type Ia supernova.
We present near-infrared and optical observations of Type Ia supernova 2001el conducted with the Very Large Telescope (VLT) and new technology telescopes from the European Southern Observatory.
The light curve of 2001el shows a peak observed approximately 120 days after the fitted explosion date, and its spectrum is very similar to that of a typical type.
A type Ia supernova one month after reaching its maximum brightness.

We investigated the possible causes of the late light curve break observed in 2001el, comparing it with normal type Ia supernovae and other type Ia supernovae (SN 2002bo, 2003hv, 2003bb, and 2003ee) observed under different cosmic backgrounds.

Our results support a Chandrasekhar-mass white dwarf model for 2001el, even though we cannot completely rule out the possibility of a non-degenerate companion or the presence of a helium-rich composition in the progenitor.
Late observations from more Type Ia supernovae are crucial for better understanding the role of degenerate binary scenarios and possible explosion variations.
In this article, we present a rigorous mapping that connects the Ising spin glass model and the Ising model over a longer temperature range, where the former exhibits only disordered behavior.

The proof is based on the so-called Hamiltonian decomposition, which allows the partition function of the spin glass model to be expressed as a product of simpler terms, each corresponding to a specific frozen spin configuration.

The properties indicated by frozen spins suggest that the coupling between corresponding terms in the Ising model and the glass spin model is positive. Therefore, the entire product must be positive, which allows us to restrict our consideration to positive Boltzmann weights, greatly simplifying the analysis.
The mapping is done for a general graph, which means that the underlying lattice structure is not specified.

In this paper, we study a 4D Z_2 symmetric thick brane solution in AdS spacetime.
We calculate the Witten index and vacuum density corresponding to this solution.
We indicate that these densities are non-trivial and depend on spacetime and the fifth dimension.

We consider the 5-dimensional Einstein-Maxwell action, utilizing a 5-dimensional Minkowski spacetime metric, and generating a potential that has a Z_2 symmetric thick brane solution. At the same time, we take into account the 5-dimensional Riemannian metric and the 4-dimensional induced metric on both sides of the brane, as well as the appropriate jump in the fifth component of the 5-dimensional vector potential on the brane.
Using this brane configuration to solve the 5D motion equations, we calculated the Wightman function and vacuum density of the system.
We prove that these densities are non-trivial and depend on spacetime and the fifth dimension.

Despite extensive research in recent years, the ferromagnetism of doped graphene remains an important unresolved issue.

In the case of electronic doping, there is strong evidence indicating the presence of Stoner ferromagnetic instability, while in hole-doped systems, there is a substantial amount of evidence supporting the existence of a non-magnetic ground state.
Here, we indicate that the magnetic properties of hole-doped graphene can be understood using the bosonization theory with SU(4) C1S0 symmetry.
Our method starts with a generalized Hubbard model that has full SU(4) symmetry.
Using a combination of non-perturbative methods, namely the functional renormalization group and cluster perturbation theory, we find that the model exhibits ferromagnetism at low energies.

This suggests that the C1S0 symmetry may be generally related to the ferromagnetic ground state in doped graphene and could also be associated with other systems with strong electron correlations, such as high-temperature superconductors.

According to our recent research (Carroll et al. 2012, hereinafter referred to as Paper I), we provide evidence of an active star formation event occurring in the supercompact H ii region NGC 7538 in the Perseus spiral arm, using Spitzer and IRAS data.
IRAS determined that 70% of the brightness of NGC 7538 comes from this small region, and Spitzer identified 12 infrared point sources with spectral types B3 or later.
These results, along with our multi-band analysis of the region, suggest that stars may be forming in the area at a higher rate.
In this study, we further investigate this formation event using new molecular outflow data obtained from the Jansky Very Large Array (JVLA).
We combine the new observational results with existing near-infrared and mid-infrared data to further study the processes occurring in NGC 7538.
We use the CLOUDY photodissociation region (PDR) modeling code to create a physical scenario for the molecular outflow in NGC 7538.
This analysis indicates that the region is likely producing stars rapidly through bipolar outflows rather than through gravitational collapse.
SunOS/Solaris is a widely used Unix operating system and is one of the most popular operating systems for servers, desktops, and workstations.
In this article, we evaluate the availability of some SunOS/Solaris systems by analyzing the corresponding wtmpx and Syslogd log files.

The wtmpx file stores user-related work timestamps, while the Syslogd log file contains information from the system logs (such as error messages, information generated by the run level transition mechanism, and other information that the system is supposed to log).
These two files are regularly backed up in different locations.
We study the availability of these systems by examining the corresponding wtmpx and Syslogd files, as well as observing the relevant syslogd and getty processes.
We detect various types of failures, such as irrecoverable equipment or software failures, shutdown or startup failures, and process failures.

In addition, we have noticed that the logs are not always kept for a long enough duration to properly detect certain faults, such as run levels that are not configured to be retained for an extended period or getty processes that terminate after a certain time.
The results indicate that for the analyzed system, considering different types of failures, the mean time between failures (MTBF) ranges from 3.12 hours to 4.96 hours.
The corresponding mean time to repair (MTTR) ranges from 5 minutes to 5 hours, with a median of 30 minutes.
We suggest distinguishing between neutron stars and black holes by observing the event horizon of neutron stars rather than the event horizon of black holes.
Unlike black holes, gravity stars have an additional surface called a hanger hole, through which matter can fall into the interior of the gravity star but cannot escape.
Therefore, a test particle in the gravitational field of a gravastar will accumulate energy while trying to climb the hanger hole, but ultimately will fall within the event horizon.
On the contrary, in the gravitational field of a black hole, test particles do not experience such cumulative energy transfer; instead, they are pulled into the event horizon.
The suggested distinguishing observational features will help resolve the current debate regarding the nature of dark matter.

Keywords: Dark matter, gravitational star
