The translation of "小东农民 arXiv.org 2022年6月1日" into English is "Little Dong Farmer arXiv.org June 1, 2022."
In 1994, Mazur and Mottola proposed the possibility of an object called a gravastar as an alternative to black holes.
Gravitational stars are different from black holes because they have an additional surface known as the "hanger hole," through which matter can fall in but cannot escape.
Therefore, a test particle can accumulate energy in the gravitational field of a gravitational star while attempting to climb over the hangers, but will fall beyond the event horizon.
In contrast, test particles in the gravitational field of a black hole do not experience this cumulative ergodic energy transfer; instead, they are pulled into the event horizon.
The proposed distinguishing observational features may help address the current debate regarding the nature of dark matter.
This article studies the second-order optimality in electrical impedance tomography (EIT).
For the standard elliptic electromagnetic inversion problem, a state with minimal energy relative to specified electric boundary conditions does not necessarily correspond to a physical shape.
This phenomenon is commonly referred to as impedance artifact.
Research has shown that this problem can be reformulated as a constrained second-order minimization problem, subject to incompressibility constraints and globalization conditions.
In this work, we propose a unified shape optimization method for first-order and second-order electrical impedance tomography (EIT).
We indicate that the corresponding energy functional is second-order when the current state deviates from the optimal solution.
We apply a convex relaxation to the second-order shape derivative in order to characterize it through the Dirichlet energy, thus reducing the analysis to the level of convex analysis.
Provided numerical experiments to illustrate the theory.
In three-dimensional topology, the Sassone norm is a natural generalization of the Euler characteristic.

Although its definition is reasonable for any three-dimensional manifold, characterization has so far only been done for representations of its fundamental group in the special linear group over the complex field.
We indicate that the Thurston norm can be computed by considering any such representation in standard three-dimensional space, and that the representation is over the real numbers.

Therefore, we provide a new proof showing that the standard surfaces in certain knot complements are compact: each smooth embedded disk in these surfaces has an odd multiplicity at each of its points.

The proof is based on the work of Agol, Boileau, and C.T. Tseng, as well as the research by Rosenthal and Sivek on the primary decomposition of regular surfaces, and Gay's studies on the complex field—this is the real version of the classical Grauert-Remmert theorem.
We also provided a new proof indicating that fiber surfaces of normal surfaces in the correction space are strong norm SP surfaces.

The spectral and astronomical measurement data are presented in section 2.

Turbulence is typically characterized by the locality hypothesis, under which kinematics and dynamics are largely separable in space and time.
In this paradigm, fluid motion has been decomposed into characteristic patterns or vortices, which are typically arranged in quasi-regular structures such as shear, jets, and fronts.
As an example, in compressible turbulence, these vortices typically exhibit a hierarchical arrangement, where large-scale structures such as filaments and clusters fall within smaller-scale vortices.

This process is usually characterized by power-law scaling, where the size, velocity, density, and temperature of vortices at each scale are related to these quantities at the next smaller scale by a characteristic scale factor.
This phenomenon is called multifractality, which implies a self-similar structure and has been observed with varying degrees of rigor in multiple physical systems.
In this work, we presented high-resolution direct numerical simulations of compressible turbulence, with a particular focus on the nature of multi-scale characteristics within the range of scales.
We found that the multiscale phenomenon is not as obvious as in comparable experimental and Euler grid-based simulations, but it is clearly present under a range of flow conditions.

We believe this is due to the multi-scale development in compressible turbulence. As the characteristic time scales increase, the scale relationships gradually break down because the patterns begin to separate.
This process is referred to as intermittency, meaning it has a negative scaling exponent and correspondingly has a flatter multifractal scaling exponent.

We validate this hypothesis by constructing a multifractal model and demonstrate that the predicted intermittency leads to multiscale rupture, as the flow transitions from a steady state to an unstable state.
This provides a useful framework for explaining multi-scale observations in turbulence and has significant implications for the dynamics of clusters in highly compressible fluids.
Turbulence, including turbulence generated in the atmosphere and in fusion plasma simulations.
The anomalous X-ray pulsar 4U 0142+61 has been monitored by the Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer (RXTE) for over 11 years.
The obtained data was analyzed in both the time domain and the frequency domain.
The results indicate that the source has experienced several flux state transitions, exhibiting temporal irregularity and broadband noise components at low frequencies.
We have for the first time detected quasi-periodic oscillations (QPO) at 27.6 seconds and 60.4 millihertz.
High-frequency quasi-periodic oscillations (QPO) are likely the Kelvin frequency of the distorted magnetosphere of compact celestial objects.
The low-frequency QPO will be a frequency group of a neutron star.

Previously, 4U 0142+61 was observed to switch between two states: one is the soft state, during which the source exhibited high-frequency QPOs; the other is the hard state, during which the source exhibited low-frequency QPOs.
The source has never been observed to be in two states at the same time.
In the current dataset, the source is in a hard state for almost the entire monitoring period, only being in a soft state for a short period of time.
The transition between different flux states and the time irregularities observed in the source's temporal behavior may be results of changes in the geometry of the source's magnetic field.

Our results indicate that further research on the long-term temporal and flux behavior of this source will contribute to a better understanding of the internal structure of neutron stars and the processes governing particle transport in the magnetospheres of neutron stars.
In this article, we study a special case of quantum walks where the probabilities of the walker moving left and right are biased by a factor α in one direction.
The model is referred to as self-interacting quantum walk and can be implemented in various physical systems, such as electrons on an inhomogeneous lattice.

We consider a general initial condition, allowing the walker to have an arbitrary fractional part, and prove that the quantum walker will converge to a pure quantum state in a finite amount of time, whose eigenvalue density is equal to 1.
We also considered this classic analogy of walking, where at each time step, the pedestrian can choose to take a step to the left or to the right with a certain probability.
Due to the fact that classical random walks are typically asymptotic, we demonstrate that when α is sufficiently small, classical walks will always converge to a periodic configuration.
We presented numerical simulations of the time-dependent behavior of quantum and classical self-interacting walks.
As a further application of our technology, we have demonstrated that quantum walks converge to classical walks in distribution.
In addition, we studied two metrics of mixed time: the quantum version of quantum regression localization and the classical version corrected by the Klein gas.
Finally, we conducted a large deviation analysis on the classic self-generated gait and demonstrated that the walker is most likely to remain in a limited number of cells.
We have derived the entropy inequality for the lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) for ideal gases.

The lattice Boltzmann equation is a popular discretization method for the continuous Boltzmann equation of rarefied gases, providing a simple algorithm for calculating moments similar to the Navier-Stokes equations.
However, Chapman and Enskog's analysis of the lattice Boltzmann method indicates that the method does not provide cooling, which is an entropy error first pointed out by Zhou et al.

"[J. Stat.]" can be translated into Chinese as "[统计学杂志]" (if it refers to a specific statistical journal, such as "Journal of Statistics"), but since it is an abbreviation, we usually retain the original text "[J. Stat.]". If you can provide more context, I can offer a more accurate translation.

The translation of the Chinese text is:

"Physics, 165, 1 (2016)."
Our first result is an upper bound on the heat flow when the LBM conservation moments are considered.
We then use the Kullback-Leibler relationship and the monotonicity property of discrete chain rates to prove a discrete entropy inequality.
We prove that as long as the solution has at least second-order accuracy in space and time, the LBM conservation moments satisfy this discrete entropy inequality.
We propose an LBM discretization that satisfies the discrete entropy inequality with first-order and second-order accuracy, applicable to both space and time.

Numerical evidence indicates the practicality of our entropy-corrected LBM scheme, as it can provide statistically accurate solutions for the fluctuating viscous compressible Navier-Stokes equations in both two-dimensional and three-dimensional spaces.
Polarized proton-proton (PP) collisions make precise studies of proton spin structure and the nature of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) possible.

In April 2021, the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) conducted collisions of longitudinally polarized proton beams at a center-of-mass energy of 200 GeV. These collisions provide an opportunity to study spin interactions in high-energy polarized colliders.

A fundamental plane of galaxy clusters is proposed, described by the correlation between the optical diameter of the galaxy clusters and the temperature measured by the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect.
The assumptions of this aircraft are minimal, making it very robust.

The normalized distribution of sources on the plane matches well with the theoretical model of structure formation, indicating that this plane can be used to characterize the dark matter content of clusters, thereby inferring their masses.
The plane observations estimate for galaxy clusters detected through the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect and X-ray thermal emission is provided.
The estimated normalized intrinsic dispersion in the plane is lower than the measured independent normalized uncertainty, indicating that the intrinsic scattering within the plane is also low.
This may be due to the close correlation between the optical diameter of the star cluster and its temperature.
The optical diameter of a star cluster can be determined by imaging the sunlight reflected off its surface, for example using the Hubble Space Telescope.

The temperature of a galaxy cluster can be measured using the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect, which causes the thermal spectrum of the cosmic microwave background radiation to shift towards longer wavelengths when the cluster pulls some of the background gas of the cosmic microwave background radiation towards it.

In the literature, the collection of magnetic monopoles has been widely studied due to their potential significance in quantum chromodynamics (QCD), which is the fundamental theory of strong interactions.
These sets provide a framework to explore non-perturbative aspects of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) that cannot be studied using Monte Carlo techniques.
In this work, we use the monopole solution of the Bogomolny equation to constrain such a set.
These magnetic monopoles are point particles that possess both electric charge and magnetic charge simultaneously.
They are coupled under the magnetic dipole moment.
We use an improved Powell method to solve the resulting nonlinear equations and generate an integral of monopole solutions.
The strength of the constraints in this set is controlled by varying the 't Hooft coupling constant, which is a theoretical parameter that governs the self-interaction of magnetic monopoles.
We characterize this set through several order parameters and observe that the system exhibits a deconfinement phenomenon, where magnetic charges move freely in Euclidean spacetime.
This letter describes a preliminary study of the constraint properties of such a collection and the order parameter that characterizes it.

In the process of mixing different components, soft repulsive spherical particles (RSS) typically segregate into distinct global phases, where the amount of medium-range RSS mixing, Q2, is relatively small.
Here, we report the identification of strong attractive depletion interactions over a wide range of Q2 in RSS binary mixtures, even at high RSS filling fractions.
The strong depletion interaction arises from the competition between two different forces between particles, namely the hard-sphere steric repulsion and the RSS attraction.

Using three independent techniques, we found that these depletion forces dominated other pairwise forces, such as RSS particle wetting, RSS electrostatic interactions, and short-range chemical bonding, over a Q2 range spanning three orders of magnitude.

At high RSS filling densities, attractive depletion interactions lead to enhanced RSS separation, resulting in an unexpectedly rich phase diagram with the emergence of two or even three coexisting global phases.

The identified strong attractive depletion interactions may find potential applications in customized programmable phase diagram RSS mixtures, as well as in controlling RSS self-assembly in the fields of bottom-up nanotechnology and soft robotics.
A method of light cone quantum chromodynamics has been proposed to study the distribution amplitude of axial vector mesons.

Using the collective representation of distribution amplitudes in light cone formalism, we obtained the following results: (1) We reproduced the well-known early Gegenbauer polynomials/coefficient for the axial vector mesons of three flavors of leptons; (2) We calculated two additional Gegenbauer polynomials/coefficient for the first twist-2 distribution amplitude (DA) of the axial vector meson; (3) We conducted a detailed study of three types of asymptotic DAs: the Chernyak-Zhitnitsky DA, its transverse version, and a version of the more commonly used positive mapping Lambert W DA; (4) We investigated and provided an explanation in the language of light cone quantum chromodynamics (QCD) for several ideal properties of axial vector DAs; (5) Recent experimental data from CLAS12 on the transition form factors of π mesons were well described.

clean_wm_text: The global Wolf-Rayet content derived for the nearby NGC 300 galaxy is 12%, significantly higher than the currently estimated 7% (Schaerer & Vacca 2010).
This high value may be explained by a recent star formation event suggested by the detected ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) in the outskirts of the galaxy (Israel et al. 2014).
However, a closer examination of the archived data shows that the global WR content upper limit for NGC 300 is actually 7%.
In addition, the contribution of the entire Milky Way to the upper limit of brightness in the U band is 2.2%, while the value derived from the global Wolf-Rayet component is 8.3%.
This apparent difference can be explained by the late-type star composition of the galaxies.
Late-type stars dominate in optical wavelengths. Considering the relationship between age and metallicity, they will exhibit a higher proportion of early-type Wolf-Rayet stars.
Indeed, the KS test conducted on the observed and modeled optical colors of the galaxy indicates that the probability of the two samples coming from the same population is very low (P < 0.001).
We estimate that the global WR contribution of the galaxy in the U band brightness is 1.2%, which is consistent with the observed upper limit.
The sub-dwarf B (sdB) stars are composed of partially degenerate helium cores that were once massive late-stage helium stars.

Due to their degenerate core, sdB stars are essentially black bodies in the visible light range; their spectra are composed of many absorption lines, the strengths of which are proportional to the surface temperature.
Because the temperature of sdB stars typically reaches several thousand Kelvin, their spectra can be observed with ground-based telescopes.
In fact, people can detect the pulsations in the spectrum of sdB stars, but their nature is currently unclear.
With the discovery of the three sdB stars pulsating, we have a unique opportunity to further study their internal structures.
We presented the observational results of three pulsating stars: HS 0039+4302 and HS 0444+0458, and discussed the characteristics of pulsating stars as a whole.
Through high-dispersion spectroscopy, we discovered pulsations in three variable stars: HS 0039+4302, HS 0444+0458, and studied the characteristics of variable stars as a whole.
Pulsating stars are divided into two categories: one is those with multimode pulsation spectra, and the other is those with single-mode spectra.
The former exhibits a complex spectrum and appears to be multiperiodic; in contrast, the latter is a single-mode pulsar with a stable frequency.
The frequencies are similar in amplitude and frequency for each pulsator, but there are differences in peak intervals, pulsation amplitude, and phase.
We assume that these pulsating stars represent different stages in the same evolutionary pathway.
A pulsating star with a multimode pulsation spectrum is a candidate for an sdB star that is about to merge, situated in the final stage before electron degeneracy occurs.
We report for the first time the monomode pulsation frequencies of three sdB stars.
These pulsating stars may represent different evolutionary states of a common ancestor.
We have found evidence of two different types of pulsating stars in the sdB population.

This discovery adds three new pulsating stars to the small but growing survey of sdB pulsating stars and provides an important opportunity to study the internal structure of sdB stars and the evolution of their progenitors.
A branch-and-bound algorithm for half-space depth problems has been proposed.
This problem is considered to be strongly NP-hard.
The proposed algorithm first generates a set of bounding boxes for the input space.
Then, it solves a series of strongly simplified instances using the branch-and-bound method.
To accelerate the solving process, intermediate results are cached.
In order to ensure the optimality of the solutions found, a method based on cutting planes was used.
The performance of the proposed algorithm was evaluated on two large-scale airplane landing problem instances from the CUT willingness-to-pay dataset.
The obtained results were compared with the best known solution obtained through the CUT automatic optimization tool and two existing cutting plane-based algorithms.
References: Z. Du, Z. Hu, W. Yang, and J. Cheng.
The branch-and-bound algorithm for the half-plane depth problem.

In the narrow-line region of the quasar SDSS J154141.33+155426.6 at redshift z = 0.1723, a quasar outflow possibly driven by a radio galaxy analogy has been discovered.
The outflow has a width of at least 1000 kilometers per second, a dynamic mass of at least 10^42 solar masses, and is moving at a high speed (v = -0.999995 c, relative to the quasar frame).
The width, dynamic mass, and velocity are all similar to those of broad emission line jets, but slightly lower than them.
The gas in the narrow line region has an asymmetric distribution around the quasar, with one side being closer to the quasar than the other side.

The side that is closer resembles a radio galaxy, which indicates that the quasar wind is partially reversed under the radiation pressure of the active galactic nucleus and is interacting with the host of the radio galaxy.

The density of the outflowing gas calculated from X-ray absorption is sufficiently high (about 10^11 cm^-3) to affect the spectra of quasars, which naturally explains the unusually blue ultraviolet/optical/near-infrared colors of quasars, as well as the phenomenon of detecting MgII absorbers in previous observations of radio galaxies.

The paper investigates the invariance properties of the linear parabolic equation \( x' = A(x) \) in n-dimensional space under transformations of the independent variable \( x \) and the solution \( x \), where \( A \) is a matrix with all eigenvalues equal to zero.
We established the complete invariance of the Galilean transformation and scaling transformation for the case of \( n \geq 2 \), as well as Galilean invariance for the case of \( n = 1 \).

We have also established the invariance under the transformation of the form x → λ(x), where the eigenvectors corresponding to the zero eigenvalue of A satisfy λ(x1, …, xn) = 0, and the invariance of the transformation xT - x under all vectors x.
Through the application of the results, we have demonstrated the existence of the conservation law of this equation.

Keywords: Invariance, Conservation Law, Parabolic Equation

Through this overview, we investigated the energy-efficient resource allocation problem in wireless networks.

We divide the solutions to these problems into two major categories: one category is algorithms that optimize a single network objective, such as energy consumption or total throughput; the other category is algorithms that optimize multiple objectives, such as energy consumption and fairness.
We investigate the game theory approach to solving these resource allocation problems.
The game is a mathematical model that describes the conflicts between rational agents, each of whom has different preferences for outcomes.
The game-theoretic solution for resource allocation in wireless networks assigns matching roles to algorithm agents (senders or receivers), which compete or cooperate to reach a solution.

We divide the game-theoretic methods for wireless network resource allocation into two categories: 1) best response algorithms, which only involve seeking the best response within the agent's own strategy set; 2) non-trivial algorithms, which utilize the underlying game to improve the process of finding the best response.
We investigate the approximate solutions and martingale solutions to the multi-agent resource allocation problem.
Specifically, we investigated Lagrangian relaxation, subgradient methods, and virtual games.
Finally, we conclude our overview by investigating the emerging research areas for the future directions of this field of study.

Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD), Sulfur Dioxide (SO2), Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2), PM2.5, PM10, temperature, and relative humidity were measured at an urban location in the Tokyo metropolitan area of Japan (36.5N 137.5E) from January 2014 to December 2017.
High pollution events (HPE) are defined as days when the PM2.5 concentration exceeds 300 micrograms per cubic meter.
HPEs account for 42% of the total days and dominate during the warm season.
HPEs have high AOD, high SO2, high NO2, and low wind speed.
The diagnosis of the dominant aerosol processes indicates that 61% of high particulate matter concentration events are related to secondary aerosol formation.
24% of the high-energy particles are related to resuspension, 11% are related to regional transport, and 5% are related to gas-phase chemical reactions.
These processes are more active in winter, indicating the importance of winter transportation in the Greater Tokyo area.
The analysis of the emissions inventory shows that the combustion of fossil fuels and industrial processes are the main sources of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and PM2.5.
It is estimated that the formation of secondary aerosols contributes 44% to sulfur dioxide, 61% to nitrogen dioxide, and 73% to PM2.5.
These processes, along with high temperatures and low wind speeds during HPE, are significant factors contributing to the high aerosol optical depth (AOD).
The main aerosol processes are different from those observed in previous studies, which were primarily related to regional transport.
This may be due to the fact that Japan's emission patterns and climate conditions differ from those of North America or Europe.
Quasars are the most powerful inactive galaxies, and their relativistic jets are closely aligned with our line of sight.
They are divided into two categories based on the presence or absence of high-energy radiation, but it is unclear what their particle accelerator is.

The observation data indicates that the radiation is most likely to originate from the vicinity of the black hole's event horizon, although not all models are capable of producing high-energy gamma rays.
The launching mechanism from the blazar remains uncertain.
A popular theory is the Blandford-Znajek process, in which the magnetized central black hole drives jets by extracting the black hole's spin energy.
The initial proposal was intended for application to weak stellar magnetic fields, but subsequent research has shown that the magnetic fields in quasars can be several orders of magnitude stronger.
Another popular model is the Synchrotron Self-Compton (SSC), in which synchrotron radiation scatters some of its photons to high-energy gamma rays.
Blazar typically exhibits variability across all wavelengths on very short timescales (from hours to days).
A blazar is a powerful emitter of radio waves, optical light, and gamma rays, with significant variability in this electromagnetic radiation.
In this work, we demonstrate that the jets of quasars are closely related to the inner regions of their associated accretion disks.
The jets seem to be emitted from a small internal region of the accretion disk, and there is a strong correlation between the height scale of the disk and the power of the jets.
Such a correlation is expected in the Branford-Znajek model and aligns well with the existing data.
This article is aimed at a broad interdisciplinary audience, including experts in fields such as plasma physics, black hole physics, relativistic astrophysics, and nuclear physics.
In this article, we demonstrate that superconducting correlations can be induced in the ferromagnetic layer of a superconductor-ferromagnet (S/F) structure due to proximity effects.
When a magnetic field is applied to such an S/F structure, an uneven magnetization phenomenon will occur within the ferromagnetic layer.
This led to the Doppler shift of ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) signals and the superconducting current in superconductors.
We found that the triplet component that induces superconducting correlations exhibits a local maximum near the FMR resonance frequency and the magnetic field where non-uniform magnetization occurs.
These results indicate that fermionic magnetic resonance (FMR) can be detected in superconducting/ferromagnetic (S/F) structures using techniques from superconducting spintronics.
The complete paper "Inhomogeneous Magnetization and Superconductivity in Superconductor-Ferromagnet Structures" can be found at the following link: https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.07446
The single crystal of PbZr0.52Ti0.48O3 (PZT) undergoes a phase transition from a high-symmetry phase to a low-symmetry phase at approximately 600 °C.
This structural phase transition is accompanied by a significant change in conductivity.
It has been demonstrated that changes in conductivity can be explained by variations in carrier concentration caused by thermal excitation of deep energy level trap states.
It is further suggested that in order to accurately describe the changes in conductivity, it is necessary to consider the activation energy distribution of deep trap states.

The traditional method for obtaining this distribution is the quasi-equilibrium approximation (QEA), which is an assumption about the thermal evolution of carrier concentration and requires a comprehensive description of carrier diffusion.
Here, we propose a method to relax the quasi-equilibrium assumption and use the finite element method to solve the coupled heat diffusion and drift-diffusion equations.

The obtained conductivity-temperature-relaxation time distribution function is consistent with the quasi-equilibrium approximation results at lattice temperatures below approximately 700 degrees Celsius.
However, at higher temperatures, the differences between the two methods are quite significant and increase with rising temperature.

We believe this is due to an approximation inherent in the quasi-equilibrium approximation, and we propose a different approximation that shows good consistency with the results obtained from our new method.
A robust developmental program is crucial for multicellular organisms to perform their functions, such as forming body structures and limbs, as well as adapting to environmental changes.
We establish a theoretical and experimental framework here to study the robustness of multicellular development, which is based on an epigenetic model of gene regulation.

The model first covers the role of cell division in developmental robustness. Our theoretical and experimental findings suggest that developmental robustness can arise from a compromise between developmental speed and the program, as well as a compromise regarding the robustness to variability in cell type composition.
Using this framework, we have identified several non-mutually exclusive pathways to enhance development resilience.

For example, an increase in the pace of development may enhance robustness; while alternative strategies to enhance robustness may be (i) reducing noise effects in gene expression, or (ii) reducing the heterogeneity of cellular components.

These results establish a theoretical foundation for the robustness of multicellular development, and we suggest that our theory should be able to further identify and implement strategies for improving robustness in synthetic systems and regenerative medicine.
In this article, we study the problem of finding rational points on elliptic surfaces.
An elliptic surface is a surface of the form \( y^2 = x(x^2 + Ax + B) \), where \( A \) and \( B \) are constants, which can be regarded as minimal models of certain elliptic curves.
Finding rational points on this form of the elliptic surface will provide integer solutions to the elliptic curve given by the following Weierstrass equation: \( y^2 = x^3 + Ax^2 + Bx + C \).

This curve has drawn attention in the study of quantum error-correcting codes (QEC). H. Davenport, C. Lewis, and Y. Tang announced a proof of its integer points in 2013, but this result has not yet been published.
In this article, we announce the proof of this result and provide our complete manuscript.

We provide numerical results on scalar field disturbances caused by particles from rotating black holes in orbit.
We use the numerical methods proposed in previous studies to evolve the perturbation equations.
We evolve the 2+1 dimensional perturbation equations in Misner-sharp variables, using the incoming dimensionless profile instead of the turtle-like radial coordinates.

We obtained various discrete values of angular momentum \( l \) and charge \( q \) for the quasi-normal modes (QNMs) of the Schwarzschild black hole and the Kerr black hole with different spin parameters.
The frequency and damping time of QNM have been compiled into a table.
We also discussed the calculation of energy and angular momentum in gravitational waves, using a new integration definition to describe the radiation from any spin perturbation.
Finally, we apply the results of scalar field perturbations to estimate the energy and angular momentum in the scalar waves of particles moving in circular orbits around a Kerr black hole.
We found that the energy and angular momentum released are negligible compared to the mass and spin of the black hole.
In ultracold atomic experiments, quantum mechanics allows for some effects that are reversible in classical physics, such as quantum back action or measurement backaction.
We observed the quantum measurement backaction of ultracold atom gases.
By using state-selective spin echo, we detected atoms that have undergone unitary transformations of operators without mean values in the initial state of the system.
We performed quantum process tomography on the unitary transformation and demonstrated that our measurement results reproduced the dynamics predicted by quantum mechanics.

Our results establish the existence of measurement backaction in a fundamentally pure system, satisfying \( \frac{dB}{dt} \geq \frac{|h|}{\tau} \), where \( dB \) is the change in the expectation value of the operator and \( \tau \) is the characteristic evolution time.
These results will enable new methods for quantum control and precision measurement, with potential applications in quantum information and ultra-low light noise measurement.
We observed the quantum measurement backaction of ultracold atomic gases.
In experiments with ultracold atoms, quantum mechanics allows for the occurrence of certain effects that are reversible in classical physics, such as quantum feedback or measurement feedback.
We perform quantum process tomography on this unitary transformation and demonstrate that our measurement results reproduce the dynamics predicted by quantum mechanics.
Generally speaking, quantum backaction occurs when a quantum system responds to a measurement.

The theory of quantum measurement describes the statistical relationship between quantum systems and measurements, where the process of measuring observable quantities can affect the state of the system.

The measurement reaction occurs when the measured observable does not have a mean value in the initial state of the system; it is defined as the rate of change of the expected value of that observable.
It may take various forms.

For example, if an operator is an observable quantity of a quantum system, then the system being measured will be entangled with the measurement apparatus in a process known as quantum entanglement, and the back action corresponds to how the measured system and the measurement apparatus evolve together over time.

Another option is that if the operator is a parameter of a unitary transformation, then the feedback action can achieve control and measurement of the unitary transformation parameter, for example in quantum process tomography.
So far, the measurement of reaction has only been observed in the presence of quantum entanglement or incoherent forces (such as gravity or spin forces related to magnetic fields).
We demonstrate the measurement's reaction through entanglement or additional incoherent forces.
On the contrary, we observed the measurement backreaction of an essentially pure system, without any losses caused by interactions with the larger environment.
The process is reversible because our experiments are conducted near the quantum limit of a few-atom system.

Our results establish the measurement backaction in a system that is essentially pure, and satisfy \( dB/dt \geq |h|/\tau \), where \( dB \) is the change in the operator expectation value, and \( \tau \) is the characteristic evolution time.
These results will promote new methods in quantum control and precision measurement, with potential applications in quantum information and ultra-low light noise measurement.
Millisecond pulsars (MSPs) are rapidly rotating, highly magnetized neutron stars.

The double pulsar system is usually regularly detected in a close orbit near its companion star, and some of these systems emit strong radio waves due to the interaction between the pulsar and its companion star, a process known as accretion disc erosion.
Isolated millisecond pulsars (MSPs) that are very similar have been detected at a much lower frequency and have now been found in about half of the transient gamma-ray bursts (GRBs).
These systems lack companion stars, so they are expected to be radio silent.

Here, we report on the detection of PSR J1453+1902. This is an isolated millisecond pulsar that was previously only known at 1400 MHz. The upper limit of the 1.4 GHz pulsar radio signal we obtained is more than an order of magnitude lower than the average value for other isolated millisecond pulsars.
We use large-area multi-band transiting satellites (LSAM).
We compare the radio luminosity upper limit of PSR J1453+1902 with the radio luminosity distribution of more common millisecond pulsars (MSPs) and find that it is a very high-luminosity outlier.
Therefore, we suggest that PSR J1453+1902 is the first isolated millisecond pulsar discovered in a short gamma-ray burst.
Galaxy clusters are the largest structures known in the universe, containing hundreds or even thousands of galaxies.
Although they are important, studying the large-scale behavior of star cluster galaxies is not easy.
Most of the time, people have to rely on studying individual galaxies or small samples.
A promising approach is to model the overall light distribution of galaxies and use the obtained model to fit the light of distant galaxies.
This method was proposed by Falco et al. in 1987 and was applied to large-scale datasets by Gonzalez et al. in 2002.
Since then, several improvements and adjustments have been proposed for different galaxy samples.

We present a dataset of early-type galaxies in the WINGS cluster, which is a multi-wavelength catalog that includes morphological classifications, Hubble Space Telescope imaging, and extensive follow-up data.
The dataset has been modeled and fitted using three different techniques: non-parametric star formation history (SFH) modeling, bulge + disk decomposition, and semi-parametric Boxy4 modeling.
The results indicate that during the lifecycle of star clusters, the importance of star formation history and of the bulge has changed.
A large number of astronomical objects can be identified through their infrared (IR) radiation, including young stellar objects (YSOs) and galaxies, which are often heated by massive stars.
Therefore, the infrared spectrum of the sky encodes information about the star-forming regions where these celestial bodies originated.
These regions, in turn, determine the initial mass function of stars, thereby affecting the number of stars that can form in a specific environment.

Lasers, especially, may be particularly interesting for those studying the early stages of star formation, as their characteristics (bright energy transitions and precise positional correspondences) make them excellent detectors for very young regions.

I reviewed the infrared environments of 22 water and ammonia masers, which are associated with the early stages of high-quality star formation and were detected in a recent sensitive infrared survey conducted using the Spitzer Space Telescope.

I discussed what information about the birth region can be obtained from the spectral energy distribution of the constructed data and suggested how to utilize future infrared facilities to expand such research.
In this article, we will extend the famous Caldeira-Leggett quantum Brownian motion model to environments with arbitrary spectral density and external forces.
The power density and external forces are both assumed to be general functions of frequency.
By utilizing generative functional techniques, we obtained exact solutions to the corresponding master equations in both Markovian and non-Markovian limits.
The article discusses in detail the influence of the general environment and external forces on quantum Brownian particles.
In particular, we demonstrate that an environment with constant spectral density and external force can be regarded as a special case of our general model.

The impact of the special spectral density of the environment and external forces on quantum Brownian particles has been studied in many previous works, and thus is included as a special case in our general solution.
We also briefly discussed the dephasing function of our model.
The optimization script system has been the focus of praise and criticism in the cryptocurrency community for many years.
The script system is a plugin for cryptocurrency wallets that allows users to make incremental payments to people, services, and machines.
Many people believe that scripting systems are a fundamental missing component in cryptocurrency, making practical applications that would be difficult or impossible to achieve without them possible.
The script system can automate the task of paying people for the things they produce (such as content, labor, or data).
They may also make it easier to manage large payments or to make payments to multiple recipients, which can be challenging when using cryptocurrencies.
However, critics warn that the stock system may be prone to crashes, which could lead to erroneous payments, and due to its design, it may create opportunities for abuse or unethical behavior.
In this work, I compared three commonly used payroll systems: Bitwage, Libera, and Wagepoint, and described several ways to improve them.
First, I described the design decisions behind each scripting system, which I believe could be reconsidered.
Secondly, I discussed my research on alternative note system designs that I believe would improve security and reliability.
Third, I described how to design a token system to reduce the opportunities for abuse or misconduct.
I have finally summarized some ways that cryptocurrency projects can adopt and fund this work through developing partnerships or sponsorships.

The search for the radiative lepton decay B+ → γ l+ ν was conducted using a sample of pp collision data collected by the ATLAS detector at the CERN laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland, with an integrated luminosity of 672 fb⁻¹, at a center-of-mass energy of s ≈ 8 TeV.
No evidence of this rare decay has been found, and limits on the decay ratio have been set.

These restrictions vary between approximately 7.1×10^-8 (with a minimum photon energy of 1.6 GeV) and 3.7×10^-7 (with a minimum photon energy of 100 MeV), depending on the assumed branching fraction to specific final states.
These are the strictest so far.
This study was published in the paper: B. Tramontano et al., "Searching for the radiative lepton decay B+ --> γ l+ ν," arXiv:2004.08629.

[hep-ex] — Abstract — Using a sample of pp collision data totaling 673 fb^-1, a search for the radiative lepton decay B+ --> γ l+ ν was conducted at the ATLAS detector of the LHC at CERN in Geneva, Switzerland, with a center-of-mass energy of approximately 8 TeV.
No evidence of this rare decay has been found, and limits on the branching ratio have been set.

The range of these limits is approximately from 7.1×10^-8 at a minimum photon energy of 1.6 GeV to 3.7×10^-7 at a minimum photon energy of 100 MeV, depending on the assumed branching ratio to a specific final state.
These are the most stringent to date.
B+ mesons are produced in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and transported through the ATLAS detector, resulting in a data sample of (BLΛ[U]/Ts)×10^9 (GeV)^2.
The sample is used to search for B+ → γ l+ ν, which is a radiative lepton decay where the B+ meson decays into a wino and a photon, with the latter carrying 50% of the total momentum of the B+ meson.

The focus of this analysis is the double muon decay mode of the B meson, with the final state including two oppositely charged muons, at least two photons, and missing momentum from the decaying B+ meson.

Using LHCb's distribution, a signal with b-flavored symmetry and a general charm quark continuum background was generated simultaneously in two orthogonal polarization directions."
In order to model the signal, photons are produced from the radiative lepton decay of B+ mesons, using the photon probability distribution function (PDF) obtained from simulations.
The signal and background predictions are embedded into the MC event samples and are used to determine the expected sensitivity.

Recent discoveries of exoplanets have opened a new chapter in the field of astronomy.
With the upcoming transit missions like TESS and PLATO, the number of known planets is expected to increase several times over the next decade.
Most of the known exoplanets are smaller and denser than our Earth.
When we examine Kepler's data, we find that the surfaces of most planets are covered by water.
However, when we observe these planets in a more precise manner, we find that the possibility of oceans existing on these planets is uncertain.
As the technology for detecting these planets continues to advance, astronomers tend to describe them through their atmospheres rather than their surfaces.
This means that in the future, we may only be able to confirm the existence of life, but not the presence of surface water.
In other words, we will know nothing about the existence of most planets.

Dynamic research is a key driving force in the detection and characterization of exoplanets, and this field can gain significant benefits from advanced computing, data analysis, and system identification techniques.
In this paper, we study one-dimensional quantum dots under strong attractive contact interactions, which can lead to local deformation of the Wigner crystal ground state.

Using quantum Monte Carlo and density matrix renormalization group techniques, we determined the ground state energy as a function of system size and deformation amplitude, and investigated whether the ground state is a stable configuration for any amplitude less than the critical value.

We use local density distribution to characterize this deformation, from which we calculate the local charge and bond order parameters, and identify the one-to-one correspondence between these parameters and the underlying deformation.

We also use the path integral Monte Carlo method to determine the effects of quantum fluctuations on this deformation and compare our results with quantum Monte Carlo data from large system sizes, finding good agreement within the stability region.
Finally, we discussed the implications of our results on the experiment and proposed directions for future work.
In this study, we investigated one-dimensional quantum dots under strong attractive contact interactions, which can lead to local distortions of the Wigner crystal ground state.

Using quantum Monte Carlo and density matrix renormalization group techniques, we determined the ground state energy as a function of system size and deformation amplitude, and identified whether the ground state is a stable configuration for any amplitude below the critical value.

We use local density profiles to characterize this deformation, from which we calculate local charge and bond ordering parameters, and establish a one-to-one correspondence between these parameters and the potential deformation.

We also employed the path integral Monte Carlo method to determine the effects of quantum fluctuations on this deformed state, and compared our results with quantum Monte Carlo data from large system sizes, finding good agreement within the stability region.
Lastly, we discussed the experimental significance of our results and proposed directions for future work.
In recent years, advancements in computer technology and algorithm development have made it possible to conduct long-term molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of strongly coupled dynamic systems.
In order to monitor the conservation of energy and momentum over such a long period of time, it is necessary to switch between various force fields.
From this work, we propose a general algorithm for energy and momentum conservation in molecular dynamics simulations using force fields with switching potentials.
The general situation has been considered.
The switching potential is obtained through the analytical solution of the corresponding motion equation.
The general solution only includes parameters that need to be determined by the initial conditions.
Therefore, the proposed method is easy to apply and cost-effective in terms of computation.
We take the Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential as an example to illustrate the effectiveness of this method.

By applying the proposed algorithm, we obtained the energy and momentum conservation results of the LJ system over 600,000 time steps at a relatively low cost, which is about 27% of the cost of traditional algorithms over the same number of time steps.
Researchers have proposed various methods to identify unwanted or broken links on the internet.
These methods can be divided into three categories.
This first category includes methods based on machine learning.
These methods train a classifier to identify dead links by utilizing the features of the links and the pages they are located on.
The second category includes methods based on reinforcement learning.
These methods use proxies to interact with the internet to search for dead links.
The third category includes methods based on the principle of like attracting like.
These methods identify dead links and live links based on associated patterns.
Recently, several research groups have proposed link management algorithms to improve the quality of dead link detection methods.
These two methods analyze pages with dead links to look for similar pages that contain valid links.
These valid links are used to replace the invalid links.
These methods can be classified as link replacement algorithms.
We propose a vacancy positioning algorithm to improve the quality of the link replacement algorithm.
Our algorithm first detects dead links using existing methods, and then investigates similar active pages to identify replacements, that is, active links that can replace the dead links.
The positions of these vacancies are recorded and used by our algorithm to replace invalid links with valid ones.

We conducted a large-scale study on the dataset of dead link detection tracks obtained from the D4M dataset and demonstrated that our vacancy localization algorithm improved the overall performance of the link replacement algorithm.
The simplest dark energy model with a constant equation of state (EoS) parameter of -1 is the cosmological constant (CC).
However, according to the experimental data, there are issues with fine-tuning and coincidence.
Many improvement plans for CC have been proposed to address these issues.
One of them is the so-called transient acceleration model.
In this case, the EoS parameters are time-dependent, while CC only describes the early stages of cosmic evolution.
The simplest model of this type is the so-called T model.
In this article, we consider a dark fluid T model with a vacuum component.
This new model describes the evolution of the universe in the same way as the T model, but in addition, it also explains the observed phenomenon of the universe's accelerated expansion.
This article includes the solutions of the corresponding modified Friedman equations and the characteristics of model evolution.
In addition, we have also imposed constraints on the model parameters based on the latest observational data.

In machine learning, one of the most powerful learning paradigms is ensemble learning, which combines one or more learning algorithms to achieve better generalization performance than any single constituent learning algorithm.
Evolutionary algorithms (EAs), particularly those based on evolutionary computation (EC) such as genetic algorithms (GAs), have been successfully applied to many machine learning problems.

In this article, we explore the application of evolutionary algorithms (such as genetic algorithms, GA), based on evolutionary computation (EC), in hyperparameter optimization for machine learning problems in ensemble learning.

We designed a single genetic algorithm process to automatically search for multiple hyperparameters of a given basic machine learning algorithm (such as the number of base learning algorithms K, and the weight factor w of each learning algorithm in the weighted sum of the weighted algorithm) in order to achieve optimal generalization performance on the training data.
We tested this genetic algorithm-based Genetic Algorithm (GABGAS) on five benchmark machine learning problems that had not previously attempted genetic algorithms.

The results indicate that GABGAS will automatically find good values for K (ranging between 1 and 20) and w (ranging between 0.1 and 0.9), and for each benchmark problem, the achieved generalization performance is significantly better than the known best values of K and w obtained through manual tuning.
We also demonstrate that the computational complexity of GABGAS is significantly lower than that of existing methods.
Monte Carlo (MC) simulations have been conducted to study the dynamic response of the oscillatory change in chemical potential due to a monolayer of silver (Ag) adsorbed on Au(100).
As the chemical potential increases, silver atoms adsorb at sites with higher coordination numbers, leading to the densification of the layers.
When the chemical potential decreases, silver atoms desorb, resulting in the expansion of the thin layer.
We indicate that the dynamic response of silver monolayers strongly depends on the heating and cooling rates.
A significant hysteresis phenomenon was observed, especially at slow heating and cooling rates.
This behavior was analyzed within the framework of the generalized Lindemann parameter, which takes into account the coordination changes of the adsorbed atoms during heating and cooling processes.
It is known that small changes in the chemical potential of components in a complex system can lead to significant fluctuations in the corresponding Gibbs free energy.
According to the heating and cooling rates, these escapes can trigger dynamic phenomena, such as hysteresis effects.
Here, we report for the first time the observation of hysteresis in the dynamic behavior of silver monolayers under oscillatory changes in chemical potential.

Our research findings are of great significance for the modeling and interpretation of experimental data, as well as for the control of surface diffusion during chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) growth processes.
The von Kármán flow with mass load is a standard benchmark for studying turbulence.
It consists of a set of non-interacting vortices, with energy concentrated in the vorticity, and the encapsulation of each vortex is very distinct.
These vortices are self-similar and exhibit scale invariance in a higher-order cascade state.
From this article, we developed a simplified two-dimensional dynamic model that captures the essential features of high-level cascading states.
The evolution of vorticity (Omega) is modeled by a diffusion equation with no-flux boundary conditions.

The dissipation of turbulent energy mainly occurs through two different processes: direct viscous dissipation, which smooths the vorticity field locally, and cross-spiral flow, which transfers vortex energy from the vortex region near the core to the outer region.
We prove that these two processes lead to a scale solution with time-independent vorticity and energy dissipation, consistent with the dynamic model.
We then indicate that the evolution of large-scale momentum is controlled by the rate at which vorticity is transferred to the external region.
We derived an evolution equation for the vorticity flux related to scale, and conducted a linear analysis to calculate the scale variation of the flux.
This analysis ignores the secondary vorticity flux term, which aligns well with the complete dynamics model in the high-Cascade state.
This work is supported by the U.S. Department of Energy under award number DE-SC0019468.
The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is a dwarf galaxy satellite of the Milky Way, located approximately 163,000 light-years (56,000 parsecs) away from the center of the Milky Way.
The Large Magellanic Cloud has a prominent neutral hydrogen gas halo that extends over several hundred thousand parsecs (about 160 kpc).

Studying the distribution and characteristics of this neutral hydrogen gas can deepen our understanding of the formation and evolution of the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC), as well as its halo and the surrounding intergalactic medium (IGM).
The previous LMC neutral hydrogen gas catalog was created using a smaller field-of-view single-dish telescope.
Through this work, we present a new catalog of neutral hydrogen clouds in the Large Magellanic Cloud using the MeerKAT radio telescope.

This is the largest and most sensitive catalog of neutral hydrogen clouds in the Large Magellanic Cloud to date, which may aid in studying the impact of the Large Magellanic Cloud on the IGM and the structure and evolution of the local group.
In this article, we study the cohomology of affine A-d groups.
We have proved that the first reduced homology group with integer coefficients is infinitely generated.
We give an explicit infinitely generated subgroup of the first reduced homology group.
We also studied the second reduced homology group with certain finite-dimensional representations.
We have proven that in certain cases this second cohomology group is zero, and in other cases we have provided an upper bound for it.
As an application, we demonstrate that the mapping class group of a big surface has infinite higher homotopy dimensions.
We also study upper layer cohomology with local coefficients.
We describe the cohomology groups of local coefficients in the formal representation in some special cases.

We demonstrate that the local homology groups with respect to local coefficients are isomorphic to the corresponding Artin group’s event homology in the case of normal representations, generalizing the results of Mimura and Toda for classical Artin groups.
We also calculated the cohomology of local coefficients in standard representations under certain special circumstances.
Our research on the cohomology groups with local coefficients allows us to solve Bass's famous conjecture regarding the rank of the 2nd cohomology group of arithmetic groups.

More precisely, we prove that if the Zariski closure corresponding to the arithmetic group does not have simple exceptional type factors, then the rank of the 2-torsion group of that arithmetic group is divisible by 2 and the BSD invariants of its constant part.
We also discussed the combinatorial aspects of these cohomology groups with local coefficients, particularly the impact of the Schensted correspondence on these cohomology groups.

Finally, we provided a new implementation for the model mixed buildings of the special orthogonal group, as an asymmetric space, which allows us to utilize the corresponding results of the orthogonal group to compute the homology of the special orthogonal group.
Therefore, we provide an alternative proof that shows that the cohomological dimension of the special orthogonal group is 2.
In this article, all statements are representations of the complex.
The local coefficient homology groups studied in this article are primarily with integer coefficients.
They can be studied using rational coefficients through standard localizable arguments.
Finally, we mention some possibilities of extending our results to other Artin groups, such as classical Artin groups and braid Artin groups.
This paper is a collaborative work by C. J. Delingpole, Y. L. Pan, and Y. Zhou.
Thank you for your interest in our paper.
We hope that this article can provide new insights for the study of affine Artin groups and has potential applications in geometric group theory and modular representation theory.

This paper proposes several new techniques and different approaches to existing theories, which will surely be of great help to experts in these fields and will attract broader interest from the mathematical community.
Therefore, we encourage both audience groups to provide feedback and suggestions.
We will continuously update our paper as the research progresses to address feedback and new results.
Thank you for your attention and support.
Through this article, we propose a novel hierarchical method for reliability analysis of cache-based commercial RAID storage architectures.

The proposed method combines fault detection and isolation techniques from Markov chain analysis and Bayesian network analysis to assess the impact of different types of faults on system availability and response time.

The effectiveness of this method is demonstrated through a series of real-world experiments conducted on a highly available production cluster, involving more than 2,000 virtual machines and hundreds of file transactions.
The results show that a large number of failures can occur without negatively impacting the availability of the cluster.
Additionally, the system's response time is not affected by many occurrences of failures.
However, a large number of faults can affect the system's response time, which may have a significant impact on the overall user experience.
Using the proposed method, we are able to identify and quantify these faults and their impact on cluster reliability.
U_q(sl_n) represents the diagrammatic category of the theory.

This defines a compact closed structure on equivariant K-theory in the context of the Hamiltonian reduction of a monoid, generalizing the Springer correspondence and its recent classification extension.
In the combinatorics of lattice paths, it allows for a unified treatment of (a) type A, (b) type B, and (c) arbitrary quantum groups.
This has several exciting applications in the categorification of the classical multiplication preprojective functions and generalized Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials.
The applications related to finite representations, combinatorial classification, quasi-hereditary modules, and quantum groups will appear in subsequent research.

The category of diagrams being discussed is the path category P(N-1, N) of the symmetric Laplace operator; this provides a unified treatment for types (a) and (b), as well as for type (c) when N is an integer.
We propose a quantum chromodynamics (QCD) model with high density and large quark mass to explain the quantum chromodynamics phase diagram.
The model is based on an infinite-dimensional Bologov-type gauge theory and reduces to N coincident 1+1 dimensional SU(N) theories.

The Yang-Mills theory at high temperatures transitions into N overlapping 1+1 dimensional U(1) gauge theories at low temperatures, and at infinite temperature, it transitions into three-dimensional space.
The parameters in the model include temperature T, quark chemical potential μ, and the time scale L(T) of the one-dimensional spacetime theory.

We obtain three phases when lowering the temperature T: a high-density deconfined phase at low chemical potential μ and high temperature T, a low-density confined phase at high chemical potential μ and low temperature T, and an intermediate crossover phase between the two.
Under high chemical potential, the finite phase is expected to be described by the dual description of low-temperature superconductors.
The model provides a sensible scenario illustrating how the continuous crossing between these phases occurs as the temperature T decreases.
The stability of shock waves in supersonic gas flows was studied.
The case of non-viscous and isentropic conditions has been solved, and it was found that the supercritical shock wave is the least stable.
The results confirmed through the stability analysis of viscous shock waves, showing that these waves are stable for all possible wave numbers.
The stability effect of viscosity was discussed.

In the case of inviscid flow, the equations of one-dimensional isentropic gas dynamics simplify to a nonlinear wave equation concerning pressure; whereas in the case of viscous flow, they simplify to a semi-linear degenerate hyperbolic equation.
Therefore, for the inviscid case, the shock wave is stable with respect to viscosity; while for the viscous case, the shock wave is stable for all wave numbers.

These results are very interesting in several fields of astrophysics and gas dynamics, where shock waves are generated by phenomena such as nucleosynthesis or star formation, and viscosity may be an important influencing factor.
Stars exhibit a variety of magnetic field topologies during their evolutionary process.
Compared to the development of other stellar properties such as mass, radius, and rotation, the evolution of magnetic fields has been relatively less studied.
To study the development of this field, we analyzed high-resolution spectropolarimetric observations of five main-sequence stars.
These five stars were selected because they cover a range of effective temperatures and characterize various surface field strengths.
Most of the samples exhibit characteristics dominated by a radial field, along with small-scale irregularities.
Two stars, HD 485A and HD 37402, have a stable dipole field emitting from their cores.
The remaining star EK Cep exhibits a highly complex non-axisymmetric magnetic field.
This star also exhibits a persistent emission core in its meridional field.
We found that the distribution of different field topologies in the samples is statistically indistinguishable.
We observed a dipole field with a stable emission core in the sample, even in the rapidly rotating HD 37402.
We discussed the impact of these stable dipole fields on the mass loss rate and angular momentum evolution.
