The Costas property of the unit circle (CP), also known as the circular rotation property, indicates that the complex exponential function Θ(t) = e^{it}, where i is the imaginary unit and t is a real number, rotates by 2π radians or 360 degrees when operating around the origin.

This article promotes CP in the following way: Let \( f \) be a differentiable function on the open interval \( I \) (with endpoints \( a \) and \( b \)), which is one-to-one on that interval, and satisfies \( f'[a] \neq 0 \) and \( f'[b] \neq 0 \).
Then, for all \( t \) in the interval \( I \), the equation \( f(x) = t \) has at most two solutions.
The author refers to functions that meet the aforementioned conditions as CP-generalized.
Some attributes of CP have been inherited by this general definition.
Specifically, the constant function \( f(x) = c \) is CP-general for any real number \( c \).
The author provides several examples of functions with CP-promoting characteristics, but these functions do not possess the other properties of Costas functions.
The article summarizes several unresolved issues.
A simple phenomenological model is proposed to explain the cosmic ray electron (CRe) spectrum in the galaxy cluster Sersic 159-03 discovered by Fermi-LAT.

The results indicate that if the spectral break of the cosmic ray electron spectrum is below the energy threshold (1.5 PeV) of the radio telescope used, then both the gamma-ray flux and the radio limits can be well explained.

Compared to the hadron models that suffer from the issue of extremely high density differences, this model naturally explains the relatively low gamma-ray luminosity of the observed hard X-ray tail while retaining most of the CRe population in the halo of Sersic 159-03.
The model also shows compatibility with the lepton asymmetry that was initially detected between the north and south of the star cluster.
Finally, we briefly discussed the detectability of this model using current and future International Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes (IACT) and the Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA).
In astrophysics, rotating black holes (BHs) are sources of observational signals across various lengths and time scales, from gamma rays to radio waves and optical wavelengths.

The most obvious observable manifestation of a rotating black hole is the apparent elliptical modulation of light when a companion star passes behind it. This phenomenon can be observed in astronomical objects known as X-ray binaries.
This type of X-ray binary consists of a normal star and a compact object (either a black hole or a neutron star) forming a close binary system.

This normal star is surrounded by an accretion disk, which is fed by material from the wind of the normal star and ejects material from the star's outer shell into space, forming an X-ray binary system.
If the compact object is a rotating black hole, the surface of the black hole will be disturbed due to frame dragging, resulting in the generation of a large-scale magnetic field.
The magnetic field can distort the trajectories of the particles in the disk, causing them to precess.
The closer the companion star is to the black hole, the stronger the magnetic field is expected to be.
This enables us to measure the rotation rate of black holes.
Interstellar dust is composed of various submicron-sized carbonaceous and silicate particles, which originate from different types of parent bodies and have a complex grain size distribution.
The smallest observed interstellar particles, with a minimum size of 4.6 angstroms, are likely to originate from low-temperature carbonaceous asteroids.
Most interstellar particles have a radius between 0.1 and 0.3 microns, and they are likely formed intermittently from carbon-rich gas clouds or volatile polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).
Although most observed interstellar particles range in size from 0.1 to 0.3 micrometers, they seem to have an arbitrary cutoff around 1 micrometer, and denser particle aggregates may exist.
The characteristic size range of these particles is from 0.3 to 1 micron.
"It is currently unclear whether these polymers are formed through aggregation or by other processes."
In addition, the surface of these particles is coated with a thin layer of polar non-volatile material, which provides a second cross-section for hydrogen bonding sites.
People believe that this layer of non-volatile material provides the bonding mechanism for the aggregate, binding it into a larger structure.
The typical size range of these structures is from 0.5 to 5 micrometers, with a preferred size of 2 micrometers.
The main components of these larger interstellar particles may have transitioned from silicate cores to graphite coatings, as this can provide high transparency to infrared radiation.
The abundance and size distribution of globular clusters (GCs) are key diagnostic indicators of the formation process of the Milky Way galaxy.
GCs (globular clusters) are primarily ancient self-gravitating systems surrounding stars, thus providing a fossil record of the star formation events of their constituent members.
Therefore, the GC system of galaxies (CGCS) provides a valuable tool for studying the formation and evolution of galaxies.

We studied 13 massive, X-ray selected, optically faint galaxies (SDGs) with masses ranging from 1.3 to 4.5 x 10^11 M⊙, redshifts z = 0.02 - 0.33, and ages from 1.3 to 10.5 billion years, using Hubble Space Telescope (HST) WFC3/G-band images.
We found that these 7 sustainable development goals exhibit a bimodal or multimodal GC system.
We compare our observations with the predictions of the classical early merger scenario, the delayed merger scenario, and a novel merger-binary-spiral component scenario.
We believe that sustainable development goals may be formed through various pathways.
At low redshift, these pathways include large-scale mergers of similarly sized galaxies, as well as smaller-scale mergers and aggregations.
During the high redshift period, the SDGs may have experienced more minor and major mergers, as well as pure dry minor mergers.
However, we suggest that the late mergers of gas-rich spiral galaxies formed the dense central cluster systems of SDGs.
The lack of strong rotational support in these galactic nuclei may reflect the gas richness during these merging events.
Regarding this scenario, we expect to find recent or ongoing major merger kinematic features in galaxies dominated by diffuse globular cluster systems, and we have identified three such galaxies.

Using our spatially resolved color data, we demonstrate that the composite stellar populations of galaxies (SDGs) and their constituent globular clusters (GCs) both possess intermediate to old stellar populations, and that the proportion of young stars increases with distance from the center of the galaxy.

We found that the spatial distribution of globular clusters (GCs) is more extensive than that of old stars, and the globular cluster system exhibits a truncated radius (i.e., the average projected distance at which half of the globular clusters in the system are found) and a power-law slope consistent with predictions from recent major mergers and completely dry minor merger scenarios.
We believe that this indicates that within the truncation radius of at least five galaxies, either significant mergers have occurred, or purely dry minor mergers have taken place.
By February 24, 1987, the Sun and the asteroid were almost overlapping in the sky.
Therefore, SN 1987A can be easily observed with optical telescopes, and since then, it has become one of the most intensively studied supernovae.

The observations from the Chandra X-ray Observatory confirmed the location of the explosion center inferred from optical observations and provided the first reliable measurements of the physical extent of the supernova shockwave.
The exported angular size is 0.5 milliarcseconds, and the shock wave radiates at a speed of approximately 1053 Ergs per second.
These measurements provide key constraints on the properties of supernova shock waves and the material between the stars and the shock wave at the time of the explosion.
Supernova 1987A is a typical Type II supernova.
The early spectrum showed strong hydrogen and helium spectral lines.
As the eruption material spread, these lines gradually evolved into shapes derived from the characteristics of stripped nucleons.
"In the second type, stars do not become neutron stars."
Finally, the spectrum becomes featureless in the late stage, revealing the nature of the exploding celestial body.
Supernova 1987A is special because it is only 50 parsecs away from the Sun, making it one of the closest supernovae to Earth in the past twenty years.
Therefore, the details of shock wave propagation and early radiation can be studied in detail.
The shockwave reached the center of the star in less than 20,000 years (the time it takes for light to reach Earth).
The derived explosive energy is 10^53 ergs.
The first X-ray emission was observed 390 days after the explosion.
It is a faint point source, much dimmer than the optical radiation of a star.
With the propagation of the shock wave, the radiation intensity of radio waves, optics, and X-rays increases.
On the 800th day, the X-ray flux is 8 x 10^-17 W m^-2.
"When the optical emission reaches its peak, the X-ray emission is 5.5 x 10^-17."
The translation of "W m-2" into Chinese is "瓦每平方米" (pronounced: wǎ měi píng fāng mǐ).
The light curve shows that the rise rate of X-rays is slower than that of optical and radio waves.
The peaks of optical and radio flux occur at around day 400, while the peak of X-ray radiation occurs at around day 800.
With the rapid increase of the human population and industrial development, water resource shortages are becoming a significant issue faced by humanity.
It is expected that by 2025, approximately 58.5 million people will be affected by water resource stress.
In addition, the majority of the world's population significantly relies on fossil fuels to meet their energy needs.
This trend in energy consumption may significantly increase greenhouse gas emissions and global climate change.
These factors raise the question of how to utilize the water and energy in the air, which is the most abundant substance in the universe.
Water vapor is the most abundant solute in the atmosphere and can be captured using existing technology.
The captured water vapor can be used for many beneficial applications, such as producing fresh water and generating hydrogen fuel.
This process can be implemented on a large scale and is economically viable.
At the same time, the captured energy can be used to evaporate water and generate green electricity.
Therefore, the dual utilization of water and energy from the air can significantly alleviate water resource shortages while simultaneously reducing carbon emissions.

The following is the translation of the Chinese text into English:

"The theory of two-photon interactions of broadband down-converted light and entangled photons involves entangled photon pairs generated by spontaneous parametric down conversion (SPDC), which are widely used to demonstrate quantum non-locality and quantum entanglement."

SPDC, also known as spontaneous parametric down-conversion, occurs when a single-mode electromagnetic field is excited in a nonlinear crystal, resulting in the generation of photons with different frequencies.

The two photons generated through spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC) have some unique properties, such as correlated amplitudes and phases, as well as anti-correlation in their frequencies.
These characteristics can be used for quantum information processing and communication.
However, it is difficult to achieve two-photon interference based on these characteristics.

In this paper, we propose a theoretical framework for two-photon interference based on broadband down-converted light and entangled photons generated through spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC).
We use a universal model to describe the two-photon interference of broadband down-converted light and entangled photons.
The model can be used to simulate and optimize the setup for two-photon interference using broadband down-converted light and entangled photons.
We derived a phase matching condition that restricts the frequency range of spontaneous parametric down conversion (SPDC).
We also introduced the broadband down-conversion light generated through quasi-phase matching and described the down-conversion process under bandwidth limitations.
We provide theories with detailed calculations.
Heterogeneity and increasing returns to scale can drive socioeconomic transformation.

Industrialization usually begins at the margins of a system, where there are situations of diseconomies of scale. However, when innovation improves scale efficiency, industrialization tends to become concentrated.
The English translation of the provided Chinese phrase "增加收益可以推动集中化。" is "Increasing returns can drive centralization."
Another example is the Industrial Revolution, where major innovations included the steam engine and factory production, combining heterogeneous components.
At the same time, new market indicators show that returns are increasing in several industries, including transportation, finance, and waste management.

These increasing returns may reflect specific heterogeneity, such as in transportation systems, where shorter distances and broader road networks may exhibit increasing returns with regard to airport networks.
These heterogeneities may interact with innovation, as improvements in transportation and communication have reduced the costs of scale improvements.
These interactions may lead to systemic changes.

Applying these ideas to historical systems, this article argues that the Industrial Revolution began in the peripheral regions of Europe, where significant improvements in transportation and communication enabled the widespread adoption of the steam engine and factory production.
On the contrary, the transformation of emerging markets often begins internally, where innovations may seem local but are universally applicable throughout the entire system.
These internal transformations present increasing benefits, but ultimately lead to the adoption of the entire system.
These ideas may also explain the challenges faced by existing economic sectors.
After a significant improvement in scale efficiency, heterogeneity may enhance returns in the concentration of increased profits, until the industry can no longer maintain its entrenched position.
This dynamic can explain the successes and failures of existing companies, as their focus on existing improvements tends to delay rather than prevent systematic transformation.
Recent infrared surveys have discovered a group of brown dwarfs with effective temperatures exceeding 1300 K, which could not be detected by previous optical and visible light detection technologies.

We conducted new broadband Y, J, H, and Ks photometric measurements of the Pleiades cluster, covering a wavelength range of 5-22 microns, and including two newly identified members that are located near the boundary of the TWA moving group, within the same-age young cluster.

We fitted the Y, J, H, and Ks magnitudes of all members of this star cluster, which is 25 million years old, using the V Rayleigh scattering method. We found that the best-fit distance is 145 pc, with an overall estimated accuracy of 9%.
We found that the effective temperature of the latest type member is 1325-1425 K, which is consistent with previous findings based on spectroscopy.

Based on the comparison with the Cond model and effective temperature of the IRTF/SpeX spectrum from @Dahm08, we suggest that the spectral types of the late M-type and L-type candidates are M7.5 and M8.5, respectively.

We also discussed the differences between the previously measured larger distances and the now-confirmed extended population of brown dwarfs in the Prometheus star cluster, which may arise from the parallax zero-point error in the HIPPARCOS mission.

We have provided a new list of potential substellar members of the Pleiades cluster, with masses below 15 M$_{Jup}$ (spectral types later than M8.5), based solely on 2MASS photometric data. We believe that this list is more reliable than previous larger-scale photometric and spectral samples.

Finally, we present evidence of variability for some of our brighter sources, including an M8.25 variable with a period of 3.5 hours, as well as an M8.5 candidate member that shows evidence of two different periods, one close to 6.5 hours and the other close to 11 hours.
In this article, we demonstrate that a four-dimensional membrane world can be realized in an arbitrary number of spacetime dimensions, without the need for discrete symmetry requirements.
As a specific example, we demonstrate a brane world in six-dimensional spacetime, where there is an accompanying scalar field that develops a vacuum expectation value along the spacetime direction.
This model does not have discrete symmetry, so it has the potential for realism.

It provides a self-sustaining late cosmology that can explain the recent expansion of the universe and naturally generate small density irregularities without the need for a period of cosmic inflation.
Our model has a large number of arbitrary parameters; however, we propose a simple scenario in which all these parameters are determined by a small number of parameters.
The model thus has strong predictive power.
Specifically, the dynamics of the Friedmann-Robertson-Walker brane provides constraints on the compactification scale of extra dimensions and the scale of spontaneous Lorentz symmetry breaking.
We indicate that the current experimental limitations on these scales may be achievable within the framework of our model.
In addition, we studied methods to realize chiral fermions on a membrane.

In particular, we indicate that after spontaneous Lorentz symmetry breaking, right-handed neutrinos and left-handed antineutrinos can be confined to a single four-dimensional spatial location, while right-handed antineutrinos and left-handed neutrinos remain unconstrained in additional dimensions.
Therefore, our model is not only realistic but also addresses the problem of dark matter.
Finally, let's discuss the cosmological significance of our work.
In particular, we demonstrate that a 4D Friedman equation can be derived from our volume theory.
We propose a scenario in which this dynamics combines with the accelerated expansion of the late universe, providing a natural explanation for the observed Hubble rate.
The situation we present is very simple, and there are no free parameters.
Additionally, it may be able to meet the current observational constraints.
The model may be testable in current and future experiments.
The current experiments that may be able to test our model include MEG, PLANCK, and FOCUS.
In the future, SHENGM7 will be able to test this scenario.
In addition, exciting gravitational wave experiments, such as LIGO and VIRGO, will also be able to test for violations of Lorentz invariance in the gravitational sector.

Overall, the model proposed in this paper has a strong predictive ability, requiring no additional assumptions or adjustments, and may address the issues of large-scale structure, dark matter, and the cosmological constant.
Research on double white dwarfs as gravitational wave sources may help improve the detection rates of LIGO and Virgo.
We estimate the expected occurrence rate of double white dwarf merger events that the LISA instrument can detect and estimate the parameter range that would lead to observable LISA signals.

We found that double white dwarf stars with an overall merger rate of \(1-100\) Gpc\(^{-3}\)yr\(^{-1}\) could be detectable through LISA, and the parameters of the merging double white dwarfs may vary significantly, leading to observable signals.
We identified systems with lower merger rates, which may be good candidates for future space gravitational wave detectors (such as eLISA).
The authors are Michael C. Brown and Joel R. Allin. The study of binary white dwarfs as sources of gravitational waves may help improve the detection rates of LIGO and Virgo.

We estimate the expected occurrence rate of double white dwarf merger events that can be detected by the LISA instrument, and estimate a range of parameters that would lead to observable LISA signals.
Research on double white dwarf stars as sources of gravitational waves may help improve the detection rates of LIGO and Virgo.
We estimate the expected frequency of double white dwarf merger events that can be detected by the LISA instrument, and we estimate the range of parameters that will lead to observable LISA signals.
In a previous study on the interstellar X-ray background, active galactic nuclei (AGN) and X-ray binaries were considered as potential sources of the unresolved cosmic X-ray background (UcxRB).
These populations cannot fully explain the excess in the Chandra data, so further research is needed.

In this study, we examine the contribution of the 24 micron Spitzer sources to the ultra-soft X-ray background radiation (UcxRB) by modeling their distribution and characteristics, and then perform a stacked analysis of the archived Chandra data.

The model can describe the characteristics of the source and generate an integrated spectrum that is consistent with the Compton y distribution, with an optimal fit temperature of 1.4 keV, normalized to (5.3 ± 2.3).

It translates to:
"× 10^(-4) cm^(-2) s^(-1) keV^(-1) with 30% confidence."
These results suggest that the 24-micron Spitzer sources may contribute 20-30% to UcxRB, and may help explain some of the excess galaxies observed by Chandra.
The year 2020 was marked by several profound events that changed our world.
This began with the first report of a newly discovered virus that triggered an outbreak, which then rapidly evolved into a pandemic.
Meanwhile, this year witnessed the rise of chaotic and apocalyptic cults, commonly referred to as "cults," including the "Bioweapon 7" and "Children of God" cases.
Meanwhile, other events occurred in the scientific community, such as the reemergence of smallpox for the first time in over 20 years.
Finally, at the beginning of the year, the accidental death of the most famous scientist in history, Albert Einstein, occurred. He was a true idol of humanity.
Einstein's life can be seen as a unique intersection of science, art, and the humanities.
The son of a famous scientist, he gained fame for his paper on special relativity while studying physics in Zurich.
After his early experiments, his findings did not receive widespread recognition and were even criticized as being commercialized.
He was later more or less forced to abandon research in quantum electrodynamics, which was considered the most promising direction in his field.
In 1925, Einstein was proposed to serve as the director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Physics, but he declined the offer and preferred to continue as an active researcher.
In his later years, Einstein devoted himself to playing a leadership role in the resistance movement in Germany, which brought all the accompanying risks to his family.
In the last few years of the war, the Nazis attempted to expel him to Russia, but the American military authorities rescued him and brought him to the United States.

However, the verification of his genius was not an easy task: not only did he have to struggle with serious health issues, but due to his deafness, even the most ordinary tasks became nearly impossible for him.
In the seemingly dark events of his life, Einstein was always a humanitarian and saw the value of science even in the darkest moments.
Throughout his life, he maintained a philosophical perspective on the world, attempting to approach it with reason and logic, free from fanaticism and superstition.
In the end, Einstein faced the most difficult moments with resilience and calmness, accepted his fate, and still became a model of humanity.
In the semi-simple deep inelastic scattering of nuclear matter, the hadronization process was studied using the Statistical Hadronization Model (SHM).
This model has been found to accurately describe the experimental data, reproducing the shape and normalization of the transverse momentum distribution of pions and kaons.
The excitation functions of the p/d and K/π ratios have been calculated for several atomic nuclei, reaching good agreement with existing data.
The nuclear ratios, defined as the ratio of nuclear to proton ratios, have also been calculated.

Although the p/d ratio remains essentially unchanged in the presence of the nucleus, the K/π ratio decreases significantly, which is attributed to the increased contribution of weakly excited resonant state decay in the nuclear environment.
The nuclear correction factor was also compared with the ratio derived from the theoretical model calculations based on energy loss in nuclear-nuclear collisions and the light product jets.
There is good consistency found between the two.
The above data were obtained from the HERMES and COMPASS experiments at DESY, CERN, and LMSL.

By using a novel method to analyze the long-term climate records preserved in ice cores, new observational constraints on the duration of solar activity's extreme minima and maxima have been obtained.
These new restrictions indicate that the recent period of low solar activity, known as the Maunder Minimum, may have been the longest such interval in the past 1500 years.
The large extreme values are likely related to the formation of the hypothesized solar active regions at the end of the 16th century, although other explanations cannot be ruled out.

The evidence for the existence of grand solar minima is weaker than that for solar maxima, but the Maunder Minimum remains a significant event and will undoubtedly be remembered as one of the solar minima.
The recent low solar activity period is referred to as the Maunder Minimum, and it is likely the longest such interval in the past 1,500 years.

The evidence for the very large existence is weaker than that for the very small existence, but the Maunder Minimum is undoubtedly a significant event that will be remembered as one of the lowest points of solar activity.

The higher-order Schwarzian derivative (HOSD), its application in chaotic behavior, and a new invariance condition for chaos are proposed.
First, we provide the definition of HOSD and list some properties.
Next, analyze the relationship between HOSD and asymptotic stability.
The application of HOSD in finding sufficient conditions for chaos is presented.
In addition, a new invariant sufficient condition has been proposed to determine chaos.
Finally, some examples were provided to demonstrate the validity of the results.
The High-Order Schwartz Derivative (HOSD), its application in chaotic behavior, and a new sufficient condition for chaos invariance are proposed.
First, we provide the definition of HOSD and list some properties.
Next, we will analyze the relationship between HOSD and asymptotic stability.
The application of using HOSD to find sufficient conditions for chaos is presented.
In addition, a new invariant sufficient condition for chaos has been proposed.
Finally, some examples are provided to demonstrate the validity of the results.
Cool stars play an important role in the dynamics of galaxies, transporting energy and matter from the core.

However, their influence extends far beyond their host galaxies, as they can also affect the structure of the interstellar medium (ISM) through feedback effects, and even impact the halo of the Milky Way.
Here, we present new optical and ALMA observations of a special cold star, HK loops, located in the rich metallicity ring of the nuclear disk of the spiral galaxy M83.
This star is located near the center of the Milky Way, just a few thousand light-years away from the supermassive black hole, and it may be growing through accretion.
We report a possible gas eruption event and the resulting broad molecular hydrogen and atomic hydrogen lines, which is the first detection of such a phenomenon in a cold star, aside from the Sun.
We also observed the flow of dust and plasma around this star, which further confirms the complex interaction between the star and its environment.
We discussed the potential impact of this finding on our understanding of cold star feedback in extreme environments and its connection to galaxy evolution.
In active galactic nuclei (AGN), one of the most reliable origins of narrow emission lines is gas moving toward the nucleus, commonly referred to as "backward" gas supply.

By simultaneously modeling the spectroscopy of gas dynamics and ionization, we demonstrate that in a subset of 65 active galactic nuclei (AGN) with both optical spectral and X-ray observations, the majority of galaxies exhibit a double sine wave-like backward profile, with two distinct minima: one indicating outflow and the other indicating inflow.

These data suggest that the distribution of accretion rates of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in active galactic nucleus host galaxies may not follow a single decreasing function, but may instead exhibit a bimodal distribution.

The physical mechanism that leads to this distribution is still unknown, but the observed bimodality suggests that "bimodal" feedback may be an important component in the co-evolution of active galactic nuclei and their host galaxies.

The near-ultraviolet and optical spectra of ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) are often well-fitted by simple multi-color blackbody (MBB) models or more complex continuous models that include an accretion disk plus blackbody components.

Using parametric models (such as the accretion disk spectrum from the Cambridge accretion code) or non-parametric models (such as cubic splines) to describe the emission of the disk, the apparent radius of the emission region can be independently estimated as a function of the gravitational potential of the black hole.
We prove that for a given black hole mass and distance, the estimated Eddington ratio and the temperature of the MBB continuum are very sensitive to the assumed spectral shape.

Using a spherical model (for example, relativistic disk inverse Compton scattering), we assume a high-spin black hole ($a$=0.95) with a mass of 1.4 M⊙, targeting the object ESO243-49 HLX. We demonstrate that if the spectrum is a MBB rather than a disk + BB spectrum, the estimated Eddington ratio will be reduced by half; if the spectrum is the disk + BB with an apparent temperature of kT = 0.15 keV instead of 0.6 keV, the estimated Eddington ratio will decrease by a factor of five. We also show that for the same black hole mass and spectrum, if the spectrum is a MBB with kT = 0.15 keV instead of a disk + BB spectrum with kT = 0.6 keV, the estimated temperature of the MBB continuous spectrum is very different.

These differences affect how to classify ultra-bright X-ray sources with the same near-infrared radiation as those produced by high-spin black holes or those that are dominated by the appearance of accretion flows.
We discussed some implications for the interpretation of ULX spectra and suggested some observational tests that could help distinguish between different models of ULX continuous emissions.

Recent hydrodynamic simulations of galaxy mergers indicate that a small but deep central channel can form in the midplane of the merger remnant, along the direction of gas inflow, allowing a significant amount of gas to be delivered to within a kiloparsec of the center.

This gas can fuel the central supermassive black hole (MBH), leading to rapid growth of the MBH and producing a characteristic high-luminosity active galactic nucleus (AGN) phase, also known as the "quasar" phase.
The subsequent nuclear starbursts can further enrich the circumnuclear gas and the observed Seyfert phase.

In this letter, we simulate the spiral-in process of two massive black holes (MBHs), with their masses adjusted according to the observational scales of the central region. We find that in less than one billion years, the smaller black hole will merge with the larger black hole, leaving behind a remnant object with a mass of about 10^8 solar masses, which is more likely to be a bulge of an active galactic nucleus rather than a Schwarzschild black hole.
Tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) are usually formed from material stripped away from other galaxies during high-speed interactions.
TDGs provide a strong gravitational force measurement in a high diffusion range because they form at high speeds under weaker gravitational conditions.
MOND does not provide such strong tests, and the inconsistency with observational results may indicate that MOND cannot describe gravity in low acceleration conditions.
Therefore, modifying MOND is an interesting possibility to resolve the contradiction between MOND and the observations of tidal TDGs.

We present N-body simulation results showing that the introduction of a mass-dependent acceleration scale g0(r) ~ r-a0 in MOND modifications (where a0 is a constant) can successfully describe the dynamics of tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs).
The corresponding interpolation function \( fs(R) = (a_0/r)^2 \) fits the rotation curve of dark matter halos very well, indicating that it may also naturally arise as a modification of MOND.

We apply this interpolation function to TDGs and demonstrate that it can accurately reproduce the scaling relationships of the internal dynamics of TDGs with galaxy mass, rotational speed, and orbital direction, without relying on a0.
These results indicate that the observed differences between MOND and tidal TDG dynamics may be due to modifications to MOND that interpolate between strong and weak gravitational regimes.
The rotating stratified flow, such as that in a planetary boundary layer, contains a combination of vortex patterns and wave patterns.

We conduct a numerical simulation of a statistically uniform rotating stratified fluid that exhibits strong random variations in rotation, temperature, and density, while applying double periodic boundary conditions in the horizontal direction.
The flow becomes turbulent with time variations related to the initial conditions.
We calculate the time-averaged flow statistics, energy spectrum, kinetic energy, and potential energy of the vorticity.

The potential energy is concentrated on a large scale and seems to decay following a logarithmic law in the infrared, while the kinetic energy is concentrated on a small scale and appears to be distributed in a cascading manner.
The initial large-scale forcing is primarily in the form of vortex patterns, with a broad energy distribution in the flow.

However, after a period of time, a localized energy distribution is formed, where the energy at smaller scales accounts for a larger proportion, and it develops and evolves according to the cascade spectrum model.
The dynamic range is too large to be fully captured by direct numerical simulation with a small grid spacing.
This is the first direct numerical simulation of statistically homogeneous rotating stratified flow, revealing the vortex patterns and fluctuation modes.
It also reveals the spatial and temporal scales of dynamic range and cascade range, and suggests directions for further research.

In the theory of dynamical systems, the Generalized Alignment Index (GALI) is a new dynamic measurement indicator for local numerical order, capable of detecting weak interactions between chaotic trajectories.
In this work, we studied the fundamental properties of GALI: its definition, stability under coordinate transformations, and its saturation behavior.
We also discussed its main geometric features, including its singularities and limit sets.

We will illustrate the different characteristics and applications of GALI through several examples, including calculating the geometric factors affecting the stability of different types of periodic orbits, estimating the thresholds for global instability in dynamical systems, and analyzing the paths of separating lines for perturbed homoclinic orbits and homoclinic bifurcations.

We also applied GALI to the detection of multiple synchronizations, provided illustrative examples, and analyzed the stability of the synchronization states in different dimensional coupling mappings.
Grids are widely used in various disciplines such as computer science, statistics, and even social sciences to better represent potential structures.

For example, the protein structure is viewed as a three-dimensional lattice, where each element in the lattice corresponds to a specific protein atom, and the distance between any two atoms represents the shortest path connecting them in the protein structure through chemical bonds and other interactions.

Through this method, the protein structure can be simplified into a Boolean lattice, where each lattice point is either "1" or "0," indicating the presence or absence of a chemical bond between the corresponding atoms, respectively.
A similar grid concept is also used in social sciences to model social relationships, distinguishing between close friends and distant friends.

In this way, social networks can be viewed as a special type of graph, where the vertices represent individuals and the edges indicate the strength of the relationships between the corresponding individuals, which can also be conveniently represented as a Boolean lattice.

Therefore, by observing the graph structure in various applications in a way that takes into account the lattice structure, we can potentially detect some underlying patterns and structures that are obscured in existing methods due to insufficient modeling capabilities.
The 8-micron luminosity function (LF) of local galaxies is derived from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) DR7 data, using data in the U, g, r, i, and z bands.
We calculate the number of galaxies in bins of 0.5 dex width for the i-band apparent magnitude, Kron magnitude, and Petrosian radius R50.
LF uses a double Schechter function for parameterization.
We used the maximum likelihood method to determine the best-fitting parameters and found clear evidence of curvature in the galaxy number statistics.

Through simulations, we studied the effects of scattering noise, edge effects, and survey limitations on our LF results and found that these factors have no significant impact on our determination of the parameters of the dual Schechter function.
Using our best-fit Schechter function, we predict the number of galaxies in different apparent magnitude ranges.

We compared our results with the published values from the ninth data release of SDSS and found generally good consistency. However, our study shows evidence of a higher normalization phenomenon at brighter apparent magnitudes and lower characteristic magnitudes.
Using our best-fitting Schechter function, we calculated the absolute i-band luminosity of the sample galaxies and compared it with the stellar population synthesis models.
We found that the characteristic luminosities of the galaxies in our sample are consistent with those of passively evolving stellar populations formed at a recent redshift of z~2.
Social influence is ubiquitous, permeating our daily lives and affecting a range of decisions, from our everyday arrangements to larger strategic choices (such as which company to work for).
Although social influence is everywhere, most people are unable to explain the strategies for resisting social pressure.

In this article, we study a general decision problem in which an agent faces multiple options, with these options dependent on the agent's own choices, and each option has a social influencer with a known preference for one of the options.
The agent's goal is to determine which option to choose in order to maximize their own benefits while adhering to preferences.
We characterized the structure of this general question and provided the necessary and sufficient conditions for social influencers to express maximum preference for an option.
Based on this characteristic, we propose a proxy algorithm to ensure the maximization of expected utility.

Finally, we demonstrate the application of our framework in decision-making influenced by social factors in the real world, such as making dining decisions based on friends' recommendations and choosing universities based on admissions criteria and SAT scores.
The double-charged scalar has been proposed as a candidate for dark matter and is used to explain the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon.
These particles can also be produced in colliders, and if they decay into standard model (SM) particles, they may exhibit characteristics of having a large invariant mass of the majority of leptons.

In this article, we demonstrate that the data from the second round of LHC operations can be used to impose the strongest direct collider limits on the parameter space of the double charged scalar production model to date.

We also considered a specific Two Higgs Doublet Model (2HDM) as an example and showed that after correcting for the effects from the slope electroweak corrections, this model becomes less supported in comparison with the observed Higgs signal strength.
We then updated the previous analysis of the model, including constraints from multi-lepton plus MET signals from LHC Run II data.
We indicate that, in this case, the 2HDM model with explicit flavor symmetry is consistent with all the data.
In complete counting statistics, if the detector has finite resistance, the moments of the transferred charge will take different values compared to the moments of the Gaussian distribution.
The third-order cumulative quantity is positive for any value of the counting field when the environmental resistance exceeds a certain threshold.
In this case, for a long period of time before the quantum mechanical system reaches its steady state, its dynamics exhibit characteristics of an inverted harmonic oscillator.

We study the counting statistics of charge transfer in quantum point contacts (QPC) through experimental research, focusing on its relationship with environmental impedance R. By applying an appropriate voltage bias to the external environment, we can change the impedance of the environment, thus altering the threshold of non-Gaussian behavior.
For sufficiently small resistance, we observe that the third-order cumulant is always positive.

The result is consistent in magnitude with the predictions of the rate equation model based on a fully quantum description of the dissipative quantum point contact (QPC), whether in the case of negative or positive values of the counting field.
Our work provides the first direct experimental access to the complete counting statistics of microscopic quantum systems coupled to external systems with arbitrary spectral density.

The design purpose of grazing-incidence X-ray telescopes (GIXTs) is to collect X-ray signals emitted almost perpendicular to the optical aperture from space, thereby minimizing optical flux and avoiding optical distortion.
Therefore, GIXT must be equipped with an extremely compact grazing-incidence mirror to accommodate the volume and mass constraints of the satellite.

Therefore, these mirrors are made of very thin materials with a high atomic number (usually gold or silver), making them very sensitive to electronic contamination. This means they are particularly sensitive to the presence of low-energy electrons that may exist within the volume of the satellite, which could be released by modules attached to the telescope.

We proposed a model to assess electron contamination within the volume of a satellite, which is based on measurements of X-ray signals collected by telescopes. We applied this model to evaluate the degradation caused by electron contamination due to the presence of low voltage power units (LVPU) installed on the satellite.
We indicate that this degradation can reach several tens of percentage points, and it is correlated with the intensity of the X-ray signal irradiated onto the satellite.
Nano devices typically lack classical analogies in terms of heat and charge transfer.
Nevertheless, some believe that the fluctuation theorem may apply to them.

The translation of the provided Chinese text into English is:

"[1, 2] in Chinese is written as [1, 2]. The numbers remain the same as they are universally understood."
Here we show that the facts are not as such.
We consider the Jarzynski equality for nano-devices and demonstrate that it fails in a simple system of two coupled Langevin equations with a bistable potential.
The standard derivation of the Jarkowski equation utilizes the reversibility of Hamiltonian dynamics, which is no longer applicable in this case.
Therefore, it is speculated that the fluctuation theorem may not be applicable to nano devices [5].
We clarify that the situation is not as such, and provide a corrected fluctuation relation, which we verify through direct numerical integration of the complete dynamics of the nano-device.
In [1, 2], Nataf and Vulpiani claim that the fluctuation theorem may apply to Brownian motion motors.
They demonstrated the dynamics of energy during a transient period in a Nosè-Hoover oscillator (a classical Brownian motion model) following the Jarzynski equality.
However, it was later shown that the Nosè-Hoover oscillator is Hamiltonian and that the Jarzynski equality holds [3, 4].
Therefore, the statement that the fluctuation theorem may apply to Brownian motors has been found to be incorrect.
Our work will add nanoscale devices to the list of systems where the Jarzynski equation does not hold.

We emphasize that the Jarzynski equality is not a necessary condition for the applicability of the fluctuation theorem; in fact, our results indicate that even more general modified fluctuation relations hold for the systems we consider.

Debris disks are the remnants of protoplanetary disks, and protoplanetary disks are the precursors of planets.
Many debris disks show astonishing uniformity in terms of dust characteristics and luminosity, indicating that planet formation may occur rapidly, lasting less than 1,000 years.

However, there is still strong evidence in many debris disks indicating that planet-forming materials are continuously being generated. This evidence includes dynamical evidence for embedded planetary-mass bodies and collision evidence for the rapid formation of large planetesimals.
The collision evolution of small planetary bodies leads to the accumulation of debris disks, which may result in observable features such as infrared excess and gaps.
The beginning of this collisional evolution was delayed by the formation of the embryo body.

I have summarized the observational constraints on embedded planetary-mass bodies in multiple debris disk systems, proposed new dynamical limits for their existence, and argued that the dynamical evidence for planetary-mass bodies is compelling.

I also summarized the constraints on the collisional evolution of small celestial bodies due to general collisions, proposed limitations on the time span of small body growth, and discussed the implications of these constraints for the formation of short-lived planets.
My conclusion is that the simultaneous formation of planetary embryos and asteroids in debris disks is a reliable conclusion, and it is likely that an explanation for their coexistence is needed.
This work introduces the sensitivity analysis of the aerosol module for the MICS Phase II daily grid point data products in both drought and non-drought seasons.
Analysis indicates that, in the second phase of the MICS aerosol products in Asia, the selection of aerosol optical depth is generally robust for both seasons.
However, several channels have found a significant impact from AOD input selection.

These are the aerosol optical depth (AOD) measurements corresponding to the channels measured by IASI in South India, as well as the aerosol optical depth (AOD) measured by MISR in the Eastern Pacific.
The analysis also indicates that the MICS Asia Phase II AOD product is more sensitive to AOD calculated using the related thinNRG and DRF models during the dry season.
This may be due to the contribution of aerosol optical depth (AOD) during the dry season in the Indian region, and the relevant models do not capture it well enough.

Regarding the sources of AOD, the analysis indicates that neglecting the contributions of the boundary layer and molecular species to AOD may significantly affect the AOD products of MICS Phase II in Asia during the dry season.
This paper is the result of the internal technical review of the second phase of MICS Asia.
Compton scattering is often used to explain the complex spectra of accreting compact objects, such as X-ray binaries and black hole binaries.

This scenario requires seed photons from the cold plasma to be upscattered by electrons in the hot plasma, thereby generating power law components, which could contribute up to 100% of the spectrum in some systems.
Here, we present broad-band X-ray observations of the island state in the transient binary system IGR J1748-288, conducted using the orbital X-ray observatory XMM-Newton.
The data reveal that the radiation from this source extends into hard X-rays, with a photon index of −2.3 ± 0.2.
This result stands in sharp contrast to the Wien tail of the blackbody spectrum usually observed in this state.
We discussed the Comptonization model in detail and showed that it provides a better description of the broadband X-ray spectrum than the simple thermal accretion shock model.

Using Monte Carlo simulations, we explored the parameter space and demonstrated that considering the relativistic Doppler effect and broadening is crucial for the successful application of the model to the broadband spectrum of IGR J1748-288.

Finally, we demonstrate that the temperature of Comptonized plasmas is positively correlated with the amplitude of kHz QPOs, which supports the view that these QPOs are Doppler-modulated versions of the inner accretion flow.
The unprecedented resolution and dynamic range of modern cosmological simulations allow us to quantify some discrete effects that were previously unnoticed.

We are here concerned with those factors that may affect the validity of cosmological paradigms, specifically how standard algorithms may fail to accurately track the behavior of dark matter particles as they become increasingly constrained to collapsed structures.

We found that these "shell crossing" events cause systematic displacements in the spatial distribution of dark matter particles, with displacement amounts reaching several tens of kiloparsecs. These displacements are persistent and require hundreds of Hubble times to be reestablished.

These so-called "discrete effects" may therefore represent a significant obstacle to using dark matter as a cosmological tool, potentially leading to biases in scales observed in current galaxy surveys or larger.
In this supplementary paper, we quantify the extent to which these previously unquantified effects impact current cosmological data.

The Carter constant is a proportionality constant that describes the relationship between the spin of a rotating compact object and its orbital angular momentum. It plays an important role in determining whether a binary black hole system will form after the inner rotation.

In a recent study [Hinder et al. (2021)], the role of the Carter constant in the dynamics of black hole binary systems was investigated. It was shown that for the formed systems, this constant evolves over time, causing the spin of the binary system to align with the orbital angular momentum.

It also indicates that, in certain cases, the magnitude of the quadrupole moment of a black hole and the orientation of the orbital plane can affect the evolution of constants, resulting in one black hole's spin being anti-parallel to the orbital angular momentum.
From this work, we have expanded the above research by systematically studying the impact of the quadrupole moment of black holes on the evolution of the Carter constant.
We found that for binary systems with small quadrupole moments, their evolution qualitatively resembles that of systems without quadrupole moments.
However, for larger quadrupoles, the evolution is no longer continuous, resulting in divergent values of the constants.

We demonstrate that this behavior can be understood through a simple geometric argument based on the impact parameter of a binary system. We also show the existence of a critical quadrupole moment value, beyond which the evolution of the constant will undergo a qualitative change.
We have provided examples of systems with various properties that are applicable to our predictions, and we discuss the implications of our findings for astrophysics.
The process of heavy ionization ended the darkness of the universe and became a powerful tool for studying cosmophysics and astronomy.
The 21 cm emission and absorption signals track the neutral fraction of the intergalactic medium (IGM) and are influenced by the underlying density field structure and galaxy dynamics.
The early stages of reionization in the universe are difficult to observe because these are localized features in the large-scale 21-centimeter signal.
Related random walks (CRWs) are a statistical tool that can be used to infer small-scale information from large-scale signals.
In this article, we consider the effects of galaxy bias and nonlinear coupling on the statistics of cosmic baryon fluctuations (CRW).
We generated CRW signals from N-body simulations of reionization physics in the universe and observed that for galaxy bias, the CRW signal reached its maximum at the percentage level.
Using observational data from the Global Reionization Era Array (Glow), we are able to place a constraint on the galaxy bias parameter of up to 3.7% (1σ).

In addition, we indicate that the best-fit deviation does not match the intrinsic deviation (calculated from N-body simulations) and point out that future observations at higher frequencies may be able to better constrain the deviation.

The early hybrid inflation was driven by the coupling to the fundamental scalar and its superpartners.

We found that, generally speaking, these two phases can occur consecutively, with the false vacuum decay in the first phase generating the curvature perturbations needed for the second phase.
This allows for flexible selection of parameters for each model without affecting the feasibility of subsequent phases.
In this model, the spectrum of density perturbations is flat.
This work is related to the previous paper arXiv:1908.05761.
In [hep-th], we consider a slightly different scenario where the decay of the first stage of the false vacuum does not generate curvature perturbations, but rather amplifies them.
This work is also related to arXiv:1907.11961.
We consider a model with multi-stage expansion and identify the conditions under which the parameters of each stage can follow each other.
The natural broadening of the iron Kα resonance line was observed for the first time in the X-ray spectrum of NGC 3783.
The observed width of the spectrum line is significantly greater than the instrument resolution.
The observed broadening is likely caused by velocity-dependent scattering in the nuclear disk, as the observed width is comparable to the velocity of the gas in the broad line region.
This scattering may be due to small-scale inhomogeneities in the gas density or caused by the deviation of the gravitational potential of the nucleus from spherical symmetry.
The redshifted iron Kα line and its underlying continuous spectrum have also been studied for the first time.
The shape of the continuum is consistent with the results of previous studies.

The equivalent width of the spectral line is measured to be about 120 eV. In the rest frame, the equivalent width of the spectral line is about 240 eV. The correlation between the observed equivalent width and the redshift of the spectral line indicates that the emission and fluorescence processes in the broad line region are more complex than previously assumed.
The variability of NGC 3783 on different timescales has also been studied.
After two years of Chandra X-ray observations, no significant changes in the spectral line flux have been detected.
The change in equivalent width is not significant at the 2 standard deviation level.
The existing data cannot detect variability over a longer timescale.
The silicon surface exhibits many interesting phenomena due to the significant electronegativity difference between silicon and oxygen.
The regular step pattern on the surface of (100) is one of the most notable examples, which has been observed for over seventy years.
The face exhibits a similar structure but possesses double symmetry; this structure was first described in 1952 and is referred to as "densité échelonnée" ("stair-step arrangement of chains").
Due to its highly faceted shape, the (110) surface has become the subject of many recent studies.
Here, we report high-resolution low-energy electron microscopy experiments that reveal detailed reconstruction models of the adjacent (100) and (110) surfaces.

In addition to the well-known surface step density wave pattern, we observed that the bending induced by steps at the triple point between the steps, as well as the bending of the chain, formed a "V"-shaped step.
Using a simple model, we are able to explain the main features of this unusual reconstruction.
The information we provide here will facilitate future experiments and simulations on these interesting surfaces.
This paper is about the controllability of the heat equation and the wave equation.
We first propose a series of new, explicit finite difference methods for approximating the heat equation and the wave equation.
We then study the controllability in finite difference methods by defining the control as a local function on the boundary of the region.

By carefully selecting these localization functions, we are able to demonstrate that the exact solutions of the heat equation and the wave equation can indeed be steered to any desired state in arbitrarily short time.
This result holds for any positive time, even for a time that is independent of the size of the field.
Our controllability results depend only on the local behavior of the exact solution and the spatial behavior of the control.
We also provided counterexamples to demonstrate that our results do not apply to the exact heat equation and wave equation.
This is a collaborative work by Marta Sanz-Soriano.
Long-duration gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are the most intense explosions in the universe.
However, their research is affected by the complex influence of unpredictable random directional light beams, which makes precise positioning difficult.
Transient gamma-ray bursts with known redshifts in the universe provide a crucial opportunity for studying nature.
Long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are the most intense explosions in the universe.
However, their research is affected by unpredictable, randomly directed beams, making precise positioning difficult.
The brief and high-energy gamma-ray bursts provide an important opportunity, under known cosmic redshifts, to study the nature and structure of the universe.
Most long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are observed by the Swift satellite, which not only provides rapid localization but also offers rich multi-wavelength data.
We studied the spectral evolution of 57 Swift long gamma-ray bursts with known redshifts and found the presence of three distinctly different states.
The characteristic of the first state is that it undergoes a cooling period, followed by a simple power law.
Two to four dissipative slopes were observed in this area.
The second phase is observed in 17 outbursts, characterized by an initial thermal component with a blackbody function or a non-thermal tail, followed by a single power law.
For the third and final state, among the 30 impacts, there are no identifiable spectral breaks, and the spectrum can be well fitted with a single power law.
The cosmic models that best describe the observed burst data are the curvature model and the finite universe, with probabilities of 68.3% and 95.7%, respectively.

This result is surprising because the standard candle model assumes that all explosions have the same intrinsic luminosity, which would lead to a single power-law relationship presented across all ranges.
This work was partially supported by NASA's Swift Award No. 1223370, with funding provided by the University of Wisconsin-Madison.
The electronic properties of dried DNA have attracted considerable attention in recent years due to their potential applications in electronic technology.
The electronic properties of dry DNA are significantly different from those of its hydrated form.
For example, dried DNA has higher conductivity and turns into a semiconductor at room temperature.
Understanding the electronic properties of dry DNA is crucial for its potential applications in electronic technologies and DNA-based sensors.
Despite its significant technical importance, the electronic structure and mechanisms of dried DNA have not yet been fully understood.
In this work, we developed a multi-scale model of dry DNA that can capture its electron transport behavior from the atomic scale to the macroscopic scale.
A local structure of a segment of dry DNA is modeled using energy functional theory.
A transport model was established using the tight binding method to describe the electronic transport behavior along the entire length of dry DNA.

The developed model will capture the electronic transport behavior from the atomic scale to the macroscopic scale and represents an important step in understanding the electronic structure and mechanisms of dry DNA.

The analysis of quantum error correction in holographic coding indicates that the error correction characteristics of holographic coding depend on the causal structure of spacetime, which may become blurred under the influence of the environment and forgotten upon observation.

By considering the impact of environmental interactions on the state of the black hole event horizon, we introduce a holographic noise model, which indicates that even in the absence of errors, it is statistically inevitable to read local boundary data from the irreducible quantum uncertainty inherent in the description of the horizon.
Therefore, environmental interactions make the precise calculation of local boundary data uncertain, and any expectations regarding local boundary data are an illusion.

Although the specific form of the noise model proposed here is unlikely to correspond exactly to an accurate model of actual experimental conditions, we have demonstrated that this noise model imposes fundamental limitations on the precise calculation of local boundary data, and it provides a very natural explanation for many previously difficult-to-rationalize experimental results.

In the shear transformation zone (STZ) model of amorphous solids, the localization of strain is studied.

In this model, the amorphous solid is composed of particles that interact through short-range repulsive cores and long-range attractive tails, forming a potential energy that is sheared below the glass transition temperature Tg, thereby generating the amorphous solid.
In quasi-static deformation, high shear stress regions (τ (shear)) form in locally high strain areas (e (loc)), which act as wavefronts propagating as described by the strain localization theory.
Specifically, as the ratio of the localization length λ to the initial system length L0 increases, a transition is observed from spatially extended to localized strain.

We have developed an analytical theory that describes the spatial, temporal, and frequency-dependent shear modulus G(τ,ω) associated with shear stress and strain waveforms, which allows us to analyze the frequency dependence of local shear stress and strain τ(loc)(ω) and e(loc)(ω).

The localization time τ(loc) is observed to have three distinct decay regions, characterized by critical exponents related to the scale-free space, which increase with frequency, exhibiting the relationship 1/τ(loc) ∼ ω^{νz}, where ν = 0.5 represents the divergence of the correlation length, while α and β depend on the details of the potential decay, describing the dependence of the critical strain amplitude required to induce strain localization on frequency.
e(loc) shows similar critical exponents to τ(loc), but differs in the critical amplitude exponents, specifically α=νz=1/2 and β=1/2.

In addition, the critical exponents and scaling laws were compared with results from ultracold liquids (the objects for which the model was originally proposed for explanation) as well as amorphous solids with different potential energies, demonstrating the consistency between the predictions of the STZ model and these observations.

These results suggest that the strain localization theory of amorphous solids, based on the theory of supercooled liquids, can provide a framework for understanding the mechanical responses of amorphous solids in various model systems.

Recently, cognitive radio has received widespread attention because it can automatically search for available unused spectrum for new use, which is particularly useful in situations of spectrum scarcity.

To avoid interfering with primary spectrum users, secondary cognitive radio transmitters must adopt rate adaptation to control their transmission rate based on the interference received by the primary users, where this interference is unknown and difficult to observe.

To this end, this paper proposes a non-Bayesian rate adaptation method, which includes two design approaches: one is an automated and adaptive method based on restless multi-armed bandits for actively seeking unavailable spectrum; the other is a Lyapunov optimization-based method aimed at finding the operating point that causes the least average interference to the primary user.

Specifically, the former uses a large number of discrete channel states to approximate the dynamic and continuous levels of interference, while the latter adjusts the transmission rate from a static mode to a dynamic mode based on the observation of interference, gradually converging to a working point that achieves the worst average interference.
The simulation results show that the proposed method achieves nearly optimal performance in both effective spectrum utilization and average interference to primary users.
The optical and electrical properties of dialkyl anthracenes (DAs) can be reversibly switched between two stable states using light of different wavelengths.
This property has been used in the design of optical and optoelectronic molecular devices, covering areas such as photorefractive media, optical data storage, and molecular devices.

Recently, molecular devices based on diphenylene have been developed, exhibiting photochromism, which is the ability to maintain a stable state in the dark and transition to another state under light.
Through this study, we conducted a theoretical investigation of molecular junctions based on diaryl ethylene.

The current-voltage (I-V) characteristics show that the DA molecular junction exhibits a reversible and cyclic switching effect under illumination with two different wavelengths of light, indicating the potential application of DA molecules in optical and photonic switching molecular devices.

The Switching Mechanism of Photochromic Diphenylethylene Derivative Molecular Junctions  
Wu Daoyuan, Qiu Zhenzhen, Zhang Shaofeng, Zhou Xiangfeng, Zhang Jingyue  
"Molecular Devices," 19(30), 12321-23, 2020  

The photo-driven switching behavior of photochromic diphenylethylene derivative molecular junctions has recently garnered widespread attention due to their potential applications in optical storage, photo-refractive materials, and optical data storage.
So far, several styrene derivatives have been explored as components for constructing stereodriven molecular devices.

Generally speaking, photochromic type diaryl ethylene derivatives are considered as photo-driven switch components, and the relevant molecular devices are constructed by introducing different electrodes.

To explore the more intrinsic switching behavior of diarylethene derivatives, we designed a novel molecular device in this paper, in which the diarylethene units are connected to two electrodes through an alkyne spacer.

Alkyne-based spacers are very flexible and can undergo different cis-trans isomerization processes in light or dark environments, which leads to varying intermolecular forces between diaryl ethylene derivatives, thereby altering the electrical properties of molecular devices.

Based on this mechanism, the current-voltage (I-V) characteristics show that the DA molecular junction exhibits a reversible and cyclic switching effect under illumination at two different wavelengths, indicating the potential application of DA molecules in optical and photo-switching molecular devices.
Here, we present a theoretical study on molecular connections based on di-phenyl ethylene.

The current-voltage (I-V) characteristics show that the DA molecular junction exhibits a reversible and cyclic switching effect under illumination with two different wavelengths of light, indicating the potential application of DA molecules in optical and photo-switching molecular devices.
The switching mechanism is based on the mutual transformation between two isomers, namely the E isomer and the Z isomer.
As shown in the figure.
1a, the Z isomer has a relative plane, while the dihedral angle of the E isomer is about 60°.
